p.seg: This may be so,
but I hope to speak up on everything I have learnt,
and it is up to the Great King apportion the crimes of which I am thereby guilty.
I have learnt:
all the states, Yān in the north and Wèi in the south,
have linked up with Chǔ and bolstered up their relations with Qí
and they have taken in Hán to create a vertical (north/south) alliance.
They are all set to face westwards to create difficulties for powerful Qín.
I permit myself to laugh at them.
In this world there are three kinds of ruinous conditions,
and the whole world has got to the point of having all three:
Probably that is a point relevant to the present situation.
I have heard:
"If using chaos one attacks good order,
if with wickedness one attacks correctness,
if with recalcitrance one attacks obedience, one will be ruined."
Now the civil and military storehouses in the world are not full
and the granaries are all empty.
But they have taken out all their citizens,
and they have lined up an overall armed force of up to a million men.
Those who kow-tow, put on feather head-dress to become generals and who profess to be determined to to die in the front line,
are more than one thousand men.
But they all die in words only.
When the white blades are out up front
and the axes and chopping blocks are behind their backs,
then on the other hand they turn round and run away, unable to risk their lives.
It is not that the citizens are unable to face death.
The reason is that the leadership is basically incompetent .
When they propose rewards they do not deliver them,
when they propose punishments they do not carry them out,
and rewards and punishments are not reliable
so that the citizens are not in a position to face death.
Now Qín promulgates announcements and orders and is carrying out rewards and punishments.
Recognition for achievements or lack of recognition are according to actual service.
From the time people here emerge from their parents' bosom
all their lives they have simply never seen an enemy of the state.
But when they hear there is war
they stamp their feet and demonstratively take off their upper garments,
they rush against white blades,
they tread on glowing coals
and they are determined to face death in the forefront:
this is all because of this policy of statutes and the rewards and punishments.
There is a big difference between being determined to face death and to live,
and the reason why the people do this
is because they value fighting until death highly.
One man fighting until death is able to fend off ten of the enemy,
ten are able to fend off one hundred,
one hundred re able to fend off one thousand,
one thousand can fend off ten thousand,
and ten thousand can win against the whole world.
Now as for Qín, if you give and take a little,
is several thousand square lǐ large,
its renowned armed hosts are counted by the hundred thousands.
As for the public orders and ordinances, rewards and punishments of Qín,
the strategic advantages and dangerous points in the territory,
there is no one in the world who can match the state of Qín.
If one takes this state and contrasts it with the rest of the world,
then the rest of the world is not even worth combining under one's sway.
Therefore Qín, whenever it launches into a battle, never fails to win,
and when it launches an attack it never fails to take the object of that attack;
whomever she faces she never fails to destroy,
and as a result it has expanded its territory by several thousand square lǐ.
This is its great achievement.
And yet, arms and armour have no edge,
the citizens are sickly,
accumulated supplies are exhausted,
fields lie fallow,
granaries stand empty,
the neighbouring feudal lords in all four directions do not submit,
and the name of a leading king has not been established.
For this there is no other reason:
all the advising ministers do not fully do their best for the ruler.
I venture to declare:
In the past Qí ruined Chǔ in the south,
it ruined Sòng in the east,
subjected Qín in the west,
ruined Yān in the north,
and controlled Hán and Wèi in the central region.
Its territories were enlarged and its armed forces were strengthened,
in battles it won, and in attacks it took the target,
and it gave orders to all under Heaven.
The clear Jì river and the murky Yellow River in the state of Qí
served well as blocking borders;
a long wall and gigantic dikes
served well as blocks against an enemy.
As for Qí
she is a state that has won five major battles.
But in one battle it did not prevail, and Qí was no more.
Viewed from this point of view.
warfare
involves the survival or ruin of large and powerful states.
Moreover, I have learnt:
"When one cuts down a tree trunk one should not leave any roots;
one should not court disaster,
then there will be no source of disaster"
When Qín went to war against the leadership of Chǔ,
and they greatly defeated Chǔ,
they invaded the capital Yǐng,
they took Dòngtíng, Wǔhú, and Jiāngnán.
The king of Chǔ, ruler and ministers, went into exile,
and he submitted to find refuge in Chén, towards the east.
At this time,
if one had pursued Chǔ with armed force,
then it would have been possible to conquer Chǔ.
If it had been possible to conquer Chǔ
then its population would have been worth seeking profit from
and its territory would have been worth deriving revenues from.
In the east one would have been able to weaken Qí and Yān,
in the centre one could in that way have dominated the Three Jìn.
And so, at one stroke, in this way,
one's fame as a leading king could have been established,
the feudal lords from the neighbouring states could have been made to come to our court.
But this is what the advising ministers did not do.
They lead the troops into retreat,
and they went on to make peace with the people of Chǔ.
They caused the people of Chǔ to regain their lost country,
to gather again the scattered people,
to establish a lord of the altar of land and grain,
to establish the ancestral temples.
They caused them to lead all under Heaven to direct their attention to the west
and thus to make trouble for Qín.
This certainly was the first lost opportunity for leadership.
The whole world again ganged up and encamped at Huáxià,
the Great King had already issued orders to rout them,
the armed forces had arrived below the outer city walls of Liáng.
If one had surrounded Liáng for several ten-day weeks,
then it would have been possible to take Liáng;
if one had captured Liáng
then Wèi could have been taken;
once one had taken Wèi,
then the political designs of Chǔ and Zhào would have been thwarted;
Once the political designs of Chǔ and Zhào were thwarted,
then Zhào would have been in a precarious position.
Zhào would have been in a precarious state, and Chǔ deeply uncertain.
In the east one could thus have weakened Qí and Yān,
and in the central region one could thus have exerted pressure on the Three Jìn states.
And so at one stroke one could have established one's name as the leading king,
all the neighbouring feudal lords could be made to come to court.
But the advisers did not do this.
They lead the army into retreat,
again they made peace with the Wèis.
They caused the Wèis to reassemble their lost state,
to re-gather the scattered people,
to establish a ruler for the altars of land and grain,
and to establish the ancestral temples.
They caused Wèi to lead the world to face west and make trouble for Qín.
This certainly was the second way in which the leadership of kings was lost.
Quite some time ago when Marquis Xiāng governed Qín
he deployed the armed forces of one state
and tried to accomplish achievements for a pair of states.
And so the soldiers spent all their lives exposed out in the open country
the citizens were worn out and sick in the capital,
the reputation of a leader of kings was not established.
This certainly was the third lost opportunity of establishing the name of a leader.
The Zhàos
are a central state,
it is inhabited by a mixed population,
and the people are easy-going and hard to employ.
Their announcements and ordinances are not properly administered,
their rewards and punishments are not reliable,
their territorial conditions are not advantageous,
so at the basic level they cannot make full use of the strength of the people.
Those are certainly the features of a state doomed to ruin,
but they were still not worried about the people.
They encamped all their citizens below the walls of Chángpíng
in order to fight for Shàngdǎng in Hán.
The Great King had already given orders to destroy the place,
and he took Wǔān.
At this time,
relations between superiors and inferiors were not close and good among the Zhào,
noblemen and commoners had no faith in each other.
Consequently Hándān was not properly defended.
Had he taken Hándān,
had he brought Héjiàn east of the Mountain under control,
had he lead the army away
to attack Xiūwǔ in the west,
had he crossed Yángchǎng,
he would have subjugated Dài and Shàngdǎng.
Dài consists of 36 districts,
Shàngdǎng consists of 17 districts:
without using a single leather-shield covering the neck,
without wearing out a single citizen,
these would all have become possessions of Qín.
Dài and Shàngdǎng would all have gone to Qín, without a battle,
Dōngyáng and Héwài would all have reverted to Qí, without battle,
Zhōngshan and the area north of Hūtuó would all have reverted to Yān, without battle,
and so Zhào would have been won;
and if Zhào would have been won, Hán would have been lost;
if Hán had been lost, then Chǔ and Wèi could not have stood firm independently;
if Chǔ and Wèi would not have stood firm independently;
then at one stroke one could have destroyed Hán,
one could have stung Wèi,
one could have controlled Chǔ,
in the east one would thus have weakened Qí and Yān,
one could have opened the White Horse dam to inundate the Wèi:
thus at one stroke the Three Jìn successor states would have been ruined,
and their followers would have been defeated.
The Great King could have just waited for this, hands down,
and the whole world would have combined to follow him and submit to you.
Then it would have been possible to establish the name of a leader of kings.
But the advising ministers did nothing of the kind:
they lead the army into retreat,
on the contrary they made peace with the Zhàos.
Now with Your Great Majesty's perspicacity,
with the might of the armed forces of Qín,
you have given up the mission of becoming the leader of kings,
even an addition of territory it was impossible to obtain,
and on the contrary you were cheated by states that were doomed to ruin:
such results are due to the incompetence of the advising ministers.
Now when Zhào was due to be ruined but was not ruined,
when Qín was due to become the leader of kings but did not become leader of kings,
then the world certainly reassessed the quality of the advisers of Qín for a first time.
Again, when all the officers and men were used in the attack on Hándān,
and they were unable to take the place,
when they dropped their armour, weapons and crossbows,
when they shivered, fretted and retreated,
then the world certainly reassessed the strength of Qin for a second time
The army then was lead to retreat
and they gathered near Fúxià,
and Your Great Majesty again gathered another army got there,
and they fought a battle against them but were unable to win against them
and moreover were unable to turn back,
and when the army left, exhausted,
then the world certainly reassessed the strength of Qín for a third time.
Regarding the internal situation they reassessed our advising ministers,
regarding the external situation they saw the limits of our military strength.
From this point of view
I consider that the vertical alliance
should have practically no problems.
But while inside our state
our arms are in tatters,
the citizens are sick,
the supplies are exhausted,
the fields lie fallow,
the granaries are empty,
while on the outside
the whole world have closed ranks and are firm in their allegiance.
I hope the Great King has something to make plans against this with.
Moreover I have learnt:
"If you shiver and you tremble with fear,
and every day you are careful about that day,
if you really are careful about the Way,
then the whole world may be yours."
How does one know that this is so?
In ancient times Zhòu was the Son of Heaven,
and he was in command of a million armed soldiers of the world,
his left wing he rested for drink at the little river Qí,
his right wing he rested for drink from the brook Huán,
so that the little river Qí went dry and the brook Huán ceased to flow:
and with this army he made trouble for King Wǔ of the Zhōu.
King Wǔ lead three thousand armoured men wearing mourning.
They fought a battle for one day,
and they destroyed the capital of Zhòu,
took the man prisoner,
occupied his territory and took possession of his population.
No one in the world felt distressed about this.
The Earl of Zhì led the hosts of three city states (Zhì, Hán, Wèi)
and attacked ruler Xiāng of Zhào at Jìnyáng.
He diverted the river and flooded the place for three months,
and the inner city walls were just about to be taken.
Then ruler Xiāng pierced tortoise shells, consulted the milfoil and made a prognostication
in order to see the good and bad prospects,
and to which state one should surrender.
At that point he sent out his subordinate Zhāng Mèngtán,
and then Zhāng Mèngtán left the city by foot, secretly,
turned round the alliances of the Earl of Zhì,
gained the allegiance of the hosts of the other two states.
He attacked the Earl of Zhì,
took the man prisoner
and restored ruler Xiāng to his original position.
Now as for Qín, if one disregards minor deviations in territory,
has a territory of several thousand lǐ square,
and its distinguished army has several hundred thousand men.
As for the public ordinances and rewards and punishments of the state of Qín,
the relative advantages of the territory,
no one in the world comes up to these.
If one engages the whole world with these,
then one can control each and every part of it.
At the risk of my life I have aspired to an audience with the Great King,
in order to put forward the way of destroying the vertical alliances in the world,
to take Zhào, to ruin Hán
to make slaves of Chǔ and Wèi,
to cultivate close relations with Qí and Yān,
so that you will establish a name as a leader of kings
and the way to cause all the neighbouring feudal lords to come to your court.
If Your Great Majesty really listens to these explanations
and if then the vertical alliances in the world are not routed at one stroke,
if Zhào is not taken
and Han is not ruined,
if Chǔ and Yān are not subservient,
if Qí and Yān are not in close allegiance,
if the name of a leader of kings is not established,
if the neighbouring feudal lords do not come to show their respect at court,
then Your Great Majesty may cut me at the waist and display my body in the state,
to serve as a warning for those who advise kings without loyalty.
Now your servant has humbly learnt about your distinguished ministers' plans,
that they have taken out the army and are about to launch a formal attack against Hán.
In fact, the Zhào have assembled officers and men,
are fostering adherents of an East-West alliance (against Qín)
and intend to forge links between the whole world's armed forces:
they understand full well that if Qín is not weakened,
then the feudal lords will have their ancestral temples destroyed,
and they intend to turn against [Qín in the] West to achieve their purposes.
This is not an ephemeral plan of theirs, it is a long-term strategy.
Now if you set aside>disregard the impending trouble from Zhào
and you put off Hán, which acts like one of your own ministers,
then it will be clear to the whole world that the Zhàos' strategy has succeeded.
Now Hán is a small state,
and in order to respond to attacks from all directions
her rulers were humiliated and her ministers suffered hardship:
for a long time those above and those below have been in common troubles.
They have built defensive structures,
they have taken guard against strong enemies,
they have piled up supplies,
and they have built walls and moats
to ensure solid defences.
If one launches a formal attack on Hán now
one won't necessarily be able to destroy the place within one year.
If one the other hand one takes out one city and withdraws,
then one will be regarded as a lightweight by the world,
and the world might break>defeat our forces.
If Hán rebels then Wèi will respond,
Zhào will rely on Qí for ultimate support,
and under these conditions
then Hán and Wèi will help Zhào to win the support of Qí
so that the East-West alliance will be strengthened
and on this basis they will join the struggle for supremacy.
The good fortune of Zhào will spell disaster for Qín.
Now if one is unable to take Zhào in an offensive attack,
then draws back to attack Hán and is unable to gain a military victory,
then one's crack soldiers will get exhausted in open field battles,
the transport troops will be too exhausted to provide the supplies,
and then one will assemble embittered and weakened forces to face the enemy,
and one faces a combined force of war chariots (of Qí and Zhào):
this is not the attitude with which to ensure the demise of Hán.
If one follows your noble minister's plans
then Qín is bound to become the target of the armed forces of the world.
Then even if Your Majesty whittles them down as metal or stone,
the day when you may unite the world will never come.
Now your menial servant's inept plan is as follows:
Send an ambassador on a mission to Jīng,
give substantial presents to the minister in charge of the relevant matters,
and explain the ways in which Zhào is behaving dishonestly towards Qín.
One should exchange hostages with Wèi in order to put their minds at ease,
one should join forces with Hán in an attack on Zhào:
then although Zhào may combine forces with Qí,
this is no cause for worry.
When the affair concerning these two states is finished,
then the matter of Hán may be settled through an exchange of letters.
In this way, if through one action on our part two states appear to be ruined,
then Chǔ and Wèi are likewise bound to submit on their own accord.
Thus it is said:
"As for arms, these are inauspicious tools."
One should not fail to deploy them judiciously.
If Qin is opposing Zhào,
and Qí is added to the opponents,
then if now one turns one's back on Hán, in addition,
then one will have nothing to firm up the allegiance with Jīng and Wèi.
If one fails to win in one battle,
then disaster will ensue.
As for plans,
these are what one settles one's tasks with:
should be investigated carefully.
The relative strength of Zhào and Qin
will be decided just within this year.
Moreover, Zhào has been making secret plans with the feudal lords for long.
Now if you move once and show weakness in regard to the feudal lords,
that is a dangerous matter;
if you make plans and make the feudal lords be suspicious of us,
that is extremely dangerous.
Showing two such instances of negligence
is not the way to gain strength vis-à-vis the feudal lords.
It is my humble hope that Your Majesty will grace this matter with his careful attention.
If you launch an attack and you cause the East-West alliance to get involved
it is too late for regrets.
You have decreed that the memorial submitted by the foreigner Hán
- the memorial submits that the ruler of Hán cannot yet be successfully attacked -
has been handed down to your servant Sī.
I strongly disagree with the memorial.
Qín's relation to Hán
is like a man's relation to a disease in the middle of his stomach.
When one lives quietly one feels uncomfortable,
as if one were living in a damp place,
it clings to one and will not go away.
But when one runs fast,
then the disease will break out fully.
Although Hán behaves as a vassal to Qín
it never ceases to be a disease in the body of Qín.
If there now is an urgent affair
Hán is not to be trusted.
Between Qín and Zhào there is trouble.
Jīngsū is on a mission to Qí,
and one still does not know how this has gone.
In my view
the relations between Qí and Zhào
will not necessarily be disrupted by Jīngsū.
If they are not,
then one will employ all the resources of Qín to resist two ten thousand chariot states.
Now Hán has not submitted to the just cause of Qín,
she has submitted to the power and strength.
If we now concentrate solely on Qí and Zhào
then Hán will be an ulcer in the middle of the stomach
and will break out.
If there is a conspiracy between Hán and Chǔ
and the feudal lords chime in with it,
then Qín is bound to be exposed again to a disaster like that at the Yáo Pass.
The arrival of Hán Fēi here in Qín
is probably not unconnected with his ability to work for the survival of Hán,
it is because he is a powerful figure in Hán.
He makes sophistical explanations and polishes his formulations,
he makes what is wrong look beautiful and engages in deceitful plots
in order to gain advantages from Qín,
and observes Your Majesty secretly with Hán's advantage in mind.
If the relations between Qín and Hán get closer
then Hán Fēi will gain in influence.
These are his plans for his own advantage.
I have examined Hán Fēi's proposals,
and I find his wanton explanations and confused disquisitions elegant enough.
He is very talented.
I fear that Your Majesty will indulge yourself in Hán Fēi's rhetoric
and that you will lend your ear to his thievish designs
so that you do not examine closely the real facts of the matters at hand.
Now I have an inept suggestion:
If Qín sends out her troops without specifying whom they are attacking,
then those responsible in Hán will decide to side with Qín.
Your servant Sī hereby ask to go to see the King of Hán
to cause him to come to Qín for an audience.
When Your Great Majesty has seen him here,
you keep his person here and do not send him off again.
After a short while you summon leading ministers of Hán
and enter into a barter agreement for the release of the king of Hán:
then you may carve out a good piece of Hán territory.
Then you order Xiàngwǔ to bring out the soldiers from the Eastern Province.
You observe the troops on the border
but you do not declare where they are to head for.
As a result the people of Qí will get scared
and they will follow Jing Sū's plan, cutting off relations with Zhào.
In this way, before our troops have crossed any frontiers
the vigourous state of Hán will be captured through our power play
and powerful Qí will follow us because of our justness of our cause.
When this comes to the attention of the feudal lords,
the Zhào's will find their fighting spirit ruined
and the people of Chǔ will become full of doubts:
both are bound to make their plans in loyalty [to Qín].
If the people in Chǔ do not move against us
then Wèi will be nothing to worry about,
and as a result the feudal lords can be gulped down, the whole lot of them.,
and we can take on the Zhàos as equals.
I hope Your Majesty will grace your stupid servant's inept plan with his attention,
and that you will not be careless on this matter."
Qín then did send Lǐ Sī to act as an ambassador to Hán.
Lǐ Sī had gone to deliver a message to the king of Hán
and he had not yet obtained an audience
when he took the opportunity to submit a memorial:
From ancient times Qín and Hán have joined their forces and thought alike
so that they have not encroached on each other.
No one in the world dared to go against their will.
Matters have been like this for several generations.
Not too long ago five feudal lords launched a combined attack on Hán,
and Qín brought out her forces to save Hán.
Hán is situated among the central states,
its territory does not even fill out one thousand square lǐ.
The reason why Hán can rank among the feudal lords in the world
and that rulers and ministers supported each other
is that for generations they have taught each other
to submit to the superior power of Qin.
Some time ago when the five feudal lords launched a combined attack on Qín
Hán on the contrary was at the head of the column of the feudal lords
facing the forces of Qín below the pass.
The army of the feudal lords got into trouble, their strength exhausted
and they had no way out.
The armies of the feudal lords were worn out.
When Dù Cāng was prime minister in Qín.
he raised an army and sent out generals to avenge the world's hostility
and he first attacked Chǔ.
The prime minister of Chǔ considered the situation as dangerous
and said: As for Hán, she considered Qín as unjust
but she maintained brotherly relations with Qín
and together with Qín caused bitter trouble to the world.
In the end Hán again turned her back on Qín
and she led the column of the armies attacking the Pass.
Hán is thus situated among the central states,
and she is so fickle, one does not know what she will do.'
The various states together cut off ten cities from Hán's best territory
by way of apology to Qín
and they withdrew their troops.
Now when Hán once turned against Qín
then its state got into trouble and its territory was encroached upon.
Its troops are weakened to this day.
The reason for this is this:
you have listened to the loose explanations of wicked ministers
and you have not assigned proper weight to the underlying facts.
The result is that even if you were to execute the wicked ministers
you could not restore Hán to its former strength.
Now Zhào wishes to amass an armed force
and all of a sudden she turns on Qín.
They have sent someone to Hán to ask for right of way.
They maintain that they intend to launch a formal attack on Qín,
but under the circumstances they are bound to take Hán first and then Qín.
Moreover I have heard it said:
'When the lips are gone the teeth get cold.'
Now Qín and Hán are doomed to sharing the same troubles,
this is evident from the constellation of things.
When Wèi intended to bring out her troops to attack Hán,
then Qín ordered someone to turn the Wèi envoy over to Hán.
Now the king of Qín has sent his me, his servant Lǐ Sī, here,
but I am unable to obtain an audience.
I fear that your entourage continues the earlier wicked ministers' plots
and will bring it about that Hán again will suffer the loss of territory.
If, without having obtained an audience
I [have to] ask permission to return and report on my visit,
then the links between Qín and Hán will are bound to be disrupted.
My arriving here on a mission
is in order to submit the goodwill of the king of Qín
and it is my hope to hand up a beneficial plan:
How could this be a reason for Your Majesty to oppose your humble servant?
I hope to obtain a single audience
to step forward and speak of my inept plan
and after I have stepped back you may carve me up and kill me.
It is my hope that you will pay attention to this matter.
If you now kill me here in Hán
that will not serve to strengthen Your Great Majesty.
But if you do not listen to my plans
this is bound to spell disaster.
Once Qín has sent out her troops they will not stop in their march
and the altars of the land and grain will be in severe trouble.
Once my body is exposed in the market place of Hán
then even if you wanted to look more closely into my inept but loyal plans,
it will definitely be too late.
Once the border regions are being decimated
and the capital has to be firmly defended,
when the sound of gongs and bells is in people's ears,
then to first begin using my plans
will be too late.
Moreover, the state of the Hán troops is clear to all who want to know
and now you go on to turn your back on the powerful Qín.
Once one has abandoned the city walls and has the army defeated,
then thieves in your immediate entourage will invade the cities.
If the cities are all gone, conglomerations of people are dispersed,
when conglomerations of people are dispersed, there will be no army.
If a city is firmly defended
then Qín is bound to raise troops to besiege Your Majesty's one capital.
When communications are interrupted
then it is hard to come up with convincing plans
the situation will be beyond repair.
Your advisers' plans are useless.
I hope Your Majesty will consider matters carefully.
If my suggestions to not fit with the realities of the situation
I hope I will be able to finish my presentation in front of you.
Then afterwards the law enforcement officials may put me to death,
and that will not be too late.
The king of Qín does not enjoy his food and drink
and he does not enjoy himself on his pleasure trips.
His mind is all set on making plans concerning Zhào.
He has sent me to come here with some suggestions
and he hopes that I shall be able to gain a personal audience
so that on that occasion I can present to Your Majesty some urgent plans.
Now if you bring it about that I do not get through with my message
that means that Hán's good faith remains uncertain.
Then Qín is bound to disregard the troubles with Zhào
and move their forces against Hán.
I hope Your Majesty will grace this matter with his repeated attention
and honour me with a decision on these matters in return.
If one is quite trusty and quite respectful
if one is firm and earnest
then one is considered inept and not up to scratch.
If one makes many words and offers detailed pronouncements,
lining up comparable categories and comparing things,
then one is considered as empty and useless.
If one is summary and one's explanations are brief,
if one is right to the point and unadorned,
then one will be considered sharp and not well-spoken.
If one is brisk, goes close in on one's subject
and one pries deep into others' real thoughts,
then one is considered evil-tongued and unrelenting.
If one is comprehensive and wide-ranging
far-reaching and unfathomable
then one is regarded as grandiloquent and useless.
If one talks in a petty way about minor family matters
and lists them all up,
then one is regarded as vulgar.
If in one's public speeches one keeps to what is current
and if one's formulations do not arouse conflict and opposition,
then one is considered as one who fears death and flatters the leadership.
If in one suggestions one keeps at a distance from the vulgar,
and is busy quibbling with what is current among the people
then one is considered as a big-mouthed.
If one is nimble-tongued and adept at rhetoric,???
elaborate in one's rhetorical flourishes,
then one is considered a scribal hack.
If one rejects literary effort
to produce substantial reliable public suggestions,
then one is considered as crude.
If time and again one quotes the Songs and the Documents
talks of taking antiquity as one's model
then one is regarded as a reciting regurgitator.
For these reasons I find it hard to make proposals
and am deeply worried about it.
Thus even if one's assessments should be correct
they are not necessarily listened to;
even if one's moral ideas and principles should be comprehensive and correct
they will not necessarily be used.
If Your Majesty regards this as untrue,
then at the very least I shall be maligned and slandered,
and at the worst I will suffer disaster, misfortune and death.
Thus Zǐxū was good at making plans, but the state of Wú had him executed,
Confucius was good at making explanations but at Kuáng they besieged him.
Guǎn Yíwú was reliable and talented but Lǔ incarcerated him.
Of course these three dignitaries were men of excellent talent,
but their three rulers were unenlightened.
In highest antiquity there was King Tāng the Successful,
and he was sagely in the extreme;
then there was his distinguished minister Yī Yǐn,
and he was extremely competent.
Now an extremely competent man was persuading an extremely sagely person
but after seventy persuasions he was not accepted,
personally he had to hold the cauldrons and meat plates to became a cook
to get close to his inner circles and gain his confidence,
only then Tāng the Successful recognised his excellence and employed him.
Thus it is said:
"Even if an extremely competent person persuades an extremely sagely person,
he will not necessarily win through and be accepted:
Yī Yǐn persuading Tāng was such a case.
If as a competent person one persuades a stupid person
one will certainly not be listened to.
King Wén persuading Tyrant Zhòu was such a case.
Thus king Wén persuaded Tyrant Zhòu, but Zhòu went on to incarcerate him.
The Lord of Yì got fried;
the Lord of Guǐ was made into dried meat;
Bǐgān had his heart carved open;
the Baron of Méi was pickled;
Guǎn Yíwú was thrown in fetters;
and Cáo Jī had to flee to Chén.
Bólǐzǐ was reduced to begging in the streets;
Fù Yuè was sold from one man to the next;
Sūnzǐ Bìn had his kneecap cut off in Wèi;
Wú Qǐ wiped off his tears at Ànmén,
distressed that Xīhé region belonged to Qín,
and was finally dismembered in Chǔ.
Gōngshū Cuó said Gōngsūn Yǎng was the most talented man in the state,
but this was considered wrong-headed,
so Gōngsūn Yǎng fled to Qín.
Guān Lóng Páng was dismembered;
Cháng Hóng was disembowelled;
Yǐnzǐ was thrown in a pit in the brambles;
Sīmǎ Zǐqī floated dead in the Yangtse River,
Tián Míng had his dead body carved up;
Mì Zǐjiàn and Xīmén Bào never quarrelled with anyone but died at the hands of others;
Dōng Anyú died and was exhibited in the market place;
Zǎi Yú could not escape from Tián Cháng;
Fàn Jū had his ribs squashed in Wèi.
These ten odd people
were all the worlds most humane, talented, loyal and skilled men,
but by misfortune they met misled and confused rulers and died.
Why is it, then, that even the talented and sagely could not escape death or escape from execution and humiliation?
It is because the stupid are hard to convince.
That is the reason why the gentleman finds it hard to make public statements.
Moreover, truly perfect words grate in the ear and go against the heart:
only a talented or a sagely person can listen to them.
I hope Your Great Majesty will look carefully into this.
if there is no distinction in rank among the ruler's consorts
this is bound to endanger the regular heir;
if brothers do not subordinate themselves to the ruler
they are bound to endanger the altars of the land and grain.
I have heard that if a ruler over (a state with) thousand chariots takes no precautions
there is bound to be a minister with a hundred chariots by his side
who will move the allegiance of the people and overturn his state.
If a ruler over chariots takes no precautions
there is bound to be a clan with chariots by his side
and they will affect his authority and overturn his state.
Thus when wicked subjects thrive
the way of the ruler will decline and disappear.
And along the same lines expansiveness of the feudal lords
does harm to the Son of Heaven;
the excessive wealth of the various ministers
will lead to the defeat of the ruler.
When generals and prime ministers manipulate their ruler and make their clans flourish
these are the people the ruler of men will keep at bay.
Among the myriad things none is more more precious than one's person
nothing more worthy of respect than rank;
nothing more important than the authority of the ruler,
nothing more exalted than the ruler's position of power.
These four points of excellence
one does not seek on the outside
and one does not ask for from others:
one obtains them as a result of going about things the right way.
Therefore it is said:
When the ruler is unable to use his assets
then in the end he will find himself set aside in the end.
This is something that a ruler of men should be familiar with.
In ancient times the ruin of Zhòu
and also the decline in status of the Zhōu
were all the result of the expansiveness of the feudal lords;
the division of Jìn
and also the usurpation of Qí
were all the result of the various ministers being too rich.
The reasons why in Yān and in Sòng they assassinated their rulers
were all of this kind.
Thus taking in antiquity the cases of Yīn and the Zhōu,
and in later antiquity the cases of Yān and Sòng,
they were all in accordance with this theory.
Therefore the enlightened ruler will rear his minister in such a way
that he uses to law to make them do their best
and that he uses preventive measures make them stay on the correct path.
So he will not pardon those condemned to death
and he will not be lax on punishments;
pardoning those condemned to death and being lax on punishments
that is called having one's authority become indulgent.
Then the altars of the land and grain will be in danger
and the nation will have a slanted distribution of authority.
Therefore even if the great ministers have high stipends
they are not allowed to use their authority to fortify market towns with walls;
even if they have many adherents and partisans
they are not allowed to have officers and soldiers in their employment.
So a minister, while living in a state, must not hold private court,/
while staying with the army he must not form private associations,/
from the stocks and armouries they are in charge of they must not privately make loans to individual clans:/
This is how the enlightened ruler puts a stop to their [potential] wickedness./
Thus they are not allowed to ride four-horse chariots,
they will not carry unregimented weapons of any sort.
Unless someone is an official courier or a speed-courier
if he carries any unregimented weapon or shield
he should be held punishable to death without pardon.
This is how the enlightened ruler will guard against the unforeseen.
Thus the enlightened ruler remains empty and still, waiting for things to happen:
he brings it about that names name of themselves,/
he brings it about that matters are settled of themselves./
Being empty he understands the inner essence of things,/
being still he understands the just measure of action./
Those who have suggestions will make job descriptions for themselves,/
those who have services to offer will find their own forms of actions:/
when forms of action and terminology fit together,
first then the ruler does not need to get involved,
and he lets things revert to their very essence./
Therefore it is said:
The ruler should never openly show his desires./
When the ruler openly shows his desires,/
then the ministers will carve and polish themselves;/
The ruler should not show his thoughts./
When the ruler shows his thoughts,/
then the ministers will change the expression of their opinion./
Therefore it is said:
Discard likes, discard dislikes,/
then the ministers will show their genuine colour;/
discard old prejudice, discard one's own competence, RHYME?
then the ministers will fend for themselves.RHYME?
So the ruler may have competence but not use it to engage in concrete planning,/
he should see to it that the myriad things find their places;/
he may have talent, but he should not act on the basis of it:
he should observe what his ministers and inferiors are basing themselves on.
he may have courage, but he should not show fierce anger on the basis of that:/
he should see to it that the ministers do their very best in the use of weapons./
Thus the ruler discards (concrete) competence and opts for (abstract) insight./
he discards talent and opts for achievement;/
he discards bravery and opts for strength./
When the various ministers take good care of their official duties,
when all the officials keep to their regular routines,/
and the ruler, on the basis of their abilities, deploys these people,
then that is called the proper exercise of regular routines./
Thus it is said:
All quiet, without exercising official duties he holds his place,/
All limpid, no one knows his whereabouts./
The enlightened ruler practises non-assertive action above
and the various ministers live in fear below./
The Way of the enlightened ruler
is to get the competent to do their utmost in planning/
so that the ruler decides matters on that basis./
As a result the ruler does not exhaust himself for the sake of competence./
The talented adjust their talents/
and the ruler employs them on the basis of that./
Therefore the ruler does not exhaust himself for the sake of (concrete) abilities./
If there are achievements then the ruler claims the talent;/
if there are failures then the minister takes responsibility for the misdeeds:
therefore the ruler does not wear himself out for the sake of fame./
In this way the ruler, without being talented himself,
is the teacher of the talented,
without being competent himself he becomes a correcting force for the competent./
The ministers have the troublesome work
This is called the guideline of the talented ruler./
The Way [of the ruler] consists in being invisible,
the function of the ruler consists in being beyond other's understanding;/
Empty and still, unoccupied by concrete business
from the darkness one observes others' faults./
One sees but is not seen
one hears but is not heard,
one understands but is not understood./
When one understands a proposal properly one proceeds,/
one should not change anything, one should not replace anything/
and by the method of comparison of words with deed one should observe what happens.
For each position there is one person,/
and he does not allow officials to speak on each other's business,
so that all things will be carried through to the end./
One hides one's traces,
conceals the basic motivations,/
and those below are unable to get to the source of things./
One discards one's competence,
one gets rid of one's abilities,/
and those below cannot guess one's purposes./
One must take care not to give away one's purposes and check whether others conform to them,(/)
one must take care to hold the handle and to grasp it firmly./
Cut off their hopes,
thwart their guessings,
do not allow others to wish for these (handles of power)./
When you are not careful about closing the doors,
when you are not firm in control of the gate,/
then the [ambitious] tigers will persist./
If you are not careful about your business,
if you do not hide your real feelings,/
then the villains will emerge./
They assassinate their rulers
and take their place,/
so that all the others join their cause:/
that is why they are called tigers./
When they are in the entourage of their ruler/
they are wicked ministers
and they hear about the ruler's faults,/
that is why they are called villains./
One must scatter their gangs,
one must mop up their remains,/
bar the gates
snatch away their supporters:/
then there will be no tigers in the state./
One must be immeasurably great
and one must be unfathomably deep;/
one must hold official duties and performance up against each other,
and one must carefully investigate laws and rules./
If those who take unauthorised action will be executed,
then there will be no villains in the state./
Therefore there are five types of blockage for the ruler:
The minister shutting in the ruler is one form of blockage of the ruler.
The minister controlling material profits is another blockage.
The minister taking actions and issuing order on his own authority is another blockage.
The minister getting to carry out what he thinks right is another form of blockage.
The minister getting to establish others in leading positions is another blockage.
When the minister shuts in the ruler,
then the ruler loses his position of power;
when the minister controls material profit,
then the ruler loses his ability to display magnanimity;
when the minister takes actions and issues orders on his own authority
then the ruler loses administrative control;
when the minister is responsible for doing the right thing
then the ruler will lose his enlightened control;
when the minister gets to establish others in leading positions
then the ruler loses his loyal faction.
These are ways in which the ruler secures his independent initiative
they are not something for a minister to gain control of.
As for the way of the ruler of men/
he takes calm and withdrawal as his main treasures./
One does not get involved with concrete business,
but one understands ineptness and cleverness in others;/
one does not get involved in concrete planning and deliberations,
but one understands what brings good fortune and what misfortune./
Thus the ruler does not speak out,
the ruler does not constrain the ministers, and these are good at excellent performance./
When a proposal has got a response
then the ruler holds onto this as a contract;
when a business has been excellently performed
then he holds onto this as a tally of an agreement.
When the tallies are fitted together,
that is where reward and punishment arise.
Thus when the various ministers put forward their proposals
the ruler assigns tasks according to these proposals.
In accordance with the task he demands performance.
When the performance corresponds to the task undertaken,
and the task corresponds to the proposals,
then there is reward;
when the performance does not fit the task
and the task is not in accordance with the suggestions,
then there is punishment.
According to the Way of the enlightened ruler
ministers cannot put forward proposals that they do not live up to.
Thus the meting out of rewards by the enlightened ruler
is dark and rich like seasonal rain:
and the people enjoy its richness;
his meting out of punishments
is awe-inspiring like thunder and rain:
even divine sages cannot disentangle themselves from the system.
So the enlightened ruler gives no secret rewards,
and he does not pardon those who deserve punishment.
If rewards are secret
then meritorious ministers will be lax in the performance of their duty;
if one pardons those who deserve punishment
then wicked ministers will easily get on with their evil deeds.
Therefore, if there really is excellent performance
then even if the person is distant from the court and humble, he will be rewarded;
if there really is a mistake,
then even if he is close to the court and dear to it, he will be punished.
When the distant and humble are bound to be rewarded
and the close and beloved are bound to be punished,
then the distant and humble will not be remiss in their work,
and the close and beloved people will not be arrogant in their attitudes.8
King Zhuāng of Chǔ annexed states,
and he opened up three thousand square lǐ of land;
but when king Zhuāng passed away in the service for his nation
Chǔ was ruined because of this.
Duke Huán of Qí annexed thirty states
and he opened up three thousand square lǐ of land;
but when Duke Huán passed away in the service for his nation
Qí was ruined because of this death.
Duke Xiāng of Yān ruled down to the Yellow River,
with Jì as his capital,
he attacked Zhuó and Fāngchéng,
he routed Qí,
he levelled out and destroyed Zhōngshān:
so mighty was he that those who had the allegiance of Yān were powerful
those who did not have the allegiance of Yān were weak;
but when king Xiāng died in the service for his nation
Yān was ruined as a result.
King Anxī of Wèi attacked Yān and rescued Zhào,
he took territory from Hédōng;
he completely occupied the territories of Táo and of Wèi;
he applied military force to Qí
and made Pínglù into his own personal city;
he attacked Hán and took out Guǎn,
won a victory near Qí,
and at the battle of Suīyáng
the Chǔ forces were exhausted and ran away [from the Wèi forces];
in the battle of Cài and Zhàolíng
the army of Chǔ was routed [by king Anxí];
his army was spread in all directions through the world
his authority was generally recognised in civilised countries where hats and belts are worn;
but when king Ānxī died Wèi was ruined.
And so, while Zhuāng of Chǔ and Huán of Qí were alive
Chǔ and Qí were able to hold dominating positions.
While Xiāng of Yān and Anlí of Wèi were alive
Yān and Wèi were able to be strong.
Now the reason why all these ruined their states
is that their various ministers and enforcement officials
were all striving for things that would lead to political turmoil,
and they did not strive for things that would lead to political good order.
When the state is already in political turmoil and weak,
then for all to go on to set aside the laws of the state
and to pursue personal ends beyond what the law prescribes
that is trying to put out fire with firewood on one's back.
The result is extreme political turmoil and weakness.
So, turning now to the present times
if one is able to remove private illegal practices
and is able to keep to the public law,
then the people will find peace and the state will be well governed;
if one is able to remove private actions
and practise the public law,
then one's armed forces will get stronger and one's enemies will be weakened.
If carefully assessing gains and losses
one has a system of laws and regulations
and applies these to all ministers,
then the ruler cannot be cheated through fraud or deceit;
if carefully assessing gains and losses
one has a standard for weighing matters
so that one applies these to matters that are remote (from one's court),
then the ruler cannot be cheated on the true weight of things in the world.
Now, if one advances people in rank on the basis of renown
then ministers will be distanced from their superior
and inferiors will form factions;
if promotion in office is based on the factions to which candidates belong
then the people will be concerned to establish connections
and they will not aim for the regular functioning of the law.
When the offices miss out on candidates of ability,
then the state will be in disarray.
If rewards are made in terms of praise
and if punishments are made in terms of public criticism,
then the people, who basically like rewards and dislike punishments,
will dismiss public-spirited action.
They will instead act according to their private philosophies,
and they will form gangs of people working for each other.
They will disregard the ruler and make their connections outside the court,
in order to promote their associates,
and as a result subordinates will have little to serve their superiors with.
If connections are many and associates are many,
if outside and inside the court there are friends and accomplices,
then even if someone has committed a serious transgression,
this is going to be hidden in most cases.
Then loyal and guiltless ministers are in danger of death,
and wicked ministers without achievements are sure of prosperity.
When loyal ministers are in danger of death
but not because of any guilt,
then capable ministers will lie low;
when wicked ministers feel sure of benefits,
but not on the basis of achievements,
then wicked ministers will gain advancement.
These things are the basis of ruin.
If one proceeds like this,
then the various ministers will spurn the law
and they will act on their personal advantage,
then they will make light of the public law.
Again and again they will come to the gates of the men with political clout,
and not even once will they come to the court of the ruler;
a hundred times they will be planning for the advantage of the private families,
not once will they make responsible plans for the state, which is the ruler's.
One's underlings may be many,
but they are not the kind that would give honour to the ruler;
all the officials may be on hand,
but they are not the kind that take responsibility for the state.
Under these conditions the ruler has the title of a ruler of men,
but in fact he has delegated authority to the clans of the various ministers.
Therefore I say:
"In a state doomed to ruin there are no people at court."
When I say 'there are no people at court'
that does not mean that the court declines,
it means that the clans are concerned to serve each other's advantage
and are not concerned to work for the best of the state;
the great ministers are concerned to work for each other's public respect,
and they are to concerned to work for the public respect of the ruler;
the minor ministers take their salaries and cultivate their connections,
and they do not make official duties their main business.
The reason why this comes to pass
is because the ruler above does not settle things by law from above
but trusts that his inferiors will take appropriate action.
Therefore the enlightened ruler makes the law choose people,
and he does not choose them himself;
he makes the law assess achievements,
and he does not measure these himself.
If abilities cannot be hidden,
if defeats cannot be dressed up,
if it is impossible to promote those who are popular,
and if one cannot demote those who are unpopular
then there is a clear distinction between ruler and ministers
and they are easy to govern.
Thus if the ruler ensures that the laws are correct then things will be fine.
A man of talent who enters someone else's service
will face north and make formal presents [to his master],
[to show that] he will not have two loyalties.
At court he does not presume to decline humble tasks,
in the army he does not presume to decline difficult tasks.
He acts in accordance with the initiatives of his superior
and he follows the laws laid down by the ruler;
humbly he awaits orders
and does not set himself up as judge over right and wrong.
Thus he has a mouth but does not make proposals directed at personal profit,
he has eyes but does not take a egotistic perspective on things
so that the ruler will completely control him.
Someone who is in someone else's service
is like a hand (of his employer),
above he looks after his head,
below he looks after the feet;
from chill and warmth, from cold and heat
he has to save his master;
even when the mighty Mòyé sword is nearing his limbs,
he will not dare not to grapple with it with his bare hands.
One should not show excessive personal favour towards talented and wise ministers,
and one should not show excessive personal favour towards officials who are capable.
As a result the people will not make friendships beyond their neighbourhood,
and they will feel no strong concern for matters a hundred lǐ away.
The noble and the base will not overstep their boundaries,
the inept and the competent will will each stand in their place, holding the balance.
Such is the perfection of good political order.
Now as for those who make light of official honours and stipends
and who will easily leave their masters and disappear
in order to choose a ruler,
these I do not call morally pure.
Those who are fraudulently persuasive and go against the law,
who turn against the ruler and make a power play of giving advice,
these I do not call devoted.
Those who practice generosity and who dole out benefits
and thus gain the allegiance of underlings and establish a name for themselves,
these I do not call kind-hearted.
Those who leave the vulgar world and live in hiding
and deceitfully criticise their superiors,
these I do not call righteous.
Those who are in the service of the feudal lords abroad
but who at home waste their states,
and who just wait eagerly for the dangerous situation
so that they can scare their rulers and say:
"Without me you will not strike up close relations,
without me you cannot resolve enmities"
and the ruler will put his trust in them
so that the state will listen to them.
They debase the ruler's good name to make themselves famous,
they destroy the opulence of the state in order to profit their clans.
These I do not call competent.
These various things (egotistic wisdom, righteousness, loyalty, humaneness)
are the talk of a dangerous world,
and the laws of the former kings made light of these things.
The law of the former kings said:
"The ministers should not build up authority.
They should not create wealth,/
but rather follow the king's intentions;/
they should not do evil,/
but rather follow the king's path."/
In ancient times the people who were well governed for generations
upheld the common law,
and they rejected private philosophies;
they concentrated their thoughts and unified their actions
and waited in everything to perform assigned tasks.
If as a ruler one personally wants to supervise personally all the officials,
then the days will not be enough
and one's strength will not be sufficient.
Moreover, if those above use their eyes
then those below will make themselves beautiful to look at;
if those above use their ears,
then those below will make themselves beautiful to listen to;
if those above use their intellect,
then those below will come up with elaborate formulations.
The former kings regarded these three things as insufficient,
so they dismissed their own abilities and relied on the arts of law,
and they paid careful attention to rewards and punishments.
What the former kings guarded carefully was the crucial thing,
and so the laws were sparse and they were uninfringed.
Independently they controlled all within the Four Seas:
the sharp and clever people did not get to deploy their deceptions,
the garrulous busybodies did not get to employ their glib rhetoric,
and the wicked had no one to rely on.
Even as far away as one thousand lǐ,
they did not dare to take their public speeches lightly;
power lay with the courtiers,
and these men did not dare to hide goodness or embellish wrongdoings;
all the subordinates at court
combined their individually weak forces in the service of their ruler
and would never dare to infringe on each other's duties.
Thus there was not enough to do in government and too many days to do it in.
The ruler's way of using his power brought this about.
The way in which ministers encroach upon the authority of the ruler
is like progress through territory:
gradually things change as one goes on,
and they cause the ruler to lose his basic orientation,
east and west change directions and he does not know where he is.
Therefore the former kings established the use of the compass pointing south
in order to find their bearings on where the sun rises and sets.
And similarly the enlightened ruler sees to it that the ministers do not stray beyond the law,
and that they do not show generosity [even] within the law,
that in everything they do they follow the law.
Through formidable laws
one prevents transgressions and keeps egotism away;
through strict punishments
one has orders carried through and inferiors chastised.
Authority must not be imposed from two sources,
and control must not go through a common gate.
When authority and control are shared in common
then all the kinds of wickedness will show themselves;
when the law is not reliable
then the ruler's actions are precarious;
when corporal punishments are not decisive
then wickedness will not be overcome.
Therefore it is said:
The skilful carpenter will hit the ink-line by visual intuition,
and yet he certainly first takes the circle and the square as his standard;
the superbly competent man will act gingerly and get everything right,
and yet he certainly takes the laws of the former kings for comparison.
Thus as long as the ink-line is straight then warped wood will end up straight;
as long as the water balance?? is even, great unevennesses will be levelled off;
as long as the scales are evenly hung then weights will be levelled out;
as long as bushels and stones are standardised, quantities will be levelled out.
Thus ruling a state by use of the law
is simply a matter of carrying out standard measures.
The law does not pander to the noble,
the ink-line does not get all bent according to what is crooked.
Where the law applies,
the crafty cannot make their excuses
and the courageous will not dare to fight against it.
The physical punishing of transgressions should not spare great ministers;
the rewarding of the good should not bypass the ordinary person.
As for correcting the ruler's oversights,
as for pursuing subordinates' wickedness,
as for sorting out insubordinacy and unravelling mistakes,
as for removing the superfluous and evening out the incorrect,
as for uniting the tracks for the people to follow,
nothing is as good as the law.
As for being strict with officials and the establishing of one's authority over the people,
as for removing wantonness and dangerous behaviour,
as for stopping fraud and pretence,
nothing is as good as physical punishment.
When corporal punishments are heavy,
then the noble will not dare to make light of the base;
when the laws are carefully observed,
then those above are honoured and [their authority] is uninfringed.
When those above are publicly honoured and [their authority] uninfringed
then the ruler is powerful and guards carefully what is crucial.
That is why the former kings valued these things and transmitted them.
When the ruler dismisses the law and follows his private inclinations,
then there will be no proper division between superiors and inferiors.
And those who act as ministers are afraid of execution and punitive sanctions,
while they regard rewards as beneficial.
Therefore, if the ruler will use his own measures of punishment and generosity,
then the ministers will be in fearful awe of his awesome authority
and will concentrate on what they regard as advantageous. [or: converge on what is prof. to ruler]
On the other hand the depraved ministers of our time are not like that.
If they hate people,
then, if they can get their way with their ruler they accuse them of crimes;
and if they feel loving care for people,
then, if they can get their way with their ruler, they will have them rewarded.
Now if the ruler fails to insure that threat and the awe-inspiring benefit of rewards and punishments originate in himself,
and if he listens to his ministers in administering rewards and punishments,
then throughout the state people will all revere the ministers and make light of their ruler;
they will turn to the minister and distance themselves from the ruler.
This is the disastrous consequence of the ruler losing control over acts of punishment and public generosity.
Now the reason why a tiger is able to subdue a dog
lies in his claws and fangs.
Suppose the tiger gives up his claws and fangs,
and suppose a dog gets to use them,
then, on the contrary, the tiger will submit to the dog.
As for the ruler
he is the sort of person who controls ministers through punishments and generosity,
Now if the ruler gives up control over punishments and acts of generosity
and makes his ministers deploy them,
then the ruler will, on the contrary, be controlled by his ministers.
Thus Tián Cháng asked, on the one hand, for authority over ranks and stipends
and distributed them among the various ministers,
on the other hand he increased the sizes of the picul
and distributed grain to the people.
Through this Duke Jiǎn lost the power to exercise generosity
and Tián Cháng exercised it.
As a result Duke Jiǎn was assassinated.
Zǐ Hǎn said to the the ruler of Sòng:
"As for handing out rewards and making presents,
these are what the people are delighted to receive,

If the ruler wishes to prevent wickedness,

Performance and official title

When the minister puts something forward then he makes a proposal,

Exclusively on the basis of assigned task does he demand successful performance.
If effective performance fits the assigned task,

In ancient times Duke Zhāo of Hán was drunk and resting.
The officer in charge of the caps noticed that the ruler was cold
and he put some clothes over him.
When the ruler woke up from his sleep he looked satisfied
and he asked his entourage:
"Who put put those clothes over me?"
His entourage replied:
"The officer in charge of the hats did."
As a result the ruler brought accusations both against the officer in charge of the clothes and the officer in charge of the hats:
the accusation against the officer in charge of the clothes
was because he considered that he had been remiss in his duties;
the accusation against the officer in charge of the hats
was because he considered that the man had exceeded his duties.
The point was not that he did not hate the cold,
but he considered that the harm of infringing on one's official duties was more serious than [his own] coldness.

The third is "elders".
What does one mean by "elders" [in this context]?

The princes born from non-main wives

The fourth is "breeding disaster".
What does "breeding disaster" mean [in this context]?

The fifth is called "the people".
