Eight: When one has made a mistake not to listen to loyal ministers
and putting one's thoughts into practice heedless of theirs,
that is the beginning of destroying one's good name and of becoming the laughing stock of others.
Nine: If one does not assess correctly one's strength within one's country
and relies outside on the feudal lords,
then that will lead to the disaster of the truncation of the state.
Ten: When one's state is small, shows no ritual politeness,
and does not employ ministers given to remonstration,
then that is a constellation in which one's line of inheritance will be broken.
What does one call petty loyalties?
In ancient times King Gōng of Chǔ and Duke Lì of Jìn
fought a battle at Yānlíng.
The Chǔ army was defeated
and King Gōng was injured in the eye.
In the heat of the battle,
marshal Zǐfǎn felt thirsty and wanted to find something to drink,
and his servant boy Gǔyáng took a beaker of wine and offered it up.
Zǐfǎn said:
"Ha!
Out of my sight
That is wine."
Gǔyáng said:
"This is not wine."
Zǐfǎn accepted it and drank it.
Zǐfǎn's disposition was such
that he was very fond of wine,
and in fact he found it so pleasant
that he was unable to stop himself from drinking,
so he got drunk.
When the battle was over
King Gōng wanted to renew the battle
and he sent someone to summon marshal Zǐfǎn,
but marshal Zǐfǎn declined on the grounds of acute psychological indisposition.
King Gōng yoked his carriage and went over in person.
When he got into the tent
he smelt the stench of wine and turned back
saying:
"In today's battle
I have personally got injured.
The person I felt I could rely on
was our marshal,
but you our marshal get drunk again like this:
this is to disregard the altars of the land and grain of Chǔ
and to fail to show proper deep concern for my numerous people:
I am not going to renew battle."
And so he turned round his army and left the battlefield,
He had Sīmǎ Zifǎn cut up in a large scale public execution.
Now when the servant boy Gǔyáng proffered the wine
that was not an act of enmity against Zǐfǎn,
but in his heart he loyally loved him
and that was all it took to cause his death.
Thus it is said:
The practice of petty loyalty
is the enemy of great loyalty.
What does one mean by concern for small profit?
In ancient times Duke Xiàn of Jìn wanted to ask for right of passage from Yú
in order to attack Guó.
Xún Xí said:
"You should use the bì-jade from Chuíjī together with team-horses raised in Qū
to bribe the Duke of Yú
and ask for the right of passage,
and he is bound to grant us the right of passage."
The ruler said:
"As for the bì-jades from Chuíjī
they are treasures from my father;
as for the team-horses raised in Qū
they are the most outstanding horses I have.
If he takes my precious presents but does not grant us right of way,
what would we do?"
Xún Xí said:
"If that man does not grant us right of way
he is bound not to accept our precious presents of silk.
If he accepts our precious presents of silk and grants us right of way
then this amounts to taking these treasures from the inner treasury
and hiding them away in the outer treasury,
and for the horses it is like taking them from the inner stables
and keeping them in the outer stables.
You should not worry about this."
The ruler said:
"All right."
And he ordered Xún Xí to take the bì-jade from Chuíjī as well as the team-horses bred in Qū
and bribe the Duke of Yú and ask him to grant the right of passage.
The Duke of Yú was greedy after the bì-jade and the horses and he was inclined to accede to the request.
Gōng Zhī Qi remonstrated and said:
"This should not be granted.
Yú is to Guó
like a cart to the leather straps holding up the body of a carriage:
the leather straps are linked to the carriage,
and the carriage also leans on the leather straps.
The constellation of Yú and Guó is exactly such.
If you grant him right of passage
then if in the morning Guó is ruined, Yú will suffer the same fate in the evening.
This is not acceptable.
I hope you will not accede to this request."
The Duke of Yú would not listen to this advice
and he granted right of passage to them.
Xún Xí attacked Guó and vanquished the state.
After his return three years went by
then he raised an army to launch a formal attack on Yú,
and he vanquished that state as well.
Xún Xí dragged along the horses, took along the bì-jade
and reported the event to Duke Xiàn of Jìn.
Duke Xiàn was satisfied and said:
"The bì-jade is still as before;
However,
the horses' teeth have surely grown longer by now."
Now, that the of the Duke of Yú were exposed to fatal danger
and that his territory was truncated,
why was that?
He craved small profit and did not take precautions against the ensuing harm.
Thus it is said:
Concern for petty profit
is to the detriment of large profit.
What does one mean by "acting extravagantly"?
In ancient times King Líng of Chǔ conducted a meeting at Shēn,
and the heir apparent of Sòng was late to arrive.
The King detained him and had him put in prison;
he behaved with improper informality towards the ruler of Xú;
he put Qìng Fēng from Qí under house arrest.
A palace archery guard remonstrated:
"When one calls together the feudal lords one must follow ritual politeness,
This is the crucial point leading to survival or ruin.
In ancient times Jié conducted a meeting in Yǒu Róng (in Shāndōng),
and the Yǒu Mín tribe rebelled;
Zhòu went on a hunting expedition at Líqiū,
and the Róng as well as the Dí rebelled:
all this was because of lack of ritual politeness.
You should consider your decision carefully."
The ruler did not listen
and he went on to act according to his original idea.
Not even a year had passed
when King Líng was on a pleasure trip in the south,
and his ministers went after him and kidnapped him.
King Líng of Chǔ was starved to death on the Gānxī River.
Thus it is said:
Acting extravagantly and being wilful,
being impolite to the feudal lords,
this is an extreme case of bringing ruin upon oneself.
What does one mean by loving music?
In ancient times Duke Líng of Wèy was about to go to Jìn
and when he got to the banks of the river Pú
he unhitched the carriages and set free the horses,
he set up a hut to stay for one night.
At midnight
he heard someone strumming a new tune, and he felt pleased.
He sent someone to ask his entourage about this,
but he reported that they all had not heard it.
Then the Duke summoned Music Master Juān and told him:
"There is someone who is strumming a new tune.
I have sent someone to ask my entourage,
but all them report that they cannot hear it.
Its appearance was like a ghost or spirit.
You listen to this for me and imitate it."
Music Master Juān said:
"Very well"
And so he sat down quietly, played his lute to imitate the tune.
Music Master Juān reported the next day:
"I have got the tune,
but I have still not practised it properly.
May I ask to practise on it for another night."
Duke Líng said:
"Very well"
And so he stayed for another night.
The next day
the Music Master had already learnt it properly.
Later, the Duke left and proceeded to Jìn.
Duke Píng of Jìn offered him wine on the Shīyí terrace.
When they had drunk a fair amount of wine
Duke Líng got up.
The Duke said:
"There is a new tune.
I wish I could ask them to perform it for you."
Duke Píng said: "Very good"
Then he summoned Music Master Juān,
ordered him to sit next to Music Master Kuàng,
to take his lute and to strum the tune on it.
Before he had finished
Music Master Kuàng touched his arm and stopped him,
saying:
"This is a tune of a state doomed to ruin.
One should not go through with it."
Duke Píng asked:
"Where is this tune from?"
Music Master Kuàng said:
"This was created by Music Master Yán:
he was making extravagant music for [the wicked] Emperor Zhòu.
When King Wǔ attacked Zhòu
Music Master Yán fled towards the east,
when he got as far as the River Pú he killed himself.
Therefore as for hearing this tune
you must have heard it on the River Pú.
He who hears this tune before he gets to the River Pú
is bound to have his territory truncated.
One should not go through with this tune."
Duke Píng said:
What I like
is the music as such.
You should let him go through with it."
Music Master Juān strummed the tune to the end.
Duke Píng asked Music Master Kuàng:
"What is this tune called?"
Music Master Kuàng replied:
"It is called pure shāng."
The Duke said:
"Is the pure shāng really the saddest note/key?"
Music Master Kuàng said:
"It is not as sad as the pure zhǐ."
The Duke asked:
"May I hear the pure zhǐ note/key?"
Music Master Kuàng said:
"You may not.
Those who, in ancient times, listened to the pure zhǐ note/key
all had rulers who were magnanimous and righteous.
Now our ruler's charismatic integrity is slight,
so we are not qualified to listen to that note/key."
Duke Píng said:
"What I like
is the sound of the music.
I very much hope listen to it."
Music Master Kuàng had no way out.
He took the lute and began to play.
When he played it for the first time
two groups of eight reddish-black cranes
came in from the south
and settled on the circular wall on top of the palace entrance.
When he played it for the second time
they formed rows.
When he played it for the third time
they craned their necks and sang,
spread their wings and danced.
When his intonation hit the gōng and the shāng notes
the tune resonated in Heaven.
Duke Píng was highly satisfied,
and those who were sitting with him were all delighted.
Duke Píng raised a beaker
and rose to drink to the long life of Music Master Kuàng,
when he had returned to his seat he asked:
"Is there no music sadder than the pure zhǐ-Fifth?"
Music Master Kuàng said:
"It is not as sad as the pure jué-Third.
Duke Píng said:
"May I hear the pure jué-Third?"
Music Master Kuàng said:
"You may not.
In ancient times when the Yellow Emperor assembled the ghosts and spirits
on Mount Tài,
they rode on ivory carriages pulled by six jiāo dragons,
Bìfāng (spirit of trees) keeping apace with the axle-caps,
Chìyóu was up in front,
the God of Wind proceeded, brooming as he went,
the Master of Rain sprinkled the way,
tigers and wolves were the front guard,
ghosts and spirits were the rear guard,
flying snakes were crouching on the ground,
phoenix birds were hovering over the scene.
On the occasion of this grandiose reunion of ghosts and spirits
he made the pure jué-Third.
Now your magnanimity is slight:
he is not qualified to listen to this.
If you listen to it
in the future I am afraid there will be defeat ahead.
Duke Píng said:
"I am already old.
What I like is music.
I want to hear it anyway."
Music Master Kuàng had no alternative and he played it for him.
When he played it for the first time
reddish-black clouds emerged from the north-western region.
When he played it for the second time
there was a great storm.
Rainstorms followed
and they tore up the curtains,
smashed the ritual vessels,
ruined the tiles in the corridor
Those who were in attendance fled in all directions.
Duke Píng got frightened
and he lay face down between the porches and buildings.
In the state of Jìn there occurred a great draught
which scorched the earth for three years.
Subsequently Duke Píng's body became decrepit and ill.
Thus it is said:
If one does not make it one's business to attend to political matters
and is endlessly fond of music,
then that is conduct that leads one into an impasse.
What does one mean by greedy and insensitive?
In ancient times Yáo, the Earl of Zhì, lead Zhào, Hán, and Wèi
to launch a formal attack against Fàn and Zhòngháng,
and completely routed them.
When he returned
he rested his armed forces for several years
after which he ordered someone to ask for a piece of territory from Hán.
Kāngzǐ from Hán wanted to refuse to hand over that territory,
but Duàn Guī remonstrated and said:
"It is unacceptable not to give the piece of territory to them.
By nature the Earl of Zhì
is eager for gain, arrogant and insensitive.
When that man comes and asks for territory and one refuses to give it to him,
then he is bound to move his forces to Hán.
You must give him the territory.
If you give him what he wants then that man will get overconfident
and he will ask for territory from other states.
Among these other states there will be those who will not co-operate.
If they do not co-operate
then the Earl of Zhì is bound to apply military force.
When such a situation arises
Hán may be able to avoid disaster
and can quietly await the reversal of the situation.
Kāngzǐ said:
"Very well"
And he sent an envoy to hand over a district with families
to the Earl of Zhì.
The Earl of Zhì was gratified
and he went on to send someone to ask for a piece of territory from Wèi.
Xuānzǐ wanted to refuse the request,
but Zhào Jiā remonstrated and said:
"That man has asked for territory from Hán
and Hán has given it to him.
Now he is asking for territory from Wèi
and if Wèi refuses to give it to him
then Wèi may get stronger internally
but externally one will arouse the anger of the Earl of Zhì.
If we refuse to give it to him
he is bound to use armed force against Wèi.
It is best that we give it to him."
Xuānzǐ said:
"Very well"
And he sent someone to hand over a district with families
to the Earl of Zhì.
The Earl of Zhì went on to send a person to go to Zhào
and to ask for the territories of Cài, Gāoláng.
But Xiāngzǐ of Zhào refused to give it to him.
And so the Earl of Zhì entered into a secret agreement with Hán and Wèi
wanting to launch a formal attack on Zhào with their help.
Xiāngzǐ summoned Zhāng Mèngtán and announced to him:
"The Earl of Zhì is by nature
overtly friendly and secretly hostile.
Three times he has sent embassies to Hán and Wèi
but I have not given him what he wanted.
He is bound to use military force against me.
Now how am I to deal with the situation?"
Zhāng Mèngtán said:
As for Dǒng Èyú,
he was a gifted minister to ruler Jiǎn,
and in his government of Jìnyáng
Yinduó followed Dǒng Èyú's principles.
and the after-effects of their teachings are still being felt.
You should simply fix your abode in Jìnyáng"
The ruler said;
"Very well"
And he summoned Master Yánlíng
and ordered him to lead an expedition of chariots and horsemen
to go to Jìnyáng first,
and then the ruler followed behind.
When the ruler arrived
he went on a tour of the inner and outer walls
as well as the store houses of the various officials.
The inner and outer walls were not well kept,
in the granaries there were no stockpiles of grain,
in the treasury there was no accumulated cash,
and in the settlements there were no defensive implements.
Xiāngzǐ was frightened
and he summoned Zhāng Mèngtán and said:
"I have been on a tour of the inner and outer cities
and of the repositories of the various officials,
and they are all not well supplied:
how am I going to deal with the enemy?"
Zhāng Mèngtán said:
"I have heard it said that the good government of the sage
locates its stores in the people
and does not store in treasuries and armouries;
he will try to work at their education
and will not work at inner and outer walls.
You should issue an order
and order the people to leave for themselves three years' food,
and if there is leftover grain to enter them into the granaries;
to leave for themselves money to cover three years' expenses,
and if there is leftover cash, to enter it into the treasury;
if there is surplus labour
to make them to work at the repair of the inner and outer walls."
In the evening the ruler issued the order,
the next day
the granaries could not find room for the grain,
the treasures had nowhere to pile in the cash,
the armouries did not accept armour and weaponry.
After five days had passed the inner and outer walls were repaired,
and the defensive arrangements were all complete.
The ruler summoned Zhāng Mèngtán and asked him:
"My inner and outer city walls are well built,
my defensive arrangements are all complete,
cash an grain there is enough of,
armour and weapons there are in abundance:
But what can I do without an arrow?"
Zhāng Mèngtán said:
"I have heard it said that when Dǒngzǐ governed Jìnyáng
then all around the official residence
he has built a wall of dí and gǎo reeds of the kǔ and the chǔ trees.
Some kǔ-trees are more than two meters high.
You should take them out and use them."
Thereupon the Duke took the kǔ-trees and tried them out.
It was so strong that even the hardest bamboo
could not surpass it in strength.
The ruler said:
"I am fine for arrows,
but how about the metal?"
Zhāng Mèngtán said:
"I have heard it said that when Dǒngzǐ governed Jìnyáng
the official residence as well as the halls of the minor officials' housing
all had copper columns and column bases.
You should take these out and use them."
Thereupon the Duke took them out and used them,
and there was more than enough metal.
When the orders and ordinances had been defined
and the defensive arrangements were complete
the armies of the three states did in fact arrive.
And when they arrived they tried to scale the inner city walls
and then they did give battle.
In the course of three months they were unable to take out the city.
So they let the army fan out and they besieged Jìnyáng.
The redirected the water flowing into Jìnyáng to inundate the place.
In this way they besieged Jìnyáng for a period of three years (months).
The people moved into "bird's nests" and lived there,
they had to hang their pots high up to cook their food,
their supplies and their food were about to be depleted
the freemen and the great officers were weak and sick.
Xiāngzǐ told Zhāng Mèngtán:
"Food is in short supply,
our resources are exhausted,
our officers and senior officials are weakened and sick,
I am afraid we cannot defend the place.
I intend to surrender together with the city.
But to which state should one surrender?"
Zhāng Mèngtán said:
"I have learnt
that if when faced with ruin one cannot survive,
and if when faced with danger one cannot remain calm,
then one can in no way count as noble and competent.
You should reject this plan.
I beg to be allowed to try to sneak out
and to visit the rulers of Hán and Wèi."
Zhāng Mèngtán visited the rulers of Hán and Wèi and said:
"I have learnt that when the lips are gone the teeth get cold.
Now the Earl of Zhì is leading you two rulers to attack Zhào,
and Zhào is about to go under.
If Zhào goes under
then you two rulers will be next in line."
The two rulers said:
"We know that this is so.
However,
by nature the Earl of Zhì
is of a crude inner disposition and has few close friends.
If we organise a plot and it is discovered
then disaster is bound to hit us.
What can we do?"
Zhāng Mèngtán said:
"The plot will emerge from the mouths of you two rulers
and it will enter my ears:
no one will know about it."
And so the two rulers with Zhāng Mèngtán
agreed on the three armies' revolt,
and they agreed on a day with him.
They sent Mèngtán to enter Jìnyáng at night
to notify the city of the two rulers' revolt.
Xiāngzǐ welcomed Mèngtán and bowed twice for him:
he was both terrified and delighted.
After having sent Zhāng Mèngtán along according to the agreement
the two rulers then proceeded to go out to have an audience with the Earl of Zhì
and they met Zhì Guò outside the military gate.
Zhì Guò found their facial expressions strange
and so he went in to see the Earl of Zhì and said:
"To judge from their appearance the two rulers will revolt."
The ruler said:
"What is their appearance like?"
He replied:
"Their deportment is proud and their aims are set high,
they are not restrained as at any other time.
You had better anticipate them and strike first."
The ruler said:
"I have entered a neat agreement with these two rulers
to destroy Zhào and to divide its territory into three.
This is what I use to cultivate a close relationship with them.
They would never turn against me and turn fraudulent.
The troops have been deployed at Jìnyáng for three years.
Now at any time we shall take the city and will reap our profit:
Why should they have other thoughts?
You must be wrong.
You had better put this out of your mind and stop worrying about it.
And don't breathe a word about it."
The next morning
the two rulers again went out to attend court,
and again they saw Zhì Guò at the military gate.
Zhì Guò went in to see the Earl of Zhì and said:
"Have you told the two rulers what I said?"
The ruler said:
"How did you know?"
He said:
"Today when the two rulers went out to attend court,
as they saw me they facial expression was altered
and they stared at me.
Considering this they are certain to be bent on revolt.
You had better kill them."
The ruler said:
"You had better leave this. And don't talk to me about it again
Zhì Guò said:
"Oh no
You absolutely must kill them.
If you cannot get yourself to kill them
then you should in fact cultivate a close relationship with them.
The ruler said:
"Why cultivate a close relationship with them?"
Zhì Guò said:
Xuānzǐ of Wèi had an adviser Zhào Jiā,
and Hán Kāngzǐ had an adviser Duàn Guī:
these were all able to change their rulers' plans.
You should agree with the two men
that having annihilated the state of Zhào
you will proceed to enfeoff these two men
each one with a district of ten thousand families.
If you do this
then the attitudes of the two rulers may not bent on rebellion."
The Earl of Zhì said:
"If having annihilated Zhào and having divided the territory into three
I then go on to enfeoff the two men
each with a district of ten thousand families,
then what I get out of this will be less than the others.
That is not acceptable."
Zhì Guò could see that his words were not being heeded,
he left,
and he proceeded to change his clan-name into Fǔ.
When it came to the night of the appointed day
the Zhào killed the dike guard
and inundated the army of the Earl of Zhì.
When the army of the Earl of Zhì were all in disarray fighting the flood
Hán and Wèi attacked him from the wings:
Xiāngzǐ lead lead solders to launch a sudden attack at the front,
and they completely routed the Earl of Zhì's army
and took the Earl of Zhì prisoner.
The Earl of Zhì died, and his army was destroyed.
His state was divided into three,
and he became the laughing stock of the world.
Thus it is said:
Being greedy, insensitive and eager for gain
that is the root of destroying one's state and losing one's life.
What does one mean by being addicted to female musicians?
In ancient times the king of the Róng Barbarians sent Yóuyú
to pay a formal visit to Qín,
and Duke Mù of Qín asked him:
"I have on occasion heard about the Way,
but I have never seen it with my own eyes.
I hope to learn about how the ancient enlightened rulers regularly won their states and lost their states."
Yóu Yú replied:
"I have once come to learn
that quite regularly rulers have won their states through thrift
and that they have lost their states through luxuriousness."
Duke Mù said:
"I very politely consult you, Sir, about the Way,
but you reply to me in terms of thrift:
What do you mean to say?"
Yóu Yú replied:
"I have learnt that in ancient times when Yáo was in charge of the world
he ate from earthenware vessels
and he drank from earthenware pots.
His territory extended to Jiāozhǐ in the south
to Yōudū in the north,
in the east and in the west, right until the points where the sun rises and where she sets,
and everyone submitted as guests to him.
When Yáo handed over the government of the world
Shùn took over the reins of government.
and he created food vessels.
He cut down mountain trees and used them as materials.
He hewed them and sawed them and polished uneven points,
he poured lacquer and ink over them,
he transported them to the palace and used them as food vessels.
The feudal lords considered him as excessively extravagant
and thirteen states refused to submit to him.
Shùn abdicated the throne and passed it on to Yǔ.
Yǔ created sacrificial vessels:
with ink he impregnated their outsides
and he painted the insides red,
plain fine silk served for his mattresses,
he had wild rice mats with decorated borders.
The beakers and ladles for wine had many colours,
and the wine goblets and meat bowls with slim high bases were decorated.
This was even more extravagant,
and there were thirty three states that did not recognise his authority.
When Xiàhòu clan had gone under
the Yīn people took over.
They made large carriages
and they established the system of banners with nine pendants.
The food vessels were sculpted and carved,
wine beakers and ladles were engraved and incised in the metal
the walls were chalked and the stairways plastered,
the mattresses and mats were embellished with patterns.
This was even more extravagant
and fifty three states refused to recognise their authority;.
The gentlemen all become connoisseurs of embellishments
and those who want to recognise their authority become ever fewer.
That is why I say:
Frugality is the right way."
When Yóu Yú had left
the Duke summoned the Inner Archivist Liào and told him:
"I have heard it said that if in a neighbouring state there is a sage
then that spells trouble for a competing state.
Now Yóu Yú
is a sage
and I consider that as disastrous.
What can I do?"
The Inner Archivist said:
"As far as I know the dwelling of the King oft the Róng barbarians
is in some out-of-the-way place a long way off:
he has never heard the songs from the central states.
You should present him with female musicians
in order to confuse his administration,
and only after that should you request that Yóu Yú return later
in order to keep him from remonstrating.
When there is a rift between this ruler and the minister among the other party,
only then you can you make proper plans in this matter."
The ruler said:
"Very well"
and he sent the Archivist Liào
to present the King of the Róng with two rows of eight female musicians,
and to avail himself of the opportunity to ask for a delayed return of Yóu Yú.
The King of the Róng agreed to the request.
When he saw the female musicians he was gratified,
he arranged for wine and set up a drinking party,
he spent the whole day listening to the music.
For the rest of the year he did not move to find new pastures
and half of his oxen and horses died.
When Yóu Yú returned
he then took the opportunity to remonstrate with the King of the Róng
but the King of the Róng would not listen to him.
Yóu Yú then did indeed left the Róng and went to Qín.
Duke Mù of Qín welcomed him and appointed him Minister in Charge,
and he consulted him on the military and geographic constellation among the Róng.
Having got this information
he raised his army and launched a formal attack against the Róng,
joining twelve states to his own,
and he opened up a territory of a thousand square lǐ.
So that is why it is said:
To get infatuated with female musicians
and not to pay attention to the administration of one's state,
such behaviour will lead to the disaster of losing one's state.
What does one mean by leaving the court and going on distant journeys?
In ancient times Duke Jǐng of Qí travelled on the sea
and he was enjoying himself in the process.
He issued an order to the various grandees, saying:
"He who proposes to go back is to be held guilty of death."
Yán Zhuōjù said:
"You go on sea journeys and you are enjoying yourself,
but what if there is someone among the ministers who is plotting against the state?
You may be enjoying yourself now,
but will you be able to enjoy it in the future?"
Duke Jǐng of Qí said:
I have published an order saying:
'He who proposes that we should go back is to be held guilty of death',
now you have offended against my order."
He took a battle axe and was about to strike out against him.
Yán Zhuōjù said:
In ancient times Jié killed Guān Lóngpáng
and Zhòu killed Prince Bǐgàn.
Even if you kill me
to make it three of us, that will be all right.
I speak up for the sake of the state,
I do not by any means speak up on behalf of my person.
He stretched out his neck, stepped forward and said:
"Go ahead and strike out at me"
The ruler threw down his battle axe
hastened to have his carriages yoked and returned home.
After three days
he heard that among the people in the state some had conspired
not to allow Duke Jǐng back.
The reason why Duke Jǐng of Qí did indeed maintain control over the state of Qí
was because of Yán Zhuōjù's vigourous efforts.
Thus it is said:
If one leaves one's court and goes on distant journeys
that is a way of endangering one's life.
What does one mean by
not listening to loyal ministers when one has made a mistake?
In ancient times Duke Huán of Qí assembled the feudal lords nine times,
unified the world
and was the greatest of the Five Hegemons.
Guǎnzhòng assisted him.
When Guǎnzhòng had grown old
and was unable to conduct public business,
he retired to his home.
Then Duke Huán of Qí asked him about this:
"Senior Advisor Zhòng, you stay at home and are sick,
if by misfortune you do not recover from this illness,
to whom should I transfer the government?"
Guǎn Zhòng said:
"I am old,
I am not someone to consult.
None the less
I have learnt as a truth
that when it comes to understanding ministers, the ruler is best at it,
and when it comes to understanding sons, the father is best at it.
You must try to decide the matter on the basis of your own thinking. "
The ruler said:
"How about Bāo Shūyá?"
Guǎn Zhòng said:
"He is unacceptable.
Bāo Shūyá is by nature
inflexible and stubborn, and he values ferociousness.
Being inflexible he will offend the people with his cruelty,
being stubborn he will not gain the people's allegiance,
Being ferocious his inferiors will not allow themselves to be employed by him.
In his mind there is no proper fear:
he is not an aide for a hegemon."
The Duke said:
"Well then, how about Shù Diāo?"
Guǎn Zhòng said:
"He is not acceptable.
It is in the essence of man that they all take good care of their own bodies.
You being a jealous man, and fond of women
Shù Diāo castrated himself in order to administer the harem.
Even his own body he does not take good care of,
how is he going to go on to take good care of his ruler?"
The ruler said:
"Very well But how about Prince Kāi Fāng of Wèy?"
Guǎn Zhòng said:
"He is not acceptable.
Between Qí and Wèy there is no more than a ten-day's journey,
but in order to serve you
and because he wanted to please you,
he did not once go back to see his parents in fifteen years:
this is not a proper humane attitude.
If he cannot cultivate a close relationship with his parents,
how can he go on to cultivate a close relationship with his ruler?"
The Duke said:
"Very well But how about Yì Yá?"
Guǎn Zhòng said:
"He is not acceptable.
This Yì Yá is in charge of the cooking for you.
The only thing you have never eaten is human flesh.
Now Yì Yá broiled his son's head and offered it up as a dish:
and this is something you remember.
It is in the essence of men that they all take good care of their children,
but now he broiled his son in order to make a delicacy for his ruler:
his own son he would not take good care of,
how can he go on to take good care of his ruler?"
The Duke said:
"Very well But who, then, is acceptable?
Guǎn Zhòng said:
"Xí Péng is acceptable.
By nature
he is inwardly firm and incorruptible in his relation to others,
he has few desires but has plenty of good faith.
Now if someone is inwardly firm
he is qualified to serve as a model for others;
if someone is incorruptible in his relations with others
then he can be given great responsibilities;
if someone has few desires
then he is able to deal with the masses;
if someone has plenty of good faith
then he can cultivate close relations with neighbouring states.
This man is an aide to a true hegemon.
You should use him."
The ruler said:
"Very good."
More than a year passed,
and Guǎn Zhòng died.
The ruler did not in the event employ Xí Péng
but sided with Shù Diāo.
After Shù Diāo had ran the government for three years
Duke Huán travelled to Tángfù
Shù Diāo led Yì Yá, Prince Kāifāng of Wèi and senior ministers to stage a political revolt.
Duke Huán died of thirst and hunger in the bedroom by the southern gate, the building guarded by the Duke.
Three months after he had died his body had not been collected
the worms were emerging from the door (to the bedroom with his body).
Thus the armed forces of Duke Huán went all over the world,
and he became the leader of the Five Hegemons.
But in the end he was assassinated by his ministers
and had his high name destroyed,
became the laughing stock of the world.
Why was this?
It was the mistake of not acting according to Guǎn Zhòng's advice.
Thus it is said:
If, when one has made a mistake one does not listen to loyal ministers
but acts independently on the basis of one's own ideas,
then that is the beginning of destroying one's good name and
and of becoming the laughing stock of the world.
What does one mean by not carefully assessing one's power at court?
In ancient times when Qín attacked Yíyáng
the Hán were desperate.
Gōngzhòng Péng told the ruler of Hán:
"Our allies cannot be relied upon.
We had better use Zhāng Yí and sue for peace in Qín
and at the same time we should bribe them with a famous city
and we launch a formal attack on Chǔ in the south together with Qín.
By such a means our trouble with Qín is resolved
and the damage is passed on to Chǔ."
The Duke said:
"Good"
Then he gave warning that Gōngzhòng would go on his journey,
and that he would make peace with Qín in the west.
When the King of Chǔ learnt about this
he got frightened.
He summoned Chén Zhěn and announced to him:
Hán Péng is going to make peace with Qín in the west:
what are we going to do?"
Chén Zhěn said:
"Qín has obtained one city from Qín.
They will send out their crack troops,
Qín and Hán will unite to confront Chǔ in the south.
This is what the King of Qín has prayed for in his ancestral temples.
There is no doubt that this will inflict damage on Chǔ.
Your Majesty must quickly send off your most trusted minister,
give him many carriages,
give him a large amount of silk gifts
to submit to Hán and to say:
'our state may be small,
but we have mobilised all our soldiers.
I hope your great state will show high morale against Qín.
And so I hope that your great state will send an envoy to us
who will survey the mobilisation of soldiers in Chǔ."
Hán sent someone to Chǔ,
and so the King of Chǔ then sent carriages and horsemen,
and he lined them up at the Great Road North,
and he told the envoy from Hán:
"You report back to your ruler of Hán
and say: our poor settlements' troops will presently enter his realm."
The envoy returned and reported to the ruler of Hán,
and the ruler of Hán felt very greatly relieved
and he stopped Gōngzhòng.
Gōngzhòng said:
"This is not right.
The one who in reality is harming us
is Qín;
the one who in name only is rescuing us
is Chǔ.
If one accepts Chǔ's [as yet] unsubstantiated words
and makes light of the real disaster impending from powerful Qín,
then that is the root of danger for the state.
The ruler of Hán would not accept this.
Gōngzhòng got angry and returned home,
for ten days he did not attend court.
When Yiyáng got more and more desperate
The ruler of Hán sent envoys to hurry up the forces from Chǔ.
The caps and canopies of the various envoys were within sight of each other
but no troops arrived.
Yíyáng was in the end taken,
and the place became the laughing stock of the world.
Thus it is said:
If one does not carefully assess one's internal strength
and relies on support from the feudal lords outside,
that will lead to the truncation of one's state.
What does one mean by failing to show politeness as a small state?
In ancient times Prince Chóngěr of Jìn went into exile
and he passed through Cáo.
The ruler of Cáo saw him as he was stripped to the waist.
Xǐ Fùjí and Shūzhān were in attendance before him.
Shūzhān said to the ruler of Cáo:
I have observed the Prince of Jìn,
and he is not an ordinary person.
If you treat him without proper politeness,
then if at some appropriate time he returns to his state and raises an army
then I fear this will have deleterious consequences for Cáo.
You had better kill him."
The ruler of Cáo did not take the advice.
Xǐ Fùjī returned home and was sulking.
His wife asked him and said:
"You come home from abroad and you cut a sulking face:
what is the matter?"
Fùjī said:
"I have learnt:
'A ruler's good fortune does not reach one,
but his disaster entangles one.'
Today my ruler has summoned the Prince of Jìn,
and he has treated him without proper politeness.
I was present in front of him.
So that is why I am so unhappy."
His wife said:
"I have observed the Prince of Jìn,
and he is a ruler over ten thousand chariots;
as for his military and civil advisers
they are all ministers of ten thousand chariots.
Now he is in straights and in exile, and he passes through Cáo
and Cáo treats him without proper politeness.
If this man gains back his state
he is bound to punish those who had been impolite towards him,
and then Cáo is going to be the first in the row.
Why don't you dissociate yourself from Cáo in good time?"
Fùjī said:
"All right"
He put gold into a mug
filled up the rest of the mug with foodstuff.
put a bì-jade on top,
and during the night he sent someone to present these things to the Prince.
When the Prince saw the emissary
he bowed twice
received the food but refused the jade.
The Prince went on from Cáo to Chǔ,
and from Chǔ he went to Qín.
After he had been in Qín for three years
Duke Mù of Qín summoned together the various ministers
and consulted with them saying:
"In ancient times my relations with Duke Xiàn of Jin were good
and the feudal lords all knew about it.
Unfortunately, Duke Xiàn is separated from his ministers,
and this happened about ten years ago.
His heir is not of the good sort.
I am afraid that this man will bring it about
that his ancestral temples are not kept clean.
and that at the altars of the land and grain there will be no bloody food-offerings.
When things are in such a state and we refuse to put them right
then that is not a way of maintaining good relations with others.
I want to help Chóngěr and make him re-enter Jin.
What do you think?"
The various ministers all said:
"A good idea"
The Duke thereupon raised soldiers:
he mobilised five hundred armoured chariots,
two thousand horsemen
fifty thousand foot soldiers
helped Chóngěr to re-enter Jìn,
and established him as the ruler of Jìn.
After Chóngěr had been on the throne for three years
he raised an army and attacked Cáo.
At the same time he sent someone to tell the ruler of Cáo, saying:
"Tie up Shūzhān and take him out of the city,
I will immediately have him killed and stage a large-scale public execution."
He also sent someone to tell Xǐ Fùjī:
"The army is close to the city.
I remember well that you did not offend me.
You should put a mark on your neighbourhood gates.
I shall issue an order
ordering the army not to presume to violate these areas."
When the people of Cáo heard about this
those who lead their relatives along and found refuge in Xǐ Fùjī's neighbourhoods
were over 700 families.
This was the effect of proper politeness.
And so Cáo
was a small state
and she was under pressure both from Jìn and from Chǔ.
The ruler's position was precarious as that of eggs piled up on top of each other
but he treated the Prince of Jìn without proper politeness.
That is why his hereditary line was disrupted.
Thus it is said:
If a state is small and shows no politeness,
and if one does not make use of remonstrating ministers,
that is a constellation where one's hereditary line will be disrupted.
Ministers conduct their official tasks in accordance with orders,
in accordance with the law they administer their offices.
Such people one does not by any means call "men of power".
As for men of power
they act on their own authority without official orders
they fail to live up to the law in order to further their own private interests,
they squander what belongs to the state in order to work for their clan.
Through their power they are able to gain the support of the ruler.
This is what is called men of power.
A freeman who understands the art of political control will analyse clearly,
and as one accepts advice from or employs such a person
one will immediately expose the hidden real sentiments of the men of power;
a freeman who is capable of practising the law is vigourous and straight,
and as one accepts advice or employs such a person
one will immediately set right the wicked practices of the men of power.
Thus when freemen who know about government and are capable to practising the law are used
then noble and powerful ministers are sure to remain outsiders.
So gentlemen who understand the law and people in control
are mortal enemies that cannot coexist.
If the people in control deal with the important parts of business on their own authority
then those within the country and outside will be exploited by them.
Thus if the feudal lords do not align themselves with them
then their projects get no response,
and as a result rival states will sing the praise of those people who are in actual control;
if the various officials do not align themselves with these men of power
then their undertakings will not be brought forward in court,
and as a result the various ministers will work on their behalf;
if the minor officials do not align themselves with these men of power
then they do not get to be close to the ruler,
and as a result the military and civil entourage conceal (the big men's weaknesses);
if the men of learning do not align themselves with these men of power
then their sustenance stipends will be slight and the ritual status low,
and as a result the men of learning speak have to speak on their behalf.
These four accomplices
are the means by which the wicked ministers make themselves look good.
The men of power cannot do their loyal best for their ruler
so as to promote their adversaries (the legalists);
the ruler of men cannot get past the four helpers
so as to expose and investigate his ministers.
As a result the ruler becomes ever more ill-informed
and the senior ministers become ever more powerful.
In general men of power have a relationship with their ruler
such that they are rarely not trusted and loved,
and moreover they are the ruler's confidants.
When it comes to adapting oneself to the ruler's way of thinking
and identifying with his likes and dislikes
these are basically ways of promoting themselves.
When offices and high ranks go along with nobility and power
factions will in addition be numerous
and the whole state will sing their praise.
On the other hand specialists in the philosophy of law,
if they wish to work to achieve a high position,
it is not because they have a close relationship of trust and mutual care,
or that they have the wealth of feelings enjoyed by the confidants,
it is because they have plans to use proposals about the philosophy of law
to correct the ruler's bent towards flattery by others.
Thus such a person is in structural opposition to his ruler.
The position he occupies is humble,
without a faction, he is all isolated.
Now as someone distant from the ruler to fight with those who are close to him, beloved and trusted,
the signs are that one will not win;
if with inexperienced forces one is to compete with old hands
the signs are that one will not win;
if one goes against the ruler's idea
and competes with those who share his likes and dislikes
the signs are that one will not succeed;
if on the basis of a slight and lowly position, one competes with those who are noble and powerful,
the signs are that one will not win;
if as one person one competes with the whole state
the signs are that one cannot win.
The specialists in the philosophy of law
move in five non-winning constellations
they can count the years and still do not win an audience.
Meanwhile the men in control avail themselves of the five winning resources
and from morning to night they present their explanations to the ruler under four eyes.
So, the specialists in the philosophy of law
by what path can they get to advance,
and at what time can the ruler of men come to properly appreciate them?
When one's backing is such that one is bound not to win
and the constellation is such that all cannot survive,
then how can the specialists in the philosophy of law
fail to be in a precarious position?
Those of them who can be done in because of some crime or fault
get punished according to the public law;
and those of them whom one cannot accuse of some crime or fault
meet their end by the private sword [of hired assassins].
And so those who clearly understand the philosophy of law and who go against their rulers or the leadership
if they do not die at the hand of executioners
are bound to die from the private sword [of hired assassins].
If people's factions and groupings will keep the ruler ignorant
and their proposals are devious in order to serve private interests,
then their loyalty is bound to be to the men of power.
Those who can use the pretence of some achievement
one honours with office and rank;
those who cannot make pretence at a distinguished name
they make powerful on the basis of foreign influence.
Therefore those who keep their rulers in the dark and who hasten to attach themselves to the private gates,
if they do not gain distinction of office or rank
are bound to gain power through foreign influence.
Today's rulers carry out punishments without cross-checking the facts
and they confer rank and stipends without having seen achievements.
So, as for the specialists in the philosophy of law
how can they risk death and ruin to put forward their explanations?
And as for the wicked ministers how could they be willing to reject profit and put their persons last?
Thus the ruler above becomes ever more humble
the private clans become ever more exalted.
Now Yuè may be a rich state with strong armed forces,
but the rulers of the central states all knew that she would be of no advantage to them,
and they say:
"This is not a country we/one can come to control."
Now although someone in charge of a state
may have a large territory and a numerous population
if the ruler is blocked and ill-informed
and the senior ministers monopolise power
then such a state is a 'state of Yuè' (and uncontrollable by any ruler of another state).
If one is intelligent enough to understand that one's state is not like that of Yuè,
but one does not understand that one's state is not what it used to be,
that is not to understand the general categories of things.
The reason why people believe that Qí is ruined
is not because its territory and its walls were ruined,
it is because the Lǚ clan was unable to control the place
and the Tián clan gained control;
the reason why they believe that Jìn was ruined
is not that the territory and the walls were ruined
it is because the Jī clan is not in control
and the six ministers have monopolised control over it.
Now when the senior ministers hold the handle and make their independent decisions
and the ruler is unable to understand how to regain the instruments of political control:
this is because the ruler of men is not clear-sighted.
If one has the same illness as someone who has died of that illness
one cannot be made to survive;
if one undertakes the same things as a ruined state
one cannot be made to retain one's state.
Now to continue in the footsteps of Qí and Jìn
and to want the state to continue to exist peacefully,
that is impossible to achieve.
In general the difficulty of practising the philosophy of law
does not only apply to a state of ten thousand chariots,
the situation in a state of one thousand chariots is the same.
The entourage of a ruler is not necessarily competent.
If the ruler has competence on something but listens to others
and then assesses proposals with this entourage
this is to pass judgement on matters of competence with the stupid.
It is not certain that the ruler's entourage is talented,
and if the ruler treats someone politely because he has certain talents
and then discusses their behaviour with his entourage
this is to discuss and assess talent with the talentless.
If the competent have their stratagems decided by the stupid,
and if talented freemen have their actions assessed by men without talent
then the talented freemen will feel shame and the ruler's judgements will be misguided.
As for those ministers who wish to obtain office
those who are cultivated freemen will make their persons firm through purity,
the intellectuals advance in their trade by perfecting rhetoric.
Cultivated freemen cannot serve others for the sake of bribes,
they rely on their refined purity
and they certainly cannot conduct their government by perverting the law.
And so, if freemen cultivating competence will not serve the ruler's entourage
these will not listen to their special pleas and representations.
The civil and military entourage of the ruler
are not (virtuous) Bó Yís in their deportment.
When their requests do not get through,
and when their loans and bribes do not reach their end,
then their refined rhetorical exploits cease
and slanderous as well as fraudulent proposals arise.
If the exploits of those who work at rhetoric
are determined by those who are close and familiar to the ruler,
if pure conduct
is judged by slanderers and panderers
then minor officials who are cultivated or have competence will be dismissed,
then the clear perspective of the ruler is blocked.
If one does not judge competence and conduct on the basis of objective achievement,
if one does not investigate crimes on the basis of multiple checks
but listens to the words of one's entourage and one's confidants
then freemen without abilities will be at the court
and stupid as well as unclean minor officials will occupy formal offices.
The bane of a state of ten thousand chariots
is that the senior ministers are too powerful;
the bane of a state of one thousand chariots
is that the civil and military entourage is trusted to much.
This is what rulers equally regard as disastrous.
Moreover when ministers are guilty of great crimes,
and rulers make big mistakes,
the reason is that the proper interests for ruler and ministers are different.
How can one make that clear?
It is as follows:
The ruler's interest is in having people of ability serving in office
the minister's interest is in serving without ability;
the ruler's interest is that rank and emolument should go to those who have made an effort,
the minister's interest is to gain wealth and rank without achievement;
the ruler's interest is in men of extraordinary ability and in deploying the able,
the minister's interest is in forming factions and serving his private purposes.
That is why the state territory is truncated and the private families get rich,
the ruler on top has low status and the senior ministers are powerful.
When the ruler loses his position of power and the ministers control the state,
the ruler is renamed an 'enfeoffed minister',
and the Senior Secretary breaks the official tallies.
This is how the minister cheats the ruler and serves his private purposes.
So as for the powerful ministers of the present time
if there is a change in the political power of the ruler
those who get to enjoy the ruler's confirmed and continued favour
are no more than two or three out of ten.
Why is this?
It is because the senior ministers are guilty of great crimes.
The great crime of the ministers
is that they engage in deception against the ruler,
and that crime deserve death.
Then intellectuals will recognise the situation from a distance
and they will be afraid to die or be ruined
and they are sure not to join the powerful men.
As for the worthy freemen they will cultivate moral purity
and they will be ashamed to join wicked ministers to cheat the ruler
and they are sure not to join the powerful ministers.
Under such circumstances the followers of the men in power
are either stupid and do not understand impending disasters,
or they are dirty folks who do not shy away from wickedness.
If the senior ministers have stupid and filthy folk under their wings,
if above they cheat the ruler in collusion with them,
if below they gain their profit and encroach on others,
if they form factions and gang together
and they co-ordinate their talk;
confusing the ruler and ruining the rule of law
so that they create havoc among the freemen and the people;
if they cause the state to be endangered and truncated,
and the ruler to be troubled and humiliated:
this is the great crime.
If, when a minister has a great crime, the ruler refuses to put a stop to it
that is a great omission and mistake.
If one brings it about that the ruler makes great mistakes on top
and that the ministers commit great crimes below,
then if one aims to avoid having one's state ruined,
that is impossible to achieve.
In general the (practical) difficulties of persuasion
consist in understanding properly the way of thinking/attitudes of the person one is trying to persuade,
and having the possibility to fit this disposition with one's persuasion.
If the man to be persuaded starts from working for one's reputation being high
and one persuades him in terms of substantial profit
then one will be seen as morally inferior, one will be treated as vulgar,
and one is bound to be discarded and kept at a distance.
If the person to be persuaded is the sort of person who starts with considerations of substantial profit
and one persuades him (saying that) his name will be elevated
then one will be considered as mindless, will be kept at a distance from the real conduct of affairs
and one is bound not to be accepted in the governing circles.
If the person to be persuaded secretly is the sort of person who works for rich profit
and openly/for appearances works for his name becoming elevated,
and one goes on to persuade him in terms of his name becoming elevated
then on the face of it he will admit one's person to his vicinity,
but in reality he will keep one at a distance;
if one persuades him in terms of maximising gain,
then he will secretly use one's proposals but will, for the sake of appearances reject one's person.
One must not leave this uninvestigated.
Now projects succeed when they are kept secret,
talk fails when it leaks out.
And if without necessarily leaking a secret point oneself,
in conversation, one touches upon a matter that has been held secret,
then one's person will get into danger.
The persuaded party may have something he is undertaking on the face of it,
but this is because he really wishes to accomplish something different;
and if the persuader not only knows what he is overtly doing
but he also knows why he is (really) undertaking this,
if things are like this then his person will get into danger.
If one plans an extraordinary undertaking and one gets it right
but clever people guess it from the outside and get wind of it,
and the matter leaks to the outside,
then the ruler is bound to consider that one was working for one's own interests,
and then (as the persuader) one gets into danger.
When the ruler's positive feelings for one are not yet profound
and one's talk is [already at that stage] extremely clever,
then if one's persuasion is acted on and one has success
then one is going to be disregarded;
if one's persuasion is not acted on and suffers defeat,
then one will be held in suspicion.
In this way, as a persuader, one gets into danger.
When the noble man [i.e. the ruler] has negative tendencies
and the persuader openly speaks of ritual and XXX propriety and pokes in (tiǎo) his vices,
then, as a persuader, one is in danger.
If the noble person [i.e. the ruler] got a plan somewhere and wishes to regard it as his own achievement,
and the persuader is also aware of this situation,
then, as a persuader, one is in danger.
If one forces the ruler to do what he cannot do
and one insists on stopping him from doing what he cannot stop
then, as a persuader, one is in danger.
Now, if as a persuader one assesses a person as important with the ruler
then the ruler will think that one sows discord between that important person and himself;
and if as a persuader one assesses a person as slight in front of the ruler
then the ruler will think that one is selling oneself as important.
If one passes judgement on someone of whom one is fond
then he will consider that one is relying on that man's support;
and if one passes judgement on someone whom one dislikes
then he thinks one is testing him.
If one presents one's persuasions economically
then he will consider one as incompetent and as inept;
if one is trivially detailed and wide-ranging in one's rhetoric
then he will consider this as wordy and convoluted.
If, concisely to the point one sets forth one's ideas
then he will say to himself: he is chicken-hearted and not detailed enough;
if one considers matters in broad and expansive detail
then he will say (to himself): he is arrogant and rude.
These difficulties with persuasion
must be understood properly.
The main point with persuasion
is in understanding how to dress up what the person persuaded shows pride in
and to gloss over what the person persuaded regards as shameful.
If the other party has urgent private concerns
one must present the matter in terms of public morality
and back up his intentions.
When his intentions are somewhat base
but he cannot stop him from going through with them
then the persuader dresses this up for him as beautiful
and he pretends that few people are not doing such things.
When his mind is somehow set on some high morality
but he is not able to live up to it
then the persuader brings out the excessiveness
and he shows up the ugly points,
and he exaggerates the value of not doing it.
If the ruler is given to bragging with his cleverness and his abilities
then one should bring up different cases of the same sort
and provide for him more evidence in favour,
making him avail himself of oneself in his explanations
but pretending that one does not understand what is going on
in order to back up his [pretended] cleverness.
If one wants to submit proposals regarding peaceful coexistence within
then one should use positive terminology to make clear one's point
and show subtly that this fits in with the other party's private advantage.
If one wants to put forward a dangerous and harmful matter
then one makes clear the counter-arguments
