is like having firm carts and good horses in travelling by land
and having light boats and convenient oars when travelling by water:
he who avails himself of these things will then achieve his aim.
Yī Yǐn learnt these methods
and Tāng became a true king because of that;
Guǎnzhòng learnt them
and Qí became a hegemon because of that;
the lord of Shāng learnt them
and Qín became strong because of that.
These three people
were all clear about the political philosophy of a hegemon of kings,
they had a subtle understanding of the methods of good government and of strength,
and they were not pulled about by the fashionable proposals of their time;
they adapted to the ideas of the enlightened rulers of their time
so that being straight ordinary employees and commoner freemen
they got established in the office of prime minister;
when they held their high offices and governed the country
the fact is that there was a ruler held in honour and a territory that was broad;
these are called ministers that were worth holding in high honour.
When Tāng got hold of Yī Yǐn
he got established as Son of Heaven with of square lǐ of territory;
when Duke Huán got hold of Guǎnzhòng
he was established as a hegemon ruler
nine times he called together the feudal lords
and he united all under Heaven;
when Duke Xiào got hold of the lord of Shāng
his territory was increased as a result
and his army got stronger as a result.
Thus, when one has a minister who does his loyal best
then outside one has no equally strong states to be troubled by
and inside one has no rebellious ministers to worry about,
for long stretches of time there will be peace in the world
and one's name will be handed down to later generations.
That is meant by a minister who does his loyal best.
As for Yùràng he acted as a minister to the Earl of Bó,
above he was unable to persuade the ruler and cause him
to understand the principles of the art of the system of law and political philosophy,86
so that one could avoid the troubles of political disaster and chaos,
and below he was unable to lead the masses
to bring peace to the state.
When Zhào Xiāngzǐ killed the Earl of Zhì
Yùràng marked his own face black and cut off his nose
he ruined his body and facial appearance
to avenge Xiāngzǐ's injustice against the Earl of Zhì.
Even if such a person maims his body and gets himself killed
in order to gain a name as someone working for his ruler
but in fact he was of no use to the Earl of Zhì,
as insignificant as the tip of an autumn hair.
This is what we rate low
and what the rulers of our time consider as loyal and elevated.
In ancient times there were Bó Yí and Shū Qí.
King Wǔ left the rule over the empire to them but they would not accept:
the two starved to death by the Shǒuyáng mountain.
Ministers of this kind,
they do not stand in awe of heavy punishments,
they do not regard as profitable heavy rewards,
they cannot be stopped through fines,
they cannot be made to do things through rewards.
These one calls ministers who are of no use.
Such people we regard as being of little value, and keep them away,
but they are the ones whom the rulers of our time admire and seek out.
As the saying goes:
"The lepers feel pity for the king."
This is an irreverent proposition.
None the less
the ancients had no empty proverbs
and one should investigate them carefully.
This proposition regards a king who is doomed to assassination and death.
If a ruler does not have a philosophy of the law
so as to steer his ministers,
then even if he lives long and has handsome talents
his powerful ministers will all the same gain positions of power,
act without authority and be in charge of decisions
and each of the ministers will be urgently eager for his own private interests.
And then it is to be feared that elders and outstanding freemen
will borrow the ruler's power
to stop punishments being applied to themselves,
and as a result they will assassinate their talented seniors and junior weaklings,
they will set aside the straight aim and will establish those without moral principles.
Therefore the Spring and Autumn records:
"Prince Wéi from Chǔ was about to make a formal visit to Zhèng.
Before he had left his country
he heard that the king had fallen ill and he returned.
Then he went in and paid a sickness visit.
With his hat-cord he strangled the king and killed him
and he established himself as ruler.
As for Cuī Shū, his wife was handsome
and Duke Zhuāng had sexual intercourse with her.
Several times he went to Cuī's house.
When the Duke was on his way
Cuī's disciple Jiǎ Jǔ lead Cuī's disciples to attack the Duke.
When the Duke entered the house
he asked to divide the state between himself and Cuī,
but Cuī did not go along with this.
The Duke asked permission to kill himself in the ancestral temple
but Cuī again did not go along with this.
Then the Duke fled
and he jumped over the southern enclosure wall.
Jiǎ Jǔ shot at the Duke
and hit him in the thigh.
The Duke fell to the ground,
Cuī's disciples cut down the duke with a dagger-axe, put him to death
and they established the Duke's younger brother Duke Jǐng."
To take what we have seen closer to our own time:
When Lǐ Duì took control of Zhàō
he left the ruler's father famished for one hundred days until he died.
When Zhuō Chǐ had taken control in Qí
he had the sinews pulled out of King Mín
and had him suspended on a beam in the ancestral temple
so that he died a slow death which took a whole night.
Now a leper may have all sorts of swellings and boils,
but if you compare his fate with what is reported in the Spring and Autumn
he does not quite get to the point of getting strangled or shot in the thigh;
or if you compare him with what is closer to our generation
he does not starve to death or have his sinews pulled out.
So, as for a ruler who gets killed or sent into exile,
the worries and fears in his mind
and the hardship as well as the pain in his body
are certainly worse than those of a leper.
From this point of view
even the saying "the leper feels pity for the kings" is justified.
If one's various ministers cultivate learning,
if one's retinue are fond of disputation,
if the travelling and non-travelling merchants amass wealth abroad
and petty commoners have weapons as their most important concern,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If one is fond of palaces, raised wooden platforms, as well as dikes and artificial lakes,
if one cares about carriages and is devoted to vessels and toys,
if one likes to wear out the people
and to grab and then waste away goods,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If one uses propitious times and dates in one's undertakings,
if one serves ghosts and spirits,
if one believes in prognostication by bone and milfoil stalks,
and if one is specially fond of the various sacrifices,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If one follows advice according to rank and does not rely on checked evidence,
if one employs one person to guard the gates of power,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If offices and appointments may be sought on the basis of political power,
when rank and stipends can be got through bribes,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If one is slow of mind and does not carry things through to completion,
if one is weak and fretful and rarely makes decisive decisions,
if one is not definite in one's likes and dislikes
and has nothing to which one is firmly committed
then one is likely to face ruin.
If one is insatiably gluttonous and greedy,
if one tends towards superficial profit and likes to get things
then one is likely to face ruin.
If one delights in wanton formulations and does not conform consistently to the laws
if one loves explanations full of sophistries and does not seek their usefulness,
if one is excessive on stylish appearance and disregards achievement,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If one is shallow and superficial and easily given to expressing feelings,
if one lets things sieve out and does not hide anything,
if one cannot keep things completely secret
and spreads around the talk of the various ministers,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If one is hard and uncompromising,
if one is stubborn regarding remonstrations and loves to keep the upper hand,
if one shows no proper concern for the altars of the land and grain
and acts lightly, having faith only in oneself,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If one relies on the help from one's connections
and fails to pay proper attention to one's close neighbours,
if one is dependent on succour from the strong and the great
and is impolite to states that one is a close neighbour to,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If migrants and travelling folk
have weighty treasures stacked up abroad
but on a high level they interfere with policy-making
and below they interfere with the business of the people,
then one is likely to face ruin.
When the people have faith in the prime minister
and those below do not regard the one on top as the capable person,
if the ruler loves and trusts him and cannot dismiss him,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If the outstanding men from the local area do not engage in public work
and one seeks freemen from outside,
if one does not judge performance according to concrete achievement
but likes to elevate and place people according to their reputation,
if migrants rise to noble status and dominate the permanent citizens,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If one does not pay proper respect to the direct heir
and the sons by secondary wives throw their weight around,
if before the heir apparent is determined the ruler dies,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If one is full of oneself and never regrets,
if, when the state is in chaos one is still full of praise for oneself,
if one does not assess properly the resources within one's own borders for anything
then one is likely to face ruin.
If one's state is small and one does not take a humble stance,
if one's power is slight and one does not stand in awe of the strong,
if one is impolite and is rude to one's great neighbours,
if one is greedy and stubborn and inept at striking up good relations,
then one is likely to face ruin.
When the heir apparent is already established
then if one takes a wife from one's strong competitors,
then the position of the heir apparent is precarious,
and under these conditions the various ministers will change their tactics;
and if the various ministers change their tactics,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If one is fretful and weak at holding one's positions,
if one shows one's opinions early but is weak and dithering in one's attitude,
if when one knows there is a certain situation and approves a certain response,
one makes decisions but does not have the courage to carry them through,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If the ruler, who has left, is abroad and within the state someone else is established
or if the heir apparent serves as hostage abroad and has not yet returned
and the ruler appoints another son as heir apparent,
then the state will be of two minds. ???
When the state is of two minds
then one is likely to face ruin.
If having humiliated senior ministers one shows them improper familiarity,
if having punished ordinary citizens one employs them,
then these will think of their anger and ponder their shame
and if one goes on to specially cultivate them, then villainy will arise;
when villainy arises
then one is likely to face ruin.
If two senior ministers hold powerful positions,
if the elders are numerous and strong,
if factions from within the state solicit outside help to fight for power,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If the words of female slaves and concubines are listened to,
if the cleverness of beloved ones and playmates is made political use of,
and if in spite of sighs of sadness outside and inside the court
one frequently acts against the law,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If one slights and humiliates senior ministers,
if one fails to show proper politeness to one's elders,
if one imposes hardships on the people
and executes innocent people,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If one likes to adapt the law in accordance with one's personal insights
if one repeatedly dilutes the public practice with private demarches,
if laws and prohibitions are changed
and if orders and ordinances are frequently issued,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If one has no secure geographical boundaries,
if the inner and outer city walls are in bad shape,
if one has no accumulated supplies,
if one's material resources are sparse,
if without defensive preparations
one lightly undertakes an offensive campaign,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If one's relatives do not live long lives,
and rulers die quickly one after another,
if small children become rulers
so senior ministers gain sole political control,
if one establishes migrants so they form factions
and one frequently gives away pieces of territory for the sake of good relations,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If the heir apparent is highly honoured and illustrious,
if his adherents are numerous and strong,
if they frequently cultivate relations with other big states
and his position of power is firmly established before the proper time,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If one is unsteady and hot-headed,
if one easily flies into rages and readily flies into action,
if one is irascible and is not wary about precedents and consequences,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If the ruler often flies into rages and likes to use military force,
if one is negligent about basic training and lightly launches military attacks,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If the noble ministers are envious of each other
if the senior ministers are domineering,
if on the outside they rely on competing states
and if internally they trouble the people
in order to be able to attack their hated enemies,
and if the ruler will not punish them for this,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If the ruler is incompetent and the members of his family talented,
when the heir apparent is a lightweight and the other potential heirs are big shots,
if the minor officials in the offices are weak and the people push their weight around,
under these conditions the state is in a hustle;
and when the state is in a hustle
then one is likely to face ruin.
If one hides one's wrath inside and refuses to let it out,
if one suspends action on crimes and will not punish them,
if one makes the ministers secretly resentful
and increasingly worried and fearful
so that for a long time they are in suspense about what the ruler will do,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If sending out armies one gives too much power to the generals,
if in the border regions the governors get too high a status,
if they take sole control and issue unauthorised orders,
if they act immediately and do not ask about anything,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If the royal wife is sexually profligate
if the ruler's mother cultivates indecent relations,
if outside and inside the court there are indecent relations
and there is no distinction between men and women
then that is called there being two rulers;
and if there are two rulers
then one is likely to face ruin.
If the main wife enjoys humbler status than slaves and concubines,
if the heir apparent is less highly honoured than the other possible heirs,
when the Senior Secretary has less influence than the messenger,
if things are in such a state then those within and outside the court are at variance;
and if those inside and outside the court are at variance with each other,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If the senior ministers are very highly honoured
if their factions are numerous and strong
if they block the ruler's decisions
and with their power they exercise unauthorised control over the state,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If officials from the private families are publicly employed,
if those with a distinguished military record are dismissed
if those who have distinguished themselves in the provinces advance
and those who have put in an effort in office are dismissed,
if one gives higher status to private initiatives than to public achievements,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If the ducal house has an empty name only and senior ministers hold real power,
if the regular inhabitants are poor and the temporary visitors are rich,
if freemen engaged in agriculture or war are in straits
while people engaged in non-productive work reap the profits,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If one sees great profit but does not hasten towards it,
if one learns about the beginnings of disaster but does not guard against it,
if one only pays scant attention to matters of struggle and defence
but is mainly concerned to embellish one's image with morality,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If one does not practise the public spirited filial piety of a ruler
but show admiration for the private filial piety of a commoner,
if one does not pay attention to the interests of the altars of the land and grain
but obeys the orders coming from the ruler's mother,
if women are in charge of the state
and eunuchs are in charge of the administration,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If one's formulations are sophisticated but not according to the law,
if one's mind is competent but without the art of political philosophy,
if the ruler has many abilities
but does not proceed according to the system of the law,
then one is likely to face ruin.
If the ministers close to one advance and old friends are removed,
if incompetent people are in charge and men of talent lie in hiding,
if men without achievements have higher status than men with hard-won achievements
if things are like this then those below will be resentful;
and if those below are resentful
then one is likely to face ruin.
If the salary levels of elders and senior ministers are greater than their achievements
if their insignia and their official dress illegally exceed their rank,
if palaces and provisions are excessive
and the ruler fails to prohibit this
then the ministers' ambitions will be unending;
and if the ministers' ambitions are unending
then one is likely to face ruin.
If the duke's sons in law and his grandchildren live next door to the people
and are violent and arrogant against their neighbours
then one is likely to face ruin.
When there are symptoms of ruin
this in no way means one is bound to be ruined,
it means that one is likely to face ruin.
Now two Yáos cannot make each other into kings,
and two Jiés cannot ruin each other;
the mechanism that causes ruin or kingship
〓#are unevenly distributed.
When a tree breaks this is bound to be because of wood-boring insects,
when a wall collapses this is bound to be because there are rifts in it.
However, although there may be wood-boring insects in a tree,
without strong winds it will not break;
even if there are rifts in a wall
without great rain it will not collapse.
A ruler with an armed force of ten thousand war chariots
if he has the ability to devote himself to the art of government and to practise the law,
so that he may be the thunderstorm for the rulers with symptoms of ruin,
will have no trouble in uniting the whole world into one empire.
If ministers bring up in formal consultation oversights of those in command
mistakes by those carrying out the administration
and the real feelings of ministers who have been elevated to high position,
and the ruler does not hide this in his heart
but leaks it to those in his close entourage
and he causes the ministers who want to speak up
to make sure that they please
and only then to go on to make themselves heard by the ruler,
then under such circumstances straight-talking men
will not get to see the ruler
and the earnest and straight will become more and more distant to the ruler.
If when one is fond of a person
one does not independently work to his benefit
but depends on the public praise before one works for his benefit;
if when one dislikes someone
one does not independently work to harm him
but depends on public criticism before one works to harm him
then under such circumstances the ruler has no authority
and the political weight is in his entourage.
If one dislikes the labours of governing in person
and makes the ministers take care of the administration wheeling around one ??
thus passing on the handle of control and moving the powers
bringing it about that the mechanism for deciding life and death,
and the crucial decision whether to take away or to give away things
rests with the senior ministers,
if one acts like this, then (as a ruler) one will get encroached upon.
This is what is called not having the three safety measures all in place.
When the three defensive measures are not all in place
that is a symptom of impending arrogation of power and murder.
Altogether there are three illegal arrogations:
there is the arrogation of a title;
there is arrogation of executive authority,
and there is arrogation of the authority over punishments.
When ministers enjoy the dignity of senior ministers in court
and for the outside hold the keys to the state so as to be able to support the various ministers
and bring it about that internal court matters and external matters
cannot be carried through without themselves,
then even if there are worthy and talented people
if they oppose these powerful ministers they are bound to meet disaster
and if they agree with them they are bound to meet good fortune.
Under such circumstances straight ministers will not dare to do their loyal best for the ruler and worry about the statē
so as to engage themselves in harm or benefit for the altars of the land and grain.
If a ruler, even if talented,
is unable to make his political calculations independently,
and if ministers dare not do their loyal best for their ruler
then the state must count as a state doomed to ruin.
This is what is called the state not having ministers.
The state not having ministers
is surely not a matter of the corridors being empty
and there being few ministers at court.
If the ministers maintain their stipends and cultivate their connections,
if they practise their private way and do not do their best in public loyal service
this is called arrogation of title.
The ministers sell favours and usurp power,
they make pretences on the outside in order to win victories on the inside,
riskily they speak of what bodes bad luck and good, success and failure,
thus pandering to the likes and dislikes of the ruler.
Then the ruler listens to their advice,
humiliates his person and makes light of his state in order to support them.
When a project fails, these ministers share responsibility for disasters with the ruler,
but when they succeed then the ministers claim sole responsibility.
When all those in charge of the administration
unanimously and using the same phrases talk about someone's good points
then if the ruler mentions his bad points he is bound not to be believed.
These situations are called arrogations of the executive authority in practice.
Regarding the administration of prisons
the system of prohibitions and punishments as well as fines,
when the ministers usurp the authority over these matters
then that is called arrogation of the punitive authority.
When the three safety measures are not in place
then the three kinds of illegal arrogation will arise;
when the three defensive measures are all in place
then the three illegal arrogations will stop.
If the three illegal arrogations are stopped and blocked
then one will become a true king.
Therefore a minister
will not for a moment cease to observe his ruler's attitudes,
and when the ruler is lazy and arrogant on top
this is the reason why in our time the power of rulers is arrogated
and why rulers are assassinated.
If as a ruler one places too great faith in one's sons
then wicked ministers will avail themselves of the sons
to achieve their private aims:
and so Lǐ Duì acted as tutor to the King of Zhàò
and starved the ruler's father to death.
If as a ruler one places too great faith in one's wife
then wicked ministers will avail themselves of the wife
to achieve their private aims:
and so Yōu Shī acted as tutor to Lìjī
and he killed Shēn Shēng and established Xī Qí on the throne.
Now if even in the case of close relations like a wife and a son
one still cannot place one's faith in people,
then one should put one's faith in none of the others.
Moreover, in the case of a ruler with ten thousand war chariots
or a leader with one thousand war chariots
among his consorts, wives, prospective heirs and heirs apparent
there will probably be those who hope that the ruler will die early.
How does one know that this is so?
As for a wife,
she does not have the emotional links that go with blood relations,
if one loves her she is close,
if one does not love her she is distant.
As the saying goes:
"When the mother is handsome the son gets hugged."
And so, what one does is the inverse:
"When the mother is ugly her son will get dismissed."
When a man has reached fifty
his taste for beauty has not yet dissolved,
but when a woman is thirty her beauty has declined.
If as a woman of declining beauty one serves a husband who is fond of beauty
then her person will be kept at a distance and she will be held in low esteem
and her offspring will held in suspicion and will not be made successors.
This is why empresses and wives will hope that their masters/husbands die.
First when the mother has become dowager and her son is ruler
then her orders are invariably carried out
and her prohibitions are invariably followed.
Her sexual appetites will be no less than with the former master,
but there will be no doubt that she will arrogate to herself control over the chariots
and that is why poison, strangulation and murder get used by her.
That is why the "Táo Zuǒ Commentary on the Chūnqiū" says:
"As for the rulers who die of natural diseases, they cannot make up fifty percent (of rulers dying while in office)."
If the ruler refuses to understand this
then political chaos has many supporters.
Therefore it is said:
"If those who profit from the ruler's death are many
then the ruler is in a precarious position."
Wáng Liáng loved horses
and King Gōu Jiàn of Yuè loved people:
this was for the sake, respectively, of waging war and for travelling fast.
If a doctor is good at sucking the wounds of the injured
and if he takes people's blood into his mouth,
this is not because they have a blood relationship with their patients,
it is because this will give them added benefits.
Thus when a cartwright make carts
he hopes that people get rich and noble;
and when the carpenter makes coffins
he hopes that people die early.
This is not because the cartwright is kind-hearted and the carpenter is a villain,
it is just that if people do not achieve noble status
then elaborate carriages are not going to be sold;
and if people do not die
then coffins will not be bought.
His real feelings are not of hate for people,
but his profit is in people's death.
When the factions of dowagers, wives and heirs apparent are formed
and they hope for the ruler's death,
this is because if the ruler does not die
then their political position is not powerful.
Their real feelings are not of hate for the ruler
but their advantage is in the ruler's death.
Therefore the ruler of men must think about those who would profit from his death.
Sun and moon are surrounded by haloes,
but their villain is within.
People are well prepared against those they hate,
but their misfortune comes from those whom they love.
Therefore the enlightened ruler
will not undertake uninvestigated tasks,
and he will not eat extraordinary foods.
He will listen out for things distant and look out for things close at hand
so that he may investigate errors inside and outside the court;
he looks closely into variations between proposals
in order to understand the divisions between different cliques;
he conducts unexpected multiple checks
in order to take people to task for the performance of their proposals.
He takes final results as a basis for response to first proposals,
he takes the law as a basis to govern the masses,
he takes many elements into account when testing and observing.
When freemen do not get rewards by good luck
they will not transgress;
when executions are unfailingly in accordance to acts committed
and crimes are not forgiven
then the wicked find no place for their selfish pursuits.
When there is a lot of corvee labour then the people suffer hardship,
when the people suffer hardship then political power-play will increase;
when political power-play will increase, then one will exempt the powerful from taxes;
when the powerful are exempted from taxes then the noble become rich.
If one brings hardship to the people and riches to the noble
if one increases the possibilities for political influence and relies on ministers
that is not to the long-term benefit of the world.
Therefore it is said:
When forced labour is little then the people are in peace,
when the people are in peace then subordinates have no political influence,
when subordinates have not political influence
then political power-play will be eroded,
and when political power-play is eroded then charismatic power is on top.
Now it is surely evident that water wins against fire.
However, if one puts pots and pans between the two
then the water is boiled dry on top
and the fire gets to burn abundantly below:
the water has lost that by which it conquers.
Now that the law prevents wickedness is even clearer than this,
but if the ministers in charge of keeping the law act like the pots and pans
then the laws are only clear in one's chest
and they have already lost that by means of which they prevent wickedness.
According to the oldest traditional accounts,
and in what is recorded in the Spring and Autumn,
those who broke the law, committed crimes and perpetrated great wickedness
invariably are on the side of from noble ministers.
On the other hand the reason why laws and regulations are provided
and the reason why punishments and fines punish
is invariably in order to bring them to bear on the humble and base.
This is why the people have no hope
and they have no one to turn to to seek redress.
When the senior ministers form their gangs
they are united in keeping their superior in the dark.
Secretly they are on the best of terms but openly they display hatred
in order to show that they do not cultivate private interests.
They act as spies for each other
and spy out rifts/weaknesses in the ruler on which to set to work.
When the ruler is kept in the dark and blocked from information
he has no way of hearing about things.
He is ruler in name but not in reality.
Then the ministers monopolise the law and practise it.
The Sons of Heaven of the Zhōu were of this sort.
If the ruler one-sidedly lends his powers to others
then superordinates and subordinates change places.
This means that the ministers should not borrow political authority.
The one with whom he now guards against others
will be the one against he was guarding himself before.
If the ruler is unable to publicly promote the law
and thus to control the authority of the senior ministers,4
then there is no way for him to gain the confidence of ordinary people.
If the ruler discards the law and controls ministers through other ministers
then those who are fond of each other will form a clique and praise each other
while those who hate each other will form factions and criticise each other.
When criticism and praise compete with each other
then the ruler will be confused.
As for a minister,
unless he is famous and in a position to make special pleas
he will not make progress and acquire clout;
unless he goes against the law and monopolises political control
he has no way to exercise authority;
unless he makes a pretence at loyalty and good faith
he has no way of avoiding prohibitions against him.
The combination of these three
is what helps to confuse the ruler and destroy the rule of law.
The ruler will see to it that his ministers,
even if they intellectual ability
will not get to go against the law and take unauthorised control,
that even if they are talented in their demeanour
they will not get reward before and beyond their achievements,
even if they are loyal and faithful
they will not, disregarding the law, fail to prohibit things
this is what is called publicly promoting the law.
The ruler may be seduced by a project
or his good senses may be blocked by proposals:10
both these points one has to investigate carefully.
If a minister lightly brings up projects
and asks for few resources,
then he is cheating the ruler with this project.
If the ruler is seduced by this and does not investigate the matter closely
and if as a result he greatly values this minister
then the minister will control the ruler through his project.
This constellation is called "being seduced".
If one is seduced by a project one will be in trouble through the ensuing disaster.
If someone brings forward a proposal with few expenses
but in the end the expenses turn out to be large,
then even if the project is successful
the proposal was not reliable.
If one is not reliable one is guilty of a crime,
and if even when their project is successful the ruler does not give them rewards (in the case of excessive expenses incurred),
the the ministers will not dare to make embellished proposals
in order to confuse the ruler.
The Way of the ruler
is to see to it that when the first proposal does not correspond to the result,
when latter proposals do not correspond to the earlier ones,
then even if a project is successful the minister must face criminal charges.
This is called employing subordinates properly.
When a minister wants to arrange something for the ruler
but is afraid of criticism
then he will first put about talk to the following effect:
"Anyone who discusses this undertaking
is envious of this undertaking."
Then the ruler will keep such words in mind
and will not go on to listen to other ministers' views on the matter;
the ministers will be frightened by such words
and will not dare to discuss the undertaking.
If these two tendencies take effect
then loyal ministers will not be listened to
and renowned ministers will have the field to themselves.
This situation is called 'being blocked by words',
and if one is blocked through words then one is controlled by ministers.
The way of the ruler is such that
he will see to it that the ministers always bear responsibility for what they propose
and that they also bear responsibility for not speaking up.
If proposals are incoherent and arguments non-conclusive
that is a case where they have to bear responsibility for their words;
if through not speaking they avoid responsibility
and thus maintain their powerful position
that is a case where they have to bear responsibility for not speaking up.
The ruler should see to it that when ministers speak up
he is sure to understand their basic motivation
for then to take them to task regarding the results;
and that when they do not speak up he interrogates them about their choice
to take them to task for these.
As a result no ministers will dare to speak up wantonly
and similarly they will not dare to remain quiet,
for both for speaking up and for remaining silent they will be taken to task.
When a ruler personally wishes to undertake a project
and without understanding the relevant main points
he already publicly makes clear his desire,
then when he then goes ahead with his undertaking
his action will not reap benefits
and he is bound to come out of it with harmful results.
He who understands this properly
will rely on principle and disregard personal wishes.
There is a way of undertaking an operation:
if one calculates that the benefit is great
and that the cost are few,
then one should go ahead.
But the confused ruler is not like that:
he will calculate the benefit
but will not calculate the cost.
Even if the costs are twice the expenses
he will still not understand the harmfulness of the undertaking.
As a result he will gain on the face of it but will in fact lose.
In this way his achievements will be slight
and the harmful consequences large.
Speaking in general of achievements,
it is only when the benefits are large
and the costs are slight
that one may speak of meritorious achievements.
Now if excessive expenditure go unpersecuted as crimes
and small gain counts as a meritorious achievement,
then the minister will be prepared to have great expenses
in order to obtain small meritorious achievements,
and although the small achievements are realised
the ruler still suffers the harmful consequences.
Those who do not understand government
will inevitably say:
"One should not change the old,
and do not replace the constant pattern."
As for the changing or not changing,
the sage does not pay attention to that:
he gets the government practice right, and that is all.
Whether one should not change the old,
and whether one must not replace the constant pattern
depends on whether what is old and constant is acceptable or not.
If Yī Yǐn had not changed the Yīn,
and if Tàigōng had not changed the Zhōu,
then Tāng and Wǔ would not have become kings.
If Guǎn Zhòng had not fundamentally changed Qí,
and if Guō Yǎn had not revamped Jìn,
then Huán and Wén would not have become hegemons.
Generally, if men have objections to changing the old
is because they are wary of making fundamental changes to the comfort of the people.
Now not to change the old
is to continue in the footsteps of political chaos;
satisfying the people's inclinations
is to give free rein to wicked demeanour.
When the people are stupid and does not understand political chaos,
when the leadership chicken-livered and cannot make clear changes
then this is a failure of good government.
Now as for a ruler worth his salt,
his intelligence is such that he can understand good government
and he is stern so as to carry it through invariably,
and as a result, even if he goes against his people
he is bound to establish good order for it.
This explains why
the Lord of Shāng inside and outside of court was surrounded by iron lances
and heavy shields as a precaution.
Thus when Guō Yǎn began to rule
Duke Wén had official soldier guards;
when Guǎn Zhòng began to rule
Duke Huán had his armoured cars:
these were precautionary measures to warn the people.
Thus the people, being stupid, obtuse, slothful and lazy
are bitter about small costs and forgetful about great benefits,
and consequently Yín Hǔ was maligned.
When Jù Xīn served Yān
he was not successful and the altars of the land and grain were in danger;
When Zòu Yǎn's service to Yān
he was not successful and the political strategies in Yān were disrupted.
First the Zhào got their way with Yān,
then they got their way with Qí,
and although the state was in political chaos, their spirits were high,
and they even imagined they could be a counterweight to Qín.
This was not because the tortoise in Zhào was supernaturally efficient
and the tortoise in Yān was fraudulent.
Another time Zhào again bored holes in tortoise shells and counted stalks
and then they attacked Yān in the north:
they wanted to despoil Yān and offer resistance to Qín,
and the divination sign was "very auspicious".
When they first attacked Dàliáng
and Qín mustered her forces at Shàngdǎng,
when Zhào's forces had got to Li six of her cities had been taken out
and by the time they had got to Yángchéng
Qín had taken out the city of Yè;
when Páng Xuān drew his weapon and marched south
the city of Zhāng was completely routed.
I therefore conclude:
Even if the Zhào tortoise was not far-sighted enough to see Yān
it ought to have seen Qín which was close at hand.
But Qín relied on its "very auspicious"
in real terms it managed to expand its territory,
and in addition it enjoyed the good name of having saved Yān.
Zhào, on the other hand, relied on its "very auspicious",
but its territory was decimated and its army humiliated,
and its ruler died in desperation.
This again was not because the Qín tortoise was supernaturally efficient
and the Zhào tortoise was fraudulent.
Before this,
Wèi turned East and attacked and routed Táo and Wèy several years in a row,
but when several years in a row it turned towards the West the state was lost.
This was not because Fēnglōng, Wǔxíng, Tàiyī, Wángxiàng,
Shètí, Liùshén, Wǔkuò, Tiānhé, Yǐnqiǎng, and Suìxīng
were due West for several years;
nor was it because Tiānqué, Gūnì, Xíngxīng,
Yinghuò, and Guìtái were in the East for several years.
Therefore it is said:
"The tortoise shells, the bamboo slips, ghosts and spirits will not guarantee victory,
the stars being on the left or right, turning their backs or facing towards each other,
these things do not by themselves guarantee the outcome of a battle.
If in spite of this one relies on such things
that is the most stupid thing to do.
In ancient times the former kings did their best to take loving care of the people,
and they made every effort to ensure public respect for the law.
Now if those laws are held in public respect
then the loyal ministers will feel encouraged;
if punishments are predictable
then wicked ministers will cease their activities.
As for the loyal feeling encouraged, the wicked being stopped
the territory being enlarged and the ruler being held in esteem,
the state of Qín is a case in point.
As for the ministers forming cliques and factions
so as to obscure the straight Way and to practice their selfish wickedness
to have the territory diminished and the ruler humbled,
the region East of the Mountain is like this.
That those who are unruly and weak will fail
is in accordance with the human condition;
that those who are orderly and strong become kings
is an ancient pattern.
Gōu Jiàn, the king of Yuè, relied on divination using the linked cowrie shells
and went to battle with Wú, but failed to win:
he was personally reduced to entering the service of Wú.
When at last he returned to his state he discontinued the tortoise oracles,
he ensured proper respect for the law, cultivated close relations with the people
in order to take revenge on Wú,
and as a result the ruler of Wú, Fūchāi, was taken prisoner by Yuè.
Thus those who rely on ghosts and spirits are lax on the law,
and those who rely on foreign feudal lords endanger the state.
Cáo relied on Qí and did not listen to Sòng,
but Qí attacked Jīng and Sòng routed Cáo.
Xíng relied on Wú and did not listen to Qí,
Yuè attacked Wú and Qí routed Xíng.
Xǔ relied on Jīng and did not listen to Wèi,
Jīng attacked Sòng and Wèi routed Xǔ.
Zhèng relied on Wèi and did not listen to Hán,
Wèi attacked Jīng and Hán routed Zhèng.
Now Hán is small as a state and it relies on a big state.
The ruler shows little energy and does as Qin tells him to.
If Wèi relies on Qi and Chǔ and makes use of them,
then the small state of Hán will be all the more doomed to failure.
Thus relying on others is not sufficient for expanding one's territory
but Hán does not realise this.
Jīng wanted to attack Wèi and applied military force to Xǔ and Yān,
but Qí attacked Rèn and Hù and decimated Wèi.
This was not sufficient to preserve Zhèng intact,
but Hán will not understand this.
These are all cases where one does not hold laws and prohibitions in public respect
in order to govern a state,
and where one relies on outside forces
so as to ruin the nation as a result.
Therefore Your servant concludes:
If one is clear about the precise methods of government
then even if one's state is small
it will be rich;
if rewards are carefully considered and punishments reliable
then even if one's population is sparse
one will be strong.
But if rewards and punishments are unsystematic
then even if the state is strong,
then that one's armed forces are weak
is because one's territory is not really one's own,
and one's people are not really one's own.
Without control of territory and the population
even a Yáo or a Shùn cannot in that way rule as a king
and even the three dynasties cannot develop strength.
And yet rulers confer gifts wrongly
and the ministers reap undeserved benefits.
Those who disregard laws and regulations
and talk about the achievements of the former kings and of the enlightened ruler
are employed by their superiors and put in charge of the state.
On this Your servant comments:
This is to hope for the achievements of the ancients
and to give the rewards due to the ancients to men of our time.
That is how rulers confer gifts wrongly
and how the ministers get undeserved rewards.
If the ruler confers gifts wrongly
then the ministers will gain stolen favours;
if the ministers get undeserved rewards
then concrete achievements will not be held in proper esteem.
If people without achievements receive rewards
then public resources will be in short supply and the people will nourish gratuitous hopes;
When resources are in short supply and the people live in gratuitous hopes
then the people will not do their best.
Therefore if one makes wrong use of rewards one will lose the people,
and if one makes wrong use of punishments
the people will not show fearful reverence.
If there are rewards but they are not designed to encourage
and if there are punishments but they are not designed to prevent,
then even if one's state is large
one is bound to be in a precarious position.
Therefore it is said:
Petty cleverness cannot be deployed to plan public undertakings,
and petty loyalty cannot be put in charge of the administration o the law.
King Gōng of Jīng fought a battle against Duke Lì of Jìn at Yānlíng.
The Jīng army was defeated
but King Gōng was injured.
In the heat of the battle
Sīmǎ Zǐfǎn felt thirsty and asked for a drink.
His friend Shù Gǔyáng held up a mug of wine and offered it up.
Zǐfǎn said:
"Away with this.
This is wine."
Shù Gǔyáng said:
"It is not wine."
Zǐfǎn took it and drank it.
Now Zǐfǎn was by nature fond of wine,
Once he had got a taste of it
he could not stop himself from drinking more of it all the time.
He got drunk and fell asleep.
King Gōng wanted to renew battle and to make plans for this
and he sent someone to summon Zǐfǎn.
Zǐfǎn declined on the grounds of psychological indisposition.
King Gōng got into his carriage and went to look at Zǐfǎn for himself.
When he entered the tent
he smelt the stench of wine and turned back
saying:
"In today's battle
I was personally injured in the eye.
The person I relied on was Sīmǎ.
And now Sīmǎ goes on to behave like this
This is to ruin the altars of the land and grain in the state of Jīng
and to show no concern for the multitude of my people.
I should never go to battle with him again."
He withdrew the army and left,
and he had Zǐfǎn cut down in a great public execution.
On this subject one may comment:
When Shù Gǔyáng, when he was offering the wine,
it was not that he basically hated Zǐfǎn:
from all his heart he did his loyal best to care for the man,
but as it turned out this was simply enough to kill the man.
This is a case of practising petty loyalty
and offending against great loyalty.
Therefore it is said:
Petty loyalty
is what ruins proper loyalty.
If one were to take charge of the law by means of petty loyalties
then one would certainly pardon people for their crimes because of mutual affection
and in such a way one would have comfortable relations with one's inferiors,
however this is harmful to the proper government of the people.
When Wèi first published the lìbì laws
and followed the basic laws and orders
then those who had achievements were sure to be rewarded
and those who had committed crimes were sure to be punished
and with strength they kept order in the world
with authority they conducted affairs with their neighbours.
when the exercise of the law was relaxed
and they started making arbitrary presents
then the state was progressively diminished.
When Zhào first promulgated the State Regulations
and pursued a policy of enlarging the army
then the population was large and the armed forces were strong
and she expanded her territory to Qí and Yān.
When the application of the State Regulations was relaxed
those who employed these regulations were weakened
and the state became weaker day by day.
When Yān began to promulgate the fèngfǎ
and paid careful attention to officials' legal decisions
they made Qí their province in the east
and they took all the Zhōngshān territories in the south.
But when the fèngfǎ had fallen into disuse
official decisions were not implemented
and ministers were competing with each other,
assessments followed the advice of inferiors
so that the armed forces were weakened, the territory decimated
and the state was effectively controlled by neighbouring enemies.
Thus one concludes:
Those who give prominence to the laws are strengthened
and those who are lax on laws are weakened.
When the conditions of strength and weakness are so clear
and the rulers of our day will not act accordingly
then it is only right and proper that their states should be ruined.
The proverb says:
"When a family has a regular occupation
then although there is famine they will not go hungry;
when a state has a stable and permanent law
then although conditions may be precarious it will not be ruined."
If one sets aside the permanent law and follows one's personal opinions
then ministers and subordinates will put on a show of wisdom and ability.
If ministers and subordinates put on a show of wisdom and ability
then laws and prohibitions will not be established.
Under such conditions the Way of arbitrary thought is practised
and the way of governing the state is abandoned.
If according to the Way of governing a state
one removes what is harmful to the law
then one will not be confused by cleverness and ability
and one will not be pretend to fame.
In ancient times Shùn ordered minor officials to control the big floods.
and if someone gained successes in the work before he was given orders
Shùn killed him.
When Yǔ assembled the feudal lords and rulers at Kuàijī
the ruler of Fángfēng arrived late and Yǔ had him cut down.
From this point of view one may see
that if those who act before they were ordered to were killed
and those who are late in carrying out orders are cut down
then in ancient times one gave first priority to conformity with the law.
Thus in a mirror that is kept clean and uninterfered with
beauty and ugliness will come out in proper contrast;
if scales are kept straight and are not interfered with
then relative weight will as a result be properly recorded.
If one shakes the mirror
then it cannot bring out things clearly;
if one shakes the scales
then they cannot be exact.
The same applies to the law.
Thus the former kings took the Way as their constant standard
and they took the law to be the basis.
When the basis is properly ordered then one's name will be held in high esteem;
when the basis is disorderly one's name will not be handed down at all.
In general, understanding and insight
if it has this basis to build on it can be put into practice,
and if it lacks this basis to build on it cannot be put into practice.
Thus this understanding is a method of a single person
and it cannot be passed on to others.
The Way and the law are all-encompassing
whereas cleverness and competence often fail.
Now when one hangs up scales one gets to know weight equivalences,
and when one sets up a compass one gets to know what is round:
that is the comprehensive Way.
The enlightened ruler will cause the people to improve themselves on the basis of the Way.
As a result he obtains his results with perfect ease.
If he disregards the rules and goes by clever tricks,
if he disregards the law and goes by cleverness
that is the way of confusion and chaos.
The ruler doomed to chaos causes the people to improve themselves through cleverness
and he does not understand the basic features of the Way,
and as a result he puts in effort without achieving results.
If one disregards laws and prohibitions and listens to special pleas
then the ministers will sell offices at a high level
and they will get their rewards from those below.
Under such circumstances profit is with the private households
and authority is with the ministers.
As a result the people are not inclined to do their best to serve their ruler
and they make it their business to create good relations with their superiors.
When the people like to strike up relations with their superiors
then goods will flow upwards
and those who can make clever speeches gain employment.
If such thing happen
then those who obtain results will get fewer and fewer.
When wicked ministers gain more and more advancement
and ministers of talent are demoted
then the ruler is confused and does not know where to go,
the people form groups and do not know what Way to take.
This is the mistake of dismissing laws and prohibitions, de-emphasising results raising to office the famous and listening to special pleas.
In general people who ruin the law
are bound to set up fraudulent ruses and to use gifts
in order to attract their associates.
Moreover they love to speak of extraordinary portentous events.
This is how the unruly and chaos-bound ruler gets confused,
and how servants and talented aides encroach on their superiors.
Thus, if ministers praise Yīyǐn's and Guǎnzhòng's achievements
then those who rebel against the law and affect cleverness are aided;
if they praise Bǐgān's and Zǐxū's loyalty and their allowing themselves to be killed,
then those who are eager to to make forceful representations have a pretext.
When they first mention talented and enlightened rulers (like Duke Huán of Qí and Tāng the Successful),
and then goes on to mention violent and recalcitrant ones (like Tyrant Jiè)
then these are not representative.
Talk like this must be banned.
When the ruler establishes the law this is to promote what is right.
But when nowadays most ministers build up their private cleverness
and consider the law to be in the wrong
this is to be wicked and thereby clever,
to cross the limits of the law to establish oneself as clever.
To have this kind of practice banned
is the way of the ruler.
It is the Way of the enlightened ruler
to be invariably clear about the distinction between the private and the public interests,
to see to it that the system of the law is properly respected
and to do away with private favours.
Now, that orders be invariably carried out
and that prohibitions be invariably obeyed [what one forbids is invariably stopped]
that is the public morality promoted by the ruler;
that one invariably carries out one's private purposes
that one's faithful loyalty is to one's friends
that one cannot be encouraged to do something through rewards
and that one cannot be hindered in something through fines,
that is the egotistic morality of the minister.
When egotistic morality is practised there is political chaos
and when public morality is practised there is good government:
thus the public and the egotistic are sharply distinct.
A minister has his egotistic inclinations
but there is a public duty.
To cultivate a morally pure personality
and to practise public-spiritedness and correctness
to be without egotism in the conduct of one's official duties,
that is the public duty of the minister;
to be polluted in one's actions and to follow one's desires,
to seek comfort for one's person and to profit one's clan
that is the private inclination of a minister.
When there is an enlightened ruler in charge
then the ministers discard their egotistic inclination
and practise public-spirited morality;
when a chaos-bound ruler is in charge
then the ministers will discard public-spirited morality
and they will act out their egotistic inclinations.
Thus when ruler and minister have different inclinations
then the ruler will foster his ministers with strategic purpose in mind
the ministers will serve the ruler with a strategic purpose in mind,
and the relations between rulers and ministers
will be of a deliberate strategic nature.
Harming his personal interests to profit the state
is something the ministers will refuse to do;
harming the state to profit his ministers
is something the ruler will not do.
The ruler's basic feeling is
that to harm one's person is not profitable;
the ruler's basic feeling is
that if he harms the state he will take no good care of anyone.
The relations between ruler and minister
is co-operation based on strategic considerations.
When it comes to facing difficulties and being definitely prepared to risk one's life
to exhaust one's competence and to exhaust one's strength
this is something one does for the sake of the law.
Therefore the former kings openly gave rewards in order to encourage
and they practised severe punishments in order to show their authority.
When rewards and punishments are made plain
then the people will do their best to the point of sacrificing their lives.
When the people do their best to the point of sacrificing their lives
then the armed forces will be strong and the ruler will be respected.
When the punishments and rewards are not seen clearly
then the people will aim to get things without making real contributions
and they will gamble on escaping punishment when they have committed a crime,
and under such conditions the armed forces will be weak and the ruler unrespected.
Thus the talented aide of the former kings
gave their very best and exhausted their competence.
And so it is said:
"One must be clear about public-spiritedness and egotism,
and one must carefully investigate laws and prohibitions."
The former kings understood this.
One's person remaining unimpaired is called retaining integrity.
Integrity
is the attaining full possession of one's [inner] person.
Generally, as for integrity,
it begins to coalesce through non-assertiveness in action
and is attains its full form through the absence of desires;
it achieves its inner balance through absence of reflection,
and it reaches firm self-assurance through not being exercised.
If one asserts oneself through action and desires things
then the integrity has nowhere to dwell;
if the integrity has nowhere to dwell
then one is not complete.
If one exerts oneself and reflects on things
then one will not attain stable self-assurance;
and if one does not have stable self-assurance
then one will not achieve the desired results;
if one does not achieve one's desired results
then that is the result of cultivating integrity.
If one cultivates integrity one will lack integrity.
If does not cultivate integrity then one will come to possess integrity.
It is with this understanding that the text says:
"The person of highest integrity does not cultivate integrity,
and by this method he comes to possess integrity."
The reason why one values non-assertiveness, non-reflection and the cultivation of emptiness,
is one's innermost thoughts must not be controlled by anything.
Now those who do not have the proper technique

"Kind-heartedness"
means that one loves and cares for others with a glad heart,
that one is delighted when others meet good fortune
and that one is displeased when others meet misfortune.
It originates in what the mind cannot stop.
And it does not by any means seek reward.
That is why it says:
"The man of superior kind-heartedness acts, but does not thereby take any assertive action for a certain purpose."
"Moral principle" (or: Moral principle)
is the serving interaction between ruler and minister, superior and inferior,
it is the maintaining the proper divisions between father and son, the noble and the base;
it is the equal interaction between acquaintances and friends,
it is the maintaining proper distinctions of closeness and distance, inner and outer.
When the minister serves his ruler that is appropriate;
when inferiors are concerned about superiors that is appropriate;
when sons serve their fathers that is appropriate;
when the base show respect to the noble that is appropriate;
when acquaintanes and friends help each other that is appropriate;
when those who are close are kept on the inside and those who are distant are kept outside that is appropriate.
"Moral Principle"
refers to this appropriateness.
Regarding something as appropriate one does it.
That is why it says.
"The man of superior moral principle acts and with a definite basis on which to act."
"Ritual propriety"
is that through which one gives perceptible form to inner feelings,
it is the manifestation in visible patterns of the various forms of moral principle,
it is constitutive of the relation between rulers and ministers, fathers and sons,
it is that through which the noble and the base, the talented and the unworthy are kept apart.
Those feelings one harbours in one's heart, but does not give explicit verbalised expression to,
one will therefore make plain through hastening tread and low bowing.
What one really cherishes in one's heart but does not fully understand,
one therefore making beautiful words and elaborate expressions one causes others to believe in one.
Ritual
is that through which external ornament expresses explicitly what is inside.
Therefore one says:
"Ritual is designed to give perceptible form to inner feelings."
Whenever a person is destabilised by external things
he loses sight of the ritual rules for governing his person.
When ordinary people practise ritual propriety
it is in order to give public honour to other people,
and as a result they are at times pushed to eagerness, at other times fail through negligence.
When the superior man practises ritual propriety
it is in order to govern his person.
Since he does it in order to govern his person
he makes a spiritual practice of it and practises the superior ritual propriety.
Superior ritual propriety is spiritually concentrated (and single-minded),
whereas the common people are doublehearted.
That is why such people cannot respond to each other properly.
They cannot respond to each other properly
and that is why it says:
"As for superior ritual propriety, if one practises it, people, as a rule, will not respond to one properly."
The common people may be doublehearted
but the sage, in his repeated shows of veneration and respect
and in his consummate exercise of ritual movements of hands and feet,
neglects not the slightest detail.
That is why it says:
"He rolls up his sleeves and carries on the tradition."
The Way has something it accumulates, and accumulation gives results.
Inner integrity
is a result achieved through the Way.
In results there is a concrete reality, and from concrete reality there is a certain outward radiation.
Kind-heartedness
is the outward radiation or shining forth of inner integrity.
Behind this outward radiation there is an inner abundance, and from this there emerges realisation in action.
Moral Principle
is the realisation in action of kind-heartedness.
For each formal action there is a proper ritual propriety,
and for each form of ritual performance there is decorous patterning.
Ritual propriety
is the decorous patterning of moral principle.
Therefore it says:
"Only when the Way is lost does inner integrity get lost;
only when inner integrity is lost does kind-heartedness get lost;
only when kind-heartedness is lost does moral principle get lost;
only when moral principle is lost does ritual propriety get lost."
Ritual propriety provides an outer shape for inner feelings;
decorous patterning provides outer ornamentation for the inner substance.
Now the superior man opts for inner reality or feeling and dismisses outer shape;
he is fond of substance and dislikes ornamentation.
Now if one relies on outer form to assess inner feelings
that must be because the inner feelings are bad;
if one waits to see outer ornaments to assess inner substance
then that is because the inner substance has been degenerated.
How can one argue this?
Mr Hé's jade disk
was not decorated with the five colours;
Lord Suí's pearl
was not decorated in "silver and yellow".
These substances were so perfectly exquisite
that other things were not deemed sufficient to decorate these.
Anything that depends on decoration to become acceptable
must not already have an exquisite basic substance.
Therefore between father and son
ritual propriety is plain and simple, not overly shiny.
That is why it says:
"Slight indeed is ritual."
Generally, things do not thrive at the same time,
and Yīn and Yáng are cases in point.
Principles take away from and contribute to each other,
and formidable authority and integrity are cases in point.
When the inner reality is solid the outer manifestation is slight,
and relation between father and son as expressed in ritual is a case in point.
When one looks at things from this point of view
then when ritual is elaborate
then this is because the real mental attitude is in a reduced state.
And so those who created rituals
were people who work at the simple mind pervasive among men.
When the common people work at ritual
they are elated and pleased when others respond,
and they make complaints and are resentful when they do not respond.
Now if those who cultivate ritual
and whose task is to work at the simple mind common to all
on the contrary help people to blame each other, and get angry,
can that fail to lead to competition and conflict?
If there is competition and conflict then there is disorder.
Therefore it says:
"Ritual
is the wearing thin of loyal effort and good faith,
and it is the beginning of disorder."
If one acts before things arise, if one moves before principles are manifest, that is called premature conviction.
Premature conviction
is an arbitrary way of assessing without grounding in good reason.
How does one argue this?
Zhān Hé was sitting
with his disciple in attendance.
A buffalo was lowing outside the gate.
The disciple said:
"This is a black buffalo with a white forehead."
Zhān Hé said:
"Yes,
this is a black buffalo,
but the white is on the horns."
He sent someone out to have a look.
Indeed, it was a black buffalo with its horns wrapped in cloth.
Now with the special skills of a Zhānzǐ
to impose oneself on the minds of the masses,
that is an ostentatious and dangerous course.
That is why it says:
"It (i.e. premature conviction) is an ostentatious embellishment of the Way."
Suppose one tries to leave aside the astuteness of Zhānzǐ
and sends a five-foot stupid boy to have a look at the beast
then even he would understand it was a black buffalo
with horns wrapped in cloth.
Thus with the astuteness of a Zhānzǐ
this man overtaxed his mind and injured his spirit
before he achieved the same result as the stupid boy.
Therefore it says:
"It is the beginning of stupidity."
And so the whole passage runs:
"Premature conviction
is only a superficial embellishment of the Way,
and may be the beginning of stupidity."
The "great fellow"
refers to his wisdom72 being great.73
"Dwell in the thick, not dwell in the thin"
means that one works with basic inner reality
and rejects the outer aspects of ritual.
"Dwell in the realities and not dwell in ostentatious ornament"
means that one makes sure to carefully following principle and does not break off mid-way.
"Reject that and opt for this"
is to reject outer form and to reject the breaking off mid-way
and to opt for carefully following Principle and being fond of basic realities.
Thus it says:
"Reject that and opt for this."
When one suffer a disaster
one feels fear in one's heart;
When one feels fear in one's heart
then one's actions are principled and straight;
when one's actions are principled and straight
then one's reflections and plans are mature;
when one's reflections and plans are mature
then one gets to the principles of things.
When one's actions are principled and straight
then there will be no disasters and no harm;
when there are no disasters and no harm
then one will live out one's assigned life-span.
When one gets to the principles of things
then one will be sure to obtain achievements.
If one lives out one's assigned life-span
then one will be unharmed and long-lived.
If one is sure to obtain achievements
then one will be rich and noble.
Achieving a full measure of long life, wealth and nobility is called good fortune,
and good fortune has its basis in being exposed to bad fortune.
Therefore it says:
"Bad fortune is what good fortune depends on."
This is how one achieves success.
When man has good fortune
then wealth and nobility will come to him;
when wealth and nobility come
then clothing and food will be elaborate and beautiful;
when clothes and food are elaborate and beautiful
then a self-important mentality will arise;
When a self-important mentality arises
then one's behaviour will be wicked and in one's initiatives one disregards Principle.
When one's behaviour is wicked
then onself one will die an early death;
if in one's initiatives one disregards Principle
then one will in no case obtain any achievement.
Now if close at hand one suffers the adversity of dying early
and further afield one is not famous for achiving anything,
then that is a great disaster.
And so disaster is basically born from good fortune.
Thus it says:
"In good fortune bad fortune hides."
Now when one keeps in accordance with the Way and Principle in one's work
then there is nothing one cannot achieve.
If there is nothing one cannot achive,
then on a big scale one may achieve the position and honour of a Son of Heaven,
and on a small scale it is easy to get the rewards and stipends of ministers, prime ministers and generals.
If one disregards the Way and Principle and takes arbitrary initiatives
then even if at the top level one has the position or honour of a Son of Heaven or feudal lord
or on the lower level one has the wealth of Yī Dùn78, Táo Zhū,79 the diviners and ritual impersonators80
one will still fail to have control of the population
and one will lose one's resources.
If the common people easily disregard the Way and Principle
and lightly take arbitrary initiatives
then they do not understand the depth and size of bad and good fortune
and how broad and far-reaching the Way is.
Therefore the text instructs people:
"Who knows the ultimate?"
Everyone desires to be rich and noble and to have a complete long life
but no one can never be sure to avoid poverty, baseness, and early death.
In their minds they desire to be rich, noble and to have a complete long life,
but as it is they are poor, vulgar and die early.
This is because they are unable to attain to what they wish to attain to.
Generally, when one has lost one's way and walks at random that is called 'being lost'.
If one is lost one is unable to get where one wishes to go.
Now since the masses are unable to get to where they want to go
therefore it says:
"They are lost."
That the masses have been unable to get to where they want to go
has been so since the separation of Heaven from earth and down to the present time.
Therefore it is said:
"As for men being lost,
the days that this has lasted are certainly many."
"Correct"
means that the inner and the outer correspond to each other,
that proposals and actions match each other.
"Pure and modest"
means that one takes the fate of life and death as something inevitable
and that one thinks nothing of assets and goods.
"Straight"
means that one's moral principles are inevitably public-spirited and correct
and one's public-spirited attitude is not one-sided.
"Glory"
means that one's office and rank are elevated and noble
that one's clothes and coats are stately.
Now those freemen who have the Way,
even if they are inwardly trusty and outwardly obedient
will not publicly criticise or slander those who are in straights, or who are failures.
Even if they are prepared to die for their morality and think little of material wealth
will not humiliate those who are exhausted or make those who are greedy ashamed.
Even if they are straight in their rectitude and non-partisan themselves,
they do not go on to remove the wicked and accuse the selfish of crimes.
Even if they hold distingushed positions of power and wear beautiful clothes
they do not show off to the humble or cheat the poor.
Why is this?
Suppose someone who has lost his way
is willing to listen to those who are familiar with the place and to ask those who know
then he will not be completely lost.
Now the reason why the common people want to achieve results
but do, on the contrary, fail in their pursuits
is because they do not understand the principles of the Way
but are unwilling to ask those who know or to listen to those who are able.
When the common people are unwilling to ask advice from those who know
and to listen to those who are capable
and the sage insists on blaming them for the resulting disasters
then they will be resentful.
The common people are in the majority and the sages are in a minority.
That the minority will not win against a majority
is a question of numbers.
Now to take an initiative and become an enemy of the whole world
that is not the way to make one's person perfect and to achieve a long life.
That is why the sage acts according to established practice
when he undertakes things.
Therefore it says (ch. ):
"He is square-edged but does not scrape,
Has corners but does not jab,
is straight but not unrestrained,
shines but does not dazzle."
Sharpness of hearing and of sight, wisdom and basic competence,
these depend on Heaven;
Taking action or desisting, reflecting and planning,
these depend on man.
As for man
he relies on clear sight from Heaven in order to see,
he entrusts himself to clear hearing from Heaven in order to hear
and he counts on his intellectual faculty from Heaven in order to reflect and plan.
Now if in looking one expends too much effort
then one's eyes will not have clear sight;
if in listening one strains too much
then one's ears will not have clear hearing;
if in reflecting and planning one goes beyond the proper measure
then one's intellectual faculties will be confused.
When the eyes have no clear sight
then one cannot determine the difference between black and white;
when the ears have no clear hearing
then one cannot distinguish between the pure and the impure notes;
if one's intellectual capacities are in diesorder
then one cannot gain clear insight about points of gain and loss.
When the eyes cannot determine the colours black and white,
then one is called blind;
when the ears cannot distinguish between the pure and the impure tones
then one is called deaf;
if the mind cannot get clear about points of gain and loss
then one is called mad.
If one is blind
then one is unable to avoid dangers in broad daylight;
if one is deaf
then one is unable to understand the harm involved in thunder;
if one is mad
then one is unable to avoid the disasters of brought on by the laws of men.
The person whom the book calls 'he who governs the people'
adapts to the proper measure of action and inaction
and is sparing in the exercise of reflection and planning;
the person whom the book calls 'he who serves Heaven'
does not exhaust his power of hearing and seeing to the utmost
and does not exhaust the power of his intellectual capacities.
If he really does exercise his abilities to the utmost
then he will expend a great deal of mental energy;
if he expends a great deal of intellectual energy
then the disasters of blindness, deafness, confusion and madness will arise.
That is why the sage is sparing in the use of these.
That 'he is sparing with these'
is because he is economic in the use of his subtle inner engergies
and his sparing in the use of his intellectual capacities.
Therefore it says:
"In governing others and serving Heaven it is best to be economical."
The common people are rushed in their exercise of their mental energies.
If they are rushed then they use up a great deal.
Using up a great deal is called excessiveness.
The sage, in his use of his mental energies, is quiet.
If one is quiet then one uses up little.
Using up little is called being economical.
The basic art of being sparing
arises from the Principles of the Way.
As for someone who has the ability to be economical
such a person is someone who has decided to follow the Way
and who decided to submit to Principle.
The common people are exposed to disasters
and get trapped in misfortune,
but still do not know how to retreat
and do not decide to follow the Way and Principle.
The sage, even if he has not yet seen the manifestations of disaster
cultivates emptiness and nothingness and decides to follow the Way and Principle
so that one may say 'he submits early'.
Therefore it says (lao):
"Now because he is frugal
therefore he submits (to the Way) in good time."
As for a person who knows how to govern others
his reflections and plans are calm;
and as for a person who serves Heaven
his apertures are vacant.
His reflection is vacant and calm.
Therefore inner power does not leave him.
If his apertures are vacant
then the vital energy of harmony will enter him every day.
Therefore it says:
"He doubly accumulates inner power."
A person who is able to ensure that the original inner power does not leave
and that the new harmonious vital energy comes every day,
that person is the one who has submitted (to the Way) in good time.
Therefore it says:
"To submit in good time
that is called doubly accumulating power."
Only after one has accumulated inner power does the spirit become calm;
only after the spirit is calm will harmony multiply;
only after harmony multiplies will one make plans and achieve one's aims;
only after one makes plans and achieves one's aims can one steer the myriad things.
If one can steer the myriad things
then in battle one will find it easy to win against opponents;
if one finds it easy to win against opponents in battle
then one's conclusions are bound to spread throughout one's generation.
One's conclusions are bound to spread throughout one's generations
therefore it says:
"One will overcome everything.
Overcoming everything is based on doubly accumulating inner power.
Therefore it says:
"If one doubly accumulates inner power
then there is nothing one will not overcome."
If in battle one finds it easy to overcome the opponent
then one will control all the states in the world;
if one's conclusions are bound to spread throughout one's generation
then the people will follow one.
If in attack one can annex the whole world
and in retreat one can make the people follow one,
and if one's art of government is concerned with the long term,
then none of the common people will realise the beginning and the end of it.
No one realises the beginnings and ends of one's strategies
so no one understands the ultimate point.
Therefore it says:
"If one conquers everything
then they will not understand the ultimate point.
Generally when someone has a state and loses it afterwards
when he has a body and ruins it afterwards,
then he cannot be said to be capable of controlling a state
and capable of safeguarding his body.
If one is able to control one's state
then one must be able to ensure the safety of the altars of the land and grain;
if one is able to gurd one's body
one must be able to live out the years of one's life.
Only after that can one be said to be able to control the state
and to safeguard one's body.
Anyone who is able to control a state
and to safeguard his body
is bound to have embodied the Way.
If he has embodied the Way
then his competence is deep;
when his competence is deep
then his calculations are far-reaching;
if his calculations are far-reaching
then none of the common people can see his ultimate point.
It is just that one can cause others not to see the ultimate point of one's undertakings.
If they do not see the ultimate point of one's undertakings
that is safeguarding one's body
and controlling the state.
Therefore it says:
"No one understands one's ultimate points."
"If no one understands one's ultimate points
then one can control the state."
"The mother of the control of the state":
The mother
is the Way.
As for the Way
it is born from the art through which one controls the state.
The art through which one controls a state
