is therefore called 'the mother of controlling the state'.
With the Way
one revolves with the generations.
One's established life is long
and one maintains its stipends for a long time.
That is why it says:
"With the mother of the control of the state
one can be long-lasting."
A tree has spread roots
and it has straight roots.
The straight roots
are what the book calls 'basic root'.
The basic root
is that through which the tree establishes its life;
the spread roots
are those through which it maintains its life.
Inner power
is that through which man establishes his life;
stipends
are that through which one maintains life.
Now someone who has his foundation in Principle
will maintain his stipends for long.
Therefore it says:
"Set your roots deep."
If one embodies the right way
then the days of one's life will be long.
Therefore it says:
"Firm up the basic roots."
When the basic roots are firm
then one's life is long
when the roots are deep
then one's life is long.
Thus it is said:
"Making the roots deep,
firming up the basic roots,
that is the way of long life and of lasting enjoyment of life."
If a craftsman often changes his trade
then he will not achieve his results;
if a labourer often wavers and moves about
then he will get no results.
When one man does manual work
and he wastes half a day every day,
then in the course of ten days he will have wasted five men's results.
If men do manual work
and every day the waste half a days' work
then in ten days they will have wasted the results of men.
Thus when it comes to changing one's trade,
then the more people do this
the greater the loss.
Whenever the laws and ordinances are changed
the conditions of profit and loss change.
When conditions of profit and loss change
then the people will be seeking to bring about change.
Seeking to bring about change is called 'changing the trade'.
Thus looking at this in terms of Principle:
if in serving the great multitudes you make them waver frequently
then there will be few results achieved;
if you hide a great vessel but you shunt it about frequently
then it will often be ruined or damaged;
if you fry a small fish and you frequently stir it
then you ruin its richness;
if in governing a large state one frequently changes the laws
then the people will find this hard to bear.
Therefore the ruler who has grasped the Way sets great store by constant calm
and will not emphasise the changing of laws.
Therefore it is said:
"Governing a large state is like frying a small fish."
When a person is in the condition of an acute sickness then he sets store by doctors,
if there is a disaster he stands in awe-struck fear of ghosts.
When a sage is in charge
then the people will have few desires;
when the people have few desires
then their blood and vital spirits will be well settled and their actions will be principled;
when their actions are principled then there will be few disasters.
When in one's body there is no harm from ulcers and boils,
and if outside there are no disasters arising from punishments and executions
they will take things very easy indeed with the ghosts.
Therefore it says:
"When one governs the world in accordance with the Way
the ghosts will not display their numinous force."
The people of a generation in good order
does not enter into harmful conflict with the ghosts and spirits.
Therefore it says:
"It is not that the ghosts have no numinous force.
It is that the spirits do not harm men."
When the ghosts wreak misfortune
those who have caught the diseases say that ghosts harm men;
men exorcise them and drive them away
then they say that men have harmed ghosts.
When the people offend against the law
one says that the people harm their superiors;
when superiors execute the people
one says that superiors harm the people.
When the people do not offend against the law
then the superiors will not carry out punishments either;
when superiors do not carry out punishments
then one says that superiors do not harm the people.
Therefore it says:
"The sage will not harm the people either."
Superiors and people do not harm each other,
men and ghosts do not hurt each other.
Therefore it says:
"The two do not hurt each other."
When the people do not dare to offend against the laws
then superiors do not employ punishments to their bodies
and as for external things they do not seek profit from their work.
If superiors do not employ punishments to their bodies
and as for external things do not seek profit from their work
then the people will flourish.
When the people flourish their collected supplies will be plentiful.
When the people flourish and their supplies are plentiful
then one says one has inner power.
Generally one speaks of 'noxious influences'
when the souls have left the body and the fine spirit is confused.
When the fine spirit is confused then one has no inner power.
When the ghosts do not exercise their noxious influence on people
then the souls do not leave the body.
When the souls do not leave the body
then the fine spirit does not get confused.
The fine spirits not being confused one is said to have inner power.
If superiors have accumulated plentiful supplies
and the ghosts do not confuse their subtle spirits
then the inner power will be in all the people.
Therefore it says:
"When the two do not hurt each other
then inner power will assemble in that place."
This means: the inner power is plentiful above and below,
and it completely converges on the people.
A ruler who has grasped the Way
has no bitter enemies among his neighbouring rivals
and within his state he shows rich generosity to the people.
If abroad he has no bitter enemies among his neighbouring competitors
then when he meets the feudal lords he shows proper politness and rectitude.
If within his state he shows rich generosity to the people
then in ordering the business of others he concentrates on what is basic.
If when he meets the feudal loreds he shows proper politeness and righteousnes
then his conscripts are rarely brought out.
If in governing the people he concentrates what is basic
then wantonness and luxuriousness will stop.
In general the great usefulness of the horse
is because outside it delivers armour and weapons
and inside it provides for wanton luxury.
Now the ruler who has got hold of the Way
will rarely deploy armed force abroad,
and within his state he prohibits wanton luxury.
If those above do not employ their horses in war or in pursuit of the defeated
and if the people do not use horses indulge in wanton distant excursions
to get to special goods,
then what they concentrate all their efforts on is their fields.
If their efforts are concentrated on their fields
then they are bound to fertilise them and to irrigate them.
Therefore it says (lao ):
"If the Way prevails in the world
then luxury horses will carry dung."
When the ruler has not got hold of the Way
then he will be cruel to his people within his state
and he will invade and cheat neighbouring states abroad.
If he is cruel within his state
then the people's productivity will be disrupted;
if he invades and cheats other states
then his armed forces will often be raised.
When the people's professional activities are disrupted
then domestic animals will be few;
when the army is often raised
then officers and men are exhausted.
When domestic animals are few
then military horses will be in short supply;
if officers and men are exhausted
then the military situation will be highly dangerous.
When military horses are in short supply
then pregnant horses will be taken out in warfare;
when the military situation is highly dangerous
then courtiers have to do military service.
Horses
are what the military use on a large scale;
Suburb
means that the place is close.
Now what the army is supplied with is always with pregnant horses and courtiers.
Therefore it says:
"When the Way does not prevail in the world
then military horses give birth in the suburbs."
When men have strong desires
then their calculations and plannings are confused;
when their calculations and plannings are confused
then the strong desires they have get even stronger;
when the strong desires they have get even stronger
the wickedness in their minds wins the day;
when the wickedness in their minds wins the day
then they break of mid-way in their tasks;
when they break off mid-way in their tasks
then disasters and problems arise.
When one looks at this from this point of view
disasters and troubles arise from wickedness in the mind,
and wickedness in the mind is seduced by what is desirable.
As for the sorts of things that are desirable
when they are put forward then they teach decent people to become wicked,
when they are withdrawn they cause good people to meet disaster.
When wickedness arises
then above they will encroach upon weak rulers;
when disasters arrive
then many citizens will be hurt.
Thus when faced with the sort of things that are desirable
then above they will attack weak rulers and below they will hurt the citizens.
Now to attack weak rulers above and to hurt citizens below
that is a great crime.
Therefore it says:
"Nothing is more disastrous than what is desirable."
Therefore the sage is not seduced by the five colours
and he is not made wanton by music.
The enlightened ruler despises beautiful toys and eschews wanton beauty.
Man has neither fur nor feathers.
If he does not wear clothes he cannot cope with the cold.
He does not belong to Heaven above
and he does not pertain to Earth below.
The bowels and the stomach are basic to him
and if he does not eat he cannot survive.
Therefore he inevitably has an urge for material benefits.
The fact that his urge for material benefits has not been removed
is based on worry for his body.
Therefore if the sage has enough clothes to face the cold
and enough food to fill what is empty in him,
then he will not be worried.
The common people are not like that.
If they are big shots and they become feudal lords,
or if as minor people they have assets of over a thousand cash
their worries connected with the acquisitive urge are still not removed.
A minor criminal may escape punishment
a criminal guilty of death will at times survive.
But, now, the worries of an insatiable person are never resolved.
Therefore it says:
"No misfortune is greater than being insatiable."
Therefore if concupiscence is strong then there is worry;
if there is worry then there arises a mental hustle;
if there arises a mental hustle then one's intellectual competence declines;
if one's intellectual competence declines
then one loses one's judgment;
if one loses one's judgment
then one takes arbitrary actions;
if one takes arbitrary actions
then disaster and harm come one's way;
when disaster and harm come one's way
then one's mental hustle ties up one's inner life;
when one's mental hustle ties up one's inner life
then painful disasters will assail one from the outside;
when painful disasters assail one from the outside
then bitterness and pain are mixed in among bowels and stomach;
when bitterness and pain are mixed in among stomach and bowels
then this hurts a person severely;
if one is severely affected then one withdraws and blames oneself.
Withdrawing and blaming oneself arises from concupiscence.
Therefore it says:
"No blame is more painful than that of concupiscence."
As for the Way,
it is what makes the myriad things what they are
and what makes the myriad principles cohere.
As for principle
it is the pattern that brings things to completion;
as for the Way
it is that through which the myriad things are completed.
Therefore it is said:
The Way
is what gives pattern and principle to things.
If things have inherent principles
they cannot interfere with each other.
Things have principles
and cannot interfere with each other
and that is why Principle acts as the organising force of things.
Each of the myriad things have their different principles
and the Way coordinates all the principles of the myriad things.
Therefore these things cannot fail to be transformed.
Since they cannot fail to be transformed
they therefore have no fixed and constant patterns of behaviour.
They have no constant patterns of behaviour
and therefore they receive the vital energies of death and life from the Way.
All forms of intellectual competence and deliberations are based on the Way.
All understakings are given up or made to flourish on the basis of the Way.
Heaven gets to participate in it and gets to be high,
Earth gets to participate in it and gets pregnant with growth./
The Great Dipper gets to participate in it and achieves its awesome authority.
Sun and moon get to participate in it and get to shine permanently./
The Five Constant Phases get to participate in it and constantly hold their places.
The big stars get to participate in it and straighten out their courses./
The Four Seasons get it and control the vital transforming energies.
Yáo got to participate in it and got the Four Regions under his sovereign control./
Chì Sòng got to participate in it and achieved unison with Heaven and Earth.
The sages got to participate in it and achieved the decorous patterning of culture./
The Way
is wise with Yáo and Shùn,
is mad with Jiēyù,/
is destructive with Jié and Zhòu,
flourishes with Tāng and Wǔ./
One thinks it is close?
It roams among the four extremities of the universe./
One thinks it is far away?
It is constantly at one's side./
One thinks it is dark?
It shines resplendently.
One thinks it is bright?
Its nature is all mysteriously dark./
And so the works of Heaven and Earth are achieved,
and the Way harmonises and transforms even violent thunder./
All creatures in the universe
depend on it to be completed./
In general it is the essence of the Way/
that it does not dominate things and that it does not take definite shape./
It is pliable and soft, follows the seasons,
and it co-responds with the inherent principles of things./
The myriad creatures get to participate in it and die,
and they get to participate in it to live./
The myriad undertakings get to participate in it to fail,
and they get to participate in it to succeed./
The Way is like water:
if someone drowning drinks a lot of it then he will die,
if someone is thirsty and drinks moderately then he will live./
The Way is like a sword or a halberd:
when the stupid acts out his momentary anger with it then disaster arises,/
and when the sage punishes the violent with it then good fortune results./
Thus one comes to participate in it so as to die,
one comes to participate in it so as to live,/
one comes to participate in it so as to fail,
one comes to participate in it so as to succeed./
Few men have seen a live elephant
but they have got hold of the bones of a dead elephant
and on the basis of relevant pictures they imagine live elephants.
That by means of which one imagines things
is in all cases called 'psychological representation/image'.
Now although the Way cannot be heard or seen,
The sage takes hold of its manifest results
and by inference he catches sight of its form.
Therefore it says:
"A shape without a shape,／
an image without a physical object."／
As for principles
they are the distinguishing features of the square, the round, the long,
of the rough-and-big or slight, the strong and the brittle.
Thus only after the principles are fixed can one obtain the Way.
Thus among the fixed principles there are those of subsistence and ruin,
there are those of death and of life,
there are those of flourishing and of decay.
As for things now subsisting now disappearing,
suddenly dying, suddenly being born,
first flourishing and then afterwards decaying,
these cannot be called constant.
Only that which with the separation of Heaven and Earth was born together
and which until the dissolution of Heaven and Earth will neither die nor decay, these are called constant.
And that constant thing
does not suffer change in any way
but has no fixed principles.
Since it has no fixed principles
it is in no way in one constant place.
That is why it cannot be spoken of.
The sage observes its mysterious tenuousness
and avails himself of its revolutions.
If forced to give it a style, he will say: "The Way".
In that way it may be discussed.
And so it says:
"When the Way can be taken as the Way
is not the constant Way."
Man originates in birth and ends in death.
The beginning is called "coming out".
The ending is called "going in".
Therefore it says:
"They come out and are born, go in and die."
The human body has 360 joints,
four limbs, and nine apertures:
that is the overall sum of it.
The four limbs and the nine apertures make thirteen.
The action and repose of these thirteen
all belong to the realm of life.
Belonging to it is called "being a follower".
Therefore it says:
"Of the followers of life there are thirteen."
When one dies
all the thirteen revert
and one causes them to belong under death.
There are also thirteen followers of death.
Therefore it says:
"There are thirteen followers of life
and there are thirteen followers of death."
Quite generally the people keep reproducing themselves,
and since they live they certainly move.
When the movement is exhausted then they suffer loss.
If they keep moving
then they will keep suffering loss.
If they keep being reduced
then their life is exhausted.
The life being exhausted is called death.
And so all the thirteen
are places where one keeps dying and dying.
Thus it says:
"When the people are born,
since they are born they move,
and as they move they all move to their place of death.
These are thirteen."
So the sage makes sparing use of his subtle spirit
and sets store by dwelling in peace.
Not to take good care of the subtle spirit
and not to set store by dwelling in peace
this is more terrible than the harm from male rhinos and tigers.
Now rhinos and tigers have their proper territories,
their activity and repose have their proper seasons.
If one avoids their proper territories
and pays proper attention to the proper seasons
then one can avoid the harm from rhinos and tigers.
People only understand that rhinos and tigers have claws and horns
but no one understands that the myriad things all have claws and horns,
and they do not escape harm from the myriad things.
How does one explain this?
When the monsoon rains all pour down
and the wide open lands are open and quiet,
but in the evening or in the morning they want to get across a mountain or a river
then the claws and horns of the wind and dew harm them.
When in serving superiors people do not do their loyal best,
when they lightly offend against prohibitions and orders,
then the claws and horns of the laws regarding punishments harm them.
If, dwelling in one's home village one does not show restraint,
if in hate and love one is immoderate,
then the claws and horns of competition and strife will harm him.
If in one's predilections and desires one knows no limits,
if in one's demeanour one shows no restraint,
then the claws of boils and ulcers will harm one. [sexual diseases]
If one likes to use one's private competence and one rejects the Way and Principles
then one will be harmed by the claws and horns of the trapping nets for fish and birds.
Rhinos and tigers have their proper territories
and the myriad forms of harm have their sources.
If one avoid these proper territories
and one blocks these sources
then one will avoid all the forms of harm.
In general arms and hides
are means to guard against harm.
Those who value being alive,
even if they enter the army
have no inclination for resentful fighting.
If they have no inclination for resentful fighting
then they have no use for the implements for saving one from harm.
This refers not only to soldiers who are out in the open countryside.
The sage, as he wanders in his generation,
has no inclination to harm others
and so he necessarily avoids being harmed by others.
If he is not being harmed by others
then he does dot guard against others.
Thus it says:
"When travelling on land they do not run into rhinos and tigers."
When they enter mountains
they do not depend on precautions to save them from harm.
Thus it says:
"When they enter the army they do not take precautions against weapons."
They keep all harm at bay.
Thus it says:
"The rhinos have nowhere to direct their horns against,
the tigers nowhere to dig their claws into,
the soldiers have nowhere to sink their blades into."
To take no precautions and to be certain not to suffer any harm,
that is the Way and the Principle of Heaven and Earth.
[The sage] incorporates the Way of Heaven and Earth,
and so it says:
"There is no space for death."
When he acts, there is no space for death,
and one calls him "good at sticking to life".
If one loves one's son one will show loving care for one's son,
if one values life then one will show loving care for one's body,
if one sets store by achievements one will show loving care for performance.
A loving mother, when it comes to her weak little child,
makes every effort to bring him good fortune;
if she makes every effort to bring him good fortune
then she will work to keep away bad fortune from him;
if one works to keep had fortune away from him
then one's reflections and one's plans are mature
if one's reflections and plans are mature
then one gets hold of the principles of things;
if one gets hold of the principles of things
then one is bound to be successful;
if one is bound to be successful
then in one's moral actions one will not be in doubt;
not to be in doubt is called "being courageous".
The sage, when it comes to the myriad undertakings
is like the loving mother making plans for her weak little child.
Therefore he sees the path that he must take.
If he sees the path that he must take then he is enlightened
and his conduct of affairs is also without doubt;
Being without doubt is called "being courageous".
Being without doubt comes from showing loving care.
Thus it says:
"He shows loving care.
Therefore he is able to be courageous."
The Duke of Zhōu said:
"If during winter days one does not firmly seal things off against the frost
then in spring and in summer when one grows herbs and shrubs
they will not flourish.
Heaven and Earth cannot be always luxurious and always lavish:
how much less men?
Thus the myriad things must necessarily flourish and deline,
the myriad undertakings must necessarily relax and tighten,
in a nation there must necessarily be civil and military activities,
in public administration there must necessarily be rewards and punishments.
Thus when the professional will make sparing use of resources
his clan will be rich;
when the sage is sparing with and treasures his spirit
then his fine essences will flourish.
When the ruler takes a serious view of taking his soldiers out into battle
then his people will multiply;
when the population multiplies
then the state expands.
That is why it picks this out and says:
"One is economical,
therefore one can expand."
Everything that has a shape is easy to cut up,
and it is easy to cut off.
How does one demonstrate this?
If something has a physical shape
then it has a relative length;
if it has a relative length
then it has a relative size;
if it has a relative size
then it has a round or cornered shape;
if it has a round or cornered shape
then it has a relative hardness;
if it has a relative hardness
then it has a relative weight.
if it has a relative weight
then it has a relative brightness of pigment.
Length, size, roundness-or-squareness, brittleness
weight and brightness of pigment are called principles.
When principles are manifested in definite things, then things are easy separated off.
Thus when there are public discussions in the Great court and one speaks last
Gentlemen who have good judgment in public debates understand this.
If one wants to establish square or round forms
and follows the circle and the square,
then success in all undertakings will manifest itself.
And the myriad things all have their compasses and squares.
The gentleman who speaks up in public discussions
calculates according to compasses and squares.
The sage follows all the compasses and squares of the myriad things.
That is why it says:
"He does not presume to be the first in all under Heaven."
If he does not presume to be first in all under Heaven
then whatever he does he will get it done,
whatever he tries to achieve he will achieve,
his public arguments will be heard throughout his generation:
even if he desired not to occupy a great office,
could he succeed and remain free from official appointments?
"Occupy a great office" refers to being best at getting things done.
Thus it says:
"He does not presume to be first in all under Heaven,
therefore he is able to be best at getting things done."
A person who shows deep concern for his children
will not dare to cut them off from food and clothing;
a person who shows deep concern for his body
will not dare to deviate from the law and its regulations;
a person who shows deep concern for square and round shapes
will not dare to discard the compass and the square.
Thus, if, in dealing with the armed forces,
one shows deep concern for freemenn and minor officers
then in any war one will win against the opponent;
if one shows deep concern for instruments and contraptions,
then one's walls will be solid and firm.
Thus it says:
"If one shows proper care
then in waging battle one will win,
in defending oneself one will be firm and secure."
If one is able to keep unharmed
and to follow all the principles of the myriad things,
this is bound to be because there is something engendered by Heaven.
As for that which is engendered by Heaven,
Heaven engenders his mental attitudes.
Thus the Way in the world exhausts what is thus engendered (by Heaven).
If one guards this with deep concern
then one's undertakings will be successful without exception
every measure one takes will be adequate
so that one calls this a treasure.
Thus it says:
"I have three treasures,
I hold fast to them and treasure them ."
What the book calls the Great Way
is the correct Way;
what it calls 'ghastly'
is the wicked Way.
When it says that the "paths" are great
then this refers to ostentatious beauty.
As for ostentatious beauty
it is part of the Way of wickedness.
As for "The courts are all dirty"
this means that litigations proliferate.
When litigations proliferate
then the fields lie fallow.
When the fields lie fallow
then the storehouses are empty;
when the storehouses are empty
then the state is poor;
when the state is poor
then the habits of the people will turn wanton and profligate;
when the habits of the people turn wanton and profligate
then the enterprises concerned with clothes and food will be disrupted;
when the enterprises concerned with clothes and food are disrupted
then the people have to become pretentious, crafty and fraudulent;
when they are pretentious, crafty and fraudulent
then they understand colours and elegant patterns;
This is meant by "their clothes are patterned and colourful".
When litigation proliferates
and storehouses are empty
and there are those who make wantonness and profligacy their habits,
then the harm to the state
is as if one used a sharp sword to stab it.
Therefore it says:
"One takes along a sharp sword."
When all these fellows become pretentious and clever
to the point where they harm the state,
then the private families are bound to become rich;
The private families are bound to become rich,
so therefore it says:
"Assets and goods there are more than enough."
When matters stand like this in the state
then the ignorant common people will not fail to imitate them with tricks.
When they imitate them
then the small thieves emerge.
From this point of view,
when great wickedness arises, then small thieves follow suit;
when great wickedness calls the tune then the small thieves chime it.
As for the reed organ
it is the leader of the Five Sounds.
Thus the reed organ comes first and the bells and zithers all follow suit;
the reed organ sings forth and all the other musical instruments chime in.
Now when the great wickedness arises then vulgar people call the tune;
when vulgar people call the tune then the little thieves will inevitably chime in.
Therefore "they wear elegantly patterned and colourful clothes,
they carry sharp swords,
they drink and eat gluttonously
and still their goods and their resources are more than enough.
Such people are called "the thieves who play the reed organ."
Humans, no matter how stupid or clever they are,
invariably have positive and negative preferences.
If one is all tranquil and at peace
then everyone understands where bad fortune and good fortune come from.
But when obsessed with likes and dislikes,
when they are tempted by wanton things
only then do they change to become all confused.
The reason why this is so
is because they get drawn in by things,
and they get all confused by beautiful playthings.
When tranquil one has the rectitude of one's preferences,
when at peace one understands the plans leading to good or bad fortune.
But now dainty and beautiful things have changed people,
external things have drawn them in.
They are drawn in by things and then set out to act,
therefore it says "uprooted".
When it comes to the sage, he is not like this.
Once he has set up his priorities
then even if he sees a thing which he is fond of
this thing cannot draw him him.
The inability to draw him in is referred to by "he is not uprooted".
He is all concentrated in his real being,
even if there is something of the kind he is fond of,
his spirit is not moved by it.
That his spirit is not moved is referred to by "he does not let go of things".
One's sons and grandsons
will incorporate this way and guard the ancestral temples.
When the ancestral temples are not ruined
this is what is referred to by "the sacrifices are not interrupted".
The inherent power of the person comes from assembling subtle essence;
the inherent power of a clan comes from resources and property.
a district, a state and all under Heaven get their inner power from the people.
Now one sorts out one's person//
in such a way that outer things cannot disturb his subtle essence and spirit//
therefore it says:
"If one cultivates one's person//
one's inherent power will then be genuine."//
Being genuine
is to be firmly attentive to one's person.
If in arranging the affairs of one's clan
useless things cannot interfere with one's plans
there are more than enough resources.
Thus it says:
"If one cultivates it at home
then there will be more than enough inner power."
Those who govern a district
if they practise this line of restraint,
then those who have more than enough will become even more.
Therefore it says:
"If one cultivates it in one's district
one's inherent power will grow."
Those who govern a state,
if they practise this line of restraint,
then those who have inherent power in the districts will become more.
Thus it says:
"If one practises it in a state,
then the inner power will be abundant."
If someone who is in charge of all under Heaven
practises this line of restraint
then all inhabitants alive will enjoy this richness.
Thus it says:
"When one cultivates it in All Under Heaven
then one's inner virtue/political charisma will be far-reaching."
If those who cultivate their persons
in this way distinguish between gentlemen and petty men,
if those who govern a district, a country or are in charge of all under Heaven
each using these divisions
compare and observe the flourishing and decline of things,
then among ten thousand things they will not fail in one.
Thus it says:
"Observe the person according to the person,
observe the families in terms of the families,
observe the districts in terms of the districts,
observe the countries according to the countries,
observe the world in terms of the world.
How do we know that the world is as it is?
Because of this."
When the Way does not prevail in all under Heaven,
attacks and assaults are incessant,
for several years there is no end to mutual defense,
in armour and helmets flea's eggs and fleas breed,
swallows and sparrows settle in the tents
but the armies does not return home.
Thus it (Lao ) says:
"War-horses breed in the suburbs."
A Dí barbarian presented presented a large fox skin and a dark panther skin
to Duke Wén of Jìn.
"These make the very beauty of their skins into their own crime."
When it comes to those who govern the state
they make fame int their crime.
King Yǎn of Xú was such a person.
Or they make cities or territories their crime.
The states of Yú and Guō were such cases.
Thus it says:
"In crime nothing is more influential than desirability."
The Earl of Zhì combined the forces of Fàn and of Zhōngháng
and kept launching local attacks on Zhào.
Hán and Wèi offerend resistance,
and his army was defeated at Jìnyáng
and as for himself, he died east of Gāoliáng.
And then in the event, to finish with, he was carved up.
They lacquered his skull to make into pisspots.
Thus it says:
"No disaster is greater than insatiable greed."
The ruler of Yú was after the horse-teams raised in Qū
as well as the jade from Chuíjí,
and he did not listen to Gōng Zhīqí.
As a result the county was ruined and he himself died.
Thus it says:
"There is no moral blame more saddening than that of concupiscence."
If a country makes survival its highest norm
then probably it will be possible to become a leading king;
if a person takes living as his highest norm
then probably it will be possible to become rich and noble.
If one does not harm oneself because of desires
then one's country does not get ruined
and oneself one does not die.
Thus it says:
"Understanding what is enough counts as having enough."
When King Zhuāng of Chǔ had won his victory
he conducted a hunt at Héyǒng.
When he returned he was offering rewards to Sūn Shūào
and Sūnshū Ao asked for the territory of Hànjiān,
a sandy and stony place.
According to the laws of the country of Chǔ
ministers with stipends had their lands confiscated after two generations.
Only Sūnshū Ao still occupied his place.
The reason why they did not confiscate his country
was because it was miserable land.
So they offered sacrifices uninterruptedly for nine generations.
Thus it says:
"If one is good at establishing things they will not be uprooted;
if one is good at embracing things they will not slip loose.
Sons and grandsons will offer their sacrifices,
for generation after generation this will go on uninterrupted."
This refers to Sūnshū Áo.
Exercising control in oneself is called having weight;
not leaving one's proper place is called being at peace.
If one has weight
then one can control those who are light;
if one is at rest
then one can control those who are in a hurry.
Thus it says:
"The weighty is the root of the light;
the calm is the overlord of those who are in a hurry."
Thus it says:
"The gentleman when travelling all day
does not leave his baggage wagon."
As for the country
it is the ruler's baggage wagon.
If a ruler and father during his lifetime passes on the country
this is the sort of person who leaves the baggage wagon.
Thus even if he has the pleasure of Dài and Yúnzhōng
he simply is already deprived of Zhào.
The Ruler's Father
was the ruler over war chariots
but he makes his person appear slight to all under Heaven.
Having no position of power is called being lightweight,
leaving one's position is called acting too fast.
Therefore during one's lifetime one is in obscurity, and one dies.
Thus it says:
"If one is lightweight one will lose one's ministers;
if one acts too fast one will lose the ruler."
This refers to the ruler and father.
That his position is powerful,
that is the source from which the ruler of men feeds.
He who rules over others
has a powerful position among the ministers.
When he loses this position it cannot be won back.
Duke Jiǎn lost it to Tián Chéng,
the Duke of Jìn lost it to the Six Senior Ministers,
and their states were ruined while they themselves died.
Thus it says:
"A fish must not be removed from his deep pond."
Rewards and punishments
are the sharp tools of a country.
If these are under the control of the ruler
then he will control the ministers;
if these are under the control of ministers
then he will win against the ruler.
If the ruler openly sets out to give rewards
then the ministers will reduce these and dole [the rest?] out as their own generosity;
when the ruler openly sets out to mete out punishments
then the ministers will increase these to make it into a show of their authority.
When the ruler of men openly sets out to give rewards
then the ministers avail themselves of his position of power;
when the ruler of men openly metes out punishments,
then the ministers avail themselves of his authority.
Therefore it says:
"The sharp tools of the country
one must not show the people."
The King of Yuè entered the services of Wú as a slave,
and he indicated that Wú should attack Qí in order to ruin Wú.
When the Wú army had already won a victory at Àilíng against the people of Qí.
they spread out their forces on the Jiāng and the Jì rivers,
and they made forceful efforts at Huángchí:
as a result the Wú army could be brought under control at Wǔhú.
Thus it says:
"If one wants to contain someone
one must certainly cause him to expand;
if one wants to weaken someone
one must certainly strengthen him."
When Duke Xiàn of Jìn was about to launch a secret attack on Yú
he made them presents of round jade and horses;
when the Earl of Zhì was about to launch a secret attack on the Chóuyóu barbarians
he made them presents of broad-bodied vehicles.
Thus it says:
"If one wants to take someone,
one must certanly give presents to him."
To start working on the level of the shapeless and invisible
and to work for the great success in all under Heaven
"that is called subtle enlightenment."
To strike a posture of weakness and to emphasise one's own humility
that is called "winning as the weaker part against the stronger".
Things that have a physical shape
if they are large are bound to arise from the small;
things that are long-lasting,
if they are many, are bound to start as few.
Thus it says:
"The difficult things in the world invariably start with the easy;
the large things invariably start with the slight"
So, if one wishes to control things one must address oneself to the slight.
Thus it says:
"Making plans for the difficult is in what is easy;
making plans for the large is in what is slight."
A two thousand meter dyke is ruined by the holes of termites;
a one hundred foot home is burnt down through smoke from a rift in a chimney.
Thus it says
Bái Guī's walk along the dyke was in order to fill in the holes,
ordinary people in their concern for fire fill in the creaks.
And accordingly Bái Guī is not exposed to floods,
the ordinary people are not exposed to fires.
These are all cases of being careful about what is easy
in order to avoid what is hard,
to pay diligent attention to what is slight
in order to keep at bay what is large.
Biǎn Què paid a visit to Duke Huán of Cài.
After he had been standing for a while,
Biǎn Què said:
"My lord, you have an acute disease on the skin surface.
If one does not treat this then I shall be afraid the condition will worsen."
Duke Huán said:
"I have nothing of the kind."
Biǎn Què left
and Duke Huán said:
The reason why doctors like to treat those who have nothing wrong with them
is because they want to count this as their success.
After ten days
Biǎn Què went to pay another visit and said:
"My lord, your disease is now in the muscle and skin.
Unless one treats this the disease will go deeper."
Lord Huán made no reply.
Biǎn Què left.
Duke Huán felt again dissatisfied.
After ten days
Biǎn Què went to pay another visit and he said:
"My lord, the disease is in the bowels and in the stomach.
Unless one treats this the disease will go deeper."
Duke Huán, again, made no reply.
Biǎn Què left.
Duke Huán felt again dissatisfied.
After ten days
Biǎn Què looked at Duke Huán from the distance, turned round and ran away.
Duke Huán then sent someone to ask him about this.
Biǎn Què said:
"When the disease was in the skin surface
that could be reached by medicated liquid and by hot pressure;
when it was in the skin tissue
it could be reached by metal and stone needles;
when it was in the bowels and in the stomach,
it could be reached with boiled medicines????;
when it is in the bone and marrow
then it is a matter for the God of Fate:
there is nothing one can do.
Now it is in the bones and marrow,
and that is why I have nothing to politely suggest."
After five days
Duke Huán felt a pain in his limbs.
He sent someone to seek out Biǎn Què,
but he had already fled to Qín.
Then eventually Duke Huán died.
Thus a fine doctor, when he is treating a disease
will attack it on the surface of the skin.
These are all cases of fighting something at the stage where it is small.
Disaster and misfortune in undertakings,
also has what corresponds to the skin surface.
Therefore the sage will set to work on undertakings at an early stage of their development.
In ancient times crown prince Chóng'ěr of Jìn went into exile.
When he passed through Zhèng
the ruler of Zhèng did not treat him with proper politeness.
Shūzhān remonstrated:
"This is a crown prince of moral talent.
If you, my lord, treat him with generosity,
you can build up charismatic good will."
The ruler of Zhèng did not listen.
Shūzhān again remonstrated saying:
"If you will not treat him with generosity,
then it is best to kill him,
to make sure that there is not going to be a disaster later."
The ruler of Zhèng again did not listen.
When the crown prince returned to the country of Jìn,
he raised an army and launched a formal attack on Zhèng,
and he completely routed the state
conquering eight walled cities from them.
Duke Xiàn of Jìn used jade rings from Chuíjī
in order to get right of way from Yú and to launch a formal attack on Guō.
The grandee Gōng Zhīqí remonstrated, saying:
"This is not acceptable.
When the lips are gone the teeth will be cold.
Yú and Guō are mutually dependent for support,
but this is by no means because they are generous towards each other.
But if Jìn destroys Guō today
then tomorrow Yú is bound to follow suit and be ruined."
The ruler of Yú did not listen.
He accepted the jade rings and granted the right of way.
After Jìn had conquered Guō
they returned
and on their way back they destroyed Yú.
These two ministers were all people who
put up a struggle when the problem was on the surface of the skin
but the two rulers did not use their advice.
Thus Shūzhān and Gōng Zhīqí
are surely the Biǎn Quès of Yú and Zhèng respectively.
But the two rulers did not listen,
and therefore Zhèng was smashed,
and Yú was ruined.
Thus it says:
"In peace things are easy to keep under control,
when there are as yet no symptoms it is easy to make good plans."
In ancient times Zhòu had chopsticks made of ivory,
and Jīzǐ got frightened by this
because he considered:
"Ivory chopsticks would not be used with earthenware xíng-vessels,
but it will certainly be served in drinking bowls of rhinoceros horn and jade.
With ivory chopsticks and jade bowls
they are bound not to make broth on beans and bean-leaves.
It has to be yak, elephant or leopard foetus.
With yak, elephant and leopard foetus
they are bound not to wear short coarse clothes
and eat under attap roofs.
On the contrary they will have embroidered ninefold silk clothes,
wide dwellings, high terraces.
I am afraid of how this will end,
therefore I am deeply afraid of the beginnings."
After five years
Zhòu made a mat of flesh,
he made arrangements to roast people alive on red-hot iron rods,
he climbed his mountains of dregs
and walked up to his lake of wine,
and then Zhòu was ruined.
Thus when Jīzǐ saw the ivory chopsticks
he understood the imminent disaster for the world.
Thus it says:
"Noticing what is small is called clear-sightedness."
Gōu Jiàn became a minor employee in Wú.
In person he held the shield and the battle axe
and served as officer in charge of horse-cleaning for the King of Wú.
As a result he was able to kill Fūchāi at Gūsū.
King Wén was insulted at his royal gate,
but his facial expression did not change,
and King Wǔ captured zhòu at Mùyě.
Thus it says:
"Guarding supple weakness is called strength."
When the King of Yuè became hegemon
he did not see anything wrong with becoming a minor employee.
When King Wǔ became king he did not take exception to being insulted.
Thus it says:
"There is nothing wrong with the sage,
because he does not take exception to things
therefore he has nothing wrong with him.
A country bumpkin from Sòng found a piece of uncarved jade
and he handed it up to Zǐhǎn.
But Zǐhǎn did not accept the gift.
The country bumpkin said:
"This is a treasure.
It is suitable to serve as a tool for a gentleman
it is not suitable to be used by a slight person."
Zǐhǎn said:
"You consider the piece of jade as a treasure,
I consider it as a treasure not to accept your jade."
In this way the country bumpkin had a desire for jade
but Zǐhǎn had no desire for jade.
Thus it says:
"One's desire is not to desire
and one does not set great store by luxury items that are hard to get."
Wáng Shòu was travelling, carrying books on his back.
He met Xú Féng on a Zhōu road.
Féng said:
"As for undertakings
are things we do.
Doing arises in time.
He who understands things has no constant undertakings.
As for documents
they are words.
words arise from understanding.
He who understands does not collect books.
Now why do you travel with these things on your back?"
Then Wáng Shòu went on to burn his books and danced on them.
Thus someone who understands does not use words to talk of his teaching
and the wise person has no use for bamboo book-boxes.
This is something which everyone regards as wrong
but Wáng Shòu reverted to it.
This is to engage in the study of non-study.
Thus it says:
"Study non-study
and turn to what the hoi polloi regard as wrong."
Things have a constant moulding patterns
and so one relies on these patterns and guides them on.
So one follows the moulding patterns of things
and as a result, when inactive one is established in charismatic power,
when moving one follows the Way.
A man from Sòng made a mulberry leaf of ivory for his ruler.
After three years it was finished.
Its width and its stem??????
its fine hairs and its patterns were detailed and lush.
Were one to mix it in with mulberry leaves
it would have been indistinguishable from the others.
This man then drew stipends in the country of Sòng because of his skill.
When Lièzǐ heard about this he said:
"If Heaven and Earth took three years to finish one leaf
then few creatures would have leaves."
Thus if one does not rely on vhe resources of Heaven and Earth
but puts one's trust in one person,
if one does not follow the algebra of the Way and of principles
but studies the cleverness of one man,
these are all practices like those with the single leaf.
Thus, a grain-crop sowed in winter time
even the Divine Husbandman could not make come out beautifully.
In a rich year with a bumper grain harvest
then even Jack and Bill cannot come out badly.
If one uses one person's strength
then even the Divine Husbandman is inadequate;
if one follows the natural course of events
then even Jack and Bill have more than enough.
Thus it says:
"Rely on the natural course of the myriad things
and do not presume to take assertive action."
The apertures
are the doors and windows of the spirit and the intelligence.
Ears and eyes are exhausted by sounds and colours,
the subtle spirits are exhausted by external appearances.
That is why there is no ruler within.
When there is no ruler within
then even if disasters and good fortune are tall like mounds and mountains,
people have nowhere from which to recognise these.
Thus it says:
"Without going out through the door
one can understand all under Heaven;
without peering out of one's window
one can understand the way of Heaven."
This means that the spirit intelligence does not get separated from its real object.
Ruler Xiāng of Zhào was studying cart-racing with Wáng Zǐqī.
After a while he ran a competition with Wáng Zǐqí.
Three times he changed horses, but three times he came last.
Ruler Xiāng said:
"Are you, Sir, not finished teaching me the art of cart-racing?"
He replied politely:
"The art is already complete.
It is in its application that the mistake lies.
Generally the most important points in driving are these:
The body of the horse must be at ease with the vehicle;
the human mind must be attuned to the horses,
only then one proceed fast and reach far.
Now when you, my lord, are behind you desire to catch up with me,
and when you are ahead you are afraid that you get overtaken by me.
When you edge them on their way and struggle to reach far
you are either ahead or you are behind,
but, whether you are ahead or behind, if your mind is always set on me,
then how can your excellency get attuned to the horses?
This is why you, my lord, will come second.
Duke Shēng of Bái was plotting a political rebellion.
When he left court
he turned round his weapon and with the sharp end pierced his cheek.
Blood was reaching the ground but he never noticed.
When the people of Zhèng heard about this they said:
"If he can disregard his cheek,
what can he not disregard?"
"The further one goes out
the smaller one's knowledge."
This means that when one's knowledge ranges everywhere into the distance
then what one misses out on is close at hand.
Therefore the sage is not constantly on the move,
he is able to know by inference.
Thus it says:
"Without travelling he knows."
He is able to see by inference.
Thus it says:
"He sees nothing but is clear-sighted."
He follows the right times so as to undertake things,
he avails himself of existing resources to establish results.
He avails himself of the potential of the myriad creatures
and he gets his profit from them.
Thus it says:
"He does not take assertive action but he succeeds."
When King Zhuāng of Chǔ had led his government for three years
there was not an ordinance he issued
and there was no administration he engaged in.
The Marshal on the Right was in attendance
and he secretly told the King:
There is a bird that has settled on the hills in the southern regions.
For three years it never flapped its wings,
it has not flown, it has made no song,
all quiet, it made no sound.
What is this bird called?"
The King said:
"If in three years it never flapped its wings
that was in order to let his feathers grow.
If it never flew nor sang
it was in order to observe the rules the people obey.
He may never fly
but when he does fly he is bound to surge right up to Heaven;
even if he does not sing,
when he does sing he is bound to astonish men.
You had better set him free, Sir.
I understand this very well."
Half a year went by
and he personally attended administrative matters.
Ten things he dismissed,
nine things he took the initiative for.
He had five senior ministers executed,
and elevated six privatising freemen to high position.
As a result the country was eminently well-ordered.
He raised his army in a punitive expedition against Qí
and he defeated Qí at Xúzhōu;
he won a victory against Jìn in Héyǒng,
he assembled the feudal lords at Song,
and he ended by being the hegemon of all under Heaven.
King Zhuāng would not hurt the good cause for petty reasons,
that is why he had a great name;
he did not show his hand too early,
that is why he had big success.
Thus it says:
"A great tool is finished late,
a great tone is a rare sound."
King Zhuāng of Chǔ was inclined to launch a formal attack against Yuè.
Dùzǐ remonstrated:
"Your Majesty is launching a formal attack on Yuè,
why is that?"
He said:
"The government is in political uproar and the army is weak."
Dùzǐ said:
"Stupid as I am I consider this as disastrous.
Intelligence is like the eye.
It can see further than one hundred steps away
but it cannot see its own eyelashes.
Your Majesty's armed forces were beaten by Qín and Jìn,
you have lost a territory of several hundred square lǐ.
This is because of the weakness of your armed forces.
Zhuāng Qíqiáo was perpetrating his crimes within our borders
and the minor public order officials we unable to put stop to his activities.
This was because the government was in turmoil.
The weakness and turmoil on Your Majesty's part
is no less than that of Yuè.
and still you are inclined to launch a formal attack on Yuè.
This is because your intelligence is like the eye."
Then the King desisted.
Thus the difficulty with intelligence
is not in seeing others
it is in seeing oneself.
Thus it says:
"Seeing oneself is called enlightenment."
Zǐxià visited Zēngzǐ.
Zēngzǐ said:
"Why this sleekness?"
Zǐxià replied politely:
"I have won in battle.
Therefore the sleekness."
Zēngzǐ said:
"What does that mean?"
Zǐxià said:
"Inside I have seen the moral principles of the Former Kings,
and I found them tremendous;
outside I saw the delights of wealth and honour
and again I found these tremendous.
The two were at war in my chest,
and I was not quite sure who would win or who would lose.
So that is why I was so emaciated.
Now the moral principles of the Former Kings have won.
That is why I am so sleek."
Therefore, the problem for one's moral aspirations
is not in how win over others,
it is in winning over oneself.
Thus it says:
"Winning against oneself is called 'being strong'."
In Zhōu there was a jade tablet.
Tyrant Zhòu ordered Jiāo Gé to ask for it,
but King Wén did not give it away;
Fèi Zhòng came to to try to get it,
and the king gave it to him.
This is because Jiāo Gé had moral talent
and Fèi Zhòng did not have the Way.
The Zhōu were disinclined to have the man of talent get his will,
so therefore they gave the tablet to Fèi Zhòng.
When King Wén raised Tàigōng to high office on the banks of River Wèi
it is because he set store by him;
and when he gave Fèi Zhòng the jade tablet
this was because he was fond of him.
Thus it says:
"If one does not set store by one's teacher
and is not fond of one's resources,
then even if one is knowledgeable one is greatly misguided.
This is called the crucial mystery."
King Wǔ of Qín ordered Gān Mòu to choose which he wanted to be,
his servant or to be his agent.
Mèng Mǎo said:
"You should become his stable boy.
As for your strong point,
it is in the employment of people.
Even if you are a stable boy
the king will still give you a formal mission.
If you wear the seal of a stable boy and you act on the king's behalf
then under such circumstances you will "hold down two offices at the same time"."
Zǐyǔ visited Confucius at the Grand Steward's of Shāng/Sòng.
When Confucius had left
Zǐyǔ went in:
"May I ask about that stranger?"
The chancellor said:
"After I had seen Confucius
I looked upon you as slight like a flea.
Today I shall present him to the ruler."
Zǐyǔ was afraid that Confucius would win honour with the ruler
and so he said to the grand steward:
"Once the ruler has seen Confucius
he will also look upon you as a louse."
The grand steward accordingly refused to see Confucius again.
When King Huì of Wèi organised the contract reunion at Jiùlǐ
and wanted to reestablish the authority of the Son of Heaven,
Péngxǐ said to the ruler of Zhèng:
"Do not take his advice!
The great states dislike having a Son of Heaven
and the small states regard him as advantageous to them.
If together with the great ones you refuse to take the advice
how could Wèi together with the small ones reestablish the Son of Heaven?"
When the people of Jìn launched a formal attack against Xíng
Duke Huán of Qí was going to come to its rescue.
His minister Bàoshū said:
"This is too early.
If Xíng is not ruined
Jìn will not exhaust its strength.
If Jìn does not exhaust its strength
then Qí will not gain importance.
The achievement of supporting someone in danger
is not as good as the display of charismatic power by ensuring the survival of somebody bound for ruin.
You should save Xíng later in order to cause Jìn to exhaust its strength.
That would be the really advantageous course for Qi.
If one waits until Xíng has ceased to exist and then gives it back its existence
then that will give one an illustrious name and wealth."
As a result Duke Huán refused to save Xíng.
When Zǐxū fled
a border official arrested him.
Zǐxū said;
"When the ruler tried to arrest me
that was because I had a beautiful pearl.
Now I have already lost that pearl.
I am now going to tell him
you have taken it and swallowed it."
The official thereupon set him free.
Qìngfēng had organised a political upheaval in Qí and wanted to flee to Yuè.
A member of his clan said:
"Jìn is so close.
Why don't you go to Jìn?"
Qìngfēng said;
"Yuè is far away,
and it is more suitable to keep out of trouble."
The person from his clan said:
"If you change this atttitude of yours
staying in Jìn will be all right;
if you do not change this attitude of yours
then even if you move away as far as Yuè
can you be safe?"
The Earl of Zhì demanded territory from Xuānzǐ of Wèi
and Xuānzǐ of Wèi would not give it to him.
Rènzhāng said:
"Why didn't you give it to him?"
Xuānzǐ said:
"Without good reason he asked for territory
therefore I would not give it to him."
Rènzhāng said:
"Since he is demanding territory without reason
the neighbouring states are bound to be terrified.
If that man has weighty unsatiable ambitions
the whole world is bound to be frightened of him.
If you give him territory
then the Earl of Zhì is bound to get arrogant and to make light of his enemies
and the neighbouring states are bound to move more closely together out of fear.
If one faces an over-confident state with closely allied forces
then the Earl of Zhì will not have a long life.
The book of Zhōu says:
"if one wants to defeat someone
one must first help him;
if one wants to take from someone
one must first give to him.'
You should rather hand over the territory to make the Earl arrogant.
Moreover: why should you not, with the whole world, plot against the Earl
and why do you have to make our country a hostage to Zhì?
The ruler said:
"Very good."
And he handed over a settlement of ten thousand families.
The Earl of Zhì felt greatly satisfied
and he went on to demand territory from Zhào.
Zhào would not hand over the territory
and so the Earl besieged Jìnyáng.
Hán and Wèi revolted against him on the outside
and Zhào cooperated on the inside
so that the Zhì family was annihilated.
Duke Kāng of Qín had been building a tower platform for three years.
The people of Jīng raised an army
and wanted to use armed force to launch a pointed attack on Qí.
Rèn Wàng said:
"Famine attracts armed attacks,
acute disease attracts armed attacks,
tiredness attracts armed attacks,
political disorder attracts armed attacks.
You have built this tower (with corvee labour) for three years,
and when the Jīng now raise an army and are about to attack Qí
I am afraid their attack on Qí is for public appearances only
but in reality they are invading Qín.
We had better make preparations against this.
They garrisoned the eastern border
and the people of Jīng ceased their march.
Qí launched a formal attack on Sòng
and Sòng sent Zāng Sūnzǐ to seek help from Jīng in the south.
Jing was greatly satisfied by this request
and they agreed to come to the rescue of Sòng
and they greatly encouraged them.
Zāng Sūnzǐ returned home, worried.
His driver asked:
"You demanded support and you got it,
but now you look worried.
Why is this?"
Zāng Sūnzǐ said:
"Sòng is small and Qí is large.
To go to the rescue of little Sòng and create bad feelings with great Qí
this is something to be worried about.
The reason why the King of Jīng is pleased
is bound to be that he wants to make us firm.
If we are firmed up and Qí is weakened
that is what Jing regards as advantageous."
Then Zāng Sūnzǐ returned.
And when Qí took five walled cities from Sòng
no support was forthcoming from Jīng.
Duke Wén of Wèi asked for right of way through Zhào
in order to attack Zhōngshān
but Duke Sù of Zhào was not going to allow the request.
Zhào Kè said;
"You are wrong.
If Wèi attacks Zhōngshān and is unable to take it out
then Wèi will be exhausted.
If Wèi is exhausted then it will have little clout,
and if Wèi has little clout then Zhào will gain in influence.
If Wèi takes Zhōngshān
she will be unable to control the place from across Zhào.
Under such circumstances the one to use armed force
is Wèi
but the one to win the territory
is Zhào.
You must absolutely go along with the request.
If you accede to his request he will be greatly elated
but the man will find out that the advantages from his campaign are yours,
and he is bound to discontinue his campaign.
You had better grant him right of way
and pretend that you have no other way out."
Chīyí Zǐpí was in the service of Tián Chéngzǐ.
Tián Chéngzǐ left Qí
and on his flight he went to Yān.
Chīyí Zǐpí followed along, carrying the passport.
When they got to Wàngyì
Zǐpí said:
"Have you by any chance never heard of the snake in the dried-up swamp?
When the swamp gets dried out
the snake will move.
There was a small snake who told a big snake:
'If you go along and I shall follow you
then people will consider that we are just snakes walking along
and there is bound to be someone who kills you.
You had better take me in your mouth and walk along with me on your back
then people will think that I am a deity.'
So the large snake took the small snake in her mouth and slung her oveer his back
and in that way they crossed a public road.
People all got out of their way
and they said:
'This is a god.'
Now you are more handsome than me
and if I treat you as my honoured guest
then I will count as a ruler over a thousand war chariots;
if I take you as my emissary
then I will count as the chief minister of a ten thousand chariot state.
It will be best if you follow me as my servant."
And so Tián Chéngzǐ took the passport and followed Chīyí Zǐpí.
When they got to a guest house
the landlord treated him with great respect
and accordingly served him wine and meat.
A man from Wēn went to Zhōu
but Zhōu did not take in foreigners.
They asked him:
"Are you a foreigner?"
He replied:
"I am a native citizen.
They asked about his street neighbours, and he did not know any
so the magistrate put him into prison.
The ruler sent someone over to him to ask him:
"You are not a man from Zhōu
but you say you are not a foreigner.
How can that be?
He replied:
"When I was young I recited the ode:
'Everywhere under the sky
everything is the King's land,
Those between the sea shores
are all the King's subjects.'
Now as for the ruler
if he is the Son of Heaven,
then I must be the Son of Heaven's subject.
How can one be someone's servant or subject
and still be regarded as a foreigner.
That is why I am saying:
'I am a local citizen.'
The King ordered him to be set free.
Duke Xuān of Hán said to Jiū Liú:
"I wish I could employ both Gōngzhòng and Gōngshū.
Is that acceptable?"
He replied:
"That is not acceptable.
Jìn used six senior ministers
and the state disintegrated;
Duke Jiǎn employed both Tián Chéng and Kàn Zhǐ
and Duke Jiǎn was killed.
Wèi employed both Xī Shǒu and Zhāng Yí
and the area outside the Western River was lost.
Now if Your Majesty employ both these men
the one who has the greater power will establish cliques
and the one who has lesser power will rely on outside powers.
If among the ministers some establish cliques and are arrogant towards the ruler
and others have their connections outside and decimate the state's territory,
then your state will be in danger."
Shào Xùmèi got drunk and fell asleep, and he lost his coat.
The ruler of Sòng said:
"Does one lose one's coat just because one gets drunk?"
He replied:
"Jié lost the empire because of drunkenness
and the Kānggào says:
"Do not 'perdurably poculate'
and 'perdurably poculate' means drink constantly.
If he drinks constantly
then even a Son of Heaven will lose his empire,
and an ordinary citizen will lose his life."
Guǎnzhòng and Xípéng went along with Duke Huán
when the latter lauched a formal attack against Gūzhú.
They went out on the campaign in spring and returned in winter,
and on their way back they lost their way.
Guǎnzhòng said:
"The intellectual competence of an old horse may come in useful here."
And he set free an old horse which he then trailed
so that in the end he found the right way.
When they were marching in the mountains there was no water
and Xípéng said:
"The ants live onthe sunny southern side of the mountain
and in summer they live on the shadowy northern side of the mountain.
If there is one inch of earth with ants in it then at eight foot depth there is water.
And so they dug a well
and they did find water.
A person as extraordinarily talented as Guǎnzhòng
and a person as intellectually competent as Xípéng
when they wanted to get to what they did not know
they had no qualms about taking old horses or ants as their teachers.
Now people do not understand, with their stupid minds,
and they take the intellectual competence of the sages as their teachers.
Is that not wrong?
Someone handed up a pill of immortality to the King of Jīng.
The butler took the pill and went in.
A guard asked him:
"May this be eaten?"
He said:
"It may."
So the guard took the pill away from him and ate it.
The King flew into a rage
and he sent someone to put the guard to death.
The guard sent someone to advise the King, saying:
"I have asked the butler
and he said: "This may be eaten,
Consequently I ate it.
I am innocent,
and it is all the butler's fault.
Moreover since the stranger has handed up an immortality pill
if after I have eaten it you you kill me
then this was not an immortality pill but a mortal pill
and in that case the man has cheated you.
Now that would be to kill an innocent servant
and to make it known that someone has cheated you.
You had better let me off."
The King did not kill the man.
Tián Sì had cheated the ruler of Zòu
and the ruler of Zòu was going to send a person to kill him.
Tián Sì was terrified
and he reported the matter to Huìzǐ.
Huìzǐ went to see the ruler of Zòu and said:
"Suppose there was a person who went to see you
and he kept one eye closed.
How would you deal with him?"
The ruler said:
"I would be bound to kill him."
Huìzǐ said:
"As for being blind
that is having both eyes closed.
Why don't you kill a blind person?"
The ruler said:
"He cannot help keeping his eyes closed.
Huìzǐ said:
"Tián Sì has hoodwinked the lord of Qí
and in the south he has cheated King Jīng.
Sì's relation to cheating
is like the blind man's [to keeping his eyes closed].
Why are you so resentful of him?"
The ruler of Zòu did not in the end kill Tián Sì.
Duke Mù of Lǔ sent out his heirs,
one to serve as an official in Jìn
and the other to serve as an official in Jīng.
Lí Jū said:
"If one had to borrow a person from (distant) Yuè when trying to save a drowning son
then the man from Yuè may be a good swimmer
but the son is bound not to survive.
If when a fire has broken out and one fetches water from the sea
then although there may be a lot of water in the sea
the fire will certainly not be extinguished.
This is because water in some distant place will not help against a fire nearby.
Now Jìn and Jīng may be strong
but Qí is close at hand.
The trouble for Lǔ is that it will not be rescued.
Yán Suì was not on good terms with the ruler of Zhōu
and the ruler was concerned about this.
Féng Jǔ told the ruler of Zhōu:
"Yán Suì acts is minister
but Hán Guī has higher status with the ruler.
One should murder Hán Guī
then the ruler is bound to consider that Yān was the culprit."
Zhāng Qiǎn was prime minister in Hán.
He was ill and was about to die.
Gōngchéng Wúzhèng took along thirty cash
and paid him a visit on account of his current state of sickness.
A day went past
and the ruler asked Zhāng Qiǎn:
"If you die
whom shall we employ to replace you?"
He immediately replied:
"Wúzhèng takes the law seriously and shows fearful reverence to superiors.
None the less
Prince Shíwǒ is the better man to win over the people."
When Zhāng Qiān had died
[This story illustrates that popularity with the people is considered less important than respect for the law.]
Yuè Yáng attacked Zhōngshān as a general of Wèi
but his son was in Zhōngshān.
The ruler boiled Yuè Yáng's son
and sent him to his father in a broth.
Yuè Yáng sat down in front of his tent
and he emptied a whole bowl.
Duke Wén, addresing Dǔshī praised the man saying;
"Yuè Yáng ate the flesh of his own child for my sake."
Dǔshī replied:
"If he will even eat his son
whom will he not eat?"
Yuè Yáng relented in his siege of Zhōngshān,
and Duke Wén rewarded his achievements but was suspicious of his motives.
When Mèngsūn caught a fawn in a pleasure hunt
and he asked Qín Xībà to take it home.
The fawn's mother follwed behind, weeping.
Qín Xībā could not bear this and gave the fawn back to the mother.
When Mèngsūn got back
he went along to Qín Xībā to ask for the fawn.
He replied:
"I was not going to bear the sight and gave it back to its mother."
Mèngsūn flew into a rage
and he banished the man.
Three months passed by
and he again summoned Qín Xībā to make him his son's tutor.
His driver said:
"A little time ago you were about to accuse him of a crime,
and now you summon him as your son's tutor.
Why do you do this?"
Mèngsūn said:
"If he cannot bear the sight of the fawn suffering
can he bear the sight of my son suffering?"
So it is said;
"Breaking promises skillfully is not as good as being stupidly trusty.'
Yuèyáng was held in suspicion because he had achievements,
Qín Xībá was even more trusted as a result of his crime.
Zēng Cóngzǐ
was an expert at assessing swords.
The ruler of Wèy resented the King of Wú
and Zēng Cóngzǐ said:
"The King of Wú is fond of swords
and I am an adjudicator of swords.
May I act as an adjudicator of swords for the King of Wú
and then kill the ruler on your behalf?"
The ruler of Wèy said:
"If you do such a thing
this is not in accordance with moral principle
it would be for the sake of gaining advantage.
Wú is strong and rich,
and Wèy is weak and poor.
If you insist on going
I am afraid you will use the same dishonesty against me."
Then the ruler of Wèy chased Zēng Cóngzǐ away.
When Zhòu introduced ivory chopsticks Jīzǐ was terrified,
and considered that using ivory chopsticks
he was bound not to use plain earthenware bowls for his broth
so that he was bound to use bowls made of rhinoceros horn and jade.
In jade cups, and using ivory chopsticks
he was bound not to fill the bowls with beans and bean leaves
so that he was bound to eat embryos of long-haired buffalo, elephant and leopard.
Eating embryos of long-haired buffalo, elephant and leopard
he was bound not to wear short plain clothes
and he was bound not to spend his nights under rattan roofs
so he was bound to go clad in nine-fold embroidered clothes
and he was bound to live on high terracess and in large buildings.
If one made demands in accordance with this
then the resources of the world are not enough.
The sage notices subtle points and understands incipient signs.
He sees the beginnings and understands therefrom what they end up in.
Therefore Jīzǐ got terrified when he saw the ivory chopsticks,
and he knew that the world could not supply enough for this.
After Duke Dàn of Zhōu had won his victory over Yīn
and intended to attack Shānggài.
Duke Xīn of Jiǎ said:
"A large place is hard to attack,
and a small state is easy to subdue.
It is best to subdue many small place in order to take one large place."
Then he attacked the Nine Barbarians and Shānggài gave itself up.
Zhòu laid on a long drinking bout one long evening.
He was so happy that he forgot what day it was.
He asked his entourage
and the whole lot of them had no idea.
Then he sent someone to ask Jīzǐ.
Jīzǐ told his followers:
"When one is the ruler over the world
and everyone in the whole state forgets the date
that means that the world is probably in danger.
If the whole state does not know
and only I know what date it is
I am probably in danger."
He declined to answer on the grounds that he was unaware because of drunkenness.
A man from Lǔ was himself good at pleating sandals
and his wife was good at weaving fine gauze.
Now these two wanted to move to Yuè.
Somebody told him:
"You are bound for poverty."
The man from Lǔ said:
"Why is that?"
He said:
"Sandals are for wearing on one's feet,
but the people of Yuè walk around with bare feet;
gauze is for making hats,
but the people of Yuè keep their hair undone.
If with your specialities
you travel in a place where these are of no use,
then if you want to avoid poverty,
will you be able to?
Chén Zhěn held a high position with the King of Wèi.
Huìzǐ said:
"You must be very good at serving the King's entourage.
As for the aspen tree
if you plant it sidewise it will still grow,
if you plant it upside down it will still grow,
if you break off a branch and plant it it will still grow.
However, if you employ ten people to plant them
and one person to pull them up,
then there will be no living aspen trees.
Even when it gets to as many as ten people,
and aspen trees wich are things that are so easy to grow
these ten people cannot win against one person who pulls the trees up.
Why is this?
It is because planting the trees is relatively difficult
and removing them is relatively easy.
Although you are proficient at establishing yourself with the King
those who wish to remove you are many.
You are bound to get into a precarious position.
The Jìsūn had just assassinated their ruler in Lǔ,
and Wú Qǐ was in their service.
Someone said to Wú Qǐ:
"Now as for someone who is dead
just after he has died he has blood in him,
but in the end he is all shrivelled.
After he is shrivelled he turns to ashes,
and from ashes he turns into earth.
By the time he has turned into earth
he cannot take any initiatives any more.
Now Jìsūn is still at the initial bloody stage
and it is not so clear whether they could still turn active."
As a result, Wú Qǐ left and went to Jìn.
Xí Sīmí went to see Tián Chéngzǐ
and Tián Chéngzǐ went up on a platform with him to enjoy the view in all directions.
In three directions they had an unimpeded view.
When they looked towards the south
a tree in the home of the Xí family blocked the view.
Nonetheless Tián Chéngzǐ did not bring the matter up.
When Xízǐ had gone home
he ordered a man to fell the tree.
When the axe had cut serveral dents into the tree
Xízǐ stopped the man
and his Senior Secretary said:
"Why did you change your mind so quickly?"
Xízǐ said:
"In ancient times there was a saying:
'Knowing the fish in the deep pond spells misfortune.'
Tián Chéngzǐ plans a great undertaking,
and if I let him understand that I know his subtle motives
I am bound to be in danger.
Not to fell the trees just yet
is not quite a crime;
but to know about things before one is told about them
that is a great crime."
And then he did not fell the tree.
Yángzǐ stopped by the guest house in Eastern Sòng.
There were two concubines in the place
the uglier one was held in great honour
and the more beautiful one was accorded only humble status.
Yángzǐ asked how this was.
The old man in the guest house said:
"The beautiful one considers herself as beautiful,
but I don't see how she is so beautiful;
the uglier one considers herself as ugly
but I cannot see that she is so ugly."
Yángzǐ said to his disciples:
"When one works on one's talent
one gets rid of the attitude of considering oneself as talented,.
where will one not be admired."
A man from Wèy married off his daughter and instructed her as follows:
"Make sure that you accumulate private savings.
For a wife to be thrown out of the house
is a common thing;
for her to establish a permanent household with her husband
is a matter of good luck."
Accordingly the daughter accumulated private savings
Her mother-in-law thought she was egotistic and threw her out.
What the daughter returned home with
was twice the amount she had taken away as a dowry.
The father did not blame himself for giving the wrong instructions,
but on the contrary he understood that she had become much richer.
Nowadays ministers in the way they conduct their offices
are all like this.
Lǔ Dān attempted three times to give advice to the ruler of Zhōngshān
but his advice was not accepted.
Consequently he disembursed fifty cash to cultivate his entourage.
Then he paid another visited
and before he had even talked to him
the ruler invited him to a meal.
When Lǔ Dān left
he did not return to his place
but instead he left Zhōngshān.
his driver said:
"When you went back to visit him
the ruler was beginning to treat us well.
Why are you leaving him?"
Lǔ Dān said:
"Since he is treating me well because of what people say
he is bound to treat me as a criminal because of what people say."
Before he had even left the territory
the heir apparent maligned him and said:
