The ruler acordingly sought to detain him and accuse him of the crime.
Tián Bódǐng was fond of scholars and thereby saved his ruler,
but Duke Bái ruined Jīng/Chǔ because he loved scholars.
In their love of scholars they agreed
but their motivation was different.
Gōngsūn Yǒu cut off his own feet in order to ensure the honour of Báilǐ,
Shù Diāo castrated himself to curry favour with Duke Huán.
In their self-mutilation they were the same
but in their motivation for self-mutilation they were different.
Huìzǐ said:
"A madman may run eastward,
and his pursuers may also run eastwards.
In running eastwards they agree,
but in the motivation for running eastwards they disagree.
Therefore it is said:
When two people do the same thing
"one must investigate the matter carefully."
The man who had chosen the horse considered he had made a mistake
but the other man said:
"You have not made a mistake in judgment.
The condition of this horse is such
that it has bruised its collar bone and has swollen knees.
As for a horse that is kicking
it must lift its backside and rest on the front legs,
but the swollen knees provide no support.
That is why they cannot lift their backsides and kick.
You are good at judging the quality of horses
but you are inept when it comes to the question of 'relying on the swollen knee'."
Matters do have their basic categories under which they must be classified,
but the fact that because of a wounded knee they cannot be made to work
that is something that the competent man alone understands.
Huìzǐ said:
"If you place a monkey in a cage
he is no different from a piglet."
Thus when the external conditions are not conducive
then he has no way of showing his skill.
Wénzǐ, a general from Wèy, paid a visit to Zēngzǐ,
but Zēngzǐ did not get up and invited him to sit down
while he himself was formally ensconced in the seat of honour.
Wénzǐ told his driver:
"As for Zēngzǐ
he is a stupid man
If he considers me a gentleman
then how can he fail to show proper respect to a gentleman?
If he considers me a bully
How can one humiliate a bully?
The fact that Zēngzǐ has still not been murdered
is by the grace of fate.
Among the birds there is the zhōuzhōu,
It has a heavy head and a bent tail
and when it wants to drink in the Yellow River
it is bound to tip over.
And so the bird drinks by sucking water from from its own plumage.
When a man cannot get enough to drink
he needs to turn to his "feathers"/helpers and friends.
The eel is like a snake,
and the silk-worm is like a caterpillar.
When people see a snake
they get terrified,
and when they see a maggot
their hair stands on end.
But the fisherman catches the eel,
and the women pick up the silk-worms:
where there is profit involved
they are all like the paragons of courage Mèngbēn and Zhuānzhū.
Bólè was teaching someone he hated to judge excellent horses
and he was teaching someone whom he liked to judge bad horses.
The good horses would be sold at the rate of one in a season
and the profit was slow to come;
the poor quality horse would be sold at the rate of one per day
and the profit was fast.
This is what the Zhōushū refers to as:
"Taking ad hoc words to be of permanent use
is confused."
Huán Hào said:
"As for the way of sculpting a face
it is best, to begin with, to make the nose comparatively large
and to make the eyes comparatively small.
When the nose is too large it may be made smaller
but when it is too small it cannot be made larger.
When the eyes are too small they may be made larger,
but when they are too large they cannot be made smaller.
Undertaking actions is also like this.
If one does things which can be amended later
then one's undertakings will rarely fail.
Lord Chǒng and Èlái understood that if they did not follow Zhòu, they would be executed
but they did not realise that king Wǔ would destroy Zhòu.
Bǐgàn and Zǐxū understood that their ruler was bound to be ruined

Thus it is said:
"Chǒng and Ēlái undertood minds but not action;

The sage has all these things sorted out.

When Jìzǐ was going to visit the ruler of Sòng

Since it was raining
he took off his white coat

Yáng Bù got angry
and he wanted to strike out at the animal.
Yáng Zhū said:

"If he is able to be predictable

if he is unable to be predictable

Duke Huán asked Guǎn Zhòng:

Guǎn Zhòng replied:

so there is no more water;

Then he got two thousand liǎng of cash for it.
There are things which start out with a failure,
but that is still more intelligent than not undertaking them.
Paying the money was a case in point.

All the horsemen were envious of him.
and so he said:

He had an audience with the king
When the King acted as driver

but when the man himself drove
he did get close enough.
The King commended his driving

The prince said:
"What are you worried about, father-in-law?"
I shall smash Jìn for you!"
The father-in-law said:
"All right.

The prince said:

He said:
"It is beause I find Gōu Jiàn ridiculous.
It being so easy to deal with these people,
why did he himself have to make secret difficult plans for ten years?"
When Yáo left the empire to Xǔ Yóu
Xǔ Yóu fled from this

The relative took good care of his official leather hat.
Now when the man has refused to accept the empire

this is a case of not undertanding Xǔ Yóu.
Three lice were involved in litigation.
One louse passed by and said:
"What is the issue among the litigants?"
The three lice said:
"We dispute about a fine piece of 'land'."
The fourth louse said:
"You folks really don't worry that when the winter sacrifice comes

Thereupon they all sucked at their "mother" together
and fed on her.
The sow was all emaciated
and its human owners decided not to kill it after all.
Among the worms there is a certain huǐ tapeworm:

In their struggle to eat these two mouths bite each other

As a result they kill themselves.
When ministers fight and ruin the state

If one paints houses white
and one rinses pots and pans
then they will be clean.
Conducting one's person is also like that,
Where there is nothing to rinse and to paint white
there are few faults.
When Prince Jiū was about to stage his revolt

he looks at things without seeing them,

Gōngsūn Xǐ sent someone to break off relations with him, saying:

Gōngsūn Hóng said;

Someone else said:
"That man will soon have filled his measure of violence
You just wait a while."
He replied:
"I am scared that he will fill his measure at my cost."
and left.
Therefore it is said:
"When matters have come to a crisis point
then action is not be delayed."
Confucius told his disciples:
Who can guide Zǐxī away from his tendency to fish for fame."
Zǐgòng said:
"I can do it."
So he went ahead and guided him away from his vice
so he was no longer held in suspicion as a seeker of fame.
Zǐxī said:
"How large-hearted I am
I am not drawn in by profit.
How pure I am!
The people will be predictable in their disposition.
Then crookedness will count as crookedness

Confucius said:
"Zǐxī will not save his skin."
When Duke Bái made trouble

Thus it is said:

Zhōngháng Wénzǐ from Jìn went into exile

His followers said:

and wait for your remaining carriages?"

when I was fond of pendants

Gōng Tuō:
"That is not acceptable.

The King of Qí will certainly not support someone who is not in control in Wèi
and thereby arouse the resentment of those who are in control.
You should say:

I beg permission to see to it that Wèi will follow you.'
Then the King of Qí is bound to consider that you are in control of Wèi

Although he had the wisdom of a Guǎn Zhòng
he still relied on the help of Bào Shū.

"When a slave tries to sell his own coat he will not get it sold.
If a scholar praises his own eloquence he does not get believed."
The King of Jīng launched a formal attack against Wú
and Wú sent Jǔ Wèy and Jué Róng to offer friendly food offerings to the Jīng army
but the general said:
"Tie them up
Kill them and smear the battle drums for the attack with their blood.

did you consult the tortoise shells?"

"We did consult the tortoise shells."
"Did you get a favourable prognostication?"

"Yes, they were favourable."

it was basically to observe whether you would show anger..
If the general was angry
he would build deep moats and high ramparts
If the general was not angry
he would be all lazy.

if the general is having me killed

he had the road cleared and wanted to let him in.

and within seven months Chóu Yóu was ruined.

its crack troops are all lost.

The King of Yuè was enraged

Dignitary Zhǒng said:

Lord Wén said:

The people of Qí said:

if one's person loses the Way

Dǒng Anyú had a slow frame of mind

and to lengthen what is too short with what is too long,

There are three reliable calculations in the world:
First: there are things which one's intellect cannot achieve;

Third: there are those whom one's power cannot win against.
Thus even if one has the intellectual competence of a the sage emperor Yáo

Thus constellations are such that certain things are unobtainable

As for the techniques of peace:
The first is this:
Rewards and punishments follow right and wrong;
The second is this:
Misfortune and good fortune follow goodness or badness;
The third is this:
Death penalty or survival follow the legal system;
The fourth is this:
One takes account of talent or lack of talent, not of likes and dislikes;
The fifth is this:
One takes account of stupidity or competence, not of slander and praise;
The sixth is this:
One takes account of objective mesures not of subjective assessments;
The seventh is this:
One practises reliable good faith, not deceit.
The ways conducive to danger are as follows:
The first is this:
One cuts within the ink-line and punishes more harshly than the law prescribes;
The second is this:
One cuts off beyond the ink line and punishes what is not proscribed by law;
The third is this:
One profits from what others regard as harmful;
The fourth is this:
One delights in what others regard as disastrous;
The fifth is this:
One regards as dangerous what others find their peace in;
The sixth is this:
One does not take good care of those one loves
and one does not keep at a distance those whom one dislikes.
If one acts like this

and it did not emerge from the ruler's love or hatred.
Responsibility for glory and disgrace lay with people themselves
and it was not in others.
Thus in a generation with perfect peace
the law was invigorating like the morning dew:
it was pure and simple and undiluted.
Between the hearts of men there was no tied-up resentment/
and with their mouths they did not did not use irritated words./
As a result the cart-horses did not get exhausted on long military campaigns
the battle banners did not get mixed up in the great marshes,/
the myriad people did not lose their lives because of a foreign enemy or in military service,/
valiant men did not cut short their lives among the banners of battle. /
Heroes did not have their names inscribed on portraits and books/
and they did not have ther achievements recorded on plates and vessels,/
The wooden strips for the chronicles were all empty: there was nothing to record./
Thus it is said:
"Nothing is of more lasting advantage than plain simplicity;
nothing is more lastingly fortunate than peace.
If Stonemason Stone could spend a life-time of a thousand years wielding the hook
looking at the circle and the square
and lifting the ink-line
in order to straighten out Mount Tài,
or if Bēn and Yù took along the famous Gānjiāng sword
to bring the myriad people in line
then even if he did his very best with his skills
and even if he flourished to a very ripe age,
then Tàishān would still not be straight
and the people would still not be brought in line.
Therefore it is said:
"When the ancients shepherded the people of the world
they did not order Stonemason Stone to use all of his skill
in order to ruin the basic shape of Mount Tài,
and they did not ask Bēn and Yù to use all of their formidable authority
to damage the innate nature of the people.
If one acts according to the Way to perfect the law
then the noble will be delighted and great villainy will stop.
One will be all easy and quiet
one will adapt to the mandate of Heaven
and one will hold on to the great overall shape of things.
As a result one will cause people not to commit offenses by going against the law
and fish not to suffer the disasters which follow when they are out of water.
One acts like that
and as a result there is little in the world that is unacceptable.
If the leadership is not vast like Heaven then he will not protect everything below;
if his mind is not broad like the earth then one is not sure it can encompass things.
Tàishān does not have its likes and dislikes (of stones and earth),
therefore it is able to achieve its height.
The Yangtse River and the sea are not choosy about their small helpers
and therefore they can achieve their wealth.
Therefore the great man will entrust his physical frame to Heaven and Earth
and all things will be catered for;
his mind he will place in mountains and the sea
and his nation will be rich.
Above there will be no poison of fits of anger,
below there will be no disastrous hidden resentment.
Superiors and inferiors have straight and simple relations
and they choose the Way as their dwelling.
As a result lasting public benefits are accumulated
great achievements are realised
one's name is established by the past
and one's charismatic virtue is handed down to later generations.
that is the ultimate of good government.
No. 1 : checking and observing
If, when observing and listening one does not cross check things,
then the truth will not come to one's attention;
if one listens only through one channel
then that channel will be blocked by the relevant minister.
The explanation is in the gnome seeing the stove in a dream (.),
and Duke Ai bringing up the saying that "without the multitudes one will get lost".
And then in the man from Qí 'seeing' the Lord of the Yellow River
as well as in Huìzǐ talking about losing a half.
The ensuing disaster is as in Shù Niú starving Shūsūn to death
and in the story of Jiāng Yǐ explaining the Jīng customs.
It is in Duke Sì wanting good government but having no idea of this,
and therefore ensuring that there would be balanced opponents.
Therefore the enlighened ruler extrapolates from the piling up of iron armour
and he investigates the disaster of that market.
If one shows too much personal fondness
then the law will not prevail;
if one shows too little formidable authority
then inferiors will trespass against superiors.
Therefore when the punishments and the laws are not rigid
then prohibitions and orders are not followed.
The explanation is in the story of Dǒngzǐ travelling in Shíyì
and Zǐchǎn teaching Yóu Jí.
And so we have the stories about Confucius explaining the hail
and about the Yīn laws physically punishing the spreading of ashes
about the escort dismissing Yuè Chí,
and about Gōngsūn Yǎng imposing heave punishments for light offenses.
Therefore the gold in River Lì was not secure
and the fire in the Jī Marsh was not extinguished.
Chéng Huān considered the state of Qí as weak because of through excessive kind-heartedness,(.)
and Diviner Pí prophesised the ruin of the King of Wèi because of loving fondness and generosity.
Guǎn Zhòng understood this
and therefore he mutilated dead people;
Duke Si understood this and therefore he bought back Xū Mǐ.
If rewards and praise are slight and given out without a basis in fact
then subordinates are not fit for employment;
if rewards and praise are ample and reliable
then subordinates will easily sacrifice their lives in pursuit of them.
The explanation is in Wénzǐ speaking of people
being like wild animals and deer.
And so there is the story of the King of Yuè burning down his palace
and of Wú Qǐ setting up a slanting carriage shaft,
and of Lǐ Kuǐ deciding litigation cases through archery,
and of people in Chǒngmén in Sòng mourning themselves to death.
Gōu Jiàn understood this
and therefore he saluted the angry toad.
Duke Zhāo understood this very well,
so therefore he kept the tattered trousers.
Generous rewards will make people into Bēns and Zhūs.
That women pick up silkworms
and that fishermen catch eels,
these things can be used to demonstrate this point.
If one only listens to one party then one cannot distinguish between the stupid and the competent;
If one holds inferiors responsible for their superior's transgressions, then servants will not check their master's performance.
The explanation is in 'searching throughout Zhèng' (.) and 'blowing the flutes'. (.)
The disastrous consequences come out in the experiment by Zhào Shào and Hán Dá. (.)
Thus Prince Fàn argued for ceding Hédōng (.)
and the Lord of Ying suggested a strategy regarding relaxing on Shàngdǎng. (.)
If someone has frequent audiences but waits for a long time without getting an appointment
then the wicked will scatter like deer running away from him.
If when employing people one asks them about extraneous matters
then they will not dare to sell private favours.
Therefore Páng Jing recalled the ducal grandee, (.)
and Dài Huān gave orders to look out for the sleeper-carriage. (.)
The ruler of Zhōu deliberately lost his jade hairpin, (.)
and the Senior Steward of Shāng (Sòng) assessed the buffalo dung. (.)
If one keeps one's knowledge to oneself and asks about what one knows
then even if one is ignorant of something, one will come to know.
Once one deeply understands one thing
then a host of hidden things will change shape.
The explanation is in Lord Zhāo holding one fingernail. (.)
Thus he was sure about the South Gate, and got to know about the three other districts. (.)
The ruler of Zhōu searched for bent staffs and all the ministers got frightened. (.)
Bǔ Pi employed a commoner,(.)
and Ximén Bào pretended that he had lost the linchpin for his carriage. (.)
If one says the opposite of what one means and does the opposite of what one intends
in order to test those one is suspicious about,
then wicked basic attitudes will be disclosed.
Thus it was that the ruler of Yángshān cheated Jiāo Shù,
Nào Chi pretended there had been an official visit from Qin,
when the people of Qi started a political revolt
Zizhi used a white horse,
Zichǎn separated the litigants,
and duke Sì sent someone to pass through the custom points and markets.
In the times of Duke Líng of Wèy
Mí Zǐxiá was in favour at court
and he monopolised power in the state of Wèy.
One of the court entertainers went to see the Duke and said:
"My dream has come true!"
The Duke said;
"What did you dream?"
The gnome replied:
"In my dream I saw a stove,
and that was because I was going to see you, my Duke."
The Duke got angry and said:
"I have heard that people see their ruler and dream they see the sun,
what is this, seeing me and dreaming that you saw a stove?
The gnome replied;
"Now the sun shines on everything,
and nothing can stand in its way;
The ruler shines on the people of the whole state,
and not a single person can block him out.
That is why those who will see the ruler dream of seeing the sun.
On the other hand the stove
is something with which one person keeps warm
and the people behind him cannot see the fire.
Now perhaps one person is keeping warm in front of the ruler
so that even if I dream that I see a stove
I am surely getting things right"
Duke Ai of Lǔ asked Confucius:
"A popular saying says:
'If one does not have the support of the masses one will go astray.'
Now when I undertake something
I think about it together with all the ministers,
but the state is only getting more and more chaotic.
Why is this?"
Confucius replied:
"When an enlightened ruler consults his minister
one man will understand the matter at hand
and the the next man won't.
This being so,
the enlightened ruler is on top
and the ministers discuss things only at the lower level.
Now on the other hand all the ministers make their speeches along the lines of the Jìsūn clan.
The whole of the state of Lǔ they have transformed into a unity,
and even if you ask everyone within our borders
there is still no avoiding the political chaos."
One source says:
Yànzǐ was paying an official visit to Lǔ
and Duke Ai asked him:
"As the saying goes:
'Unless one consults with at least three people one will go astray.'
Now I have deliberated on things with the whole state
but Lǔ has not escaped from political unrest.
Why is this?"
Yànzǐ said:
"When the ancients said: 'Unless one consults with at least three people one will go astray'
they meant that one man may get things wrong
but that two will get it right.
Three people are enough to form the critical mass.
Therefore it says:
'Unless one consults with at least three people one will go astray.'
Now the public servants in the state of Lǔ are in the hundreds
but all alike they speak up for the private interests of the Jì clan.
Their number is large enough
but the person they speak for is one and the same.
How can they be as many as 'three'?"
A man of Qí said to the King of Qí:
"The Lord of the Yellow River
is a great spirit.
Why don't your majesty try to run into him?
I would like to make sure that you run into him."
And so he built an altar and an observation area on a large river
and he stood up there with the King.
After a while
a large fish was seen moving,
and so he said:
"That was the Lord of the River."
Zhāng Yí wanted to use the power of Qín, Hán and Wèi
to launch a formal attack against Qí and Jīng,
whereas Huì Shī was trying to argue for peace with Qí and Jīng.
The two men were disputing about this.
The various ministers and the entourage all spoke up for Zhāngzǐ (i.e. Zhāng Yí)
and they considered that attacking Qí and Jīng would be advantageous,
whereas no one was speaking up for Huìzǐ.
The King in the end did follow Zhāngzǐ
and he considered Huìzǐ's proposal as unacceptable.
When the matter of the attack on Qí and JJīng was already settled
Huìzǐ went in for an audience.
The King spoke and said:
"You, Sir, should not speak.
The undertaking against Qí and Jīng has in the event turned out advantageous for us.
Everyone in the whole state are all agreed that this is so."
Huìzǐ then took this opportunity to explain:
"This matter must surely be examined properly.
Now if the undertaking against Qí and Jing was really so advantageous,
and the whole state are all agreed that this is so.
how is it that the intellectually competent are so many in the country?
If on the other the undertaking against Qí and Jīng turns out to be really impossible to bring to an advantageous conclusion,
but the whole state are all agreed that it is advantageous,
how come that the stupid are so many?
In general, cases of political consultation
concern matters of doubt.
And as for doubtful things
then if they are really doubtful,
then those who consider a point of view as right are one half,
and those who consider it as wrong are the other half.
Now the whole state all consider this as right,
this means that Your Majesty has lost one half.
The kind of person who arrogates the ruler's powers
is in the nature of things the kind of person who makes him lose one such half."
When Shūsūn was prime minister in Lǔ
he enjoyed high status and was in charge of decisions.
The person he cultivated as his protege was called Shù Niú,
who likewise made unauthorised use of Shūsūn's orders.
Now Shūsūn had a son by the name of Rèn
and Shù Niú was envious of him and wanted to kill him.
With this in mind he was wandering about together with Rèn in the place where the ruler of Lǔ lived.
The ruler of Lǔ gave Rèn a jade ring
but Rèn while bowing and accepting the gift did not dare to wear it.
He sent Shù Niú to ask Shūsūn for permission.
Shù Niú cheated him saying:
I have already hasked permission on your behalf,
and they tell you to wear it."
Accordingly Rèn went on to wear the ring.
Then Shù Niú told Shūsūn:
"Why don't you provide an audience for Rèn with the ruler?"
Shù Niú said:
"Rèn has certainly already been at audiences with the ruler quite often.
The ruler of lǔ has given him a jade ring,
and Rèn is indeed already wearing it."
Shūsūn summoned Rèn
and he was indeed wearing the ring.
Shūsūn got angry and killed Rèn.
Rèn's elder brother was called Bǐng.
Shù Niú was also jealous of him and wanted to kill him.
Shūsūn cast a bell for Bǐng,
and when the bell was finished
Bǐng did not dare to strike the bell.
He sent Shù Niú to ask for permission on the matter from Shūsūn.
But Shù Niú did not ask permission on his behalf.
He moreover went on to cheat Bǐng and said:
"I have already asked about this on your behalf,
and they tell you to strike the bell."
Accordingly, Bǐng struck the bell
and when Shūsūn heard the sound he said:
"Bǐng is sounding the bell without asking permission"
Angrily he banished him from the country.
Bing left the country and fled to Qí.
After one year
Shù Niú apologised on his behalf to Shūsūn
and Shūsūn ordered Shù Niú to summon him back.
Again Shù Niú did not summon Bǐng but reported to Shūsūn, saying:
"I have alredy summoned him
and he got extremely angry.
He is unwilling to come."
Shūsūn got very angry
and he sent someone to kill Bīng.
After the two sons had died
Shūsūn got sick,
and Shù Niú nursed him back to health all by himself,
sending away all his entourage.
He did not allow people in
saying:
"Shūsūn does not want to hear the sound of people."
He did not provide him with food and starved him to death.
When Shūsūn had already died
Shù Niú then did not announce the death.
He removed the important treasures in the civil and military stores
emptied these and fled to Qí.
Now when, because one listens to words which one trusts,
one's sons as well as the father get killed,
this is the kind of trouble which arises because one does not check facts.
Jiāng Yǐ went on an official mission to Jīng (i.e. Chǔ) on behalf of the King of Wèi
and he said to the King of Jīng:
"Since I have entered Your Majesty's territory
I have heard that it is the popular custom in Your Majesty's state:
'The gentleman does not hide the excellence of others
and he does not speak of the bad points of others.'
Is that really so?"
The King said:
"That is so."
"In that case matters like the revolt of the Duke of Bái
aren't they dangerous?
If one can really get things to work like this
then public servants will be able to get away with capital crimes."
Sī, ruler of Wèy, held Rú Ěr in high regard
and he was especially fond of Shì Jī,
but he was afraid that both because of his special fondness and high regard would come to stand in his way,
and so he gave high status to Báo Yí to match the power of Rú Ér
and he honoured Wèi Jī in order to match Shì Jī
saying:
"In this way I check them against each other."
Ruler Sī was clever enough not to want to have his view blocked
but he had not yet got hold of the right method to achieve his end.
If one does not allow humble persons to publicly discuss matters concerning the noble,
but ensures that inferiors are held responsible for those crimes they denounce their superiors for,
so that one insists that they must have a balanced position of power
before they can dare to publicly discuss each other,
this is to promote even more public servants who block one's view.
At this stage the blocking of Ruler Sī's view was only just beginning.
If arrows come in from a certain direction
then one must pile up iron protection to defend against them in that one direction.
If the arrows come in from no one direction
then one builds an iron-armoured house to be protected in all directions.
If one is protected in these directions then the body does not suffer injury.
Therefore those people who take sufficient precautions do not get injured,
whereas this man, the king, taking everyone to be his competitor for power, faces no evil.
Páng Gōng was a hostage in Hándān together with the heir apparent
and he said to the King of Wèi:
"Suppose there is one man who says: "There is a tiger in the market place"
would Your Majesty believe that?"
The King said:
"I would not believe it."
"If two men say: 'There is a tiger in the market place',
would Your Majesty believe that?"
The Kings said:
"I would not believe it."
"If three people said: 'There is a tiger in the market place',
would Your Majesty believe that?"
The King said:
"I would believe it."
Páng Gōng said:
"That there is no tiger in the market place is clear enough,
and yet, when three people talk that way they create a tiger.
Now Hándān is further away from Wèi than the market place
and those who dissent from me are more than three;
I do hope Your Majesty will carefully investigate this matter."
When Páng Gōng came back from Hándān
he did not in the end get to see the King of Wèi.
Dǒng Èyú was a governor of Shàngdì in Zhào.
He went on a tour in Shíyìshān
where there was a deep gorge.
The place was steep like a wall,
and it was one hundred feet deep.
So he asked the local members of his entourage:
"Has any man ever entered this one?"
They replied:
"No one ever has."
He said:
"Babies, imbeciles, the blind, the mentally deranged:
has anyone like that ever entered this place?"
They replied:
"No one ever has."
"Buffalo, horses, dogs and pigs -
have any creatures like that ever entered this place?"
They replied:
"None ever have."
Dǒng Èyú heaved a heavy sigh and said:
"I can introduce good government here.
If I govern mercilessly offering no pardons,
so that it will be like entering the gorge and being sure to die,
then no one will dare to offend against my government.
Why should there be no good government?"
Zǐchǎn was Prime Minister in Zhèng
and he was so ill that he was close to death.
He told Yóu Jí:
"After my death
you must take over Zhèng,
and you must treat people with severity.
The appearance of fire is fiercely severe,
and therefore few people are burnt by it;
the special characteristic of water is to be weak and undangerous,
and many people drown.
You must make your appearance fiercely severe
not to let people drown in your undangerous weakness."
When Zǐchǎn died
Yóu Jí was not willing to give himself a stern appearance
and the youth of Zhèng lead each other into robbery.
They made their base in Huánzé
and from that base they were all set to cause misfortune for Zhèng.
Yóu Jí lead chariots and cavalry to battle with them,
and for one day and one night they fought.
Only then was he able to subdue them.
Yóu Jí heaved a heavy sigh and said:
"If I had practised the master's teaching earlier
I would certainly not have had to regret that things have come to this pass."
Duke Ai of Lǔ asked Confucius:
"In the records of the Spring and Autumn it says:
'In the 12th month in winter frozen dew descended but it did not harm the beans',
why was this recorded?"
Confucius replied:
"This means it could have killed them but it did not kill them.
If somebody who ought to be killed is not killed,
then peaches or pears will bear fruit in winter.
When Heaven loses its Way
then even shrubs and trees will offend against the rules that govern them,
and how much more in the case of a ruler who loses the Way"
The law of the Yīn
punished physically those who discarded ashes in the street.
Zǐgòng considered this as too hard
and he asked Confucius about the matter.
Confucius said:
"This is the way of those who understand government.
If one discards ashes in the street it will cover people in dirt.
if it covers people in dirt
people will certainly get angry,
if they get angy then they will get into fights,
if they get into fights then the three clans will ruin each other,
and this is the way to ruin the three clans.
So even meting out physical punishment in this matter is acceptable.
Moreover, heavy fines
are something that people hate,
whereas not spreading ashes in the streets
is something that people find easy.
To make people do what it is easy to do
and not to be exposed to what they hate
that is the way of good government."
An alternative source says:
According to Yīn law
those who spread ashes in public paths will have their hands cut off.
Zǐgōng said:
"The crime of discarding ashes is slight,
the punishment of cutting of a hand is severe,
why were the ancients so excessively tough."
The answer was:
"Not discarding ashes
is what people find trifling;
having a hand cut off
is what they hate.
To do what is natural and easy
and avoid what one hates
that is what the ancients regarded as natural and easy,
and therefore they did it."
Prime Minister Yuè Chí of Zhōngshān
went on a mission to Zhào with one hundred war chariots.
He selected the intellectually most competent and the ablest of his retainers
to act as a military leader on the march.
Midway, there was a mutiny.
Yuè Chí said:
"I imagined that you were intellectually competent
and engaged you to lead the march.
Now, midway, there is a mutiny.
What is this?"
The retainer took his leave and left
saying:
"You do not understand government.
One shows authority sufficient to keep people subdued,
and one provides profit sufficient to encourage them,
and as a result one is able to govern them well.
Now as for me,
I am a junior retainer of yours, mylord.
From the position of someone insignificant I have been in charge of my seniors
from the position of someone humble I have governed nobler people,
but I was not entitled to wield the handle of profit and harm
to control them.
This is why there is the mutiny.
If you had given me a charge to the effect that
the good ones of these people I can make into prime ministers,
the bad ones of these people I am entitled to have beheaded,
why should there fail to be good government?"
Gōngsūn Yǎng's laws were severe on light crimes.
Now as for heavy crimes
these are hard to commit,
but small transgressions
these are what people can easily avoid.
To cause people to get rid of what they can easily get rid of
and not to commit deeds that are hard to commit
that is the way of good government.
Now when the small transgressions do not arise
and one does not go as far as the large crimes,
under such circumstances people are without crimes and political revolts will not arise.
An alternative source says:
Gōngsūn Yǎng said:
"If in carrying out physical punishment one treats light offences severely
then the light offenses will not arise
and the heavy ones will not occur.
This is called removing physical punishments by means of physical punishments."
In the south of Jīng
in the Lì river there was found gold.
Many people were secretly collecting gold.
The prohibition against washing gold was as follows:
"When caught the guilty must always be carved up in the market place"
The offenders were very many
so that they blocked up the river
but the there was no end to people secretly washing gold.
No big crimes are heavier than those punished by public execution and dismemberment
but if still the misdeeds did not stop
this is because the perpetrators were not sure to be caught.
Therefore if there were a person
who said;
"I will give you the whole world and then kill you."
then even an ordinary person would not go in for this.
Having control over the whole world
is of great benefit to one,
but they would still not go in for this,
and this is because they know that they will die.
And similarly when culprits are not necessarily caught
then even if one publicly executes and dismembers culprits
even the secret washing of gold will not stop.
but if they know that they are bound to die
then they will not even opt for getting control over the whole world.
The people of Lǔ were burning the Jī Marsh.
A northern wind was blowing.
The fire was spreading south
and one was afraid that one would burn down the capital.
Duke Ai was scared.
In person he took command over a large expedition force to fight the fire quickly
In his entourage no one was around.
The whole lot of them had all gone off to hunt for wild animals,
and the fire was not extinguished.
Then the Duke summoned Confucius to ask his advice.
Confucius said:
"The chasing of wild animals is a social pleasure
and there are no sanctions against it;
extinguishing a fire is hard work
and there are no rewards for it.
This is why no one would extinguish the fire."
Duke Ai said:
"Good"
Confucius said:
"Since the matter is urgent,
there is no time for rewards.
If you reward the whole lot of those who would extinguish the fire
then the state does not have the resources for these rewards.
I beg to carry out only punitive sanctions."
Duke Ai said:
"Good."
Then Confucius issued and order saying:
"Those who fail to join the fire extinguishing campaign
will be deemed guilty to the same degree as deserters;
those who go on private hunts
will be deemed guilty to the same degree as trespassers in forbidden areas."
Before the law had even been spread throughout the country
the fire was already extinguished.
Chéng Huān said to the King of Qí:
"You, Your Majesty, are too kind-hearted
and you are too sensitive to the suffering of others.
The King said:
"Excessive kind-heartedness
and excessive sensitivity to others
is this not a good reputation?"
Chéng Huān said:
"This is the goodness of a minister,
it is not what a ruler of men practises.
A minister must be kind-hearted
only then can one make plans with him;
he must be sensitive to the suffering of others
only then can one be close with him.
If he is not kind-hearted one cannot make plans with him,
and his he is insensitive to the suffering of others one cannot be close with him."
The King said:
"Well then, wherein am I excessively kind-hearted,
and wherein am I sensitive to the suffering of others?"
Chéng Huān replied:
"Your Majesty is to kind-hearted to Duke Xiē,
and you are too sensitive to the suffering of others when it comes to the Tián clan.
If you are too kind-hearted to the Duke of Xiē
then your senior ministers have no political weight;
if you are to sensitive towards the sufferings of the Tián clan
then these clansmen will break the law.
When the senior ministers are not powerful
then the armed forces will be externally weak
and if the clansmen break the law
then political administration will be internally chaotic.
If the armed forces are externally weak
and political administration is internally chaotic
then that is the basis for the ruin of a state."
King Huì of Wèi told Diviner Pí:
"You have heard about my reputation
what is it like?"
He replied:
"I have heard of your loving generosity."
The King was delighted and said;
"Well then: how far did they say my achievements would go?"
He replied:
"Your achievements would lead as far as ruin."
The King said:
"I am loving and generous
and I practise goodness.
And by practising these things I am headed for ruin.
How can that be?"
Diviner Pí replied:
"Loving concern consists in being unable to bear other people's suffering,
and generosity is the inclination to give things away.
If one cannot bear suffering
then one will not punish trespassers;
and if one is fond of giving things away
then one will dole out rewards to those who have no achievements.
If trespassers are not accused of their crimes
and if people without achievements receive their rewards
then even if one's state is ruined
isn't that only right and proper?"
In the state of Qí people were in the habit of making elaborate funerals:
cloth and silk were all used on inner and outer funeral garments,
timber was all used for inner and outer coffins.
Duke Huán was irritated at this
and he told Guǎn Zhòng:
"If all the cloth and the silk is used up we have nothing to cover us with;
if all the timber is used up we have nothing to build our defenses with.
But people keep burying their folks elaborately.
How about banning this practice?"
Guǎn Zhòng replied:
"As for the purpose of all human action,
if it is not for the sake of fame
it is for the sake of benefit."
Then he issued an ordinance saying:
"If inner and outer coffins are beyond the standard size
the corpse is to be maimed
and the person in charge of the funeral is to be held criminally responsible."
If one cuts up a dead person,
that person is without fame or name;
if one holds the person in charge of the funeral criminally responsible
then there is no benefit in large funerals.
Why should people persevere in the practice?
During the times of ruler Sī of Wèy
there was a certain Xū Mǐ who fled to Wèi.
and there he served as a doctor to King Xiāng's Queen.
When ruler Sī of Wèy heard about this
he sent someone to hire him back for fifty cash (to be able to punish him).
Five times he returned on this errand but the King of Wèi did not give Xū Mǐ up,
Then in the end he struck a barter bargain for the man in exchange for the town of Zuǒshì.
The ministers and his entourage remonstrated saying:
"To buy Xū Mǐ at the price of a whole city?"
is that right and proper?"
The King said:
"This is not something you gentlemen understand.
If in matters of government nothing is too small to attend to
then political turmoil will never be great.
If the laws are not established and punishments are not inevitable,
then having ten towns of Zuǒshì would not help.
If laws are well established and punishments are inevitable
then it will not matter even if one loses ten towns of Zuǒshì."
When the King of Wèi heard about this he said:
"If as a ruler one wants to run the government well but one does not listen to him
then that is inauspicious."
And so he loaded Xū Mǐ into a carriage and went on his way (to Wèy),
and there he handed up Xū Mǐ without demanding any recompense.
The King of Qí asked Wénzǐ:
"How does one go about governing a state?"
Wénzǐ replied:
"Now it is in the nature of rewards and sanctions
that they are sharp weapons.
The ruler keeps a firm grip on them,
and he must not show them to other people.
Now people like the ministers
are like wild animals and deer:
they only go after the fodder or lush grass."
The King of Yuè consulted Dignitary Wén Zhǒng:
"I would like to attack Wú.
Is that right and proper?"
He replied:
"That is right and proper.
Our rewards are heavy and reliable
our punishments are strict and predictable.
If you want to be sure,
why don't you try setting fire to your palaces?"
And so the King did indeed set fire to his palace.
No one extinguished the fire.
Then he issued an ordinance:
"Those who die in fighting the fire
will be rewarded like those who die in battle fighting the enemy;
those who fight the fire and do not die in the process
will be rewarded like soldiers who have been victorious over the enemy;
those who do not fight the fire
will be held guilty of the crime of desertion in battle."
Those who smeared their bodies with protective substances
put on wet clothes and ran towards the conflagration
were three thousand on the left among the civilians
and three thousand on the right among the military.
In this way he made sure the constellation was one bound to lead to victory.
Wú Qǐ acted as governor for Lord Wǔ of Wèi.
Qín had a small fortified observation post close to the border
and Wú Qǐ wanted to attack this observation post.
If one did not get rid of it
then that would do great damage to the hunting in the area;
but in order to get rid of it
he did not have enough resources to assemble an armed fource.
Then he set up a slanting carriage shaft outside the North Gate
and he issued an ordinance saying:
"As for the person who is able to shunt this thing outside the South Gate
I will give him the best fields and the best house available."
But no one moved the thing.
When at last someone did move the thing
he made presents in return according to the ordianance.
After a while he placed one picul of red beans outside the East Gate
and he made an ordinance saying:
If there is someone who can move this outside the West Gate
he will be rewarded as in the previous case."
People were competing with each other to remove the beans.
Then he issued an ordinance saying:
"Tomorrow we are about to attack the fortified observation post.
The person who gets up there first
will be appointed as a state dignitary,
and he will be rewarded with the best fields and housing available."
People were competing to get to the place first.
Then he attacked the fortified observation post
and he took it out in the course of one morning.
Lǐ Kuī was governor of Shàngdì for Lord Wén of Wèi
and he wanted people to become good archers.
So he issued an ordinance saying:
"When people are engaged in doubtful litigation
we will order them to shoot arrows at a target.
The person who hits the target will win
and the person who does not hit the target will lose."
When the ordinance had been issued everyone was eager to learn archery
and they would not stop day or night.
When he fought a battle with Qín
he greatly defeated that country.
And the reason was that the people were so good at archery.
Someone from the small lanes of Chǒngmén in Sòng was in mourning
and he maltreated himself so much that he became exceedingly thin.
His ruler considered him as a model of loving care for his parents
and raised him to the public position of a teacher.
The following years
the people who maltreated themselves with lethal results
were over ten every year.
When children conduct mourning for their parents
this is because they feel affection for them
but still they can be made to do more through rewards
How much more can this be done in the case of the relation of the ruler to his people.
The King of Yuè was considering an attack on Wú
and he wanted his people not to be afraid to die.
When on an outing he saw an angry toad and he saluted the creature from his carriage.
An attendant asked:
"Why show such respect to this creature?"
The King said:
"That is because it has fighting spirit."
During the next years those who begged to offer up their heads to the King
were more than ten per year.
From this point of view
if one praises someone that it is sufficient to make him risk his life.
An alternative source says:
King Gōu Jiàn saw an angry frog and saluted it from his carriage.
The driver said:
"Why are you saluting him?"
The King said:
"Since this frog shows such fighting spirit,
can one fail to salute him from the carriage?"
When his officers heard this they said:
"Even a frog, if it has fighting spirit
the King will still salute it from the carriage.
How much more will he salute an officer who has courage"
During this year
there were those who beheaded themselves to offer their heads to the King.
Then the King of Yuè, when take revenge on Wú
he tested this teaching.
He burnt down his terrace and beat the drums
the reason why he could make the people rush to the fire
was that rewards were linked to the fire.
When he got close to the Yangtse River he beat the drums
and the reason why he made people hasten to the water
was because the rewards were linked to the water.
When approaching a battle, what makes people have their heads cut off,
what makes them slit open their stomachs without compunction
is that rewards are linked to the use of arms.
How much more will this be so if one promotes the talented on the basis of the law.
The encouragement will be even stronger than this.
Lord Zhāo of Hán ordered people to store up his worn-out trousers.
An attendant said:
"Surely you are not kind.
The worn-out trousers you are not giving to your entourage,
but you have them stored up."
Lord Zhāo said:
"This is not something you understand.
I have learnt that when the enlightened ruler is sparing with his every frown and his every smile.
When he frowns he has a reason for frowning,
and if he smiles he has a reason for smiling.
Now trousers
are surely not just frowns and smiles.
Trousers are very different form frowns and smiles.
I am bound to wait for someone with achievements to his credit,
so that is why I store them up and do not give them away."
An eel looks like a snake
and a silkworm looks like a moth.
When men see a snake they are terrified
and when they see a moth their hair stands on end;
And yet, women collect silkworms
and fishermen catch eels with their hands:
where things are linked to profit
they forget what they hate
and they all become Mèng Bēns.
The King of Wèi said to the King of Zhèng;
"Originally Zhèng and Liáng were one state
but after a long while they were separated.
Now I wish I could get Zhèng again to have it united to Liáng."
The ruler of Zhèng was distressed about this:
He summoned his ministers
and together with them he discussed how one should respond to Wèi.
A prince told the ruler of Zhèng:
"This is very easy to deal with.
You should ssubmit politely to Wèi:
'Since Zhèng originally was Wèi and the two should be united
then I hope my humble town may be able to integrate Liáng into Zhèng
and integrate her into Zhèng.'
When approached in this way the King of Wèi desisted.
King Xuān of Qí asked people to play the reed organ,
and he definitely needed three hundred men.
A recluse from the southern suburb area asked to blow the yú-flute for the King.
King Xuān was greatly satisfied with his offer.
He fed him with granary contributions from several hundred people.
When King Xuān died
King Mín ascended the throne
and he was fond of listening to the players one by one.
At this point the recluse absconded.
An alternative account runs like this:
Lord Zhāo of Hán said:
"Those who play the yú-flute are many,
I have no way of telling which are the best ones."
Tián Yán said:
"You should listen to them one by one."
Zhào ordered someone to request military forces from Hán through Shēnzǐ
and wanted to attack Wèi with these.
Shēnzǐ wanted to make a proposal on this to the ruler
but he feared that the ruler was suspicious that he would enter improper deals with outsiders;
and if he did not speak up he feared he would incur the hatred of Zhào.
So he ordered Zhào Shào and Hán Dá
to sound out the ruler's behaviour
before he made his formal proposal.
Within his state he would then understand the intentions of Lord Zhāo of Hán,
and outside he would manage to come up with contributions for Zhào.
The armies of the three states (Hán, Wèi and Qí) arrived at the Hán pass (for an attack on Qín)
the King of Qín siad to Lóu Huǎn:
"The armed forces of the three states have already penetrated deep
I want to cut out and cede the Hédōng area and sue for peace.
What do you think?"
He replied:
"To cut out and cede Hédōng
is a great waste of resources.
On the other hand to keep disaster away from the state
is a great achievement.
All this is the responsibility of the whole clan.
Why doesn't Your Majesty summon Prince Fàn
and consult him?"
The King summoned Prince Fàn and told him about the situation,
and Zǐfàn replied:
"If you sue for peace you will regret this,
and if you do not sue for peace you will also regret this.
If you know cut out Hédōng and cede it to sue for peace
then the three states will return home
and your Majesty will certainly say:
'The three states were certainly going to leave anyway,
and I have simply given them three cities to send them off.'
If you do not sue for peace
as for the three states, if they have already entered the pass
then they will certainly win a big victory
and Your Majesty will certainly will greatly regret his course of action.
Your Majesty will say:
'It is all because I did not hand up those three cities.'
Therefore I conclude:
'If your Majesty sues for peace you will regret it,
and if your Majesty does not sue for peace you will also regret it.'
The King said:
"If I am going to have regrets
I would rather lose three cities and regret,
I shall most certainly sue for peace."
The Lord of Yīng told the King of Qín:
Your Majesty has gained Wǎn, Yè, Lántiān and Yángxià
you have cut off Hénèi
and you have caused trouble for Liáng and Zhèng.
The reason why you still are not king
is that Zhào has not yet submitted.
If you relax about our Shàngdǎng that is only one local detail,
and if you then move towards Dōngyáng
then Hándān will be like a flea in your mouth.
Effortlessly and with folded hands you can receive the world in your court.
Those who are latest in showing their respect you strike with military force.
However, Shàngdǎng may be a peaceful and pleasant place,
the place is very significant.
I fear that the suggestion to relinquish it will not be followed.
What to do?"
The King said:
"I shall certainly relinquish Shàngdǎng and change the direction of my efforts."
Páng Jìng
was in charge of a province.
He sent the supervisor of the markets on a tour of inspection
and then he sent the senior inspector of the markets to get him to come back.
He stood for a while
and had no instructions to give to the man.
In the end he sent him out again on his tour of inspection.
The inspector considered that the senior inspector and the head of the provice had something to tell him
but that they had no faith in him,
and so he reached the point where he behaved impeccably without wickedness.
Dài Huān
was the grand steward of Sòng.
At night he told someone, by way of instruction:
"I have heard the last few nights there was someone riding a sleeping carriage who arrived at the gate of Archivist Lǐ.
You better keep a good eye on this for me."
The employee said:
"I have not seen any sleeping carriage.
I did see someone offering up a basket and talking to Archivist Lǐ.
After a while
Archivist Lǐ accepted the bamboo basket."
The ruler of Zhōu had lost his jade hairpin
and he ordered a minor official to look for it.
For three days he was unable to find the thing.
The ruler of Zhōu asked someone else to look for it,
and he found it between relatives' houses (where the ruler had planted it).
The ruler of Zhōu said:
"This is all because my minor officials are not doing their job.
When he looked for the hairpin
he could not find it for three days.
When I asked someone else to look for it
before the day was out he had found it."
At that point the minor officials all got thoroughly frightened
and they considered that their ruler had superb insight.
The grand steward of Shāng sent a young child by a concubine to go to the market.
When that young man returned he asked him:
"What did you see in the marketplace."
He replied:
"I noticed nothing."
The Prime Minister said:
"Very well.
But what DID you see?"
He replied:
"Outside the South Gate of the market there are a lot of buffalo carts,
one can only barely get through."
Then the Prime Minister warned the man he had sent out:
"Don't you dare tell anybody what I have asked you about"
Then he summoned the minor officers in the market and blamed them publicly:
" Why are there so many buffalo turds outside the market gate?"
The minor officials of the market were truly amazed that the Prime Minister knew so fast about these things
and so they fretted and feared in their places.
Lord Zhāo of Hán was [secretly] holding his fingernail in his hand
but he pretended that he had lost a fingernail.
He was looking for it very urgently.
Someone from his entourage cut off his fingernail and handed it up.
In this way Lord Zhāo investigated whether his entourage was earnest or not.
Lord Zhāo of Hán sent a horseman on a surveillance mission to a province.
The emissary reported back
and Lord Zhāo asked him:
"What did you notice?"
He replied:
"I didn't notice anything"
Duke Zhāo said;
"Even so:
what did you notice?"
He said:
"Outside the South Gate
brown buffalo calves are eating sprouts on the left of the roadside."
Lord Zhāo told his emissary:
"Don't you dare leak out what I asked you about"
Then he issued an ordinance:
"When the grain sprouts come out
there certainly is an ordinance forbidding buffalo and horses entering fields
but the minor officials do not care about this
and quite a number of buffalo and horses have entered the fields.
Quickly report to the authorities the number of offending animals.
Those who do not manage to report
will be charged with heavy crimes."
Then from three directions the reports came in
and Lord Zhāo said:
"That is still not all"
Then he went out to conduct an investigation of the matter
and he found the brown buffalo calves outside the South Gate.
The minor officials thought Lord Zhāo was astute.
They all fretted and feared for their positions
and did not dare to commit evil.
The ruler of Zhōu sent out an ordinance ordering people to look for bent walking canes
and the minor officials had been looking for such things for several days
but were unable to find any.
The ruler of Zhōu sent someone out privately
and before the day was out that man had found a bent walking cane.
Then the ruler told his executive officials:
"I can see that the executive officials are not working hard.
Bent walking canes are very easy to find
but the executive officials are unable to find them.
When I sent out someone to look for them
before the sun was down he had found some.
How would it be right and proper to say that such people have done their loyal best?"
Then the minor officials all fretted and feared for their positions
and they thought the ruler had superb supernatural insight.
Bǔ Pǐ was the commander of a district.
His chief surveillance officer was very vulgar and was fond of a concubine.
Diviner Bǔ then ordered a young boy to pretend to fall in love with her
to find out about the chief surveillance officer's secret feelings.
When Xīmén Bào was in charge of Yè
he pretended that he had lost the linchpin of his carriage.
He sent a minor official to look for it, but that man was unable to find it.
Then he sent someone else to look for it
and he found among the houses of members of his own household.
The ruler of Yángshān was serving as Prime Minister in Wèy
and he heard that the King was suspicious of him.
So he pretended to slander Jiāo Shù in order to ascertain the facts.
Zhuō Chǐ heard that the King of Qí hated him
and he faked an order to send an envoy from Qín to ascertain the facts.
In Qí there was someone who was preparing to start a revolt
and he was afraid that the King might find out about this.
So, with the intention to deceive, he chased away his lover
and caused her to seek refuge with the King of Qí and ascertain the facts.
Zǐzhī was Prime Minister in Yān
and when sitting inside he said with deliberate deceit:
"What was this that disappeared through the door?
Was it a white horse?"
The entourage all said they had not seen it.
There was one man who ran out to chase after the creature.
He reported back:
"It was indeed a white horse."
On the basis of this Zǐzhī knéw that his entourage was not truly reliable.
There were two people who were engaged in litigation.
Zǐchǎn separated them from each other
and did not allow them to talk to each other.
He told each of them the opposite of what the other thought
and ascertained the facts of the case.
Duke Si of Wèy sent someone to visit a border market posing as a traveller
and the border market supervisor made serious trouble for him.
Then he gave the supervisor gifts in cash
and the border official set him free.
Duke Si told the pass official:
"At such-and-such a time there was a traveller who passed through your place
He gave you some cash
and as a result you sent him on his way."
The pass official was terrified,
and he considered Duke Si as singularly astute.

div.head: 31 內儲說下六微第三十一

p.seg: Lending power away
One's position of power should not be lent out to others
When the person in charge loses one bit of these
the ministers turn it into one hundred.
Thus when the ministers get to loan powers
then their influence increases.
When their influence increases
then in court and outside they pursue their own interests;
if in court and outside they pursue their own interests
then the ruler's clear view is blocked.
The explanation is in Lǎo Dān's speaking of the fish out of its element.
Thus when the ruler has long conversations with his inferiors
then his entourage will trade on this and "give away hair-brushes".
The disastrous consequences show in Xū Tóng remonstrating with Duke Li,
and the unanimous comments on Lord Zhōu
as well as the man of Yān washing himself in shit.
CONTRASTING INTERESTS
The interests of the ruler and the ministers are divergent.
It follows that the ministers are never loyal.
It follows again that as the interests of the minister are served
the interests of the ruler are destroyed.
Therefore vicious ministers
will call in enemy military forces in order to remove competitors within
and they will engage in projects abroad in order to blind the eyes of the ruler
As long as they achieve their private advantages
they disregard disaster for the state as a whole.
The explanation is in the wife and husband from Wèy praying for a lucky long life. (.)
Thus Dài Xiē argued about the children and brothers, (.)
and the Three Huán attacked Duke Zhāo. (.)
Gōngshū let in the Qí army (.)
and Di Huáng called in the Hán troops. (.)
Prime Minister Pi persuaded Dignitary Zhǒng (.)
and Dà Chéngniú taught Shēn Bùhǎi a lesson. (.)
Simǎ Xi made a report to the king of Zhào, (.)
Lǚ Cāng admonished the states of Qin and Chǔ, (.)
Sòng Shi gave the ruler of Wèy a book (.)
and Bái Gui gave instruction to Bào Qiǎn. (.)
SIMILARITIES
As for similarity between things
this is the reason why the ruler makes mistakes in punishing
and why senior ministers achieve their private ends.
Therefore the gate-man poured out water and Yi Shè was executed. (.)
The ruler of Jiyáng faked an order and two men were accused. (.)
Simǎ Xi killed Yuán Qiān and Jì Xīn was executed. (.)
Zhèng Xiù mentioned ugly smells and the new one had her nose amputated. (.)
Fèi Wúji taught Xi Yuān and the minister in charge punished him. (.)
Chén Xū killed Zhāng Shòu and Rhino Head fled. (.)
Thus they burnt Chú Kuai and Zhōngshān laid charges. (30.31)
They killed the old scholar and Jìyáng made rewards. (30.32)
CONTRARIETIES
When something is being undertaken that is in some way beneficial
one presides over it ritually, like an impersonator of the dead.
When something is in some way harmful
then one must be sure to get to the bottom of the contrary possibilities
The enlightened ruler, in judging things,
when these are harmful to the state will investigate whom they benefit,
when these are harmful to a minister will investigate who gets the opposite effect.
The explanation is in the Chǔ army arriving and Chén Xū acting as prime minister, (.)
The broomcorn millet seeds are expensive and the granary executive officer was investigated. (.)
Thus Zhāo Xixù arrested the man who sold reeds (.)
and Lord Xi berated the second in command. (.)
Duke Wén used hair to tie round the roast (.)
and Lord Xiāng asked to establish people as emperors. (.)
Deciding uncertain constellations of power
is a source of political unrest.
Therefore the enlightened ruler pays careful attention to these.
Thus Li Ji of Jin killed the heir Shēn Shēng [.]
and the lady from Zhèng used poison. [.]
Zhōuxū from Wèy killed his ruler Wǎn, [.]
Prince Gēn took Eastern Zhōu,[.]
Prince Zhi enjoyed great favour
and Shāng Chén in the end started a political revolt. [.]
Yán Sui and Hán Wěi were struggling
and Duke Ai in the end was exposed to villains. [.]
Tián Cháng, Hān Zhi, [.] Dài Huān and Huáng Xi were enemies [.]
and the ruler of Sòng as well as Duke Jiǎn were killed.
The explanation is in Hútū praising the two predilections, [.]
and Zhāo of Zhèng replying that it was a case of not being born.[.]
Dismissal and appointment is the enemy's main concern
the point is in making the one's judgment wanton and in bringing about chaos.
When the ruler does not investgate this properly
then the enemy will take over the removal and establishment of candidates.
Thus King Wén regarded Fèi Zhòng as suitable material, [.]
and the King of Qin was concerned about the emissary from Chǔ. [.]
Li Jū left Confucius [.]
and Gān Xiàng stood in the way of Gān Mào. [.]
Thus Zixū made his pronouncement and Zicháng was employed; [.]
someone took in the beauties and Yú and Guó were ruined; [.]
someone sent a false letter and Cháng Hóng died; [.]
cocks and boar were sacrificed and the nobles of Kuài were finished. [.]
Matters like deciding doubtful cases, dismissing and appointing people,
these are things which the enlightened ruler decides inside
and he implements his decisions outside.
Supporting those with little power
and supplementing the resources of those who are weak,
this is called launching one's "attacks from the temple".
If when one's calculations have been carried out inside
one then proceeds to observing and listening to what is outside,
the fraudulent acts of one's enemies will be found out.
The explanation of this is in the gnome from Qin reporting to Duke Huiwén. [.]
Thus it is that Xiāng Ci reported the planned secret attack on Yè, [.]
and Duke Si conferred a ceremonial mat on the commander. [.]
A strong position of power
is the ruler of men's deep pool;
the ruler
is a fish living in the medium of power.
Once fish have slip away from their deep pond
it is impossible to recover it.
Once the ruler loses the preponderance of power to his ministers
then that preponderance cannot be regained.
The men of old found it hard to express their ideas directly
so therefore they entrusted their meaning to [comparisons with] fish.
Rewards and punishments
are sharp weapons.
When the ruler uses them he will control the ministers with them.
when the ministers get hold of them they will block the ruler.
Therefore if the ruler divulges early whom he will reward
then the ministers will offer the ruler's reward as their own personal generosity.
If the ruler divulges early whom he will punish
then the ministers will offer the ruler's punishments as signs of their own authority.
Therefore it is said:
"The sharp instruments of the state
one must not show to others."
The ruler of Qīngguō was Prime Minister in Qí.
When he had talked for a long time with any old friends
then it turned out these old friends became rich;
when he stuck a brush into the breast-pocket of one of his entourage
that member of the entourage would become important.
Having a long conversation with someone or putting a brush into someone's breast-pocket
these are small friendly acts,
and yet one can get rich through them.
How much more in the case of political power left with minor officials
At the time of Duke Lì of Jìn
the Six Senior Ministers enjoyed high status.
Xú Tóng and Cháng Yújiǎo remonstrated, saying:
"The senior ministers enjoy high status and are powerful.
The rulers of opposing states are all competing to serve them.
They enter illicit deals with outsiders, and they establish cliques.
When at a lower level one confuses the laws of the land,
and at the higher level the ruler's position is usurped,
then for the state not to be in a precarious position
that has never happened."
The Duke said:
"Good"
Then he executed three of the Six Senior Ministers.
Xú Tóng and Cháng Yújiǎo
"If when it comes to people who have committed the same crime
one punishes only some and not the whole lot of them
then they will harbour resentment and use the opportunity to sow discord"
The Duke said:
"In one morning I have destroyed three Senior Ministers,
I cannot bear to kill them all."
Cháng Yújiǎo replied:
"If you cannot bear to do things
then they will be able to bear to do things to you."
The Duke did not listen.
After three months
the Senior Ministers staged a revolt
they did indeed kill Duke Lì and they divided up his territory.
The Lord of Zhōu was Prime Minister in Jīng.
He enjoyed high status and he was in charge of decisions of state.
The King of Jīng was suspicious of him
so he asked his entourage
and they all replied:
"There is no problem."
It was as if this reply came from one mouth.
A man from Yān was perfectly sane
but he did wash in dog's shit.
This man from Yān
had a wife who was having a priate affair with an officer.
When the husband returned early from the outside
this officer happened to leave the house.
The husband said:
"What stranger is this?"
His wife said:
"There was no stranger."
He asked his senior employees,
and the senior employees all said: "There was no such thing",
and it was as if this reply came from one mouth.
The wife said:
"You do rather easily go off your mind."
And so they washed him in dog's shit.
An alternative source says:
Lǐ Jì, a man from Yān, liked to go on distant trips
and his wife was having a private affair with an officer.
When Jì arrived
that officer was in the inner chambers.
The wife panicked.
Her chambermaid said:
"Order the young man to let down his hair [in order to look like a ghost]
and to go straight out to the door.
We will all pretend that we did not see him."
Then the young man followed the plan
Very fast he ran out through the gate.
Jì said:
"Who was this?"
The attendants in the house said:
"There was nothing."
Jì said:
"Have I seen a ghost?"
The wife said:
"You must have."
"What shall we do about this?"
He said:
"Take the shit of the five domestic animals and bathe in it"
Jì said:
"Yes"
Then he bathed in shit.
An alternative source says that he bathed in orchid soup.
In Wèy a husband and wife were praying
and their incantation went as follows:
"May we have no problems
and may we get one hundred rolls of cloth."
The husband said:
"Why so little?"
She replied:
"If you get more than that sort of thing
you will go and use this to buy a concubine."
The King of Jīng wanted to see his princes employed in the neighbouring states.
Dài Xiē said:
"That is not acceptable."
"But if I have the princes employed in the neighbouring states
then the neighbouring states will make them powerful."
Dài Xiē said:
"If your sons go out they will become powerful,
and if they are powerful
then they will create the powerful faction in the state,
so such an action would be to teach your sons to enter improper deals with outsiders.
This is not to be recommended.
The Mèngsūn, Shūsūn and Jìsūn clans in Lǔ
were combining forces to wrest power from Duke Zhāo
they took away his state and they took illegal control.
When in Lǔ the three Huáns exerted pressure on the Duke of Lǔ
Duke Zhāo attacked the Jìsūn
but the Mèngsūn and the Shūsūn consulted together:
"Shall we go to their rescue?"
A driver of the Shūsūn said:
"As for me
I am a family employee.
how should I know anything about the house of the Duke?
Generally speaking, when it comes to the existence or non-existence of the Jìsūn
which is more advantageous to us?"
They all said:
"Without the Jìsūn there certainly will be no Shūsūn."
"Well, then, one should rescue them."
Then they broke in through the north-western corner
and when the Mèngsūn saw the banner of the Shūsūn enter
they also went to Jìsūn's rescue.
When the three Huáns were united
Duke Zhāo could not win against them.
They ousted him
and he died at Qiānhóu.
Gōngshū was Prime Minister in Hán and he once attacked Qí.
Gōngzhòng was regarded as very important by the King.
Gōngshū was afraid that the King would make Gōngzhòng prime minister
and he caused Qí and Hán to agree to launch an a attack on Wèi.
On this occasion Gōngshū introduced Qí forces into Zhèng city
in order to arrogate the ruler's power,
to confirm his position
and in order to reaffirm the contract between the two states.
Zhái Huáng
was a minister to the King of Wèi
and he had good relations with Hán.
Then he called in the Hán forces and got them to attack Wèi
whereupon he asked to get in touch with Hán on behalf of Wèi
in order to strengthen his own political influence.
The King of Yuè was attacking the King of Wú
and the King of Wú sent his apologies and declared his submission to Yuè.
The King of Yuè wanted to accept the apology.
Fàn Lǐ and Dignitary Zhǒng said:
"This is not right and proper.
In the past Heaven has given Yuè to Wú
but Wú has not accepted.
Now Heaven is opposing Fūchái,
and that is surely a Heaven-sent disaster.
When Heaven hands over Wú to Yuè
one should bow twice and accept the offer.
It is not right and proper to accept the apology."
Prime Minister Pǐ sent a letter to Dignitary Zhǒng saying:
"When the wily hares are eaten up then the good hunting dogs are broiled.
When the enemy state is ruined then the advising ministers lose their positions.
Why don't you, Sir, let Wú go free and be a lasting problem for Yuè?"
Grandee Zhǒng received the letter and read it.
He heaved a heavy sigh and said:
"Kill the messenger.
My fate is tied to that of Yuè."
Dàchéng Niú was siding with Zhào and told Shēn Bùhài in Hán:
"Using Hán, you give me political influence in Zhào
and using Zhào I beg to give you political influence in Hán.
In such a way you have two Háns
and I have two Zhàos."
Sīmǎ Xǐ
was a minister to the ruler of Zhōngshān,
and he had good relations to Zhào.
On one occasion he secretly told the King of Zhào about Zhōngshān's plans.
Lǚ Cāng
was a minister to the King of Wèi
and he was on good terms with Qín as well as Jīng (i.e. Chǔ).
He passed on secret criticism to Qín and Jīng
and got them to attack Wèi.
Then he asked to go there on a mission of peace to build up his political influence.
Sòng Shí
was a general in Wèi.
The ruler of Wèy
served as a general for Jīng.
When there was trouble between the two states
these two gentlemen both served as commanding generals.
Sòng Shí sent a letter to the ruler of Wèy:
"When the two armies are pitched against each other,
when the two banners as facing each other
do not join battle.
If you join battle one party is bound to lose.
This is a matter between the two rulers.
I have no personal resentment towards you.
Since we are on good terms, let us avoid joining battle."
Bái Guī was Prime Minister in Wèi
and Bào Qiǎn was Prime Minister in Hán.
Bái Guī told Bào Qiǎn:
"Through Hán you support me here in Wèi
and through Wèi I shall be guarding your interests in Hán,
and that way I shall have permanent control of Wèi
while you have permanent control of Hán."
Among the Middle Rank Grandees in Qí there was a certain Yí Shè
who provided the drinks for the King.
Terribly drunk he left
and he was leaning against the gate leading to the corridor.
The gatekeeper, a criminal who had had his feet amputated asked:
"Your honour wouldn't by any chance feel like donating to me some left-over dregs of wine?"
Yí Shè shooed him away and said:
"Away with you
A mutilated prisoner,
what business do you have to presume to beg for a drink from a senior."
The criminal with mutilated feet withdrew in a hurry.
When Yí Shè left
the criminal with mutilated feet was pouring away water in the drain by the gate leading to the corridor
as if someone had been urinating there.
The next day
the King went out and started swearing at him
saying:
"Who has been urinating here?"
The mutilated criminal said:
"I did not notice anyone.
However, yesterday Middle Grandee Yí Shè was hanging around here."
Then the King punished Yí Shè and had him killed.
Two ministers of the King of Wèi were not on friendly terms with the ruler of Jìyáng.
The ruler of Jìyáng then fraudulently sent out a man
to fake a royal order and to plot an attack against himself.
The King sent someone to ask the ruler of Jìyáng:
"Whom are you on mutually resentful terms with?"
He replied:
"There is no one whom I would presume to have a relation of mutual resentment.
However,
I have once had unfriendly relations with two men.
But this was not of the sort that would lead to these results."
The King asked his entourage.
and the entourage said:
"That is certainly true."
And so the King had the two men executed.
Jì Xīn and Yuán Qiān hated each other.
Sīmǎ Xǐ had recently fallen out with Jì Xīn.
Therefore he he secretly ordered a person to kill Yuán Qiān.
The ruler of Zhōngshān reckoned that Jì Xīn was the murderer
and he had him executed.
The King of Jīng had a certain favourite concubine by the name of Zhèng Xiù.
When the King had found a new beauty for his harem
Zhèng Xiù instructed her as follows:
"The King is really delighted when people hold their mouths
so when you get close to the King
be sure to hold your nose."
When the beautiful woman went in to see the King
and got close to the King
she held her mouth, accordingly.
The King asked Zhèng Xiù why,
and Zhèng Xiù replied:
"Well, she certainly did mention that she cannot stand the smell of you!"
When the King, Zhèng Xiù and the beautiful woman sat together
Xiù first warned the driver:
"If the King just happens to propose something
you must immediately obey and carry out the King's proposal."
The beautiful woman moved very close to the King
and again and again she covered her mouth.
The king was thoroughly enraged and said:
"Cut off her nose!"
The driver then wielded his knive and cut the nose off the beautiful woman.
Another account says
The King of Wèi presented the King of Jīng with a beauty
and the King of Jīng felt greatly pleased with the present.
When his wife learnt that the King was fond of the woman
she also showed great affection for her,
even more than the King.
Of clothes and pleasant beautiful things
she always picked out the ones she wanted for her.
The King said:
"The wife understands that I am fond of the new one
and she loves her even more than I do.
This is the way a filial son serves his parents
and it is the way a loyal minister serves his ruler."
The wife understood that the King did not think of her as jealous
and then she told the new one:
"The King is very fond of you.
But he rather dislikes your nose.
When you see the king you should always hold your nose
then the King will bestow his lasting favours on you."
And so the new one followed this advice.
Every time she saw the king
she would invariably hold her nose.
The King asked the wife:
"The new one constantly holds her nose when she sees me.
Why is that?"
The wife replied:
"I do not understand this."
The King insisted on asking,
and she replied:
"A short while ago she did once mention she hated to smell your odour."
The King was furious and said:
"Cut off her nose"
The wife had previously warned the driver and said:
"If the King happens to propose something
it will certainly be right and proper to follow his orders."
And so the driver took the knife and cut off the beautiful woman's nose.
Fèi Wújí
was a confidante of the Prime Minister.
Xì Wǎn had recently begun to serve the Prime Minister
and the Prime Minister was very fond of him.
Wújí then told the Prime Minister:
"You love Wǎn very dearly
Why don't you set up a drinking party for his family?"
The Prime Minister said:
"Good"
Then he told him to make arrangements in Xì Yuān's home.
Wújí instructed Yuān saying:
"The Prime Minister is very arrogant and he is fond of the military.
You must show meticulous respect.
You must first hurry to display weapons under the hall and by the entrance.
So Yuān did as he has told.
The Prime minister went over to his place and was terrified.
He said:
"What is this?"
Wújí said:
"You are in danger
Get out of this place
It is as yet unclear what all this is about."
The Prime Minister grew very angry
he mobilised a military force and started criminal proceedings against Wǎn.
Then he had him killed.
Xī Shǒu and Zhāng Shòu were enemies.
When Chén Xū first made it into the leadership
he was not on good terms with Xī Shǒu
so he sent out someone to secretly murder Zhāng Shòu.
The King of Wèi considered that Xī Shǒu was the culprit
and he had him punished.
In Zhōngshān there was a prince of lowly status.
His horses were emaciated
his cart was worn down.
There were those in his entourage who privately were not on good terms with him.,
and so they made a request to the king on his behalf:
"The prince is very poor,
his horses are very emaciated.
Why doesn't Your Majesty give him some more horse fodder?"
The King did not accede to this request.
Then the prince's entourage secretly sent someone
to burn down the fodderhouses.
The King thought that his lowly prince was the culprit
and he had him punished.
In Wèi there was an old Confucian
who was not on good terms with the ruler of Jìyáng.
A foreigner nourished a private resentment against the old Confucian
and so he launched an attack on the old man and killed him
in order to win favour with the ruler of Jìyáng
saying:
"Because this man is not on good terms with you, my lord,
therefore I have killed him for you, my lord."
The ruler of Jìyáng rewarded the foreigner without investigating the case.
An alternative account runs:
The ruler of Jìyáng had a young son by a concubine.
He was not recognised
