and he wanted to get in and to win favour with the ruler.
The state of Qí ordered an old Confucian
to dig after medicine on Mǎlì mountain.
The young prince from Jìyáng wanted to gain merit on this occasion.
He went in for an audience with the ruler and said:
"Qí has sent an old Confucian
to dig after medicine in mount Mǎlì.
In name he is digging for medicine
but in fact he is spying against your state, my lord.
If you, my lord, do not kill him,
then he will bring it about that the ruler of Jìyáng
will face criminal charges in Qí.
I beg permission to stab him."
The ruler said:
"All right."
Then the next day he got hold of the man north of the city wall
and stabbed him.
The ruler of Jìyáng at once admitted him closer into his confidence.
Chén Xū
was a minister to the King of Wèi.
He was on good terms with the Kīng of Jīng.
and he made Jīng attack Wèi.
When Jīng attacked Wèi
Chén Xū asked to go on a mission to mediate peace on behalf of Wèi.
As a result, on the basis of the power of Jīng he became Prime Minister in Wèi.
During the times of Lord Zhāo of Hán
The grain seeds, at one stage, were expensive in the extreme.
Lord Zhāo sent a man to inspect the granaries.
The relevant minor official was indeed stealing grain seeds
and he had exported it on a larg scale.
When Zhāo Xīxù was in charge of Jīng
someone set fire to the storage houses, fodder houses and fodder storage caves,
and one did not know who the culprit was.
Zhāo Xīxù ordered the magistrate to detain a thatch-seller
and to interrogate him,
and he had indeed laid the fire (thus creating a better market for his goods).
During the time of Lord Zhāo Xī
when the chief cook served up the food
there was uncooked liver in the broth.
He called in the assistant cook
and he blamed him publicly, saying:
"Why did you put uncooked liver into my broth?"
The (assistant) cook knocked his head on the ground and admitted to the mortal crime
saying:
"It was my humble wish to get rid of the top cook."
An alternative source says:
When Lord Xī was about to take a bath
and there were pebbles in the hot bath-water.
Lord Xī said:
"If the officer in charge of the baths is dismissed
is there someone who is set to replace him?"
His entourage replied:
"There is."
Lord Xī said:
"Summon him in"
He publicly blamed the man, saying:
"What for did you put pebbles in the bath water?"
The bath attendant replied:
"If the officer in charge of the baths is dismissed
then I will get to replace him.
That is why I put pubbles in the bath water."
During the times of Duke Wén
the cook served up roast meat with a human hair on it.
Duke Wén summoned the cook and blamed him publicly saying:
"Do you want me to get choked?
Why do you tie this together with hair?"
The cook knocked his head on the ground, bowed twice and said:
"I have committed three crimes deserving death:
I took the grindstone and sharpened the knife
until it was as sharp as the Gānjiāng sword.
When I cut the meat the meat was cut up but the hair was left intact.
That was my first crime.
I took the small wooden pins to pierce the pieces of meat,
but I did not notice the hair.
That was my second crime.
When I held it over the charcoal burner
the fire in the coals was red hot
and the roasted meat got nicely done,
but the hair did not get burnt.
That was my third crime.
How could there fail to be someone below your hall who secretly nourishes hidden resentment against me?"
The Duke said:
"Good."
Then he summoned his minor servants and publicly criticised them.
Indeed, it was as the cook said,
and the Duke had the culprit punished.
An alternative account is as follows:
Duke Píng of Jìn was regaling guests.
A minor servant served up roast meat that was tied together with hair.
Duke Píng was in a hurry to have the cook killed,
and there was to be no going against this order.
The cook shouted to Heaven:
Alas
I have committed three crimes.
As I meet my death I still do not understand myself properly."
Duke Píng said;
"What do you mean?"
He replied:
"My knife is so sharp
that bones are split as easy as the wind, but hair remains intact,
this is my first crime.
When I roasted the meat with mulberry tree charcoal
the meat turned roast-red and ash-white, but the hair remained unsinged.
That was my second mortal crime.
When the meat was roasted well
I had a very close look at it
that there was hair tying the roast together I did not notice.
This is the third mortal crime.
Probably below your hall
Surely it is early to put me to death."
When Lord Xiāng was Prime Minister in Qín Qí was gaining strength.
When Lord Xiāng wanted to establish Qín as the overlord,
but Qí would not accept this.
So he suggested to establish Qí as the Eastern overlord
and in that way he was able to achieve his aim.
During the time of Duke Xiàn of Jin
Li Jī held a high position.
She pretended to the status of the regular wife.
and she wanted to introduce her son Xī Qí to replace the heir apparent Shēn Shēng.
So she presented Shēn Shēng as a disaster for the ruler and saw to it that he lost his life.
Then in the end she established Xī Qí as the heir apparent.
The ruler of Zhèng had already established an heir apparent
but he had a preferred concubine
and wanted to establish her son as his successor.
The regular wife got scared
and she assassinated the ruler with poison.
Zhōuxū from Wèy had great influence in Wèy
and he pretended to the authority of a ruler in power.
The whole lot of the ministers and the important families were afraid of his influence.
In the end Zhōu Xū did indeed kill his ruler and usurp the government.
Prince Zhāo
was the crown prince in Zhōu,
but his younger brother, prince Gēn was very much in the ruler's favour.
When the ruler died
the younger brother staged a revolt from Eastern Zhōu,
and the state was divided into a pair of two states.
King Chéng of Chǔ made Shāng Chén his heir apparent
but in the end he wanted to establish prince Zhí.
Shāng Chén staged a rebellion
and in the end he attacked and killed King Chéng.
An alternative account says:
King Chéng of Chǔ made Shāng Chén his heir apparent,
but in the end he wanted to establish prince Zhí.
When Shāng Chén heard about this
he had not yet investigated the matter
and so he said to his tutor Pān Chóng:
"How can we find out about this?"
Pān Chóng said:
"Invite Jiāng Mǐ and do not show her proper respect on the occasion."
The heir apparent took the advice.
Jiāng Mǐ said:
"Oh,
you scoundrel!
Quite right, too, that the King wants to throw you out
and that he wants to establish Zhí."
Shāng Chén said:
"So it was true."
Pān Chóng said:
"Can you serve under him?"
He replied: "I cannot."
"Will you be able to cast your lot with the feudal lords?"
He said: "I cannot."
"Can you initiate 'The great undertaking'?"
He said:
"I can."
After that he mobilised the armoured palace guard and launched an attack on King Chéng.
King Chéng asked permission to eat a bear's paw and die after that,
but he was not granted permission.
He then went on to kill himself.
Hán Huì was Prime Minister to Lord Āi of Hán
when Yán Suì had great influence with the ruler.
The two men were very much out to harm each other.
Yán Suì then sent a person to stab Hán Huì at court.
Hán Huì fled towards the ruler and embraced him,
whereupon in the end the murderer stabbed Hán Huì as well as Lord Āi.
When Tián Héng was Prime Minister in Qí
Hān Zhǐ had great influence with Duke Jiǎn.
The two men hated each other and wanted to destroy each other.
Accordingly Tián Heng distributed private favours
in order to take control of the state of Qí.
In the end he killed Duke Jiǎn and usurped the administration.
When Dài Huān was the grand steward in Sòng
Huáng Xǐ had great influence with the ruler.
The two men fought it out over political projects
and were out to harm each other.
Huǎng Xǐ did in the end kill the ruler of Sòng
and he usurped the government.
Hú Tū said:
"When the ruler is fond of his harem in the inner recesses of the palace
then the heir apparent is in danger,
and when he is fond of the close ministers in the outer public parts of the palace
then the Senior Secretary is in danger.
The ruler of Zhèng asked Zhèng Zhāo:
"And how is the heir apparent these days?"
Zhèng Zhāo replied:
"The heir apparent is not yet born."
The ruler said:
"The heir apparent is already established
and still you say 'He is not yet born'.
Why is this?"
He replied:
"The heir apparent may be established
but your fondness for beautiful women is unending.
If the lady of your love gives birth to a son
you, my lord, are bound to love him,
and if you love him you are bound to want to make him your successor.
That is why I say: 'The heir apparent is not yet born."
King Wén financed Fèi Zhòng so that the latter hung around Tyrant Zhòu
and King Wén ordered him to remonstrate with Zhòu and to disorientate his mind.
The King of Jīng sent a man on a mission to Qín
and the King of Qín treated him with great politeness.
The King said:
"When our rivalling states have talented men
that is our worry.
Now the King of Jīng's envoy is most talented
and I find this ominous."
His various ministers remonstrated:
"With Your Majesty's talent and sagehoodand with the rich resources of the state,
if you have hopes for the talented men in the service of the King of Jīng
then why don't Your Majesty try to build up deep relations with him
and secretly pull him over to your side?
If Jīng considers that he is being used by foreign forces
then they are bound to punish him."
When Confucius was conducting the administration in Lǔ
no one would pick up lost items in the street.
Duke Jǐng of Qí was disturbed by this.
Lí Jū told Duke Jǐng:
"Removing Confucius is like blowing away a hair, that is all.
Why don't you welcome him with a fat salary and a high position
and present to Duke Ai of Lǔ a troop of female musicians to confuse their thoughts?
When Duke Ai takes his fresh pleasure in these
he is bound to neglect his governmental duties.
Then Confucius is bound to remonstrate,
and when he remonstrates he will lose respect and be cut off from influence in Lǔ."
Duke Jǐng said:
"Good"
And he ordered Lí Jū to present six female musicians to Duke Ai.
Duke Ai took his pleasure with them
and in the event he did neglect his governmental duties.
Confucius remonstrated, but the Duke did not listen.
Confucius left Lǔ and went to Chǔ.
The King of Chǔ told Gān Xiàng
"I want to use the influence of Chǔ to support Gān Mào
and install him as Prime Minister in Qín.
Is that all right?"
Gān Xiàng said:
"That is not acceptable."
The King said:
"Why not?"
Gān Xiàng replied:
"In his younger days Gān Mào served Master Shǐ Jǔ.
Now Shǐ Jǔ
was a gate attendant in Shàngcài.
On the large scale he does not serve his ruler,
one the smaller scale he does not serve his family.
He is famous throughout the world for his harshness and ruthlessness.
When Gān Mào served him he followed his ways.
King Huì of Qín being so intelligent,
Zhāng Yí being so well-spoken,
when Mào served them
he obtained ten official positions and was never accused of any crime.
Such was the talent of Gān Mào."
The King said:
"To make a man Prime Minister in a competing state
and to make a talented man prime minister,
why should that not be right and proper?"
Gān Xiàng said:
"In former times Your Majesty sent out Shāo Huá to go to Yuè
and within five years he was able to ruin Yuè.
The reason for this was
that Yuè was in political chaos and Chǔ was well-governed.
In those days you understood the use of having someone go to Yuè,
now you are at a loss about Qín.
You are surely too quick to forget"
The King said:
"Well then, what should I do?"
Gān Xiàng replied:
"You had better appoint Gōng Li as prime minister."
The King said:
"What qualifies Gōng Lì as a prime minister?"
He replied:
"When Gōng Lì was young he enjoyed the ruler's favour
and when he grew up he became an honoured senior minister.
He wore the clothes of the King of Qín
he ate dùruò fragrant herbs
and held jade rings in his hand
to attend formal meetings in the palance.
So this man will come in useful to reduce Qín to chaos.
Wú was running a punitive expedition against Jīng.
Zǐxū sent someone to declare to Jīng:
"If you employ Zǐqī as a general in command
we will attack;
if you employ Zǐcháng as the general in command
we will withdraw."
When the people of Jīng heard about this
they used Zǐcháng and dismissed Zǐqī.
The people of Wú attacked them
and in the end they won.
When Duke Xiàn of Jìn launched a military campaign against Yú and Guō
he first sent carriages with horse-teams raised in Qū
and bì-jade from Chuíjī
as well as a team of six female musicians
to make them self-glorifying in their thoughts and attitudes and to ruin their government.
When Shū Xiàng did Cháng Hóng in
he faked a letter on the occasion, saying:
Cháng Hóng said to Shū Xiàng:
'Tell the ruler of Jìn on my behalf
that for our agreement with the ruler
the time is now right.
Why doesn't he come quickly with his troops?'
Then he fraudulently sent this letter to the court of the ruler of Zhōu
and left quickly.
Zhōu considered that Cháng Hóng was working to betray Zhōu.
They had Cháng Hóng punished and killed him.
Duke Huán of Zhèng was about to launch a surreptitious attack on Kuài.
But by way of preparation he asked about the brave heroes, competent ministers in Kuài, the well-spoken, intellectually competent and courageous men
and he wrote down all the family names and names of the persons involved.
He picked out the best fields and handed them out as bribes to these people.
He made up names of offices and ranks and wrote them up for them.
Then he made an altar outside the Outer Wall Gate
buried the documents
sprinkled them with the blood of cocks and boar
as if in a ritual of a covenant.
The ruler of Kuài thought that all this was an internal revolt
and he killed all his competent ministers.
Duke Huán then launched a surreptitious attack on Kuài
and in the event he took the place.
Xiāng Cī, governor of Yè,
cultivated secret close relations with the entourage of the King of Zhào.
When the King of Zhào was making plans for a surreptitious attack on Yè
Xiāng Cī was always immediately informed of what was happening
and he told the King of Wèi in advance of these plans.
The King of Wèi took his precautions
and Zhào immediately withdrew its army.
A gnome fom Qín cultivated good relations with the King of Jīng
and he secretly maintained good relations with the King's entourage
and within the state of Qín he had great influence with ruler Huìwén.
If by any chance Jīng was making secret plans
and the gnome would always be the first to hear about things
so that he could report to ruler Huìwén of Qín.
During the times of ruler Sī of Wèy
he had one of his men in the entourage of a local governor.
Once the district governor was airing the mattresses
and the mats were all very much worn down.
When Duke Si returned home he ordered mats to be given to the governor
saying:
"I have heard that you have recently aired your mattresses
and that your mats are very much worn down.
I am presenting you with some mats.
The distict governor was truly amazed
and he considered the ruler as gifted with supernatural powers.
The explanation is in Tián Jiū's response to the king of Jing. [.]
Thus Mòzi made the wooden kite [.]
and Singer Gui built a military academy. [.]
Medical wines and loyal words
are things that only the enlightened and sagely ruler understands.
If the ruler when accepting proposals
does not have positive concrete results as his aim
then those who offer their explanations
will mostly come up with stories about 'The bramle thorn' and 'The white horse'. [.]
If he does not take the target as the crucial standard
then all archers will be like Archer Yì. [.]
Rulers, when it comes to explanations
are all like the King of Yān studying the Way. [.]
And those who make detailed explanations
are all like the people from Zhèng quarrelling about who was oldest. [.]
Thus among speeches there are those that have fine investigations and subtle objections
but they are not concerned with concrete business.
Thus Ji, Hui, Sòng, and Mòzi all are painted bamboo whips only.
Their discourse is deep and far-reaching,
but it is of no use whatever.
Thus Wèi, Cháng, Zhǎn, Chén and Zhuāngzi are all intellectual wizzards in pictures,
and in their public action they are fearless of trouble and determined,
but they have no achievements to their credit.
Thus Wù, Biǎn, Bào, Jiè and Tián Zhòng are all hard calabashes.
Moreover Yú Qing was an inept carpenter and the house collapsed.
Fàn Jū was an artless craftsman and the bow was broken.
Therefore, if one is looking for the truth of a matter
there is no other way but to get back to home-made basics.
If one has an ambition to work for each other, the result will be mutual incrimination,
but if one acts in one's own best interest, then things will get done.
So fathers and sons can come to resent and scold each other,
and in order to get good workers one serves fine broth.
The explanation of this is in Duke Wén's pronouncement before his attack
and Gōu Jiàn's praise for the Rúhuáng platform.
That is why Duke Huán hid his anger against Cài and attacked Chǔ first.
Wú Qi was in fact hoping to cure future fighters for him and therefore sucked their wounds.
Moreover, the poems and encomia of the former kings,
the inscriptions of bells and tripods,
are all like the footsteps on mount Pówú,
like the backgammon board on mount Hua.
Now what the former kings were aiming for was benefits,
and what they used to achieve their ends was force.
The proverb used during the building of the altar of the land
was a matter of the Duke of Jin explaining his own action.(.)
Those who engage in their literary studies ???
act out the hazy truths of the former kings
but quite possibly these do not fit the present age.
Under these circumstances
these scholars have no ability to introduce changes to the ancient Way.
This is illustrated in the story of the man from Zhèng district who got hold of the crossbar on the carriage pole, (.)
the man from Wèy wanted to be of help in shooting birds, (.)
the story of Bǔzi's wife who faithfully reproduced worn-out trousers for her husband, (.)
and the young man serving his elders imitating their every action. (.)
The as for the former kings' pronouncements
in some cases what they were getting at was trifling,
but the world interpreted it as having a large significance
in other cases what they were getting at was of great importance
but the world interpreted it as trifling.
This cannot be determined with any certainty.
The explanation of this in the explanation of the letter by the man from Sòng (.)
and the reading of the record by the man of Liáng. (.)
Thus the former kings's pronouncements were much like the letter from Ying
and later generations often explain their pronouncements like the Prime Minister of Yān reading the letter from Ying. (.)
Now failing to adapt to current concerns of state and planning in the light of the former kings
that is like the man buying shoes going home to fetch the measure of his feet. (.)
Where there is benefit to be gained the people will turn to,
where there is fame to adorn oneself with, freemen will die for it.
Therefore if effective achievements beyond the law receive rewards
then the ruler will not be able to find people to give benefits to below him;
if fame is beyond the law and it receives praise
then freemen will be encouraged in the direction of fame but will not cultivate it for the ruler.
Thus when Zhōngzhāng and Xūji became officials
then more than half the people of Zhōngmóu left their fields and gardens to engage in literary pursuits. (.)
When Duke Ping of Jin had a painful calf of his leg and his legs hurt
and he did not dare to sit straight on his legs
he was not really showing respect for Shūxiàng, but half of the country resigned their positions to emulate Shūxiàng.
Thus as for these three freemen
if they followed the laws in their words
then they would be in accordance with the regulations for their offices.
If their actions were designed to suit the circumstances
then they would count as lawful citizens.
The two rulers' respect towards them was excessive.
If one's public statements deviate from the law and actions fail to lead to concrete results
then one counts as a citizen who has overstepped the rules.
Why then should the two rulers respect such citizens?
If they respect such citizens they are bound for ruin.
Moreover, freemen dedicated to literaty pursuits
when there is no trouble in the state, they will not make a useful effort,
and when there is trouble in the state they will not wear armour.
If (as a ruler) one treats such men with polite respect
then people will fail to make an effort on agriculture and and warfare.
If one does not show such people polite respect
then these literary men will seek to damage the ruler's laws.
When there is peace in the state they will be honoured and distinguished,
and when a dangerous situation occurs they will seek to reduce the natural authority of the Duke.
What can a ruler of men get out of those freemen engaged in literary pursuits?
That is why the enlightened ruler will discuss Li Ci's mission as an observer in Zhōngshān.
The Book of Songs ays:
"If one does not practise things personally
then the common people will not be trusty."
This is illustrated by the story about 'not wearing purple clothes (.)
and by the tales of Duke Jiǎn of Zhèng and Duke Xiāng of Sòng which demonstrate that the Songs are wrong. (.)
One should demand that people pay great respect to agriculture and warfare. (.)
If one does not make division of labour clear
and one does not demand earnest effort,
but aims to give a good example to those below by one's personal conduct,
that will lead to "having to get off one's horse" (.) and "falling asleep over the legal documents" (.)
and to "covering ugliness" and "going on incognito excursions".
Confucius did not understand this
and therefore he talked about being like a water bowl shaping water, (.)
The ruler of Zōu did not understand this
and therefore he went ahead and cut off the strings hanging from his hat. (.)
The Way of the enlightened ruler
is like Shūxiàng handing over the catches after a hunt (.)
and like Lord Zhāo listening to others. (.)
When reliability in small matters is achieved
then reliablility in large matters is established.
Therefore the enlightened ruler accumulates reliability.
When rewards and punitive sanctions are not reliable
then probitions and orders are not carried out.
The explanation is in Duke Wén attacking Yuán (.)
and saving it from famine together with Ji Zhèng. (.)
Therefore Wú Qi waited for his friend before he ate,
Lord Wén met with the forest guard and went for his hunt.
Thus the enlightened ruler displays his reliability and good faith
just as Zēngzi insisted on killing the pig.
The dangers of disregarding this truth show up in King Li beating the warning drums
and Lǐ Kuǐ cheating the two divisions of his army.
Mìzǐ Jiàn was governing Shànfǔ.
Yǒu Ruò went to visit him and said:
"How skinny you are"
Mìzǐ said:
"The ruler does not understand that I am a useless person.
and he has ordered me to govern Shànfǔ.
Official business is urgent,
and I keep worrying about it in my mind.
That is why I am so skinny."
Yǒu Ruò said:
"In ancient times Shùn played on the five-stringed lute,
sang the South Wind poem,
and the world was well governed.
Now when faced with a task as slight as the government of Shànfǔ
you are all worried about its government,
how could you handle the whole world?
The point is that if you have the art of government and manage things accordingly
then personally you will be sitting in your ancestral temple hall
having the complexion of a virgin,
and this will not interfere with your good government.
But if you do not have the art of government and do not use it
then although you get more and more worn out and skinnier
you will still get nowhere."
The King of Chǔ told Tián Jiū:
"Mòzǐ
is an illustrious scholar.
His person and body are perfectly all right
but his words are many and not well-formulated.
Why is that."
He said:
"In ancient times the Earl of Qín married his daughter to a prince of Jìn
and he ordered Jìn to take responsibilty for her wedding make-up.
Following in her train were seventy elaborately clad secondary wives.
When they got to Jìn
people in Jìn loved the concubines and thought nothing of the princess.
This may be called being good at marrying off secondary wives
but it may not quite be called being goood at marrying off one's daughter.
There was a man in Chǔ who was selling his pearls in Zhèng
and he made magnolia boxes for them.
He made these fragrant with cassia spice
and fixed pearls and jade on the boxes,
decorated them with rose patterns,
studded with bundles of kingfisher jadeite.
The people of Zhèng bought the boxes but they returned the pearls.
This may be called being good at offering boxes for sale
but it may not be called being good at offering pearls for sale.
The talk of our day
always uses well-formulated explanations and elegant phrases
The rulers enjoy the looks of the patterns but forget their use.
Mòzǐ's explanations
transmit the way of the former kings
they discuss the words of the sages
in order to pass these on to people.
If one polishes one's phrases to look good
then one has to be afraid that the others will be concerned with the splended rhetoric
and will forget his straightforward meaning
so that their very polish would interfere with their use.
Compared with the man of Chǔ offering his pearls for sale
and the Earl of Qín marrying off his daughter this is of the same kind.
Therefore most of Mòzǐ's words are not well-formulated.
Mòzǐ made a wooden kite.
After three years the thing was completed,
but after it had flown for one day it was ruined.
A disciple said:
"Amazing how clever you are, master,
even to the point of making a wooden kite fly."
Mòzǐ said:
"I am not as clever as those people who make ní-bars for the carriage.
They use a small piece of wood
and they do not waste more than a morning's work,
and the result will carry a load of thirty stone,
it will go long distances and have great deal of strength,
and it will last for several years.
Now when I make this kite
after three years it is finished
and when it has flown one day it is ruined."
When Huìzǐ heard about this he said:
"Mòzǐ has great technological skill,
He regards it as skillful to make ní-crossbars across the shaft,
and he regards it as inept to make kites."
The King of Sòng was on enemy terms with Qí
and he built a military academy.
Singer Guǐ led the singing
so that passers-by stopped to look
and the builders were untiring.
When the King heard about this
he summoned the man and gave him presents.
The man replied:
"My master Shè Jī's singing
was even more excellent than mine."
The King summoned Shè Jī and he ordered him to sing.
By-passered did not stop to listen,
the builders felt tiredness as usual.
The King said:
"Passers-by do not stop to listen,
the builders feel tiredness as usual.
His singing is not up to Guǐ's in attractiveness.
What is this?"
He replied:
"Your Majesty should try to measure actual performances."
Under Guǐ they set up four planks,
under Shè Jī the number was eight planks.
When it comes to pricking holes in the structure to test its solidity
then in the case of Guǐ one can get in five inches,
and in the case of Shè Jī it is only two inches.
Effective medicine is bitter to the mouth
but those who are wise will drink it when encouraged to do so.
This is because they understand that if they swallow it it will stop their sickness.
Loyal words grate in the ear
but the enlightened ruler will follow the advice.
This is because he understands that this may lead to positive results.
There was a man from Sòng who begged
to sculpt a female monkey onto the tip of a bramble thorn.
and the King was to fast for three months
before he would be able to look at the thing.
The King of Yān supported him with three cartloads of goods.
A smith who was driver on the right suggested to the King:
"I have learnt that the ruler will not let ten days pass fasting without a feast.
Now this man knows that Your Majesty is unable to fast for long
in order to see this useless product.
That is why he laid down a three month period of fast.
Quite generally, anyone who engraves and carves
must use a carving instrument that is small by comparison with what he carves in.
Now I am a smith
and I have no way of producing such a carving tool.
This is an impossibility.
Your Majesty must definitely investigate this closely.
So the king incarcerated and interrogated the man.
It turned out that the man was a fake
and the King had him killed.
The smith said to the King:
"If when making plans about the future you do not assess precisely and measure proposals
then the gentlemen responsible for public discussion will mostly present bramble thorn explanations."
The King of Yān was fond of miniature skills.
A man from Wèy said:
I can carve a female monkey onto the tip of a bramble thorn."
The King of Yān was satisfied with him
and he supported him with a maintenance allowance of five cartloads.
The King said:
"May I try and have a look at
the female ape you, stranger, have carved?"
The stranger said:
"If a ruler of men wishes to have a look at it
you must not enter the harem for six months
and abstain from wine and meat for that period.
When the rain clears away and the sun comes out
and you look in a calm dark spot
then the female monkey on the tip of a bramble thorn may be seen."
And so the King of Yān went ahead and maintained the man from Wèy at his court,
but he was unable to have a look at the female monkey.
In Zhèng there was a smith from Táixià
who told the King of Yān:
"Your servant
is a metal carver.
I beg to submit that a tiny thing must be carved with tiny carving tools
and what one carves must be larger than what one carves with.
Now the tip of a bramble thorn does not have place for the edge of a carving knife
so that it will be difficult to work on the tip of a bramble thorn.
If you have a look at the foreigner's carving tool
then whether it can or cannot carve this is something that can be ascertained."
The King said:
"All right."
He told the foreigner from Wèy:
"Foreigner, as you produce the female ape on the bramble thorn
what do you work the bramble thorn with?"
He said:
"With a carving knife."
The King said:
"I want to have a look at the carving knife."
The foreigner said:
"Let me go home to fetch it."
And he took the opportunity to run away.
Ní Yuè
was a man from Sòng
and he was very good at making arguments.
In maintaining "a white horse is not a horse
he won rhetorical duels against the sophists of the Jìxià academy in Qí.
When, riding a white horse, he was crossing a pass
he did pay the fee for the white horse.
The empty formulations in ancient books
may win rhetorical victories throughout the state
but if one invetigates the facts according to the real situation
they cannot cheat a single person.
A newly sharpened hunting arrow
if shot from a drawn crossbow
even if it is dark and one shoots in an arbitrary direction,
the tip of the arrow will always hit its precise minutely defined place.
But if one can never hit the same place again,
then one is not called a good archer.
That is because one does not have a constant proper target.
If one sets up a target that is five inches large
and pulls the bow from a distance of ten paces,
then only Archers like Yì and Páng Měng can constantly hit the mark,
and this is because there is a permanent target.
Performance is difficult when there is a set standard measure of success
and when there are no such set standard measures they are easy.
When there are constant set targets
then Yì and Páng Měng count as skillful when they hit a five inch target;
but if there is no constant set target
then if one releases arrows in an arbitrary direction and hits minute targets
that must count as imcompetent.
Thus if one responds without a set standard
then the specialists in disputation will come up with their diverse explanations;
but if you set up an objective standard and maintain it
then those who understand things will still be afraid that they get things wrong
and they will not dare to make arbitrary proposals.
The rulers nowadays, when they listen to explanations
do not respond in accordance with a fixed objective standard but delight in the rhetoric.
They do not take effective performance as an objective standard,
instead they praise their demeanour and do not hit home.
This is why the rulers are being cheated in the long run
and this is why the specialists in explaining are being well kept in the long run.
A foreigner was teaching the King of Yān the way of immortality.
The King told a person to study with him.
Before the person whom he had sent to study this had learnt his lesson,
the foreigner died.
The King got very angry
and had the man punished.
The King did not understand that the foreigner had cheated him
and he punished the disciple for being late in learning the skill.
To believe in things that are not true
and then to punish innocent subjects,
that shows the disastrous effect of not investigating things.
Moreover there is nothing with which man is more urgently concerned
than one's own person.
If one cannot ensure that one is immortal oneself
how can one cause a King to live forever?
In Zhèng two people were quarrelling about who was senior to whom.
One of them said:
"I am as old as Emperor Yáo."
The other said:
"I am as old as the elder brother of the Yellow Emperor."
They argued about this but could not decide the matter,
so they simply determined that the one who stopped talking last was the winner."
A foreigner was decorating a bamboo whip for the ruler of Zhōu.
After three years the work was finished.
When the ruler looked at it
the whip was exactly the same in appearance as an ordinary lacquered whip.
The Zhòu ruler got very angry
and the man decorating the box:
"Build a wall that is ten planks high
and make a window in it that is eight feet wide
and then when the sun is rising
hold the cane out there and look at it."
The ruler of Zhōu did as he was told
and he looked at the shapes
They had all become complete dragons, snakes, wild beasts, carriages and horses. (All became dragons, snakes, wild beasts,....)
The shapes of the myriad things were all provided there.
The ruler of Zhōu felt greatly satisfied.
Not that the effective performance on the cane was not subtle and difficult
but its practical use was the same as that of a plain lacquered cane.
A foreigner was acting as a painter for the King of Qí
The King of Qí asked me and said:
"What is the hardest thing to paint?"
He replied:
"Dogs and horses are the most difficult."
"What is the easiest to paint?"
He replied:
"Ghosts and spirits are easiest to paint."
Now dogs and horses
are what people are what men know something about.
From morning to nightfall they are present in front of him.
It is impossible to approximate their shape completely.
That is why they are difficult to represent.
Ghosts and spirits
are things without a concrete shape,
and they do not manifest themselves in front of one.
That is why one finds them easy to do.
In Qí there was an eremite by the name of Tián Zhòng,
and Qū Gǔ, a man from Sòng went to visit him
saying:
"I have heard about your moral standards.
You refuse to earn a living by relying upon or looking up to others.
Now I have a large gourd.
It is hard as stone,
thick and without any holes.
I am handing it up to you."
Zhòng said:
"What one values a gourd
is that one can put things into it.
Now if this one is thick and has no empty space
then it cannot be cut up to be made into a container for things,
and if it is hard to carry like a solid stone
then it cannot be cut up and used as a ladle.
I have no use for this gourd."
Qū Gǔ said:
"Well, in that case
I'll throw it away.
Now Tián Zhòng refused to earn a living by relying upon or looking up to others
and he, nonetheless, was in no way of any benefit to the state.
He is also of the same kind as the solid gourd.
Yú Qìng was building a house
and he told the carpenter in charge of the building:
"The building is too high!"
The carpenter replied:
"This is a new house.
The plastering is still moist and the roofbeams are fresh."
Yú Qìng said:
"That is not right.
You see, when the plastering is moist it is heavy, and the fresh beams will get bent
If with bent beams you support heavy plaster
then the building should be low.
As the days go by
the plaster will dry up and the roofbeems will dry out.
When the plaster gets dry it gets light.
When the roof beems are dried out they get straightened out
If one uses a straight roofbeam to support light plaster
then the place will be come even higher."
The carpenter admitted intellectual defeat.
He followed the other man's instructions and the roof duly collapsed.
Yú Qìng was going to build a house.
The carpenter said:
"The timber is fresh and the plaster is moist.
When the timber is fresh then it will bend
and when the plaster is moist it is heavy.
If you support a heavy load with a bent beam
then in the short run you may succeed,
but in the long run the thing will collapse."
Yú Qìng said:
"When timber is dry then it gets more straight,
when plaster is dry it gets lighter.
Now if the stuff gets really dry
then it will get lighter and more straight every day.
Even after a long time
the roof will certainly not collapse."
The carpenter admitted defeat
and made the house as instructed.
After a while the roof did collapse.
Fàn Jū said:
"When a bow is broken
this is bound to be towards the end of the production process
and it is not going to be at the beginning.
When the craftsman bends the bow
he places it in the bow frame for thirty days and then steps on it to fits the string
then after one day he releases the bending contraption.
This is to adapt oneself to the thing in the beginning
and then to apply violent force to it in the end.
How can it fail to break?
Moreover, when bending the bow one should do nothing of the kind:
One puts them into the bender for one day then steps on them to put on the string.
nd then after thirty days one releases the bending mechanism.
In such a way you apply the violent force in the beginning
and you gently adapt the thing towards the end."
The craftsman was at a loss for words.
He did as he was told
and the bow was broken.
Fàn Jū's and Yú Qìng's proposals
were well-formulated and rhetorically successful
but they went against the essential facts of the matters concerned.
If the ruler is satisfied with such talk and does not prohibit it
this is a way of being defeated.
If one does not plan for actual performance for good government and strengthening
and is lured by sophistical explanations
and by the sound of wonderfully crafted speeches,
then this is to dismiss the specialists as useless
and to employ collapsing houses and breaking bows.
Therefore the ruler, when it comes to government business
can never compete with the craftsmen
in designing houses and stretching bows.
If none the less the specialists keep being reduced to speechlessness by Fàn Jū and by Yú Qìng
is because of empty rhetoric.
The useless won their victory.
The real facts of the matter
were not to be changed and they could do nothing about it.
If the ruler uses a great deal of useless rhetoric
and few inevitably correct proposals
this is how he ends in chaos.
In present times there is an endless row of Fàn Jūs and of Yú Qìngs,
but the rulers incessantly find them satisfactory.
This is to accord high status to the kind of people who break and ruin things
and to regard specialists as simple craftsmen.
Craftsmen are not allowed to fully deploy their expertise and their clever skills
and as a result the houses collapse and the bows are broken.
Those who understand how to govern are not allowed to exercise their skills
and as a result the state is in chaos while the ruler is in danger.
When children play together
they take dust as food
they take mud as gruel
and they take pieces of wood as chunks of meat.
But when evening comes they are sure to return home for supper.
Rice made of dirt and gruel made of mud may be played around with
but it cannot be eaten.
Now those who praise the the traditional accounts and the hymns of high antiquity
are well-spoken but they are not dutiful and diligent,
Those who take the morality of the former kings as their guiding line
but are unable to straighten out matters of state
these are also the sort who can play around
but they are unable to run a government.
Now as for those who admire morality and are weak or rebellious
the three successor states to Jìn are cases in point.
And as for those who do not aspire to morality but have strong governments
Qín is a case in point.
However, the reason why Qín has not yet won imperial power
is because its government is not yet completely efficient.
If people, during childhood,
receive negligent treatment from the parents
then as the children grow up they will feel resentment against their parents,
and when they become adults
if his care for his parents is niggardly
then the parents will get angry and swear at him.
The relation between a son and a father
is the closest of relations,
but in some cases they swear, in others they are resentful
this is in all cases because they are concerned with mutual benefit
and cannot completely act in accordance with their own interests.
Now someone who sells his services to sow and work other's fields
the ruler will feed well even at the expense of his own family,
??he will find suitable cloth so that he can change it into cash.??
This is not because he is particularly fond of his foreign labourers,
but he says to himself:
"In this way
they will plough even deeper furrows
and through hoeing they will weed out even the small weeds."
That the foreign employees use all their strength
and weed and plough as energetically as they can
that they use all their skills and keep the ridges between the plots neat,
is not because they are fond of their master,
but they say to themselves:
"In this way our broth will be excellent flavour.
money- and cloth-payment will be easy to get."
That is why they cultivate their effort
and that is why there are such good relations between fathers and sons.
Their minds are attuned to what is useful to them
and they each harbour their egotistic motives.
Thus when a person carries out official acts and distributes goods
then, if the main purpose is to benefit people
even the people of Yuè are easy to bring to harmony;
but if the main point is that this harms people
then even fathers and sons are at loggerheads and full of resentment.
Duke Wén was launching a formal attack on Sòng
and he publicly declared:
"I understand that the ruler of Sòng is unprincipled
he looks down upon and insults elders
he is not even-handed in distributing assets,
his instructions and orders are not reliable
and I come to punish him on behalf of the people."
When Yuè launched a formal attack on Wú
he made the following public pronouncement beforehand:
"I understand that the King of Wú is building the Rúhuáng platform
and he is digging deep moats.
He is wearing out the noble families
and he is burning up the assets and resources
in order to make the people exert all their strength.
I come in order to punish him on behalf of the people.
A daughter from the royal house of Cài was the wife of Duke Huán
and Duke Huán was sailing in a boat with her.
The wife was rocking the boat
and Duke Huán was greatly frightened.
He told her to stop it, but she did not stop.
The Duke grew angry and divorced her.
Then he was about to summon her again,
but the Cài clan went on to marry her off to someone else.
Duke Huán got very angry
and he wanted to launch a formal attack on Cài.
Senior Advisor Zhòng remonstrated with him saying:
"Bedroom games
are not a sufficient reason to launch a formal attack on another state.
There are no effective results to be hoped for as a result of such a campain.
I beg you not to take this as your plan to pursue."
Duke Huán did not listen to this advice.
Senior Advisor Zhòng said:
"If you absolutely must attack them
The fragrant tribute from Chǔ has not been offered up to the Son of Heaven
for three years.
You should raise an army and attack Chǔ on behalf of the Son of Heaven.
When Chǔ has submitted
you should go on, on your way back, to launch a surprise attack on Cài
and you should say:
'On behalf of the Son of Heaven I have launched a formal attack on Chǔ
and Cài has not followed suit with its army.'
Then you should go ahead and destroy the place.
By that method you will appear principled
and you will reap benefits in real terms.
Thus you are sure to enjoy the good name of punishing on behalf of the Son of Heaven
and you will achieve the real result of avenging an unfriendly act."
Wú Qǐ was acting as a general for Wèi in an attack on Zhōngshān.
Among his soldiers one had a boil
and Wú Qǐ knelt down and personally sucked out the puss.
The injured man's mother was standing by and weeping.
Someone asked her:
"The general acts towards your son like this
why are you still weeping?"
She replied:
When Wú Qǐ sucked this boy's father's wound, that father went on to die.
Now this one is also going to die.
So that is why I am weeping now."
King Wǔling of Zhào, styled Zhǔfǔ ordered his workers to use a scaling ladder
to climb mount Pówú
for the purpose of carving a human footprint into the rock,
three feet wide
and five feet long,
and to inscribe it with the characters:
"Zhǔfǔ has constantly enjoyed himself here."
King Zhāo of Qín ordered workers to use a scaling ladder
to climb mount Huá

"I have had my foot cut off,
but my crimes certainly deserved this punishment.
There was nothing to do about it.
And so when you were dealing with my case
you have bent the laws and orders
you have helped me with your official statements,
and you were very much hoping that I would avoid the worst.
And I understood all this.
When my imprisonment was decided and my crime determined
you were disappointed and displeased,
and this was clearly manifested in your facial expression.
When I saw this I again understood the situation.
It is not that you were partial to me and therefore reacted like this.
It was that your Heaven-given nature is kindly
and your heart is inherently like that.
This is why I felt pleased
and felt grateful to you."
Confucius said:
"Those who are good at acting as officials
lay foundations for good-will;
those who are incapable of acting as officials
lay foundations for resentment.
The levelling stick
is what one evens out measures with;
the official
is one who evens out legal procedures with.
In governing the state
one must not get the levelling wrong."
Tiān Zǐfāng was going from Qí to Wèi
and in the distance he saw Dí Huáng riding a chariot with side-riders and going out.
Fāng thought that this was Lord Wén of Wèi.
He changed the course of his carriage, took another road to get out of his way.
but it turned it it was only Dí Huáng.
Fāng asked him:
"Why are you riding such a vehicle?"
He said:
"The ruler is making plans and wants to launch a formal attack on Zhōngshān.
I have recommended Zhái Jiǎo
and the plan achieved the desired result;
when we were about to launch our formal attack
I recommended Yuèyáng and Zhōngshān was taken.
when we had won Zhōngshān
we were worried and wanted to govern the place properly
so I recommended Lǐ Kè, and Zhōngshān was well-govverned.
That is why the ruler has conferred on me this vehicle."
Fāng said:
"When the favours you have received are weighed against your achievements the favours are still comparatively slight."
When Qín and Hán were attacking Wèi
Zhāo Mǎo went westwards to intercede, and Qín and Hán desisted.
When Qí and Jīng were attacking Wèi
Mǎo went east to intercede and Qí and Jīng desisted.
King Xiāng of Wèi gave him a maintenance allowance of five cartloads.
Mǎo said:
"Bó Yí was buried as a general at the foot of Mount Shǒuyáng
and the whole world said:
'With the excellence of Bó Yí
and his matching kindliness
he got buried as a general.
Such a funeral is as bad as failing to cover the man's hands and feet.'
Now I have caused the armed forces of four states to desist from military action
and the King has given me five cartloads.
This way of matching up with achievements
it is like being extremely wealthy and wearing straw sandals."
Shào Shìzhōu
was a morally honest and pure gentleman of ancient times
and he was a body guard for ruler Xiāng of Zhào.
He engaged in a test of strength with Xúzǐ of Zhōngmóu
and came out second.
He went in to propose him to ruler Xiāng
so that he himself should be replaced.
Ruler Xiāng said:
"Your occupying this position
is what people want.
Why should you propose that Xúzǐ should replace you?"
The morally honest man said:
"I have served you to the best of my strength.
Now it turns out that Xúzǐ is stronger than me.
If I do not get him to replace me
I am afraid other people will talk about it
and think that I was in the wrong."
An alternative account says:
Shàoshì Zhōu was a Right Guard for the main driver of Ruler Xiāng.
When they got to Jìnyáng
there was a strongman called Niú Zǐgēng.
Shàoshì Zhōu engaged in a friendly wrestling match with the man and lost.
Shāo Shìzhōu proposed to the ruler:
"The reason why you, my ruler, have employed me as a Right Guard
was because I am a man of great physical strength.
Now there is a man who is stronger than I
and it is may hope that you will promote him to my position."
When Duke Huán of Qí was going to install Guǎn Zhòng
he issued an order to his ministers which ran as follows:
"I will establish Guǎn Zhòng as the Senior Advisor Zhòng.
Those who approve of this enter the gate and stand on the left,
those who do not approve of it enter the gate and stand on the right."
Dōngguō Yá took his place right in the middle of the gate.
The Duke said:
"I am establishing Guǎn Zhòng as Senior Advisor Zhòng
and my order said:
'Those who approve of it stand on the left
and those who do not approve of it stand on the right.'
Why are you taking up a position right in the middle of the gate?
Yá said:
"Do you think that with the professional competence of Guǎn Zhòng
you may make plans for the world?"
The Duke said:
"I can."
"With his decisive determination
do you consider he will have the courage to engage in large undertakings?"
The Duke said:
"He will."
Yá said:
"If his competence is great enough to make plans for the world
and if his determination is great enough to carry out large undertakings,
then you are handing over to him alone all the handles of power in the state.
If using the abilities of a Guǎn Zhòng
he avails himself of the Duke's power,
can that be other than dangerous?"
The Duke said:
"Good."
Then he ordered Xí Péng to take responsibility for internal affairs
and Guǎn Zhòng to take responsibility for external affairs to match him.
When Duke Wén of Jìn went into exile
Jī Zhèng was carrying the pots and provisions for him
and went along with him in that capacity.
Once he went astray and lost his way
and he lost contact with the Duke.
Hungry, he was weeping by the roadside.
By the time he went to sleep he was famished but he did not dare to eat anything from the provisions.
When Duke Wén returned to his state
he took out his troops and attacked Yuán.
He won a victory and took the place.
Duke Wén said:
"If someone is easily able to bear with the troubles of hunger,
but will leave the pots and provisions untouched,
then such a man is not going to stage any revolt in Yuán."
So he raised his position to that of Commander-in-Charge of Yuán.
Grandee Huī Xuān heard about this and diapproved of the decision
and said:
Just because he did not touch the pot with provisisons
to rely on his not revolting on the basis of Yuán
is surely incompetent"
Thus the enlightened ruler
will not rely on others not revolting against him
but will rely on that it is impossible to revolt against him.
He does not rely on others not cheating him
but relies on it being impossible for him to be cheated.
Yáng Hǔ proposed the following in the public deliberations at court:
"If the ruler is excellent and enlightened
then one will serve him with all one's mental strength;
if he is incompetent
then one will make one's wickedness appear beautiful in order to test him."
He was chased from Lǔ,
he was held in suspicion in Qi.
When he fled and went to Zhào
ruler Zhào Jiǎn welcomed him and made him Prime Minister.
His entourage said:
"Hǔ is an expert at misappropriating political power in other states.
Why do you make him Prime Minister."
Ruler Jiǎn said:
"Yáng Hǔ will be out to get political power
and I shall be out to keep it."
Then he kept to the art of government and controlled the man.
Yáng Hǔ did not dare to perpetrate wicked acts
and served ruler Jiǎn with honest effort.
He promoted the power of the ruler
so that the latter almost got to the point of becoming a hegemon.
Duke Ai of Lǔ consulted Confucius and said:
"I have heard that in ancient times Kuí had one leg.
Did he really have only one foot?"
Confucius replied:
"That is not so.
Kuí was not one-legged.
Now Kuí was a resentful, violent and evil-temped man.
Most people do not like him.
Although this is so
the way he kept out of harm's way from other people
was that he was reliable.
Everybody said:
'Having just this one point
that was sufficient.'
Kuí was by no means one-legged,
it was just that he had one thing that was enough."
Duke Āi said:
"When you think about it, this is right.
That is certainly sufficient."
Ai consulted Confucius:
"I have heard that Kuí had one leg.
Is that true?"
He replied:
"Kuí
was a man.
Why should he be one-legged?
He had no other special characteristics
the only thing he understood were sounds/tones.
Yáo said:
'Kuí has one good point that is enough.'
He employed him as officer in charge of music.
Thus the gentleman says:
'Kuí has one good point,
and that is enough.
It is not that he was one-legged."

he arrived at the ruins of Fènghuáng,
and his sock-bands got untied
so he tied them up himself.
Wàng, Duke of Tài, said:
"What do you do this for?"

At the top level
those whom the ruler associates with
are all his teachers;
at the medium level
they are all his friends;
at the lower level
the whole lot are his personal employees.

that is why I cannot order them about."

Duke Wén of Jìn was engaged in a war with Chǔ

his sandal straps got untied

The Duke said:

On the top level,
those with whom the ruler associates
are thoses whom he reveres;
at the middle level
those whom the ruler associates with
are all those whom he particularly likes;
at the lower level
those with whom the ruler associates
are all those whom he treats with disrespect.
Although I am incompetent
the former ruler's men are all in place
that is why I have problems ordering these people about.
Jìsūn was fond of learned freemen
and throughout his life he put on a dignified air.

he sometimes lost his dignified air
and could not maintain it for a long time
Therefore his retainers thought that he was fed up with them and despised them.
and developed their united resentment against him.
and in the end they went on to murder Jìsūn.
So the gentleman avoids extremes and excess.

Nángōng Jìngzǐ consulted Yán Zhuójù and said:

those he sat together with in formal court dress were in the tens,

Formerly King Chéng of Zhōu
cultivated the company of entertainers and dwarf clowns

Now the Jìsūn patronise Confucius' disciples.
Those he sat together with in formal court dress were in the tens,

Thus is said:
The point is not with whom one spends one's time.
The point is with whom one consults on important political matters.
Confucius was sitting in attendance with Duke Ai of Lǔ.
Duke Ai gave him a peach and millet.
Duke Ai said:
"Bon appetit!"
Confucius ate the millet first and then ate the peach.
The Duke's aides all covered their mouths and smiled.
Duke Ai said:
"The millet
is not at all for eating,
it is for cleaning the peach with."
Confucius replied:
"I knew that.
Now as for millet
this is superior kind of grain.
When one performs sacrifices to the former kings it is the superior offering.
Of fruits and gourds there are six kinds,
and the peach is the lowliest of them.
When one sacrifices to the former kings they do not enter the temple.
I have learnt:
the gentleman cleans what is noble with what is base.
I have not heard that he cleans what is base with what is noble.
Now to use the most superior of the five kinds of grain
to clean the most inferior kind of fruit,
that is to use the most superior thing to clean the most inferior.
I consider this as going against the principle of rectitude.
Therefore I dare not put anything before
the most distinguished offering in the ancestral temple."
Ruler Jiǎn told his aides:
"The carriage mat is too lavishly beautiful.
Even if a hat is humble
the head is bound to wear it;
footwear may be distinguished
but feet are bound to wear it.
Now for the carriage mat to be like this
is to be too lavishly beautiful.
With what footwear shall I step on them?
To make beautiful what is below and wear out what is on top
that is to go against the basis of rectitude.
Fèi Zhòng advised Zhòu as follows:
Earl Chāng of the West is talented;

the feudal lords feel attached to him.
One will absolutely have to have him executed.
If you do not have him executed
this is bound to lead to disaster for Yīn."
Zhòu said:
"You say he is a man of moral principle.
How could it be right and proper to have him executed?"

"Even if a hat is full of holes
will always be worn on the head;
even with leather shoes that are made of materials in various colours

is a subject to the king
and he practices moral principles so that people turn to him,

Zhòu said:
"Morality
is the means whereby superiors encourage inferiors.

Three times he offered his advice but went unheard.
That is why the dynasty was ruined.
King Xuān of Qí asked Kuāng Qiàn:
"Do the learned play the bó-game?"
He said:
"No, they don't."
The King said:
"Why is that?"
Kuāng Qiàn replied:
"In the game of bó the noblest thing is the owl.
The winner must kill the owl.
As for killing the owl
such an act is killing what one values most.
The Confucians consider that this is inconsistent with moral principles.
That is why they do not play the game of bó."
The King went on to ask:
"Do Confucians shoot stringed arrows?"
Kuāng Qiàn replied:
"No they don't.
As for the shooting of stringed arrows,
in that game one harms what is above from below,
and such an act is to harm the ruler from below.
The Confucians consider that this is inconsistent with moral principle.
That is why they do not shoot with stringed arrows."
Again he asked:
"Do Confucians play the sè-instrument?"
Kuāng Qiàn said: "No they don't.
The sè instrument uses small strings to make a large noise
and it uses large strings to make small noises.
This is to invert the order of the great and the small,
and it is for the noble and the base to change places.
The Confucians think that this is inconsistent with moral principle,
and therefore they do not strum that instrument."
Duke Xuān said:
"Good."
Confucius commented:
"Rather than making the people flatter those who are inferior
it is better to make the people flatter those who are superior."
Jù
wa a scholar recluse in Qí.
Chán
was a scholar recluse in Wèi.
The rulers of Qí and Wèi were unenlightened.
Since they were unable to personally look after their territories,
and they listened to their aides' advice.
Therefore these two men spent money and jade
in their attempt to get into an office.
When Xīmén Bào was the commander of Yè

There was not the slightest trace of personal profit-seeking in him.
However, he treated his aides very shabbily.
As a result the aides formed factions
and they hated Xīmén Bào.
When a whole year had passed
the royal assessment of the year's work was held
and the ruler took back Ximén's official seal.
Bào made a personal request:

but now I have learnt it.
It is my hope that I may beg for a seal
in order to reestablish my government of Yè.

The enfeoffed ruler Wén could not bear to do otherwise

Then Bào imposed heavy taxes on the registered families
and looked assiduously after his aides.
After a year
the central assessment of the year's work was held.
Lord Wén went out to meet him and bowed to him.
Bào replied:

and you took away my seal.
Now I have governed Yè in the interest of your aides
and you are bowing to me.
I am unable to run this government."
Then he handed in his seal and went his way.
Enfeoffed ruler Wén did not accept the seal
and he said:
"Earlier, I did not understand you.
Now I do understand you.
I hope you will make a special effort to govern the place in my interest.
But in the end Xīmén Bào did not accept the offer.
In Qí the son of a thief who went around like a dog
and the son of a criminal with cut-off feet were joking together and bragging.
The son of the thief said:
"Only on my father's cloak is there a tail."
The son of the footless criminal said:
"Only my father does not go without long socks in winter."
Zǐ Chuò said:
"No one can draw a square with his left hand
while he is drawing a circle with his right hand.

there will be even more ants;

then even more flies will come."
Duke Huán said to Guǎn Zhòng:
"Official positions are few and those who seek them are many.
I am worried about that."
Guǎn Zhòng said:
"You should not listen to special requests from your aides
and you should distribute stipends according to ability.
You should keep a record of achievements and appoint to offices on this basis
then no one will dare to seek official positions.
What would you then have to worry about?"
Hán Xuānzǐ said:
"My horses have lots of beans and unhusked grain,
but they are very skinny.
Why is that?
I am concerned about this."
Zhōu Shì replied:
"If the horsekeeper used up all the unhusked grain to feed them,
then even if he had no intention of fattening them
he could not achieve his aim.
If in name he is giving them a lot
but in fact he is giving them little,
then even if he had no intention of making them skinny
he also could not achieve his aim.
If you, my lord, do not carefully examine the real facts of the matter
but you sit around and worry about them,
then the horses will still not get any fatter for it."
Duke Huán asked Guǎn Zhòng about establishing administrative positions.
Guǎn Zhòng said:
"When it comes to the discriminating assessment of formulations,
the neat administration of commercial affairs,

these five men are sufficient.

then I am at your service."

when sitting he did not use double mats.

Bēnhuáng disapproved and said:

Now I congratulate you on your frugality."

a middle rank grandee has one double luxury carriage,

in times of peace

and he went around with a hungry face.

Zhōngmóu
is our thighs and arms,

so he bored a hole opening into the place where the duke used to hold his confidential conversations.
After a while, the King really did lay plans with Rhino Head
and he said:
"I want to attack Hán.
What do you think?"
Rhino Head said:
"The autumn would be the right time.'
The King said:
"I would like to turn over the state to you.
You must not leak this out."
Rhino Head politely withdrew a few steps, bowed twice and said:
"I accept your orders."
At that time Chū Lǐjí was overhearing this through his hole.
All the courtiers started saying:
"The army will be taken out in autumn and will attack Hán.
Rhino Head will be general."
Within one day
the whole lot of the courtiers knew about this.
Within one month
everyone within the borders of the state knew it.
The King summoned Chū Lǐjí and said:
"What is all this babble?
How did this get out?"
Chū Lǐjí said:
"Apparently Rhino Head is the source."
The King said:
"I have never spoken up to Rhino Head.
What can Rhino Head have to do with it?"
Chū Lǐjí said:
"Rhino Head is a migrant.
Recently, he has fallen foul of someone.
He feels lonely,
and he talks like this to ingratiate himself to the masses."
The Kings said:
"You are right."
He sent someone out to summon Rhino Head,
but the man had already escaped to one of the feudal lords.
The Duke of Tángxi told Lord Zhāo:
"Suppose there is a jade mug worth a thousand cash
but it is open at the end and has no bottom.
Can one put water into it?"
Lord Zhāo said:
"One cannot."
"If you have an earthenware vessel which does not leak
can one put wine into it?"
Duke Zhāo said:
"One can."
He replied:
"Earthenware vessels
are the humblest.
But as long as they do not leak
one can fill them with wine.
Even if one has that jade mug worth a thousand cash
it is a most precious thing but if it has no bottom,
and thus does not hold liquid
one cannot put water into it:
who would even pour ordinary rice gruel into it?
Now if you are a ruler
but you leak out the talk of your ministers,
this is like being a jade mug without a bottom.
Although you are outstanding and competent
you will never fully carry your art into practice.
And this is because you do not hold water."
Lord Zhāo said:
"You are right."
After he had heard the Duke of Tángxī's proposal,
from that time onwards,
when Duke Zhāo wanted to start on a big venture in the world
he always slept alone.
He was afraid that he would speak in his dreams
and let other people know what his plans were.
An alternative account reads:
The Duke of Tǎngxī went to see Lord Zhāo and said:
"Suppose there is a mug of white jade which has no bottom
and an earthenware mug with a bottom.
If you were thirsty,
from which would you drink?"
The ruler said:
"I would drink from the earthenware mug."
The Duke of Tǎngxī said:
"A mug of white jade is magnificent
but still you are not proposing to drink from it.
Could that be because it has no bottom?"
The ruler said:
"Yes."
The Duke of Tǎngxī said:
"If you are a ruler
but you leak out your ministers' talk
that is like a jade mug being without a bottom."
Every time after Duke Tángxī had been to visit and had left
Lord Zhāo was sure to sleep alone.
He was afraid he would talk in his sleep
and divulge things to his wives and concubines.
Shēnzǐ said:
"Being able to see independently is called clear-sightedness;
being able to hear clearly independently is sharpness of hearing.
The one who is able to make decisions independently
thus becomes the ruler over the world."
There was a wine-seller from Sòng,
and he always served a level measure of wine.
He treated his customers with tremendous diligence
and he made a wine that was of tremedous quality;
He had hung up his shop sign high up and visible to everyone.
In spite of all this he did not get anything sold,
and his wine went sour.
He was wondering what the reason was.
He asked his acquaintances,
and he consulted the village elder Yáng Qiàn.
Qiàn said:
"Is your dog fierce?"
The wine-seller replied:
"If my dog dog is fierce
why should I fail to sell my wine?"
Qiàn said:
"People are afraid of it.
Somebody sent out a little girl
carrying some cash and a pot to go out and buy wine.
but the dog ran up to her and bit her.
This is why the wine is going sour and never gets sold."
Now in a state there are also such dogs.
A gentleman who has a Way holds a method in his mind
and he desires to enlighten a ruler with war chariots.
The senior ministers are fierce dogs, run up to him and bite him.
This is the way in which the ruler is kept in the dark and put under pressure,
and that is why gentleman who have a Way do not get used.
Thus Duke Huán asked Guǎn Zhòng:
"What are you most afraid of in the governing of a state?
He replied:
"I am most concerned about the rats in the altar of the land."
The Duke said:
"What are you concerned about regarding the rats in the altar of the land?"
Guǎn Zhòng replied:
"Surely you, my lord, have seen those who build the altars of the land?
They set up planks and add plaster to them.
The rats burrow their way in through the interstices,
dig their holes their and seek refuge in them.
If one smokes them outthen one is afraid one will burn the wood;
if one floods them out then one is afraid that the plaster will peel off.
This is why one does not get hold of these rats in the altar of the land.
Now the aides of rulers
will work towards a position of power outside the court
and they will reap profit from the people;
within the court they will form factions and they will hide wickedness from the ruler.
Within the court they will spy out the rulers's real feelings in order to divulge them outside.
Outside the court and inside they engage in their power play
and the ministers as well as all the minor officials become rich as a result.
If minor officials are not chastised then they will pervert the law,
and if one does chastise them then the ruler will be insecure.
These men occupy the place and they are in charge of it.
These are surely the rats in the altars of the land."
Thus these ministers hold the handles of power and issue unauthorised prohibitions.
They make it clear that those who work for them are sure to gain profit
while those who do not work for them are sure to suffer harm.
These people are surely fierce dogs.
Now if the powerful ministers are fierce dogs
and bite freemen who have a Way to offer,
and if one's aides again are rats in the altar of the land and spy on the ruler's real feelings,
without the ruler being aware of what is happening,
if things get to this stage,
then how can the ruler avoid being blocked
and how can the state fail to be ruined?
Among the wine-sellers in Sòng there was a certain Mr Zhuāng
whose wine was consistently excellent.
Someone sent a servant to buy wine from Mr Zhuāng
but the latter's dog was prone to bite people.
The emissary did not dare to go there
and bought wine from another shop.
The servant's master demanded to know:
"Why didn't you buy wine from Mr Zhuāng?"
He replied: "Today, Mr Zhuāng's wine is sour."
Thus it is said: As long as he does not kill his dog then his wine will go sour.
Duke Huán consulted Guǎn Zhòng:
"What are you most concerned about in the government of the state?"
He replied:
"I regard as most seriously worrying the rats in the altar of the land.
The altars of the land
are produced with plastered timber.
Then the rats go on to seek refuge there.
If one smokes them out then the timber will burn
and if one floods them out the plaster will come off.
This is why I am seriously worried about the rats in the altar of the land.
Nowadays, as for the aides of a ruler
abroad they cultivate their political power in order to reap profit from the people
and at court they form factions, deceive, humiliate, and hide their evil intents.
in order to perpetrate fraud against the ruler.
If one does not chastise them then they will pervert the law,
and if one does chastise them then the ruler puts himself in a dangerous position.
These people hold and control the state.
They are surely rats in the altar of the land and grain."
Thus when ministers hold the handle of power and enforce and issue unauthorised prohibitions
making it clear that those who work for him are bound to reap profit
and that those who do not work for him are bound to suffer harm,
these are surely the fierce dogs.
Thus when the aides are rats in the altar of the land
and those in practical charge of business are fierce dogs,
then the art of government will not be practised.
Yáo wanted to pass on the empire to Shùn.
Gǔn remonstrated and said:
"That is inauspicious
How can one pass on the empire to a commoner?"
Yáo did not take the advice.
He raised an army and punished and killed Gǔn in the suburbs of Yǔshān.
Gōng Gōng remonstrated again and said:
"How can one pass on the empire to a commoner?"
Yáo did not listened to him.
He raised another army
and punished Gōng Gōng in the administrative centre of Yōuzhōu.
After that no one in the world dared to propose
that one should not pass on the empire to Shùn.
When Zhòngnǐ heard about this he said:
"For Yáo to understand the moral excellence of Shùn
was not the difficult part.
To go as far as to chastise those who remonstrated with him and to insist on passing on the empire to Shùn,
that was the difficult part."
One source comments:
"Not to ruin what one has seen clearly with what one is doubtful about
that is the difficult part."
King Zhuāng of Jīng instituted a law concerning the Thatch Gate which said:
"When ministers, grandees or princes enter the court
if the horses' hoofs stepped into the drain
the Court Officer was to cut off the carriage pole
and to execute the driver concerned.'
At that point the heir apparent entered court
and his horse's hooves stepped into the drain.
The Court Officer cut off his carriage pole
and executed the driver.
The heir apparent was furious.
He went in to the King and sobbing in front of him he said:
"You must have the Court Officer executed on my behalf."
The King said:
"As for the law
it is a means to ensure respect for the ancestral shrine
and to ensure the honoured position of the altars of the land and grain.
So those who are able to establish laws, to follow ordinances,
and to ensure the esteem and respect for the altars of the land and grain,
these are servants of the altars of the land and grain:
How could it be right and proper to have them executed?
Those who break the laws and disregard the ordinances
and who do not ensure the esteem and respect for the altars of the land and grain,
such persons dominate the ruler as ministers and as inferiors they go against their superiors.
When ministers dominate their rulers
then the ruler loses his authority;
when inferiors go against their superiors
then the official position of the superiors is endangered.
When authority is lost and one's official position is endangered
then the altars of the land and grain will not be kept properly;
then how can I pass these on to one's children and grandchildren?"
At that point the heir apparent turned round and ran off.
He kept away from his house and lived in the open air for three days.
Facing north towards the ruler he bowed twice and asked to be found guilty of death.
An alternative source says:
The King of Chǔ issued an urgent summons to the heir apparent.
According to the laws of Chǔ
vehicles were not allowed to go to the Thatch Gate.
It was raining.
In the courtyard there was a flood of rain water.
The heir apparent steered his vehicle fast direct to the Thatch Gate.
The Court Officer said:
"Vehicles are not allowed to be driven direct to the Thatch Gate.
He has driven direct to the Thatch Gate.
That was an illegal act."
The heir apparent said:
"Your Majesty's summons was urgent.
I was not allowed to wait until the puddles were gone."
And then the heir apparent was going to speed on.
The palace officer raised his official lance and struck the horse with it
thus preventing him from driving on.
The heir apparent went in and sobbing in front of him he said:
"In the courtyard there were a lot of puddles.
I drove my vehicle fast to the Thatch Gate
but the Court Officer said:
'This is an illegal act.'
He raised his lance and struck my horse
thus preventing me from driving on.
Your Majesty must be sure to have him punished."
The King said:
"In front of him there is an aging ruler, and still he does not transgress the law.
Behind, there is the ruler's successor, and still he does not try to get close to him.
How dignified and uncompromising
Such a person is truly an employee who takes good care of the law for me."
Then the King raised his rank by two grades
opened the back gate and let the heir apparent out:
"Don't transgress against him again"
Ruler Si of Wèy told Báo Yí:
"You regard my state as too small.
Do you consider that it is not worth holding office in?
I shall be able to promote you in office with all my strength.
May I promote you in rank and make you my top senior minister?"
Then the ruler gave him mú of land.
Bózǐ said:
"My mother was very close to me.
She thought that being prime minister in a ten thousand chariot state
would be something that would leave me extra strength.
However, there was a shamaness in our house who was called Mummy Cài.
My mother was very fond of her and trusted her.
She entrusted the affairs of the household to her.
My intelligence was great enough for my mother to discuss affairs of the family with me.
In everything my mother listens to me.
But after having discussed something with me
she will definitely have the matter decided by Mummy Cài.
Thus when it came to assessing my intelligence and ability
she considered that I could be prime minister in a war chariots state and still have energy to spare.
When one assesses the closeness of our relation
then it was that between a son and a mother.
And yet, she would be sure to discuss matters with Mummy Cài.
Now as for my relation to a ruler of a state,
it is not as close as that between a son and a mother,
and rulers all have their Mummy Càis.
The Mummy Càis of rulers
are inevitably the powerful people.
Now as for powerful people
these are the kinds of people who are able to act in their personal interest.
And acting in one's personal interest
is beyond the ink-line (of the law),
but what I propose
is within the law.
Between what is behond the ink-line and what is within t he law
there is a real contradiction.
These two things cannot accept each other.
An alternative source says:
When the ruler of Wèy went to Jìn
he told Bó Yí:
"I want to travel on from here together with you."
Bó Yí said:
"My old lady is alive at home.
May I go back and consult on her with this?"
The ruler of Wèy went in person to ask the old lady (Bó Yí's mother).
Bó's mother, the old lady, said:
"Yí is your servant.
If it is your intention to have him become your follower

The ruler of Wèy said:
"I have asked the old lady about this.

Bó Yí went home
and he told the old lady about what was happening.

"When you have planned the affairs of the family with me

Those who teach others to sing
will first make them breathe out and then bend and adapt to the right tones.
And when their voice returns to the pure zhī note, then he starts properly teaching them.
An alternative source says:
A person who teaches singing
will first assess his student according to a standard,
whether when he breathes fast he will hit the gōng note,
when he breathes slowly he will hit the zhī note.
If when breathing fast he does not hit the gōng note
or if when breathing slowly he does not hit the zhī note
he cannot be said to have taught effectively.
Wú Qǐ
was a man from Zhōng in the city of Zuǒshì in the state of Wèy.
ordered his wife to weave a ribbon
but the width was narrower than the required standard.
Wúzǐ ordered her to change it.
His wife said:
"All right."
When the work was finished
he measured the ribbon again
and it turned out that it did not, in fact, conform to the required standard.
Wúzǐ got very angry at her.
His wife replied:
"I had originally placed the main thread and this cannot be changed."
Wǔzǐ divorced her.
The wife begged his elder brother to have her reinstated.
The elder brother said:
"Wúzǐ
is the sort of person who works according to the law.
The reason why he works according to the law
is that he wishes to offer his services to a state of war chariots on this basis.
He must first act on it towards his wife and concubines
before he puts this into practise.

The wife's younger brother again had great influence with the ruler of Wèy
so she used his influence with the ruler of Wèy to intercede with Wúzǐ.
Wúzǐ did not listen to her.
In the end he left Wèy and entered Jīng.

When in the end he took the new ribbon and compared it with the model

Her father went up to intercede on her behalf
but Wú Qǐ said:
