Duke Wén of Jìn asked Hú Yǎn:
"I have sweet and fat food in all my halls,
beakers of wine and raised platters of meat are assembled in my palace.
Not a pot of wine gets to become mature and pure, gets always drunk before,
the fresh meat never gets properly hung, gets always eaten before.
If I slaughter a single buffalo
I distribute the meat throughout the state,
the products of female labour of the whole year
I use on providing clothes for the officers and soldiers.
Do you think that will be sufficient to cause the people to fight in war?"
Húzǐ said:
"That is not sufficient."
Duke Wén said:
"I have relaxed the official charges at passes and markets
and I have slackened physical punishments and fines.
Should this not be sufficient to make the people fight in war?"
Húzǐ said:
"It is not sufficient."
Duke Wén said:
"When my people have expenses for burial
I personally order my courtiers to look into the matter.
Those who have committed crimes I pardon,
those who are poor and destitute I make presents to.
Should that not be sufficient to make the people fight in war?"
Húzǐ replied:
"It is not enough."
These are all measures designed to show proper care for the means of their livelihood.
But making them fight
is causing them to get killed.
The reason why the people decide to follow you
is because to show proper care for the means of their livelihood.
Since you go against them and cause them to get killed
you lose that which motivated them to decide to follow you.
He asked:
Well then, what would it take to make the people fight in war?"
Húzǐ replied:
"Make sure that they have no other option but to fight."
The Duke asked:
"How can one make sure that they have no other option but to fight?"
Húzǐ replied:
"Predictable rewards and inevitable punishments,
these should be sufficient to make them fight in war."
The Duke said:
"How does one get to is the ultimate point of physical punishments and fines?"
He replied:
"Not to spare those who are close to one, or the noble
and to let the law be applied to those whom one loves."
Duke Wén said:
"Good."
The next day he ordered a hunt at Púlù
They agreed that they would make midday the agreed time.
Those who were late he applied the military law to.
At this point the Duke had a favourite by the name of Diǎn Jié,
and the man was late.
The magistrate asked about the crime he was to be charged with.
Duke Wén shed tears and was worried about what to do.
The magistrate said:
"I beg to set to work on him."
In the end he severed Diǎn Jié's backbone
and displayed his dead body to the noble families
in order to demonstrate that the law was predictable.
After this the noble families all got scared and said:
"If the ruler, when it comes to a person this noble and powerful like Diǎn Jié,
the ruler still applies the law.
What problem will there be in applying it to us?"
Duke Wén saw that the people now could be made to fight in war,
he brought out his army to launch a formal attack on Yuán,
and he conquered the place.
He launched a formal attack on Wèy
made the paths between their fields to go east-west took Wǔlù,
launched a pointed attack against Yáng, overcame Guó,
and launched a formal attack on Cáo.
In the south he besieged Zhèng,
and overturned its upper city walls.
He relieved the siege of Sòng
and upon his return he fought with Jīng at Chéngpú
greatly defeating the people of Jīng.
When he returned from this he made the covenant of Jiàntǔ
and he achieved the just covenant of Héngyǒng.
At one stroke he achieved eight things.
The cause why this came about
was not for any other reason or for any strange thing,
it was because he followed Hú Yǎn's strategy
and availed himself of Diǎn Jié's spine as his instrument.
The pain of ulcers and boils,
unless one punctures the bone and the marrow
it irks the mind and is insupportable.
If one does not understand this
one cannot make other people prick it with a half-inch stone needle.
Now the ruler's relation to good government is also like this.
One is by no means unaware that through pain there would be peace.
If one wishes to govern a state
then unless one acts as in the case of ulcers and boils
one cannot take the advice of sagely competence or punish rebellious ministers.
Rebellious ministers are inevitably powerful men.
Powerful men are inevitably people whom the ruler keeps close to and is fond of.
Those people whom the ruler keeps close to and is fond of
are interlocked with him like the hard and the white in the stone.
Now if with the qualifications of a commoner
one wishes to separate what is interlocked with the ruler like the hard and the whiteand what he loves,
this is like persuading the right thigh to cut off the left thigh.
Such an undertaking leads to the certain death of the person involved,
and the persuasion will not be successful.
Good government and strength have their origin in the law;
Weakness and chaos have their origin in flattery.
If the ruler is clear about this
then he will adjust rewards and punishments precisely,
but he will by no means treat those below him with kindness.
Ranks and stipends have their origin in achievement,
punishments and fines have their origin in crimes.
When the ministers are clear about this
then they will use up all their strength to the point of death,
and that is not because they are loyal to the ruler.
When the ruler has a thorough understanding of not being personally kindly
and the ministers have a thorough understanding of not being personally loyal
then one can become a true king.
Zhāo Xiāng understood the ruler's feelings and did not release supplies in Wǔyuàn. (.)
Tián Wěi understood what it was to be a real minister and therefore taught Tián Zhāng, his son, the art. (.)
Another example is that of Gōngyi refusing the fish. (.)
If the ruler
is orientated towards foreign states
then foreign projects will inevitably succeed in his realm.
Thus Sū Dài spoke ill of the King of Qí.
If the ruler is orientated towards the gentlemen
then private persons will not fail to become distinguished.XXX
Thus Pān Shòu spoke of the real facts about Yǔ
and the ruler failed to realise what was going on.
Fāng Wú understood this,
therefore the people were afraid and did not wear the same clothes as outsiders or associate with people other than those from their own clan.
even less did they associate with others in the exercise of power.
As for a ruler of men
he keeps the law, holds people responsible for achievements
in order to establish those with real achievements.
One hears that when officials in charge are disorderly
there is a people which is in good order;
one has never heard that when there is a rebellious people
the officials in charge are alone in good order.
Therefore the enlightened ruler governs officials, not the people.
The explanation is in shaking a tree by its trunk
and drawing a net by its rope. (.)
Furthermore there is the case of the granary guard who faced the fire. (.)
These are cases that must be discussed.
If when fighting the fire
the enforcement official takes a pot and runs to the fire
then he deploys one person;
if he wields a whip and orders people along
then he can use ten thousand men as his slaves. (.)
Thus if the person faced with these difficulties is professional
then it is like Zàofǔ facing frightened horses:
when he pulls horses along or pushes the cart he is unable to get along,
but if he takes the place of the driver, takes the reins and the whip
then all the horses will race along nicely. (.)
Furthermore the point is illustrated by the iron hammer hammering things flat,
and the bow-straightener straightening out bows. (.)
An example to the contrary
is when Zhuōchi, serving Qi, murderes King Min,
and Li Dui, in the service of Zhào, starving the ruler's father to death.
If one adapts to the principles of things
then without effort one succeeds.
Thus Zi Zhèng sat squatted on his carriage pole and sang
in order to get up on the high bridge. (.)
The disastrous consequences of the contrary are exemplified when Zhào Jiǎn's tax collectors asked about levels of taxation (.)
and when Bóyi spoke about the people in the state being well-fed. (.)
The ruler of Jiǎn was pleased by this remark, but the storehouses were empty;
The people went hungry but the wicked officials were rich.
Further, Duke Huán had the people surveyed
and Guǎnzhòng economised supplies that were rotting away, and sent away unmarried women. (.)
Failure to act according to this principle is exemplified
when the cart-horse in Yānling was unable to proceed
Zàofǔ passed by and was moved to tears by it. (.)
Zào Fǔ was steering his four horses.
They were racing along and doing their turns
and he freely imposed his will on the horses.
Freely imposing one's will on the horses
is because he was in sole control of the regime reins and the whip.
But when the horses are terrified by an emerging swine
and Zào Fǔ is unable to contain and control them,
this is not because the strictness of the reins and the whip are insufficient
is because their awesome authority had to be divided with the emerging swine.
Prince Yú Qí was officer in charge of the extra horse-teams.
Reins and whips he did not use
but he could get his will with the horses:
this is because he was in sole control of fodder and water.
But the reason why the horses trespass on the garden pond
and the officer in charge of the horse-teams loses control
is not because the resources of fodder and water are insufficient,
it is because they have to share his generosity with the garden moat.
Thus Wáng Liáng and Zào Fǔ
are the best charioteers in the world
And yet, if Wáng Liáng urges them to the left, shouting angrily,
and if Zào Fǔ urges them to the right and uses the whip and the rod,
then the horses cannot go as far as ten lǐ.
This is because they share control.
Tián Lián and Chéng Qiào
are the best lute-players in the world;
And yet if Tián Lián strums up,
while Chéng Qiào presses down
then they cannot make a musical tune.
That is also because they have shared control of the instrument.
Now even with the dexterity of a Wáng Liáng or a Zào Fǔ,
if one shares the reins when charioteering one cannot control the horses.
A ruler of men
how can he share power with his ministers in order to conduct government?
Even with the dexterity of Tián Lián and Chéng Qiào,
if they share a lute they cannot play a tune.
A ruler of men
how can he share a position with ministers and achieve success?

a sów was hiding in the ditches.
Prince Yú Qí held reins and whip straight as he approached it.
The pig suddenly emerged from the ditch.
The horse panicked and the charioteering exercise went badly wrong.
Sīchéng Zǐhǎn told the ruler of Sòng:
"Felicitations and rewards as well as gifts
are things that people are delighted to have.
You, my ruler, should administer these yourself.
Executions and punishments
are what people hate.
I ask to take charge of them."
The ruler said:
"All right."
And then he issued an authoritative ordinance
to have a powerful minister executed.
The ruler said:
"Ask Zǐhǎn on this matter."
From then on the powerful ministers stood in awe-struck fear of him
and the petty people flocked to him.
After a whole year
Zǐhǎn killed the ruler of Sòng and usurped the government.
Thus Zǐhǎn, in the fashion of the pig that came out of a ditch
and went on to take away the state from his ruler.
Duke Jiǎn held a high position,
his fines were heavy and his punishments strict.
He imposed heavy levies
and killed people.
Tián Chénghéng established a caring regime,
he promoted large-hearted and generous policies.
Duke Jiǎn considered the people of Qí as thirsty horses
and he did not show special goodwill to the people,
while Tián Chénghéng made goodness and generosity his garden pond.
Another source says:
Zào Fǔ was the officer in charge of the supplementary horse teams for the King of Qí.
He trained the horses by keeping them thirsty.
Within one hundred days the training was complete.
When the training was complete
he asked for a charioteering exercise for the King of Qí.
The King said:
"We shall hold the exercise in the orchard."
Zào Fǔ steered his vehicle into the orchard.
The horses caught sight of the orchard pond and ran away.
Zào Fǔ was unable to stop the horses.
Zào Fǔ had been training horses by keeping them thirsty for a long time.
But now when the horses saw the pond
they went all wild and ran away.
Even a Zào Fǔ could not get them under control.
Duke Jiǎn had long been using the law to keep the masses under control
and Tián Chénghéng benefitted them.
This was a case of Tián Chénghéng making an orchard pond
and showing it to the thirsty people.
Another source says:
Prince Yú Qí was entering a lǐ race with the ruler of Sòng.
They had already harnessed their horses
When they were about to set out
he drove the horses forward:
the wheels hit the ink-line perfectly.
He pulled them back and turned back
and the horses retraced their own steps.
He slapped the horses to send them ahead,
when sow walked out, in a leisurely way, from a ditch.
The horse drew back and refused to take orders.
Whips could not get the horses to go forward.
The horses went wild and ran off,
reins were unable to keep it on a straight course.
Sīchéng Zǐhǎn told the ruler of Sòng:
"Offering congratulatory rewards and gifts
is what the people like.
This you, my ruler, should carry out yourself.
Punishments and executions
are what the people dislike.
I beg to take charge of these."
Then when Zihǎn killed petty people and executed important ministers.
the ruler used to say:
"This you must discuss with Zǐhǎn."
After a year
the people understood that control over life and death was with Zǐhǎn,
therefore the whole state rallied to him.
And so Zǐhǎn went on to kidnap the ruler of Sòng
and he wrested the government from him.
The laws were unable to stop him.
Therefore it is said:
"Zǐhǎn acted as a pig that emerges,
and Tián Chéngcháng acted as an orchard pond."
Now Wáng Liáng and Zào Fǔ, driving a vehicle together,
when each of them reins the horses in to his side
and they leave through the gates and village gates,
then their excursion is bound to fail
and on their way they do not reach their goal.
If Tián Lián and Chéng Qiào play sharing one lute together
and if each man plucks one string and play forth
then the music is bound to fail and the tune will not come out.
King Zhāo of Qín fell ill.
The people bought one buffalo per village
and every family was praying for the King.
When Gōngsūn Shù went out to visit the King,
he went in to congratulate the King and said:
The people buy one buffalo per village
and they pray for Your Majesty."
The King sent someone out to ask around
and this was indeed true.
The King said:
"Fine them two sets of armour per person.
Now without a formal order to pray on one's own authority
that means that they show loving care for me.
Now if they love me
then I will surely be about to change the laws
and to follow along with them in my heart.
This will mean that the law will not be firmly established.
When the law is not firmly established
that is the Way of political turmoil and of ruin.
It will be better that every man be fined two sets of armour
and that I again practise orderly government."
One source writes:
The King of Qín was ill.
His citizenry was praying for him.
The disease got better
and they slaughtered a buffalo as thanksgiving.
The palace officials Zhōng Yān'è and Gōngsūn Yǎn went out
and observed this.
They said:
"This is not the season of sacrifice to the altar of the land or the December sacrifice,
How come that on their own authority they kill buffaloes
and offer sacrifices to the altar of the land?"
They were surprised and they asked around.
The citizenry said:
"When the ruler of men was sick
we were praying for him.
Now that he is better
we are killing buffalo as thanksgiving to the gods."
Yān'è and Gōngsūn Yǎn were pleased.
They went to see the King
they bowed and congratulated him saying:
"You have surpassed Yáo and Shùn."
The King was amazed:
"What do you mean?"
They politely replied:
"In the case of Yáo and Shùn
their people never went so far as to pray for him in thanksgiving.
Now whenYour Majesty were sick
the people were offering prayers with buffalo.
Now that you are better
they kill buffalo to offer thanksgiving.
Therefore we humbly consider that Your Majesty surpassed Yáo and Shùn."
He fined the administrators and the village elders with two sets of armour each.
Yān'è and Gōngsūn Yǎn were embarrassed and did not dare to speak up.
Several months passed.
The King was drinking wine and was tipsy and in excellent spirits.
Yān'è and Gōngsūn Yǎn told the King:
Before, we have humbly considered Your Majesty to have surpssed Yáo and Shùn.
And this was not just because we were presuming to flatter.
When Yáo or Shùn were sick
even then the people did not go so far as to offer prayers on their behalf.
The King then sent someone out to ask about it,
and in which neighbourhoods they were doing this.
Now when you were sick the people offered prayers with buffalo;
then, as you are better,
they kill buffalo and offer thanksgiving.
Now you fine the neighbourhood administrator and the group elders two sets of armour each.
We humbly allow ourselves to be surprised at this."
The King said:
"Why have you no understanding about this?
The reason why the people can be employed by me
is not that because of my love towards them I can make use of them.
It is because my position of power is such that they are used by me.
If I put aside my position of power and get on close terms with the people,
if I do this,
then if by any chance I do not show loving care for them
then the people will not allow themselves to be employed by me.
It is for this reason that I have discontinued the path of loving care."
In Qín there was a great famine
The Lord of Yìng said:
The edible plants in the Five Parks
the vegetables, the chestnuts and dates
are sufficient to make the people survive.
I beg you to issue these to the people."
King Zhāoxiāng said:
"Our Qin laws
insure that the people receive rewards when they have achievements,
that they are punished when they are guilty of crimes.
If we now distribute the vegetables from the Five Parks
then we give all the people rewards whether they have achievements or not.
If we give all the people rewards whether they have achievements or not
that is the way to political disorder.
Rather than distributing things from the Five Parks to get political disorder
it would be better to throw the dates and vegetables away and have good order."
One source says:
"If I distribute the gourds, vegetables, dates and chestnuts from the Five Parks
they will be sufficient to make the people survive.
But this will bring it about that the people, no matter whether they have merits or not, will struggle to get these things.
Rather than having them live in political turmoil
it will be better to have them dead in good political order.
Grandees, you must reject this."
Tián Wěi instructed his son Tián Zhāng and said:
"If you wish to benefit your person
you should first benefit your ruler;
if you wish to make your family rich,
you should first make your state rich.
One source says:
Tián Wěi instructed his son Tiánzhāng as follows:
"The ruler offers offices and ranks for sale,
the minister offers competence and strength for sale.
Therefore they rely on themselves and do not rely on others."
Gōng Yíxiū was prime minister in Lǔ, and he was fond of fish.
Everyone in the whole state was competing to buy fish to present to him.
But Gōng Yízǐ did not accept.
His younger brother remonstrated with him and said:
"You are very fond of fish, but you do not accept them.
Why is that?"
Gōng Yíxiū replied politely:
It is exactly because I am very fond of fish
that I do not accept them.
If I accept the fish
I would certainly have to pander to the reactions from people below.
If I pander to the reactions from people below
then I shall distort the law.
If I distort the law then I get removed as prime minister.
Then even if I am very fond of fish
these people will not come along with their fish,
and moreover I cannot supply the fish myself.
When not accepting the fish and not being removed as a prime minister,
then even if I am still very fond of fish
I am able to supply myself with fish forever.
This makes it clear that instead of relying on others it is better to rely on onself.
He clearly understood that instead of having others working for one
it is best to work for oneself.
When Zǐzhī governed Yān
his status was high and he monopolised decisions.
When Sū Dài was ambassador of Qí in Yān
the King asked him:
"What kind of a ruler must the King of Qí be?"
He replied:
"He is bound not to be become hegemon."
The King of Yān said:
"Why is that?"
He replied:
"Formerly, when Duke Huán became hegemon,
internal matters belonged under Bāoshū,
and external affairs belonged under Guǎn Zhòng.
Duke Huán let down his hair, slept with his women,
and every day he was wandering about in the markets.
The present King of Qí does not trust his powerful ministers."
At that point the King of Yān showed even greater faith in Zǐzhī.
When Zǐzhī heard about this
he sent someone to give Sū Dài one hundred taels of gold
and he followed Sū Dài's dispositions.
Another source says:
Sū Dài was ambassador for Qí in Yān
and he realised that unless he increased the power of Zǐzhī
he would return without achieving his purpose
and he would not be able to take out gifts for Qí and rewards for himself.
Then he went to see the King of Yān
and he praised the King of Qí.
The King of Yān said:
"How is it that the King of Qí is as talented as this?
He is bound to become a true king under these circumstances."
Sū Dài said:
"He hasn't even the time to save himself from ruin.
How could he become a true king?"
The King of Yān said:
"Why is that?"
He replied: "In employing those whom he loves he is not even-handed."
The King of Yān said:
"Why is he heading for ruin?"
Sū Dài replied:
"In ancient times Duke Huán of Qí loved Guǎn Zhòng
and established him as Senior Advisor Zhòng.
Internal matters were handled by him
external matters were decided by him.
The wholse state rallied to him.
So he united all under Heaven
and routinely summoned together the feudal lords nine times.
Now Qí, in employing those they love, are not even-handed.
That is how I know that they are heading for ruin."
The King of Yān said:
"Now I am relying on Zǐzhī,
is that not widely known by everyone?"
Then, the next day, he arranged for a court meeting
and he took the advice of Zǐzhī.
Pān Shòu told the King of Yān:
"Your Majesty had better hand over the state to Zǐzhī.
The reason why people call Yáo a man of talent
was because he handed over the Empire to Xǔ Yóu.
But Xǔ Yóu was determined not to accept the offer
so that Yáo became famous for handing over to Xǔ Yóu
but in fact he did not lose control of the empire.
If you now hand over the state to Zǐzhī
Zǐzhī is bound not to accept the offer
and so Your Majesty will be famous for handing over to Zǐzhī
and you will have acted like Yáo."
Then the King of Yān turned all state affairs over to him..
Zǐzhī became a very powerful man.
One source says:
When Pān Shòu
was a recluse
Yān sent someone along to invite him to court.
Pān Shòu visited the King of Yān and said:
"I fear that Zǐzhī is like Yì (minister to Emperor Yǔ)."
The King said:
"How could he be like Yì?"
He replied:
"In ancient times when Yǔ was about to die
he was going to hand over the empire to Yì.
Adherents of Qǐ then combined forces to attack Yì and they established Qǐ.
Now you trust and love Zǐzhī,
and you are going to hand over the state to Zǐzhī
but the crown prince's adherents have all the official seals
Of the men who are in favour of Zǐzhī
there is not one in the court.
If by some unfortunate chance you abandon your ministers and die
then Zǐzhī will also be in the position of Yì.
The King then collected all the clerks' seals,
those seals granting officials with more than stone of grain he gave to Zǐzhī.
Zǐzhī became very powerful.
Those through whom the ruler sees the world as in a mirror
are the followers of foreign feudal lords.
But now the followers of the feudal lords
all form cliques of private households.
Those through whom the ruler gets grassroot opinions
are the adherents of the recluses in the mountain caves.
But now all the adherents of recluses in the caves
are retainers of private households.
Why is this?
It is because the resources for taking away or giving are with Zǐzhī.
Therefore Wú Zhāng says:
"The ruler of men does not pretend to hate or love others.
When he pretends to love others
he cannot then go on to hate them again.
he does not pretend to hate others
he cannot then go on to love them again.
Another source says:
The King of Yān wanted to hand over state affairs go Zǐzhī
and asked Pān Shòu about him.
Pān Shòu replied politely:
"Yǔ loved Yì and entrusted the empire to Yì.
but after a while he employed Qǐ's men as officials.
When he had reached old age
he considered that Qǐ was not qualified to be entrusted with the empire
and so he handed over the empire to Yì,
but the power and the political weight was all on the side of Qǐ.
In the end Qǐ and his clique attacked Yì and they wrested the empire from him.
Thus in name Yǔ handed over the empire to Yì
but in fact he caused Qǐ to take it for himself.
Thus it is clear that Yǔ was inferior to Yáo and Shùn.
Now you want to turn over state affairs to Zǐzhī,
but the minor officials are all of them the crown prince's men.
This is to hand it over in name but in fact to cause the crown prince to take it for himself."
Then the King of Yān collected the seals
those from officials with a salary above stone he gave to Zǐzhī.
As a result of all this Zǐzhī became powerful.
Fāng Wúzǐ said:
"I have heard that there is an old ritual:
when travelling one should not be in the same vehicle with a man wearing clothes of the same rank
and one should not share the household with a person of the same clan.
How much less should one, when one is a ruler of men,
lend out one's control of power and place the position of power outside!"
Wú Zhāng told King Xuān of Hán:
"The ruler of men should not put on a show of loving people,
for after a day he cannot again hate them;
he should not put on a show of hating people
for after a day he cannot again love them.
Thus when the signs of making a show of love or hatred are in evidence
then the toadies will avail themselves of that and malign or praise them.
Even an enlightened ruler
cannot call back such signs,
how much less can he call them back if he has lent out substance to others?"
King Zhào was wandering in his park.
His entourage were giving a rabit to a tiger, but they stopped in the process.
The animal made big angry eyes.
The King said:
"How hateful
these tiger's eyes"
His entourage said:
The eyes of the ruler of Píngyáng are even more hateful than these
Seeing the tiger's is not quite harmful,
but if you see the eyes of the ruler of Píngyáng like this
then you are bound to die."
The next day
the ruler of Píngyáng heard about this
and sent someone out to kill the man who had made the remark,
but the King did not punish this crime.
The ruler of Wèy attended court in Zhōu.
The master of etiquette in Zhōu asked him about his appellation.
He replied politely:
"Feudal lord, Pì Jiāng."
The master of etiquette Zhōu rejected this and said:
"Feudal lords cannot have the same appellations as the Son of Heaven."
Thereupon the ruler of Wèy changed it himself and said:
"Feudal lord Calumniation."
Only after this did they let him go in.
When Confucius heard about this he said:
"How far-reaching, these prohibitions against usurpation.
Even a name without substance they did not lend to others,
how much less real matters (such as political power)."
If one wants to shake the leaves off a tree
and one plucks off the leaves one by one,
then that will be hard work but will not lead to a complete result;
But if you push the trunk from one side to the other
then the leaves will all get shaken off.
If close to a deep pool you shake a tree
then the birds, scared up, fly high;
the fish, terrified, dive deep.
Someone who is good at spreading nets will pull the main line.
If you pull each and every one of the myriad loops before you succeed
then this is hard work, and troublesome.
If you pull the guide-rope
then the fish are already bagged.
Thus the officials
are the trunk of the people,
they are the guide-rope.
And so the sage governs the officials, he does not govern the people.
As for the fire-brigade,
if one orders an official to carry the jugs and pots and run to the fire
then he will perform the duty of one person;
if he holds the whip and orders people about and urges them on
then he will control ten thousand fellows.
Therefore the sage does not show personal concern for ordinary people,
and the enlightened ruler does not personally engage in slight matters.
Zào Fǔ was hoeing in the fields
and at that time a son and his father where riding past in a cart.
The horses stalled and would not go on.
The son got down from the cart and pulled the horses on,
father and son pushed the cart,
and they asked Zào Fǔ: "Can you help us push the cart?"
Zào Fǔ thereupon gathered his utensils
he stopped hoeing and put them on the cart.
He took control of the son's team of four horses,
and then he began to take the reins and the whip,
but before he had to use them
the horses were racing forward with awesome speed.
If Zào Fǔ had not been able to steer horses
then even if he had used all his strength and worn out his body
to help them push the cart,
the horses would still not have been willing to move forward.
Now the reason why while he personally could be at ease,
loaded up his gear
and still showed generosity to the others
is because he had a skill, and he steered things accordingly.
Thus the state
is the ruler's cart;
the position of power
is the ruler's horses.
If he does not have the technique to steer them
then even if he wears out his body
he can still not avoid rebellious disorder.
If he does have the technique to steer them
then personally he will occupy a leisurely position
and at the same time he will achieve the work of a divine king.
As for cudgels and hammers
they are means to flatten what is not even;
the bèng qíng straightener
is an instrument with which to straighten out what is not straight.
The sage's practice according to the law
is his way of flattening what is not even,
of straightening what is not straight.
When Nào Chǐ was in charge of Qí
he pulled out the tendons of King Mǐn;
When Lǐ Duì was in charge of Zhào
he starved the king, who liked to call himself Zhǔfù, to death.
These two rulers
were all unable to use their hammers and bow-straighteners.
As a result they died and were killed,
and they became the laughing stock of the world.
One source says:
When one went to Qí
then one would only hear about Nào Chǐ and not about the King of Qí;
when one went to Zhào
then one would only hear about Lǐ Duì and not about the King of Zhào.
Therefore it is said:
If the ruler of men does not use the art of government
then his position of power and authority will be slight
and the ministers will monopolise fame.
One source says:
King Wǔlíng ordered King Huìwén to take charge of the government
and Lǐ Duì served as prime minister.
King Wǔlíng did not personally hold the handle of life and death
and as a result he was kidnapped by Lǐ Duì.
Zī Zhèngzǐ was pulling a carriage onto a high bridge but he was unable to move it up (by himself).
Zī Zhèng squatted on the carriage pole and sang a song.
Those who were ahead of him stopped,
those who came behind hurried forward,
and so the man-drawn carriage got up to the bridge.
If Zī Zhèng had not had the art of attracting others
then even if he had used all his strength until he died
the man-drawn carriage would still not get up.
Now the reason why his body did not go as far as to put in effort and to suffer hardship
and the man-drawn carriage still got up on the bridge
was because he had an art of attracting people.
Ruler Jiǎn of Zhào was sending out tax-collectors
and the officials asked whether the taxes should be light or heavy.
Ruler Jiǎn said:
"Do not make them too light or too heavy.
If they are too heavy
then the advantage will go to those above;
if they are too light
then the advantage will go to the people.
The officials should not be concerned with particular advantage and be straight.
Báo Yí told Ruler Jiǎn of Zhào:
"In Your Excellency's state people are well-fed."
Ruler Jiǎn was delighted and said:
"How that?"
Báo Yí replied politely:
"The storehouses and the armouries are empty above,
the people are poor and hungry below,
but in the middle the corrupt minor officials are getting rich."
Duke Huán of Qí went incognito to inspect the homes of the people.
There was an old man who was supporting himself.
Duke Huán asked for the reason.
The man replied politely:
"I have three sons.
My family is poor and we have no way of finding a wife for them.
They are out on corvee service and have not yet returned."
When Duke Huán returned
he told Guǎn Zhòng about this.
Guǎn Zhòng said:
"When supplies rot away and are discarded
then people go hungry;
when in the harem there are marriable women
then the people have no wives."
Duke Huán said:
"Good"
Then he assessed the women in the harem and married them off.
He issued an ordinance to the people saying:
"A man should start a family at twenty;
a woman should get married at fifteen."
Duke Huán was incognito and walked aroun among the common people.
There was a certain Lùménjì
who was seventy years old but had no wife.
Duke Huán asked Guǎn Zhòng:
"Are there commoners who have no wives?"
Guǎn Zhòng said:
"There is a certain Lùménjì
who is already seventy but still has no wife."
Duke Huán said:
"How can we get him to have a wife?"
Guǎn Zhòng said:
"I have learnt:
When those above pile up goods
then the people and the minsters suffer need below;
when in the harem there are unmarried women marriable age
then there are old people who are old but have no wives."
Duke Huán said:
"Good"
He gave out an order to his harem:
"Those women with whom I have never slept are to be married off."
Then he ordered males to get married at twenty
and females to get married at fifteen.
As a result there were no young women of marriagable age in the harem
and outside there were no bachelors of marriageable age.
Yánlíng Zhuōzǐ was riding in a carriage with azure dragon and wild hen decorations;
the constraining hooks for the horses were decorated up front
and there was a decorated top-needle on the whip.
When the horses wanted to proceed but the decoration on the bit stopped them,
when they wanted to pull back the decorated whip-top egged them on.
As a result the horses ran off to the sides.
When Zào Fǔ passed by he shed tears on their behalf
and said:
"The way of governing men in antiquity was also like that.
Rewards are designed to encourage, but there is criticism in them;
fines are designed to stop things, but there is praise in them.
When the people stand in the middle and do not know what to follow
that surely is an occasion for the sage to shed tears on their behalf.
One source says:
Yánlíng Zhuōzǐ was riding in a carriage with azure dragon and wild hen decorations.
Up front there were decorated bits for the horses,
behind there was a whip with a decorated top.
When the horses moved forward he would pull them back
and if they widrew he would urge them on.
The horses were unable to go forward
and they were unable to draw back.
As a result they got away and ran wild.
So Yánlíng Zhuōzǐ got down, pulled his dagger and cut off their feet.
When Zào Fǔ saw this he wept.
One source says:
Yánlíng Zhuōzǐ was riding in a carriage with azure dragon and wild hen decorations.
Up front there were decorated bits for the horses,
behind there was a whip with a decorated top.
When the horses moved forward he would pull them back
and if they widrew he would urge them on.
The horses were unable to go forward
and they were unable to draw back.
As a result they got away and ran wild.
So Yánlíng Zhuōzǐ got down, pulled his dagger and cut off their feet.
When Zào Fǔ saw this he wept.
He did not eat all day.
Then he threw back his head, looked up to Heaven and said:
"The whip
is designed to urge on
but there are bits in front;
pulling
is designed to hold back
but there is the sharp whip behind.
Now the ruler of men promotes people because of their moral purity,
and he demotes them because they do not fit into his entourage.
Jiù Fàn said:
"I have heard it said:
"Gentlemen who are fastidious about ritual
can never get too much of loyal effort and good faith;
but on the batlle field
they can never get enough of deceit.
Your Excellency should use tactics of deception, that is all."
Duke Wén sent Jiù Fàn away,
but he went on to summon Yōng Jì to consult him
and he said: "I am about to go to battle with the people of Chǔ.
They are in the majority, we are in the minority.
What can we do?"
Yōng Jì replied politely:
"If you burn the forests and go on a hunt,
and secretly take a lot of wild animals,
then afterwards there will be no wild animals left.
If you deal with people through deceit
you may secretly get away with it at one point of time,
but afterwards you will not be able to do it again.
Duke Wén said:
"Good."
He said farewell to Yōng Jì.
Using Jiù Fàn's plan he went to war with the people of Chǔ and defeated them.
When he returned from the campaign he distributed honours
and put Yōng Jì first and Jiù Fàn last.
The ministers said:
"The undertaking at Chéngpú
was Jiù Fàn's plan.
Now to use his proposal but put his person last,
is that acceptable?"
Duke Wén said:
"This is not something you people understand.
Jiù Fàn's proposal
was an expedient means at one partiuclar point in time;
Yōng Jì's proposal
was something that will be of benefit for myriads of generations."
Zhòngní heard about this
and he said:
"That Duke Wén should become a hegemon
was only proper.
He both understands the expedient means for one point of time
and he also understands what is of benefit for myriads of generations."
Someone said:
Yōng Jì's reply
does not fit Duke Wén's question.
In general when one replies to a consulting question
one will reply according to the importance and the urgency of the question.
If what one is asked about is elevated and grand
and one replies with something lowly and narrow
then the enlightened ruler will refuse to accept this.
Now Duke Wén asked about dealing with a majority with the support of a minority,
and the reply was that "later one will certainly not do the same".
This is not something with which to respond to the question
Moreover, Duke Wén did not understand the expediency of one moment,
nor did he understand what would benefit one over myriad generations.
If he goes to war and wins
then the state will be at peace and his person will be firmly established,
his military force will be strong and his authority well established.
Even if he does indeed do this again
no success can be greater than this.
Then as to the benefits of myriads of generations
why should he worry about them not arriving?
If he goes to war and does not win
then his state will be ruined and his armed strength will be weakened,
personally he will die and his name will be extinguished,
then as for extricating himself from death today that will be beyond his reach
how should he have any opportunity to wait for the benefits of myriads of generations?
Waiting for the benefits for myriads of generations
is all about victory today;
today's victory
is all about carrying out deceit vis-a-vis the opponent.
Deceiving the enemy
is simply providing benefit for myriad generations.
That is why I maintain:
Yōng Jì's reply
did not respond to Duke Wén's question.
Moreover, Duke Wén did not understand Jiù Fàn's words.
When Jiù Fàn said:
'Cannot get enough of deceit"
he did not refer to cheating the people,
he referred to cheating the enemy.
Now as for the enemy,
that is the state which one is formally attacking.
Even if afterwards one will not be able to do it again,
what is the harm?
The reason why Duke Wén put Yōng Jì first,
was that because of his achievements?
No, on the contrary what he used to win against Chǔ and destroy their army
was Jiù Fàn's plan.
Was it because Yōng Jì was well-spoken?
No, on the contrary Yōng Jì said:
'Later one cannot do it again'
and this is not quite a sound proposition.
Jiù Fàn, on the contrary, did combine these virtues.
When Jiù Fàn said
'The gentleman fastidious about ritual
never tires of loyal effort and good faith'
then this loyal effort
was that by which he shows fondness of those below;
good faith
was that by which he did not cheat his people.
Now if one already takes good care of people and does not deceive
then what speech is better than this.
But that he had to speak of things resulting from deceit
was because his was a military plan.
Jiù Fàn had the good words at the outset
and afterwards he conducted a successful war.
Thus Jiù Fàn had two achievements and was given lowest priority,
Yōng Jì did not have one achievement but received the first reward.
"That Duke Wén became a hegemon,
was that not fitting?"
Saying this, Confucius showed ignorance what it is to be good at giving rewards.
Some peasants at Mount Lì were trespassing on the borders between fields.
Shùn went there to do agricultural work.
After one year
the watering channels between the fields and the ridge-boundaries were straight and clear.
On the banks of the Yellow River the fishermen were fighting over islets.
Shùn went there for fishing
and after one year the fishermen were yielding to the seniors in each case.
The Eastern Yí barbarians made earthenware vessels that were not solid.
Shùn went there to engage in pottery.
After one year the earthenware vessels were solid.
Confucius sighed and said:
"Agricultural work, fishing and pottery
do not fall under the office that Shùn held,
but Shùn went along and took care of these things.
That is how he saved the places from decline.
Shùn was truly a humane person
And so he personally went along and sufferend hardship
so that the people followed him.
Thus is is said:
The virtue of a sage has a transforming quality."
Someone asked a Rú:
"At this moment
where is Yáo?"
The man said:
"Yáo was the Son of Heaven."
Well then,
why did Confucius regared Yáo as a sage?
If a sagely person has clear insight in the top position
then he will see to it that there is no wickedness in the world.
Now if peasants and fishermen do not quarrel,
and the pottery vessels were no longer defective
then what virtue does Shùn need to transform things?
That Shùn saved these places from decline
was due to Yáo's mistakes.
If one considers Shùn as talented
then one has to take away Yáo's clear insight;
if one regards Yáo as a sage,
then one take away Shùn's transformation through virtue.
One cannot have it both ways.
In Chǔ there was someone who was offering shields and lances for sale.
He praised his goods and said:
"My shield is so solid
nothing is able to pierce it."
Again he went on to praise his lances and said:
"My lances are so sharp
there is nothing that they do not pierce."
Someone commented:
"If one tries to pierce your shield with your lance,
what will happen then?"
The man in question was unable to give an immediate reply.
A shield that cannot be pierced
and a lance that will pierce anything,
cannot coexist in the same world.
Now the fact that one cannot praise both Yáo and Shùn
is because of the explanation about lances and shields.
Moreover, when Shùn was saving people from decline
in the course of one year he corrected one wrong practice,
in the course of three years he corrected three wrong practices.
Shùn is limited,
one's lifespan is limited.
But the wrong practices in the world are without end.
Now if with limited resources one goes after something limitless
then what one stops will be little.
If one ensures that rewards and punishments are regularly carried out in the world
and issues an ordinance saying:
'Those who match the standard will be rewarded,
those who refuse to match up to the standard will be punished.'
then if that order arrives in the morning the change will have occurred in the evening
if it arrives in the evening the change will have happened the next morning.
Within ten days all within the seas will be completely changed.
Why wait for a whole year?
Now Shùn still did not use this to persuade Yáo and to cause Yáo to follow him
but he personally attended to things himself.
Is that not a striking lack of political skill?
Now to suffer hardship oneself
and only after that to transform and educate the people,
that is what Yáo and Shùn found hard to do;
but to occupy a position of power and to set right those below
that is what a mediocre ruler finds it easy to do.
If one is going to govern the world
but discards what the mediocre ruler finds easy
but takes as one's path what Yáo and Shùn found hard,
then one is not a proper person to run an administration with."
Guǎn Zhòng was ill.
Duke Huán went along on a visit to the sick man
and he said:
"Senior Advisor Zhòng, you are sick.
If by some unfortunate chance you finish your great lifespan
what will you tell me?"
Guǎn Zhòng replied:
"If you had not brought this up
I, your humble servant, would have gone to visit you.
I hope you will remove Shù Diāo, that you cut out Yì Yá,
and that you keep Prince Kāifāng of Wèy at a distance.
When Yì Yá was in charge of food for Your Excellency,
and Your Excellency had eaten everything except human flesh.
So Yì Yá steamed his son's head and offered it up to him.
Now it is of the essential nature of humans that they take loving care of their sons.
Now he refused to take loving care of his son.
How can he take loving care of his ruler?
Your Excellency was jealous and fond of the harem,
Shù Diāo unmanned himself in order to take charge of the harem.
It is in the essential nature of men that they take loving care of their bodies.
Even his body he did not take loving care of.
How can he take loving care of Your Excellency?
Kāifāng had served Your Excellency for fifteen years,
Between Qí and Wèy the distance is only a few day's travel,
but he discarded his mother,
he served for a long time and never returned home.
Even his mother he did not take loving care of,
how can he love Your Excellency?
I have heard it:
'Bragging lies do not last long;
covering up untruths will only work for so long.'
I hope Your Excellency will remove these three men."
In the end Guǎn Zhòng died,
but Duke Huán would not carry out these measures.
When Duke Huán died
the worms were crawling out of the room where his dead body lay but he was not buried.
Someone might say:
What Guǎn Zhòng gave Duke Huán
was not the proposal of a man of precise judgment.
The reason why he was supposed to remove Shù Diāo and Yì Yá
was because they did not take good care of their persons
and adapted to the desires of the ruler.
He said: "They do not take loving care of their person
how can they take loving care of the ruler?"
So there were ministers who were willing to use all their strength to work for their ruler,
but Guǎn Zhòng refused to employ these.
It says: "They are not sparing in the use of all their strength,
how can they love the ruler?"
This is to want the ruler to remove his devoted ministers.
Moreover, because somebody not taking proper care of their persons
to reckon that they did not love their ruler
this would be to reckon that because Guǎn Zhòng was unable to die for Prince Jiū
he would not die for Duke Huán.
Thus Guǎn Zhòng is surely within the realm of those to be removed.
The Way of the enlightened ruler is not like this
he arranges for what people desire and goes on to demand their successful performance.
Therefore he gives honours and stipends in order to encourage people.
He sets up what people dislike in order to constrain the wicked.
Therefore he sets up physical punishments and fines in order to show his authority.
Felicitations and rewards are dependable and punishments and fines inevitable.
Therefore the ruler elevates the rank of those with achievements among the ministers,
and the wicked do not get employed by their superiors.
Then even if there is Shù Diāo
what can he do to the ruler?
Moreover, when ministers give their utmost
they thereby enter a trading agreement with the ruler;
the ruler dispenses honours and stipends
and he thereby enters a trading agreement with the ministers.
The interaction between ruler and ministers
is not as close as that between father and son:
it is the result of calculated strategy.
When the ruler has the Way
then the ministers will do their best and crooks will not arise;
when he does not have the Way
then the ministers will block the intelligence of the ruler above
and below they will form private interest groups.
The fact is that Guǎn Zhòng did not make this calculated strategy clear
to Duke Huán.
If he had removed Shù Diāo
then another Shù Diāo would have arisen.
That is not the way to uproot wickedness.
Moreover, the reason why Duke Huan, when he died,
had worms from his corpse crawling out of the door and did not get buried,
that was because his ministers were too powerful.
The underlying reality of the ministers being too powerful is that they usurp the position of the ruler.
If there are ministers who usurp the position of the ruler
then the ruler's orders are not meticulously carried out below,
and the real affairs among the ministers do not get communicated upwards.
The power of one person can cause a blockage between ruler and minister,
it can bring it about that efficiency and failure do not become known,
that disaster and good fortune does not get reported properly.
Therefore he suffered the disaster of not being buried properly.
The Way of the enlightened ruler is this:
one person does not combine several offices,
one office does not combine several different kinds of tasks;
humble people will not be promoted depending on the noble,
important ministers will not depend on the entourage to see the ruler.
The various offices are each perfected,
the various ministers wheel around to perfom their duties.
When there are rewards the ruler is aware of the achievement,
when there are punitive sanctions, the ruler understands the crime.
When awareness and understanding are not confused before the performance
then rewards and punishments for that performance will not be based on ignorance afterwards.
How can there then be the trouble of not getting buried?
Guǎn Zhòng by no means clarified these words to Duke Huán,
but he tried to make him remove these three people.
That is why one must conclude:
Guǎn Zhòng does not have the sound judgment.
Xiāngzǐ was besieged in the Jìnyáng area.
He escaped from the siege,
and he rewarded five people who had made important contributions.
Gāo Hè was at the head of the list of people who got rewards.
Zhāng Mèngtán said:
"In the events in Jìnyáng
Hè did not make any great contributions.
Now he is at the head of the list of people who got rewards.
Why is that?"
Xiāngzǐ said:
"The events in Jìnyáng
involved danger for my state
and grave danger for the altars of the land and grain.
Among my ministers all were thinking arrogant and humiliating thoughts.
Only Hèzǐ meticulously followed the rituals between ruler and subject.
Therefore I put him first.
When Confucius heard about this he said:
"He is good at handing out rewards, this Xiāngzǐ.
If one rewards one person then no one in the world will dare to go against ritual."
Someone may say:
Confucius does not understand what it is to be good at handing out rewards.
Now if one is good at handing out rewards and punishments
then all the officials will not dare to go beyond their official duties
the various ministers will not dare to be remiss with ritual propriety.
If those above establish the right laws
then those below will not have wicked and deceitful attitudes,
and if one does this
then that may be called being good at handing out rewards and punishments.
If in the case of Xiāngzǐ in Jìnyáng
orders had not been carried out
and prohibitions had not been respected,
then under such circumstances Xiāngzǐ would have had no state
and Jìnyáng would have had no ruler.
Then with whom should he have defended the place?
Now when Xiāngzǐ was in Jìnyáng
and the Zhì inundated his place
so that the mortars and ovens became breeding places for turtles,
still the people did not think of rebelling.
This is because ruler and subjects were on close terms.
Xiāngzǐ enjoyed the privileges of a close relations between ruler and subjects,
he was in charge of the implementation of the laws in regard of orders and prohibitions,
but still he had arrogant ministers.
This was because Xiāngzǐ failed with respect to the application of punitive measures.
As for ministers
when they loook after their affairs and have success, then they are rewarded.
But now Hè only managed not to be arrogant
and Xiāngzǐ rewarded him.
This is to be careless about rewards.
The enlightened ruler will not give rewards to those without achievements,
and he will not take punitive measures against those without a crime.
Now Xiāngzǐ did not punish the arrogant ministers
but he rewarded Hè, who had no achievements to his credit.
How could this be because of Xiāngzi's being good at giving rewards?
Therefore one says:
"Confucius did not understand what it is to be good at giving rewards."
Duke Píng of Jìn was drinking with the various ministers.
When people were tipsy
he sighed deeply and said:
"Nothing is more delightful than being the ruler of men.
One just says something, and no one dares oppose it."
Music Master Kuáng was sitting up front,
he took up his lute and threw it at him.
The Duke pulled open his lapels and shunned the attack.
The lute was smashed against the wall.
The Duke said:
"Whom are you, Grand Music Master, throwing this at?"
Music Master Kuàng said:
"Just now there was petty man's talk at my side
therefore I threw the instrument at the culprit."
The Duke said:
"But that was me"
Music Master Kuàng said:
"Oh, was it?
Well, such are not words of someone ruling over men."
The entourage begged to remove him from office.
The Duke said:
"Let him go free.
I may use him as a warning for me."
Someone may say:
Duke Píng was wrong about the way of rulership
and Music Master Kuàng was wrong about ritual.
When one disapproves of someone's behaviour then to punish this person,
that is the attitude of the ruler towards his ministers;
when one disapproves someone's behaviour
then to put forward a proposal in this regard,
and if one's good counsel is not heeded
then to keep at a distance
that is the minister's attitude towards a ruler.
Now Music Master Kuàng disapproved of Duke Píng's behaviour
and he did not present the counsel of a minister
but he practised the punishment of a ruler.
He picked up the lute and moved it close to his body.
This is to go against he ranking of high and low
and it is to go against ritual propriety for a minister.
Now as for a minister,
when the ruler makes a mistake he will remonstrate,
when his remonstrations are not heeded
then he should think little of rank and stipends and stay in attendance.
This is ritual propriety for the minister.
Now Music Master disapproved of Duke Píng's mistake,
he lifted the lute and attacked the duke with it.
Even a stern father would not do this to his son
but Music Master Kuàng did this to his ruler.
This is a method of gross obstinacy.
When his subject practised gross obstinacy
Duke Píng was delighted and listened to his advice.
This is to fail with regard to the Way of the ruler.
Thus the action of Duke Píng should not be regarded as enlightened,
for this would cause the ruler of men to make mistakes listening to others' advice
and not to understand his failures.
Neither must the behaviour of Music Master Kuàng be regarded as enlightened,
for this would make wicked ministers to be unwarranted and excessive in remonstration
and it would be to embellish what is in effect the assassination of a ruler.
One cannot regard them both as enlightened.
These are both mistaken.
Thus one says:
Duke Píng failed with respect to the Way of a ruler of men
and Music Master Kuàng also failed with respect ot the ritual propriety for subjects.
During the times of Duke Huán of Qí
there was a recluse by the name of Minor Subject Jì.
Duke Huán went three times but failed to get to see him.
Duke Huán said:
"I have heard that commoners
unless they think of honours and stipends as trifling
have no way of treating a ruler over ten thousand chariots lightly;
and as for a ruler over ten thousand chariots,
unless he loves morality.
he is also unable to show deep respect to freemen."
And so after he had gone for a fifth time and got to see him.
Someone might say:
Duke Huán did not understand morality.
As for morality
it is to worry of what is harmful to the world
and hasten to fend off disaster for the whole state,
not to avoid humiliation in all this is called morality.
Thus Yī Yǐn considered that the central states were in turmoil
and by acting as a meat-cook he sought to make connections with Tāng.
Bǎilǐ Xī considered that Qín was in turmoil
and by acting as a prisoner he sought to make connections with Duke Mù.
Both these men were worried about harm to the world
and rushed forward to fend off disaster for the whole state.
They did not decline to do this because of humiliation and public disgrace.
That is why one calls them morally principled.
Now Duke Huán has the power of someone with ten thousand chariots
but he treated ordinary freemen with respect
wanted to show proper care for the state of Qí.
But Xiǎochén Ji did not go along with this.
This shows that Xiǎochén Ji disregarded the people.
Now morality
is not to fail in the observance of ritual propriety between ruler and subject
and not to mix up the positions of ruler and of subject.
Thus within the four borders
anyone who comes to court with his offering of a wild bird is called a subject.
Those subjects and officials who have got their separate duties and tasks are called the people.
Now this Xiǎochén Ji was among the common people
but he went against the desires of a ruler above.
So this cannot be called acting according to moral principles.
And although there was no morality in him
Duke Huán still went along and treated him with politeness.
If Xiǎochén Ji ha a kind of knowledge or abilty but hid it from Duke Huán
then that would have been a case of hiding talent,
and he ought to have suffered physical punishment.
But if he had no intellectual ability
and just inanely was arrogant and boastful towards Duke Huán,
then that was deceit,
and he should have been executed.
Xiǎochén Ji's behaviour
had to be punished either by physical punishment or by execution.
Duke Huán was unable to administer the principles governing subjects and rulers,
and he showed politeness to a person deserving physical punishment or execution.
In such a way Duke Huán taught the habit of slighting superiors and of humiliating rulers to the state of Qí.
This is not the way of carrying out good government.
Thus one says:
Duke Huán did not understand morality.
In the campaign at Míjī
Hán Xiànzǐ was about to behead someone.
When Xì Xiànzǐ heard about this
he drove out to save the man.
When he arrived they had already beheaded him.
Xìzǐ then said:
"Why not display his body to the public?"
His servant replied:
"Weren't you going to save him before?"
Xìzǐ said:
"How would I dare not to share the public blame with Hán Xiànzǐ?"
Someone might say:
Xìzǐ's words
have to be studied carefully.
For it was not a matter of sharing the public blame.
As for the person whom Hánzǐ had executed
if he was guilty
then it was not right to save him.
Saving people who are guilty
leads to the ruin of the law.
When the laws are ruined then the state is in turmoil.
If on the other hand the person was not guilty
then it was not right to encourage him to display the body in public.
Encouraging him to display the body in public
was to mete out harsh punishment to an innocent person.
Meting out harsh punishment to an annocent person
is the sort of thing that gives rise to resentment among the people.
When the people are resentful then the state is in danger.
Xìzǐ's words
are either dangerous or conducive to turmoil.
One has to investigate them carefully.
Moreover, if the man whom Hánzǐ killed was guilty
what brunt of criticism was there for Xìzǐ to share?
If the executed person was not guilty
then when after he has already been executed
Xìzǐ arrives
under such circumstances criticism against Hánzǐ has already taken shape
and Xìzǐ is coming late.
For Xìzǐ to say 'Display his body'
is not enough to share the blame for killing someone,
but it does produce criticism for displaying the dead body.
Is that the kind of sharing the blame that Xìzǐ is talking about?
In ancient times Zhòu roasted people alive on red-hot metal rods
and Chónghóu and Wūlái chimed in:
cut off the shins of those who wade through the river.
How was that a way of sharing the brunt of the criticism against Zhòu?
Moreover, the people have very high expectations of their superiors.
From Hánzǐ there were unable to get it,
and moreover they were looking to Xìzǐ to get it.
Now if they were unable to get it from Xìzǐ either
then the people were disappointed in their superiors.
Therefore one says:
Xìzǐ's words are not designed to share the brunt of criticism.
On the contrary they increased the criticism.
Moreover, since Xìzǐ went out to save a culprit
this was because he considered Hánzǐ as wrong.
Not to talk about what he regarded as wrong
and to encourage him to 'publicly display the corpse',
such behaviour was designed not to let Hánzǐ understand his mistake.
Now if below one makes the people no longer look up to their superiors
and moreover one causes Hánzǐ not to understand his failures,
then I do not quite see how Xìzǐ can share the blame of Hánzǐ.
Duke Huán loosened Guǎn Zhòng's fetters and made him prime minister.
Guǎn Zhòng said:
"Now I have won your appreciation,
but my status is still low."
The Duke said:
"I shall put you above Gāo and Guó."
Guǎn Zhòng said:
"Now I am noble,
but I am poor."
The Duke said:
"I shall see to it that your family has the three-tenth taxation revenue.
Guǎn Zhòng said:
"I am rich,
but I am being kept at a distance."
And so the Duke appointed him as Senior Advisor Zhòng.
Xiāo Lyè said:
"Guǎn Zhòng thinks that as a humble person he cannot govern the noble
therefore he asks to be given a status above the Gāo and the Guó.
he thinks that as a poor person he cannot govern the rich
therefore he asks for the three-tenth tax.
Being kept at a distance he thinks he cannot govern those who are close to the ruler,
therefore holds the title of Senior Advisor.
Guǎn Zhòng was by no means greedy.
This was in order to make government efficient."
Someone might say:
Now if Jack or Bill got an order from the ruler to become prime minister
then no one would dare not to obey them.
This is not because the ministers are humble, or because Jack or Bill are noble,
it is that when someone has an official charge from the ruler
then no one would dare to disobey him.
Suppose now that the government of Guǎnzhòng
did not act according to Duke Huán's wishes,
then this would be to be without an effective ruler.
When a state does not have an effective ruler
then one cannot carry out the government.
If they had relied on the authority of Duke Huán
and if they had transmitted down the ordinances from Duke Huán,
then that would be the reason why Jack and Bill would be dependable.
Why rely on the dignity of Gāo's, the Guó's and the Senior Advisor
before one can carry these things out.
Those who deal with official business during this time,
the capital officials who get the ordinances and rules carried through,
do not avoid the noble
nor do they go for the humble.
Thus as long as they officially act according to the law
even eunuchs will command more confidence than senior ministers;
if what they do is against the law
then even a grand official will have to bow to a vulgar commoner.
Now Guǎn Zhòng did not try to honour the ruler and give prominence to the law
but he worked to increase his preferred status and his rank.
If such behaviour is not greed after wealth and honour,
then he certainly was ignorant and did not understand the art of government.
Thus one says:
"Guǎn Zhòng showed faulty behaviour;
Xiāo Lyuè gave excessive praise."
King Xuān of Hán asked Jiū Liú:
"I want to employ Gōngzhòng and Gōngshū jointly.
Do you think this will be all right?"
Jiū Liú replied politely:
"In ancient times Wèi jointly employed Lóu and Dí
and they lost Xīhé;
Chǔ jointly employed Zhào and Jǐng
and they lost Yān and Yǐng.
Now if Your Excellency jointly employs Gōngzhòng and Gōngshù
these two are bound to compete with each other and to sell out to foreign powers,
so that the state is bound to be in trouble.
Someone might say:
Formerly, Duke Huán jointly employed Guǎn Zhòng and Bāo Shū,
Tāng the Successful jointly emplyed Yī Yǐn and Zhòng Huǐ.
Now if jointly employing two ministers meant trouble for the state
then under such conditions Duke Huán would not have become hegemon
and Tāng the Successful would not have become King.
King Mǐn exclusively employed Nào Chǐ
but he himself died in the Eastern Temple;
The "Ruler's Father" exclusively employed Lǐ Duì
but he was slowly starved to death.
If the ruler does have the art of rulership
then joint employment is not a disaster;
if he does not have the art of government
then, if he employs jointly then the two will compete and sell out to foreign powers
and if he employs one person exclusively that person will monopolise political control
and they will kidnap and assassinate him.
Now Liú does not have the art of government to set up rules for his superior.
He makes his ruler reject joint appointment and employ exclusively one person.
Such behaviour will either lead to the troubles of Xīhé, Yān and Yǐng
or it is bound to lead to the disaster of death or slow starvation.
In this way Jiū Liú was not quite good at knowing what to propose.
Duke Jǐng smiled and said:
"Since your family are familiar with the market,
do you know the prices of things?"
At this time Duke Jǐng was applying a wide range of physical punishments.
Yànzǐ replied politely:
"Special shoes for prisoners with cut-off feet are expensive, ordinary sandals cheap."
Duke Jǐng asked:
"Why is that so?"
He replied politely:
"That is because the physical punishments are so many."
Duke Jǐng suddenly changed the expression on his face and said:
"How cruel I am0"
And at that point he alleviated five of the physical punishments.
Someone might say:
When Yànzǐ declared the shoes for prisoners without feet as expensive
that was not his honest opinion.
He wishes to use this expedient formulation
in order to put an end to the many physical punishments.
This is the disaster that results when one does not understand government clearly.
Now when the physical punishments are adequate it matters little whether they are many;
and when they are not adquate it helps little that they are few.
Not to make it known when they are not adequate
but to expatiate on that they are too many,
that is the disastrous result of a being unprofessional.
If one executes thousands or hundreds of members of a defeated (read: braads) army
people will still keep deserting the ranks.
Even if one administers punishments designed to reduce chaos to order
sparingly as if one were afraid that one is not using enough of them,
then the wickedness still will not stop.
Now Yànzǐ did not investigate into the appropriateness of punishments
but expatiates on there being too many of them,
is that not mistaken.
If one is stingy about cutting the straw and reeds then one is wasteful with the threshed grain and ears.
If one is generous to thieves and villains then one harms the decent people.
Now if one is lax on physical punishments and fines
and practises largesse and generosity,
that is to benefit the wicked and to harm those who are good.
This is not the way to achieve good government.
Duke Huán of Qí got drunk on wine
and he lost his cap.
He felt this was such a disgrace
that he did not attend court for three days.
Guǎn Zhòng said:
This is a disgrace for a person in charge of a state.
Why don't you, my lord, make this good again through proper government?"
The Duke said:
"What a good idea"
And so he issued the contents of the granaries and gave it to the poor,
he made an assessment of the prisons
and let out those with slight crimes.
After three days the people were singing about him:
"Why doesn't the Duke lose his official hat again"
Someone might say:
Guǎn Zhòng made up for Duke Huán's disgrace to the petty people
but he created a disgrace for Duke Huán in the eyes of the gentlemen.
To make Duke Huán distribute the contents of the granaries
and to give them to the poor
to reassess the prison population
and to release those with minor crimes,
that is not right and just,
it cannot make up for a public disgrace.
If it had been right to make Duke Huán do these things,
then as for his original moral principles,
they needed the loss of his official cap before he could practise them
so that the moral behaviour of Duke Huán
would surely be because of the loss of an official hat.
Although such behaviour might make up for the public disgrace of the loss of an official hat for petty people,
it also creates a public disgrace for dismissing moral principle vis-a-vis the gentleman.
Moreover distributing the content of the granariesand giving them to the poor
this is to reward people who have no achievements to their credit;
assessing the prison inmates and releasing those with slight crimes,
this is a failure to punish transgressions.
Now if one rewards people with no achievements to their credit
then the people will go for good luck and place their hope in their superiors;
if one does not punish transgressions
then the people will not be chastised and they will easily get to do wrong.
This is the basis of political turmoil.
How can it make up for a public disgrace?
In ancient times King Wén invaded Yú, overcame Jǔ and took Fēng.
After these three successful campaigns Zhòu resented him.
King Wén then got scared.
He begged to submit the territory of Luòxī and the state of Chìrǎng,
a thousand square lǐ in all,
in order to ask for the discontinuation of the punishment of roasting of people alive.
The whole world were all satisfied by this act.
When Confucius heard about this
he said:
"How humane he was,
King Wén
He thought nothing of a state of a thousand square lǐ
and asked to discontinue the punishment of roasting people alive.
How clever he was,
King Wén
He gave up a territory of a thousand square lǐ
and won the allegiance of the whole world.
Someone might say:
When Confucius considers King Wén as clever
that is surely mistaken.
Cleverness
consists in knowing where the disaster or difficulty are and avoiding these.
As a result one is not exposed to the misfortune.
The reason why King Wén was disliked by Zhòu
was that because he had not won public support?
Then even if he sought public support
in order to dissolve the dislike of Zhòu and that would have been acceptable,
But Zhòu disliked him because he won public support.
King Wén himself went on to put little weight on territory
in order to attract the allegiance of others:
that was to compound the suspicions against him.
That certainly was why he was fettered and incarcerated at Yǒulǐ.
A certain Zhèng Cháng had a saying:
"When one has absorbed the Way,
one should not engage in assertive action, one should not reveal oneself."
This would have been most fitting advice to King Wén,
it would not have made others suspect him.
When Confucius considered King Wén as clever
he did not reach the level of this assessment.
Duke Píng of Jìn asked Shū Xiàng:
"In ancient times Duke Huán of Qí called the feudal lords together nine times
and he united all under Heaven.
I wonder whether this was because of the efforts of his minister
or because of the efforts of the ruler?"
Shū Xiàng replied politely:
"Guǎn Zhòng was good at cutting out the pieces of cloth;
Bīn Xūwú was good at sewing things up;
Xí Péng was good at decorating the borders.
When the clothes are finished
the ruler picks them up and wears them.
That surely is because of the ministers' effort.
What effort was there from the part of the ruler?"
Music Master Kuàng bent forward over his lute and laughed at this.
The Duke said:
"Why is the Grand Music Master laughing?"
Music Master Kuàng replied politely:
"I was laughing at Shū Xiàng's reply to you.
Anyone who acts as a minister
prepares all the foods like a cook and offers them up to the ruler.
If the ruler will not eat these things
who would dare to force him?
I beg to offer a comparison:
The ruler
is arable land;
the ministers
are the plants and trees.
It is necessary for the arable land to be rich
before the plants and trees can grow big.
That surely is the contribution of the ruler.
What contribution can the minister make?"
Someone may say:
Shū Xiàng's and Music Master Kuàng's responses
were all one-sided.
To unify all under Heaven
and to routinely call together the feudal lords
that is the most handsome thing.
It is not only because of the ruler's contribution
neither is it only because of the ministers' contributions.
In ancient times Gōng Zhīqí was in Yú
and Xǐ Fùjī
The intellectual competence of these two ministers was such
that their proposals were always to the point
and their initiatives were always successful.
That Yú and Cáo were both ruined,
why was that?
That was because they were the right ministers but they did not have the right ruler.
Moreover, when Jiǎn Shū was at Gān, Gān was ruined
but when he was in Qín, Qín became the hegemon.
This was not because Jiǎn Shū was stupid in Gān
and competent in Qín.
It is a matter of there being or not being the right ruler.
When Xiàng says "it is the contribution of the minister"
that is not right.
In ancient times Duke Huán had two markets within his home
and two hundred minor gates to the housing for the wives.
He let his hair down and dallied with his wives.
When he got Guǎn Zhòng
he became the most important of the Five Hegemons.
When he lost Guǎn Zhòng
and got Shù Diāo
he died,
and the worms were crawling out through the door, but he was not buried.
If one thinks that it is not the contribution of the minister
then he will not have become hegemon because of Guǎn Zhòng;
if one thinks it is the contribution of the ruler
then there could not have been political turmoil because of Shù Diāo.
In ancient times
Duke Wén of Jìn was enamoured of a woman from Qí
and he forgot all about returning home.
Jiù Fàn remonstrated urgently,
so therefore he got him to return to the state of Jìn.
Therefore Duke Huán called the feudal lords together because of Guǎn Zhòng,
and Duke Wén became hegemon because of Jiù Fàn.
But still, Music Master Kuàng said:
"It was because of the ruler's contribution."
That again is not correct.
Generally, the reason why the Five Hegemons were able to
to obtain their achievements and their reputation in the world
was certainly because both the ruler and the ministers made their contributions.
Therefore one says:
are all one-sided.
At the time of Duke Huán of Qí
a stranger from Jìn arrived.
The officials responsible asked about the proper ritual to use.
Duke Huán said three times:
Report this to the Senior Advisor.
But the court jester said:
"How easy it is
to be a ruler.
First you mention the Senior Advisor,
then again you mention the Senior Advisor."
Duke Huán said:
"I have heard that the hard work for the ruler is to find the right people,
but then he relaxes when ordering them about.
It was hard indeed for me to find the Senior Advisor,
but having found the Senior Advisor
why should I not have an easy time?"
Someone might say:
What Duke Huán used in response to the court jester
are not the words of a ruler over men.
Duke Huán thought that the ruler has a hard time finding the right people,
but why should it be such hard work to find the right person.
Yī Yǐn approached Tāng as a cook to seek employment;
Bǎilǐ Xī made himself a prisoner to seek employment with Duke Mù.
Being a prisoner
is something one is ashamed of.
Accepting shame and humiliation in order to get in touch with the ruler above
is something men of talent do because they are so urgently concerned for the world.
And so all the ruler does is not go against the men of talent.
Finding men of talent does not present a difficulty for the ruler.
Official posts and official duties
are what one employs men of talent with;
rank and stipends
are what one rewards their achievements with.
If one sets up offices and official duties
and if one sets out ranks and stipends
then freemen will come of themselves.
What hard work is there for the ruler to do?
And again, ordering others about is not something one may relax about.
Even if the ruler orders people about
he is bound to calibrate them according to his standards.
He has to check them according to performance and job description.
If something meets the requirements of the law he carries it out,
if it does not meet the requirements of the law he does not carry it out.
When the effective performance corresponds to the original proposal he gives rewards
when they do not correspond he metes out punishments.
According to performance and job description he collects ministers
and by his standards and measures he calibrates them.
He must not omit any of these things.
How should the ruler relax?
Finding the right people is not hard work
and ordering people about is not relaxing
and when Duke Huán says: "one puts in hard work to find the right persons"
and then one relaxes ordering people about,
that is not so.
Moreover, for Duke Huán to get Guǎn Zhòng was not hard either.
Guǎn Zhòng did not die for his ruler but rallied to Duke Huán.
Bāo Shū put little weight on holding office, made room for the abler man
and employed Guǎn Zhòng.
So that it was not hard for Duke Huán to get Guǎn Zhòng
is evident.
And after he had got hold of Guǎn Zhòng,
how should things suddenly turned easy?
Guǎn Zhòng was no Duke Dàn of Zhōu.
Duke Dàn of Zhōu borrowed the position of Son of Heaven for seven years,
and when King Chéng had come of age
he transferred power to him.
That was not because he was planning for the empire,
it was because he was doing his official duty.
Now if someone does not take away the son to be able to run the empire
he is bound not to turn against his dead ruler and serve that ruler's foe;
but someone who has turned against his dead ruler to serve that ruler's foe
he will certainly have no trouble taking away the son and running the empire.
Someone who has no problems taking away the son and running the empire
is bound not to find it hard to take away his ruler's state.
Guǎn Zhòng
was a minister to Prince Jiū.
He plotted to kill Duke Huán, but was unable to carry this through.
When his ruler died he served Duke Huán as a minister.
That Guǎn Zhòng's choices were not those of a Duke Dàn of Zhōu
is readily understood.
If Guǎn Zhòng had been a great man of moral talent
then he would have gone on to act like Tāng and Wǔ.
Tāng and Wǔ were the ministers of Jié and Zhòu respectively.
When Jié and Zhòu had created political turmoil
Tāng and Wǔ grabbed power from them.
Now for Duke Huán to take it easy in his position as ruler
that is to behave like Jié and Zhòu
as he is occupying a position in charge of a Tāng or a Wǔ.
Then Duke Huán would be in a precarious position.
If Guǎn Zhòng had been an incompetent man
then he would have gone on to become a Tián Cháng.
Tián Cháng
was a minister to Duke Jiǎn,
and he assassinated his ruler.
Now if Duke Huán had taken it easy in a position above Guǎn Zhòng
that would be taking it easy as a Duke Jiǎn
and occupy a position above a Tián Cháng.
