Duke Huán would again be in a precarious position.
That Guǎn Zhòng was not a Duke Dàn of Zhōu is already clear,
but whether he is a Tāng or Wǔ, or indeed a Tián Cháng,
that remains unclear.
If he turns out a Tāng or a Wǔ
then Duke Huán is in the kind of danger that Jié and Zhòu were exposed to;
if he turns out a Tián Cháng
then Duke Huán would suffer the kind of revolt that was launched against Duke Jiǎn.
When he had already got hold of the Senior Advisor
how could Duke Huán immediately take it easy?
If Duke Huán, when he employed Guǎn Zhòng,
knew for certain that Guǎn Zhòng would not cheat him,
this would amount to knowing that he was a minister who does not cheat his ruler;
but then even if he knew who was a minister who does not cheat his ruler
then the same monopoly of power he had given to Guǎn Zhòng
he went on to lend out to Shù Diāo and to Yì Yá,
so the worms came crawling out through the door, but he was still not buried.
Thus that Duke Huán did not know who would cheat him
or who would not cheat him is perfectly clear.
And yet when he employed ministers he gave them such a monopoly on power.
Thus one says: Duke Huán was a benighted ruler.
Lǐ Kè was governing Zhōngshān
The commander of Kǔxíng handed up accounts and his revenue was large.
Lǐ Kè said:
"When language is well-articulated
and when it is pleasing to listen to but does not take moral principles as its standard,
then that is called 'flowery talk'.
When one has no benefits from forests, marshes and valleys but one's revenue is large,
then these are called 'flowery goods'.
The gentleman does not listen to flowery talk
and he does not accept flowery goods.
For the time being, Sir, you are dismissed."
Someone might say:
Lǐzǐ formulates:
"When language is well-articulated
and when it is pleasing to listen to
but does not take moral principles as its standard,
then that is called 'flowery talk'.
The well-spokenness is in the speaker,
the satisfaction is in the listener.
The words are not those of the listener.
The phrase does not take moral principles as its standard'
does not refer to the listener
and must refer to what the listener listens to.
As for the listener
he is either a lesser man
or he is a man of superior character.
The petty man has no moral principles
and so necessarily he cannot take moral principles as the standard.
If the gentleman takes moral principles as the standard
he will certainly not be willing to acquiesce in these words.
When it says: 'When language is well-formulated
and when it is pleasing to listen to
but does not take moral principles as the standard'
then these are bound to be untrue words.
'When the revenue is large these are flowery goods,'
these are words that cannot travel far.
That Lǐzǐ was unable to stop the wickedness rampant under him in good time
and brought it about that matters got to the case of those acounts,
that, in the final analysis, was his mistake.
He had no technique for understanding this, and the revenue was large.
When the revenue is large,
and it was because of the rich harvest,
then even if he had got double the revenue
what difference would that make?
If in one's undertakings one is careful about the harmony of Yin and Yang,
if in planting trees one keeps the rhythm of the four seasons,
if there are not mistakes in timing and no disasters with temperature
then the revenue will be large.
If one does not stand in the way of the large enterprise for the sake of petty success,
if one does not damage people's proper work for the sake of private desires,
if adult males do their best in agriculture,
if women use their efforts on weaving
then the revenues will be large.
If one works according the principles of the rearing of animals,
if one clearly understands what is appropriate for the the soils,
if the six domestic animals will thrive
and if the five grains will grow in abundance,
then the revenues will be large.
If one is clear about strategic plans
if one investigates soils, boats and vehicles
as well as mechanical contraptions,
if one puts in little effort
but obtains large achievements
then the revenues will be large.
If one benefits from the markets, the passes and the bridges,
if using what one has one can supply what there is a demand for,
if foreign merchants rally to one
if foreign goods are kept,
if one is economic in the use of resources,
if one is moderat e in the use of clothes and food,
if housing and mechanical contraptions serve all sorts of useful purposes
and one does not aim for beautiful playings,
then revenues will be large.
Then if revenues are large
this is all created by man.
When it comes to contributions from Heaven,
then if thuderstorms are seasonal
and if temperatures are suitable,
if without increasing the area of cultivation
one reaps the results of a good year,
then the revenues are large.
As for human effort and Heaven's contributions,
these two things all lead to the revenues being large,
and these are not benefits accruing from mountains, forests, marshes and grains.
Now when without the benefits accruing from mountains, forests, marshes and grains
the revenues are large,
then to speak of 'flowery goods' -
these are the words of someone who does not know the art of government.
Jiǎnzǐ of Zhào was besieging the outer walls of Wèy.
Defended by the small rhinoceros shields and the large rhinoceros shields
he stood beyond the reach of arrows and stones.
When he beat the drums for the attack his officers did not rise.
Jiǎnzǐ threw away the drumstick and said:
"Alas
My officers are worn out soon."
Diplomatic Secretary Zhú Guò took off his helmet and replid politely:
"I have heard it said:
Surely it is simply because of your incompetence.
None of the officers are exhausted.
Formerly our former ruler Duke Xiàn annexed seventeen states
and subjugated states,
he won victories in twelve battles.
The reason for all this was because of the way he employed the people.
When Duke Xiàn died
Duke Huì ascended the throne.
He was profligate and violent,
personally he was fond of jade ladies
and the people of Qín could freely invade the place,
They stood no more than seventeen lǐ from Jiàng.
This was also because of the way THIS man employed the people.
Surely this is also because of Your Excellency's incompetence.
The officers are not worn out."
Jiǎnzǐ removed the small and large shields,
and took his position within the range of arrows and stones.
Then he beat the drum for the attack and the officers stormed the wall.
They engaged in battle and won a great victory.
Jiǎnzǐ said:
"Rather than getting a thousand hide chariots
I should prefer to hear one speech from Diplomatic Secretary Zhú Guò.
Someone might say:
The Diplomatic Secretary has no point.
What he says is that Duke Huì was defeated with these men
and Duke Wén became hegemon with these people.
He does not let us see how they deployed their men.
It was not quite right for Jiǎnzǐ to jetison the shields quickly.
When one's strict parents are in the besieged city,
then one will easily expose oneself to arrows and stones.
That is the way a filial son shows love for his parents.
Filial sons who love their parents in that way
are one in a hundred.
Now if one considers that when one exposes oneself to danger
people can be made to fight,
this is to consider that the sons of various families will all behave toward the ruler
like a filial son who loves his parents.
That is a misleading statement on the part of the Diplomatic Secretary.
Liking profit and disliking harm
that is the thing men have in common.
If rewards are ample and dependable
then people will think little of the enemy;
if punishments are heavy and ineluctable
then the people will not run away.
As for sacrificing one's life for a superior on a long march
there is not one man among several hundred who is prepared to do that.
But with open delight in profit and open fear of incurring criminal guilt
everybody is prepared march to his death.
By not follow the art of the inevitable in leading the masses,
but pursuing a conduct which not one in a hundred persons lives up to,
the Diplomatic Secretary does not yet understand the Way of deploying the masses.
The Duke asked about Páng Xiàn's son
and Zǐfú Lìbó replied politely:
"His transgressions were three.
and these you have never heard about."
From this point onwards
the ruler held Zǐsī in high esteem
and he held Zǐfú Lìbó in low esteem.
Someone might say:
As for the house of the Dukes of Lǔ
their illegal domination by the Jìs
was surely fitting.
The enlightened ruler seeks out the good and rewards them,
and he seeks out the wicked to punish them.
The result he achieves is one and the same in both cases.
Thus when someone lets the ruler know about someone good
this is because along with the ruler he is pleased by goodness;
if someone lets the ruler know about someone wicked
this is becasue along with the ruler he is dislikes wickedness.
These ought to be the people whom rewards and praise are extended to.
If someone does not bring wickedness to the ruler's attention
this is because he is at variance with the ruler and gangs up with the wicked at the level below.
These ought to be the people whom criticism and punishment are meted out to.
Now Zǐsī did not report on transgressions and Duke Mù held him in high esteem for that,
Lìbó reported on wickedness but Duke Mù held him in low esteem.
It is in the essential nature of man that they all take open pleasure in high status
and dislike low status.
So the political insubordinacy of the Jìs took form
and was not reported to the ruler.
This is why the ruler of Lǔ was robbed of what was his.
Moreover, these are the habits of a king doomed to ruin.
But this was what the people of Zōu and Lǔ took pride in,
and Duke Mù held this in high esteem.
Surely they had it all upside down
When Duke Wén was in exile
Duke Xiàn sent Eunuch Pī to attack him at Púchéng.
Pī cut off Duke Wén's sleeve,
and Duke Wén fled to Dí.
When Duke Huì ascended the throne
he again gave orders to attack Duke Wén at Huìdòu,
but they did not catch him.
When Duke Wén returned to his state
Pī sought an audience with him.
The Duke said:
"In the military campaign at Púchéng
the ruler ordered you to take a night's rest underway
but you went immediately.
During the trouble at Huìdòu
the ruler ordered you to take three days for the trip
but you manages with one night underway.
What was the hurry?"
Pī replied politely:
"A ruler's orders are not of two kinds/ambiguous.
When it comes to removing evils from the ruler I only fear that I am not up to the task.
As for the people of Pú
and the people of Dí,
what business are they of mine?
Now that you, my Duke, have ascended the throne,
do you not have difficult episodes likes those at Pú and Dí?
Moreover, Duke Huán set aside the affair with the shooting of the bucklet
and made Guǎn Zhòng his prime minister.
The ruler then agreed to see Eunuch Pī.
Someone might say:
That Qí and Jìn had their ancestral sacrifices disontinued was that not fitting?
That Duke Huán was able to avail himself of the achievements of Guǎn Zhòng
and disregarded his resentment because of the hitting his buckle with an arrow,
and that Duke Wén was able to accept the words of the eunuch
and dismissed the crime of cutting off the sleeve,
was because Duke Huán and Duke Wén were able to forgive these two.
The rulers of later generations
had an intelligence which did not reach these two Dukes;
the ministers of later generations
were not as talented as these two men.
When less than devoted ministers serve less than enlightened rulers
and the ruler does not understand what is happening,
then there will be villains like Cāo of Yān, Zǐhǎn and Tián Cháng;
if he does understand this
then they will explain their conduct like Guǎn Zhòng and the Eunuch.
Then the ruler will certainly not punish them
and he will fancy that he has the moral power of a Huán or a Wén.
This is to make ministers of one's enemy and to be so stupid that one does not realise what one is doing.
If one gives them a lot of assets,
fancies that one is talented and is not on one's guard
then even if he is unable to pass on his position to his progeny,
is that not right and proper?
Moreover, as for the words of the Eunuch
if he openly suggests improvements for the ruler's orders without duplicity
then this is being truly devoted to the ruler.
But only when, if the dead ruler were to be born again,
the minister would not be ashamed, only then does this count as true devotion.
Now in the morning Duke Huì dies and in the evening he serves Duke Wén.
How can that fail to count as disloyalty?"
There was someone who set a riddle for Duke Huán:
"The first difficulty,
the second difficulty,
the third difficulty,
what are these?"
Duke Huán was unable to give an answer,
and he reported the matter to Guǎn Zhòng.
Guǎn Zhòng replied politely:
"As for the first diffuculty
it is that the ruler is closer to his jesters than to his gentlemen.
As for the second diffuculty,
it is that he leaves his capital and often goes to the sea.
As for the third difficulty,
it is that as the ruler gets old he is too late in establishing the heir apparent."
Duke Huán said:
"Good."
Without waiting for an auspicious day he sanctioned the establishment of the heir apparent in the temple
Someone might say:
Guǎn Zhòng's solution to the riddle did not get it.
The usefulness of a freeman does not depend on his closeness or distance to the ruler,
and court jesters as well as dwarfs
are in the nature of things people with whom the ruler holds his feasts,
so that to keep close to the jesters and keep the freemen at a distance
so as to ensure good order,
that would not be a difficult matter.
Now to occupy a position of power
but to be unable to use what one has
and to be confused and never to leave one's state
this would be to try to use one man's strength to keep a whole state under control.
Now as for using one man's strength to keep a whole state under control,
that is something that few are able to manage.
But if one is so sharp-sighted that one is able to spot distant scoundrels
and to recognise hidden and subtle symptoms
and to be sure to have one's orders concerning these carried out,
then, even if one is far away on the sea-shores,
within one's capital there will be no political upheavals.
And so to leave one's state and go to the beeches by the sea
and not to get kidnapped or killed,
that would not be the difficult point.
King Chéng of Chǔ had already established Shāng Chén as heir apparent
but he changed his mind and wanted to establish Prince Zhí instead.
Shāng Chén staged a rebellion
and he ended up assassinating King Chéng.
Prince Zǎi
was crown prince in Zhōu.
Gōngzǐ Gēn was in favour with the King
and he went on to stage a rebellion using Dōngzhōu as a base.
The state was divided into a pair of states.
All these were disasters resulting from a failure to be late in appointing one's heir apparent.
Now if in sharing out power one is not ambiguous,
if offspring from non-main wives get low status
and if those enjoying favour have no way of availing themselves of a position of power,
then even if the candidate is a powerful minister,
to install him late as crown prince is quite all right.
And so even if one installs the crown prince late
then the offspring from non-main wives will not start a rebellion.
So that again is not the difficult point.
Now as for what may be called the difficult point or crux
it is to be sure to use others to establish one's position of power
and to ensure that they do not harm one.
That may be called the first crucial difficult point.
As for the favoured concubine to ensure that she does not become a second Queen,
that is the second crucial difficult point.
As for beloved offspring, to ensure that he does not endanger the regular heir,
not to follow one minister's advice exclusively,
so that ministers dare not place themselves on a par with the ruler,
this may be called the third crucial difficult point.
Prince Gāo of Shè asked Confucius about government.
Confucius said:
"Good government consists in making those who are close feel satisfied
and rallying those who are far away."
Duke Ai asked Confucius about government.
Confucius said:
"Good government consists in selecting the talented."
Duke Jǐng of Qí asked Confucius about government.
Confucius said:
"Good government consists in economic use of resources."
When the three Dukes had left Zǐgōng asked:
"The three Dukes have all asked the same question about government,
but you, Master, have given different polite replies.
Why is that?"
Confucius said:
"Shè has a large capital but the state is small.
The people are bent on rebellion.
That is why I said:
'Good government consists in making those who are close feel satisfied and rallying those who are far away.'
Duke Ai of Lǔ has three powerful ministers
outwards they block and keep away the feudal lords
and gentlemen from neighbouring countries,
inwards they create factions to keep their ruler in a state of stupidity.
The ones who ensured that the ancestral temples were not ritually swept and exorcised
and that the altars of the land and grain were not given their blood sacrifices
were certainly these three ministers.
Therefore I said:
"Good government consists in properly selecting men of talent."
When Duke Jǐng was building the Yǒng Gate

Zǐchǎn of Zhèng was going out at dawn.

He touched his driver's hand and listened to her.
After a while
when he sent a minor official to apprehend and interrogate her;

The next day
the driver asked Zǐchǎn:
"Master, how did you know?"
Zǐchǎn replied:
"Her voice was full of fear.
In general, with regard to those to whom they are close and for whom they care,
when these begin to be sick one is apprehensive,
when they approach death one is fearful,
and when they are dead one is full of grief.
Now she was wailing about someone who was already dead,
but she was not full of grief but of fear.
Therefore I understood that there was wickedness involved."

cope with one.

using Minister of Works Gǒu instead.
Someone might say:
The dwarf jester was good at using a dream
in order to make explicit the way of the ruler.
But Duke Líng did not understand the dwarf jester's words.
Dismissing Yǒng Chú
and demoting Mǐ Zǐxiá
and using Sīkōng Gǒu instead,
this is to remove one's favourite and employ the one one regards as most talented.
Zǐdōu from Zhèng regarded Qìng Jiàn as talented and was blocked by him.
Zǐkuài from Yān regarded Zǐzhī as talented and was blocked by him.
Now if one removes one's favourite
and employs whom one regards as talented
then that still inevitably leads to one person warming himself by one's side.
When the incompetent keep warm by the ruler
that is not enough to impair the ruler's clear vision of things.
Now if without gaining any more insight
one allows a talented person warm himself near one,
then one is bound to be in danger.
Someone said:
Qū Dào was addicted to water chestnuts.
King Wén was addicted to calamus pickled meat sauce.
It is not as if these things had the correct taste,
but the two men of talent prized them highly.
What one has a taste for is not necessarily objectively beautiful.
Lord Líng of Jìn was satisfied with Shēn Wúxù,
Kuài of Yān found Zǐzhī talented.
It is not as if these were "correct" freemen,
but the two rulers honoured them.
What one regards as talented is not necessarily talented.
To employ someone who is not talented as someone talented
is the same as employing him because one loves him.
If one regards those as talented who are really talented and raises them to offfice
then that is a different situation from employing the person one loves.
Thus Zhuāng of Chǔ raised Sūnshū and became hegemon,
Xīn of the Shāng employed Fèi Zhòng and was annihilated.
All these people employed those whom they regarded as talented
but the outcome was the opposite.
Kuài of Yān may have raised to office someone he regarded as talented
but that was the same as employing someone he loved.
Could Wèy end up in the same situation?
Now this this is what the dwarf jester was not quite able to see.
The ruler's view was blocked but they did not understand that his view was blocked.
After he had seen the jester he understood that his view was blocked
and therefore he demoted the ministers that blocked his view.
This was because his understanding had increased.
We have said:
"If one does not increase one's understanding
and lets men of talent warm themselves by one's side
then one is bound to be in danger."
But now if there is an increase in understanding,
then even if people warm themselves by one's side
one is bound not to be in danger.
When Yáo was a commoner
he was unable to govern as many as three people;
whereas when Jié was Son of Heaven
he was able to ruin the whole world.
From this we understand that position of power and rank are worth relying on
and that talent and competence are not worth admiring.
Now when an arrow flies high from a crossbow that is weak in itself
that is because it is propelled by the wind;
if (as a ruler) one is personally incompetent but one's orders are carried out
this is because one gets help from the masses.
When Yáo was acting as an instructor for minor employees the people would not obey him,
but when he got to face south as emperor then the ruled as king over the whole world:
then, when he gave orders these were carried out,
when he issued prohibitions these were obeyed.
From this point of view it becomes clear
that talent and competence are not enough to subdue the masses,
but position of power and rank are sufficient to subdue men of talent."
One responds to Shènzǐ as follows:
"When dragons in flight ride the clouds,
and soaring snakes roam in the mist,
I do not consider that dragons and snakes
do not entrust themselves to the power of clouds and mists.
None the less
if one dismisses talent and exclusively relies on one's power
is that sufficient to be regarded as good government?
In that case I have not yet noticed this.
If having the position in clouds and mists they are able to ride on and roam among them,
this is because the faculties of the dragons and snakes are splendid.
Now when the clouds are abundant worms are still unable to ride on them,
when the mists are thick the ants are still unable to roam in them.
When the constellation of abundant clouds and thick mists is present
but they cannot ride on them or roam in them,
that is because the faculties of the worms and the ants are slight.
Now Jié and Zhòu faced south and ruled over the world.
They used the authority of the position of the Son of Heaven
as clouds and mist,
and the fact that the world could not avoid great turmoil
that was because the faculties of Jié and Zhòu were slight.
Moreover, when the right person, using Yáo's position
governs the world well on that basis
as for position of power, what difference is there to the position of power of Jié?
But Jié was the sort who reduced the world to turmoil.
Now as for position of power
it is not that one can be sure to make a man of talent use it
and to prevent the incompetent from using it.
When a man of talent uses it then the world is well-governed,
and when an incompetent person uses it then the world is in turmoil.
It is in the essential nature of men
that those who have talent are in a minority
and the incompetent or unworthy are the majority.
If with the advantage of a position of authority
one sets out to help the incompetent people of a world in turmoil,
then under such conditions there will be many who bring chaos to the world using their position
and there will be few who bring order to the world using their position.
Now as for position of power,
it is something conducive to good government and also advantageous to turmoil.
Therefore it says in the Zhōu documents:
"Do not give the tiger wings,
or else he will fly into your town
and pick out people to eat."
To put an incompetent person into a position of power
this is to put wings on a tiger.
Jié and Zhòu built high terraces and deep ponds
and in that way they exhausted the strength of the people.
They roasted people alive
and in that way they offended against the human nature of the people.
Jié and Zhòu were men who perfected profligate behaviour
and they authority of facing south gave them wings.
If Jié and Zhòu had been commoners
then even before they had perpetrated one thing
they would have been punished by death.
As for political power,
if it is such that it rears up the heart of a tiger or a wolf
and achieves the work of cruelty and of turmoil,
then that is the greatest disaster in the world.
As for the relation between position of power and political order versus turmoil
it is basically indeteminate,
and when Shènzǐ's speech proposes
that political position is sufficient to govern the whole world
then the reach of his intellect is shallow.
As for good horses and a solid vehicle,
if you make any old person drive them
then they become the laughing stock of the world;
but if Wáng Liáng drives them
then they will make a thousand lǐ per day.
It is not that the vehicle and the horses are different,
but in one case one covers one thousand lǐ
and in the other case one becomes the laughing stock of the world.
The point was that expertise and incompetence are very far from each other.
Now if one takes the position in a state as a person's vehicle
and his position of power as his horses
the ordinances and orders as the reins
the punishments as whips
then if when Yáo or Shùn drive this, then the world will be well ordered,
but when Jié and Zhòu drive it the world will be in turmoil,
then the reason is that worthiness and unworthiness are very far from each other.
Now if one wants to catch up with what is fast and to reach far,
but one does not know how to employ Wáng Liáng,
if one wants to promote benefit and keep away harm
but does not know how to employ the talented and the able,
that is the trouble of not recognising natural kinds.
Yáo and Shùn are surely Wáng Liángs in governing the people.
Again one might respond to this as follows:
The man (Shènzǐ) thinks that one's position of power is enough to rely on in order to sort out one's office.
When the opponent maintains:
"One has to rely on talent for good government",
then that is not right.
As for position of power this is one concept, but it has countless transformations.
If position of power is an inevitable result of things as they are of themselves
then it serves no purpose to talk about political power.
What I call position of power
refers to what man establishes.
If when Yáos and Shùns arise and are in leading positions
then even if there are ten Jiés and Zhòus they cannot create turmoil,
then this is because the political constellation is one of good order.
If when Jiés and Zhòus are born they are in top position
even ten Yáos and Shùns still cannot bring good order,
then this is because the political constellation is one of political turmoil.
Therefore it is said:
"When the constellation is one of good order then it cannot be made chaotic,
and when the constellation is one of disorder it cannot be made orderly."
This is the constellation of things as they are of themselves,
and it cannot be established by men.
As for what I am talking about
it refers exclusively to what men manage to set up.
And there talent does not come into the picture
How does one explain that this is so?
An objector might say:
"There was someone who was offering shields and lances for sale.
He praised the strength of the shields:
'Nothing can pierce them.'
After a while he again praised his lance and said:
'My lance is so sharp
it will pierce any object.'
Someone responded to this saying:
'If using your lances, Sir,
I pierce your shields,
what happens?
The man did not know what to answer.
One has to consider that a shield that cannot be pierced
and a lance that can pierce anything,
can per definition not coexist.
If it is in the nature of the man of talent that he cannot be stopped,
and it is in the nature of the position of power that it can stop everything.
then if with that unstoppable talent
one engages political power which can stop anything,
that is a contradictory situation of the matter.
That talent and political power cannot both be absolute is surely clear.
Moreover when Yáo, Shùn, Jié and Zhòu
emerge once in a thousand generations,
then this counts as coming up shoulder-to-shoulder, heel on heel.
Those who govern the world are incessantly of the mediocre kind.
Those to whom I refer when I talk about position of power
are the ones of medium talent.
Those who are of medium talent
are not up to Yáo and Shùn at the top
and they are not as low as Jié and Zhòu below.
Now if these embrace the law and dwell in their position
then there is good government;
if they go against the law and leave their position of power
then there is political turmoil.
Now if one dismisses the position of power and goes against the law
and waits for Yáo and Shùn,
then when Yáo and Shùn arrive there will be good government.
Under such circumstances there will be ten thousand generations of turmoil
and one generation of good government.
If one embraces the law and keeps to one's position of power
and waits for Jié and Zhòu
and expects that when Jié and Zhòu arrive there will be political turmoil,
then under such circumstances there will be ten thousand generations of good order
and one generation of political turmoil.
Moreover, there being one generation of turmoil in one thousand
and there being one generation of good order in one thousand,
this is like riding on Jì and Ěr and gallopping in different directions:
the cases are surely very far from each other.
If one abandons the tools and methods for making wood bend in round shapes,
and if one discards the art of measuring length,
then if one orders Xī Zhòng to make a cart he is unable to get a single wheel done.
If they had been without the encouragement of official felicitations and rewards
and without the threat of punishments and fines,
if they had rejected political power and dismissed the law
then Yáo and Shùn, going from door to door and explain things to everyone, man by man,
will be unable to govern three families.
It is surely clear from this that one's position of power is worth relying on,
and to say: 'It is necessary to rely on talent'
that is surely quite wrong.
Moreover, if he does not eat for a hundred days, waiting for fine millet and meat
then a famished person will not survive.
Now if one waits for talented men like Yáo and Shùn
to govern the people of one's generation,
this is like waiting for fine millet in order to save the famished.
Now when he says:
'As for good horses and a solid vehicle,
if you make an ordinary person drive them then they become the laughing stock of the world;
but it Wáng Liáng drives it
then it will make a thousand lǐ per day',
I do not consider this as correct.
Now if one waits for an expert sea-swimmer from Yuè
in order to save someone who is drowning in a central state,
then the people from Yuè are good enough at swimming
but the person who is drwoning is not helped.
If one waits for a Wáng Liáng from antiquity
in order to steer the horses of modern times
this is explained like the man from Yuè saving a drowning person.
It is surely clear that this is inappropriate.
Now good horses and solid vehicles
can go fifty lǐ before they given a rest once at a relay station.
Even if one makes a mediocre person steer them
reaching someone going fast or covering a long distance
are things that one can achieve,
and one can reach a thousand lǐ in a day.
Why does one have to wait for Wáng Liáng of antiquity?
Moreover, when it comes to steering vehicles, if one does not trot out Wáng Liáng
then one is bound to trot out Zāng and Huò as failures;
when it comes to governing if one does not trot out Yáo and Shùn
then one is bound to trot out Jié and Zhòu as as sources of turmoil.
This is like tastes being either sweet and honeyed
or bitter like kǔlái and tǐnglì.
If one piles up sophistries and accumulates formulations like this
then one deviates from real existing principles and fails to get hold of the philosophy of politics.
These are discussions about two extremes.
How can these refute statements of the Way and of Principle?
The opponent's arguments do not reach the level of the proposed theory.
He replied:
"In the state of an enlightened ruler
it is the official ordinances
that are the noblest speeches;
it is the laws
that are the most exemplary public business.
Among these pronouncements there cannot be two that hold the place of honour,
among laws there are not two that can be the most exemplary.
Therefore when words and actions
do not run along the ruts defined by laws and public pronouncements
then they must be forbidden.
If in some context there are no relevant laws and ordinances
then in order to be able to deal with fraud, respond to rebellion,
to ensure one's advantage and to make things predictable,
the leadership must choose the right proposals
and must demand proper realisation of them.
When a proposal turns out right
then there there should be great advantage to the proposer;
when it does not turn out right
then there should be heavy criminal charges against the proposer.
Under such circumstances the stupid will fear criminal charges
and they will not dare to speak up;
the crafty will have no way of arguing their legal quibbles.
That is the reason why there will be no public disputation.
In an age of political turmoil this is not so.
When the ruler issues an order
then the people will disagree with it on the basis of literary study;
Individual offices have control over the laws
but the people will willfully alter them through selfish action.
If the ruler gives a low profile to laws and ordinances
and publicly honours the clever actions of men of learning,
then this is how literary study gets highly regarded in a generation.
Now public proposals and actions
are the sorts of things that take results and usefulness as their targets.
If one sharpens hunting arrows and shoots them off wildly
then its tip will never fail to hit precisely a certain spot.
If none the less one cannot say that one is good at archery
that is because one does not have a constant fixed target.
If one establishes a five inch target and pulls the arrow from a distance of ten paces,
then only Yì or Páng Méng can be sure to hit the mark,
and that is because there is a constant fixed target.
Thus when there is a constant target
then Yì and Páng Méng consider hitting a five-inch target as skillful;
if there is no constant target,
then if by shooting wildly one hits a minute target that is regarded as inept.
Now when one listens to proposals and observes performance
and one does not regard success and usefulness as the target
then even if proposals are extremely perceptive and even if performance is extremely powerful,
these are wildly shot-out ways of speaking.
Therefore when one listens to proposals in a world in political turmoil
one regards things that are hard to understand as incisive,
and one regards broad culture as discrimination;
when one observes performance
one considers difference from the masses as talent
and opposition to superiors as a sign of lofty resilience.
Then the ruler enjoys argumentative and analytical proposals
and he honours 'talented' and 'resilient' behaviour.
And so when as a result those people who create the law and political philosophy
establish norms of of proper behaviour
and they will distinguish between judgments on verbal disputes,
then no one will take these as the standard of correctness.
Thus those who go in Confucian clothes and those who carry private swords are many
whereas those who engage in agriculture and war are a minority;
formulations on 'the hard', 'the white' and 'the dimensionless' flourish
whereas laws involving regulations and ordinances are left in abeyance.
Therefore it is said:
When superiors are unenlightened
then public disputation arises.
Tián Jiū said:
"This is for no other reason and for no other thing than this :
it is because the ruler has his system, the leader has his political technique.
Moreover, have you not heard, Sir,
that the Chǔ general Sòng Gū lost control of the administration,
and that Féng Lí, prime minister of Wèi, ruined his state?
These two rulers chased after sounds and formulations
and were blinded by rhetoric and explanations.
These rulers were not tested as heads of a military colony,
they were not posted in a local administration.
And so there occurred the disaster of losing control of the administation, the ruining of the state.
From this point of view
if he does not deploy the test of employing people in a position as the leader of a military colony,
and a posting in the local administration,
how can the enlightened ruler be well-guarded against disaster?
The duke of Tángxi told Hánzǐ:
"I have heard that submitting to ritual propriety and being polite
is the philosophy of remaining unharmed;
cultivating one's demeanour and downgrading cleverness
is the Way of success.
Now you, Sir, establish statecraft through law,
you establish techniques of standard assessment,
and I humbly consider this to be dangerous to your person
and perilous for your body.
How can one prove this?
I have heard you say, Sir:
'Chǔ did not follow the advice of Wú Qǐ and the state was decimated and reduced to chaos;
Qín practised government according to the ruler of Shāng and became rich and strong.
These two gentlemen's proposals were very much right and to the point,
and yet Wú Qǐ was dismembered
and the ruler of Shāng was pulled apart between vehicles.
That is the trouble with not meeting the right age and the right ruler.'
One cannot ensure that one meets the right conditions
and one cannot keep disasters at bay.
Now to keep rejecting the Way of safety and success
and to indulge in dangerous behaviour
that I humbly consider you, Sir, should not choose to do."
Hánzǐ said:
"I do understand your comments.
As for the handle of governing the world
and the systematic measures for keeping the people organised
these are very hard to deal with.
However the reason why I reject the teachings of the former kings
and practise what I choose by my humble self
is because I humbly consider that to establish the philosophy of law and to establish standards of assessment
is the means to benefit the common people
and it is a way of creating good conditions for the broad masses.
Thus not to be afraid of the disasters of unreasonable rulers and unenlightened leaders
and to insist to reflect on how one may organise the people and help and benefit them
that is humane and wise behaviour.
To be afraid of disasters from unreasonable rulers and beclouded leaders
and to keep avoiding the harm of death and ruin
to understand and be clear about the interests of one's own person
and not to see what aids and benefits the common people,
that is the behaviour of a greedy and vulgar person.
I cannot bear to opt for greedy and vulgar action
and I do not dare to offend against humane and wise behaviour.
You have the intention of taking good care of me
but in fact you greatly distressed me.
Now when one asks about this whether clothes or food are more important to men
then the point is that one cannot be without either one of these,
they are all means of maintaining life.
Now Shēn Bùhài proposed the art of politics
and Gōngsūn Yǎng practised the law.
As for the art of politics
it is to give out offices on the basis of concrete responsibilities
it is to act according to job descriptions and to demand performance,
it is to wield the handle of life and death,
and to examine those among the ministers who are capable.
These are the things the ruler of men is to hold on to.
As for the law,
the regulations and ordinances are displayed in the public offices,
punishments and fines appear inevitable to the people's minds,
rewards are vested in those who pay careful attention to the law
and punishments are being applied to those who offend against ordinances.
This is what the subjects take as their guiding authority.
When the ruler does not command the art of politics
then he will be in the dark up on top;
when the subjects are without a law
then they will be in political turmoil below.
Of these not one can be done without
all these are tools of an august king."
A questioner said:
"Just to practise the Art of Government without the law,
just to practise the law without the Art of Government,
what is wrong with that?"
Hán Fēi replied politely:
"Shēn Bùhài
was an aide to Lord Zhào of Hán.
As for Hán,
it was a state that was separated out from Jìn.
Before the old laws of Jìn were even discontinued
the new laws of Hán had already taken effect;
before the ordinances of the former rulers had been rescinded
the ordinances of the new ruler were already promulgated.
If Shēn Bùhài had not monopolised the law
and he had not unified the regulations and ordinances
then wickedness would have been on the increase.
Thus when there was benefit in old laws and former ordinances
then he used them as his guiding line;
when there was benefit in new laws and new ordinances
then he took them as his guiding line.
The advantage lay where the old and the new were in conflict,
where the earlier and later were contradictory,
so that even if Shēn Bùhài made Lord Zhào use
the art of political philosophy ten times,
wicked ministers still would have distorted his words.
Thus powerful Hán with its ten thousand chariots was his for years
but he did not get to become a hegemon,
and this was because he may have used the Art of Government above
but, disastrously, the law was not earnestly polished by the officials.
When Gōngsūn Yǎng ruled in Qín,
he established the system of reporting on each other and being responsible for each other's crimes
and of holding people responsible for their performance,
of holding groups of ten and five mutually responsible
and to hold each member responsible for the same crime any had committed.
Rewards were ample and reliable
and punishments, heavy and inevitable.
Therefore the people worked hard, using their strength, tirelessly,
they risked danger in pursuit of the enemy and did not withdraw at the sight of the enemy.
Thus the state was rich and the armed forces were strong.
And yet, if he had not had the Art of Government so as to understand wickedness
then with his wealth and strength
he would only have helped his ministers.
When it came to the time of Duke Xiào, the Lord of Shāng died,
but when King Huì ascended the throne
the laws of Qín had not yet been ruined
and Zhāng Yí sacrificed the interests of Qín to Hán and Wèi.
When King Huì died,
King Wǔ ascended the throne
and Gān Mào sacrificed Qín to Zhōu.
When King Wǔ died
King Zhāoxiāng ascended the throne
and Lord Ráng bypassed Hán and Wèi in order to attack Qí in the East.
For five years Qín did not increase its territory by a square foot,
and Ráng built city walls round his enfeoffed city of Táoyì.
The Lord of Yīng attacked Hán in a campaign of eight years
and he achieved his feof at Rúnán.
From this time onwards
all the people who made use of Qín were all like Yīng and Ráng.
Therefore, when there is victory in battle
then the powerful ministers will gain public honour.
when territories increase
then private feofs will be established.
This is because the ruler has no political philosophy
which would allow him to understand wickedness.
The ruler of Shāng may have polished his laws endlessly
but ministers made use of his resources.
Thus if one has enjoyed the resources of powerful Qín for ten years
and has not arrived at being a supreme king
this is because maybe the laws are carefully polished in the offices
but the ruler, disastrously, does not have a political philosophy above.
A questioner said:
"If a ruler uses the Art of Government of Shēnzǐ
and the officials practise the laws of the ruler of Shāng
is that acceptable?"
One politely replies:
"Shēnzǐ does not have complete control of the philosophy of government
and the ruler of Shāng did not have complete control of the law.
Shēnzǐ maintains:
"In government one should not go beyond one's official duty.
Even if one knows one should not speak up."
In government not to go beyond one's official duty
that may properly be called taking god care of one's tasks;
but to know and refuse to speak up on what one konws
that is not to report a transgression.
The ruler sees with the eyes of the whole state
therefore when it comes to watching no one sees more clearly than him.
He hears with the ears of the whole state
therefore, when it comes to listening, no one hears more clearly than him.
Now when one knows but refuses to speak up
how is the ruler then going to be able to avail himself of one?
The laws of the ruler of Shāng say:
'Someone who has cut off one head shall rise one step in rank,
and if he wishes to take office, an office of fifty stone of grain in salary;
Someone who has cut off two heads shall rise to steps in rank
and if he wishes to take office, an office of one hundred stone in salary.
The promotion in office and rank corresponded to the heads cut off.
Suppose there were a law which says:
"Those who have cut off a head are ordered to become doctors and carpenters"
then the houses will not be built and the diseases will not be cured.
The carpenter is skillful with his hands
while the doctor gets medicines right,
and if on the basis of success in cutting of heads one enters these trades
then this does not correspond to what one is good at.
Now performing the duties of an office
is a matter of competence and ability.
But in cutting off heads
it is boldness and strength that are deployed.
To take people who deploy boldness and strength
and set them to administer offices requiring wisdom and ability
this is like taking success in cutting of heads
as a criterion for making people doctors or carpenters.
Therefore it is said:
The two gentlemen, when it comes to the law and the philosophy of government
are both not completely competent.
Therefore the method designed to stop wickedness
at the highest level constrains psychological attitudes,
at the next level constrains public speech,
and at the lowest level prohibits action.
In our generation everyone says:
"As for publicly honouring the ruler and pacifying a state
this has to be through humaneness, moral principles, competence and qualifications."
And they do not understand that in fact humbling the ruler and endangering the state
is always because of kindliness, moral principles, competence and qualifications.
Therefore the ruler who is possessed of the Way
will keep far away from kindliness and moral principles
and he will set aside professional competence and skills.
He will cause others to submit through the law.
As a result, one's fame reaches far and wide and one's name carries authority,
the people are well-ordered and the state is at peace,
and all this is because one understands the method of governing the people.
In general, as for the art of government
it is what the ruler holds on to;
as for the law
it is what the officials take as their guiding orientation.
So to cause courtiers to keep hearing the Way outside the court gates,
and then to get to the point where they see the law every day within the country
that again is not the most difficult thing.
In ancient times the Hùshì had Shī Dù,
the Huāndōushì had Gū Nán
and the Sān Miáo had Chéng Jū.
Jié had ？？？Chǐ,
Zhòu had Chǒng Hóu Hǔ,
Jìn had Yōu Shī.
These six persons
were the servants of states doomed to ruin.
They publicly spoke of right as if it were wrong,
they publicly spoke about wrong as if it were right,
within the court they caused danger through villainy,
and outside the court they were petty and careful
in order to demonstrate goodness.
They spoke with praise of times past
and caused good enterprises to be blocked.
They were experts at monopolising power of the ruler
in order to collect the subtle secrets of the leadership,
and they create turmoil according to their own liking.
These are the typical examples of courtiers and members of the entourage.
Among the rulers of bygone generations
there are those who find able collaborators so they are safe and their state survives
and there are those who find able collaborators
but who get into danger and have their state ruined.
On the face of it they all find able collaborators
but the profit and harm differ one thousand or ten thousand-fold.
Thus the ruler has to pay close attention to his entourage.
If a ruler is really clear about the proposals ministers submit
then he will keep apart talent and incompetence like black and white.
Now as for Xǔ Yóu, Xù Yǎ, Jìn Bóyáng
Diǎn Jié from Qín, Qiáo Rú from Wèy, Hú Bùjī, Chóng Ming
Dǒng Bùshì, Biǎn Suí, Wù Guāng, Bó Yí, Shū Qí,
these twelve men
did not show delight when they saw benefits for themselves from above,
and when they faced problems below they were not terrified.
Some were such that one offered them the Empire but they did not take it,
At the cost of living with a reputation for degradation and humiliation
they were not prepared to enjoy the benefits of living on proper grain.
Now if when they see profit they are not delighted
then even if the leadership offers ample rewards
he has no way of encouraging them to do what he wants them to do.
If when facing difficulties they are not afraid
then even if their superior applies strict punishments
he has no way of exercising his authority over them.
These are called people who cannot be made to follow orders.
Now as for these twelve people
some died in hiding in caves,
others were shrivelled up among shrubs and trees,
others starved to death in the mountains and valleys,
and still others drowned in the rivers.
If there are people like this
then even the sage kings of old are all unable to make ministers of them.
And in our generation
how can one use them?"
As for Guān Lóng Páng, Prince Bǐ Gān, Jì Liáng of Suí
Chén Xièyě, Shēn Xū from Chǔ, Zǐ Xū from Wú,
these six men
they were all eager for struggle, strong in remonstration to win over their rulers.
If their proposals were listened to, their projects were carried out
then their position was like that of a teacher in relation to a disciple.
But if one proposal of theirs was not listened to
or one project not carried out
then they terrorised their ruler with words
and followed this up with a show of authority.
Even at the risk that they themselves died and their family was ruined,
that their waist and neck would no longer hang together,
that their hands and feet ended up in different places,
they did not find it difficult to do what they did.
As for ministers like this
even the sage kings of antiquity were all unable to put up with them.
In our times
how is one going to be able to use them?
Now as for Tián Héng from Qí, Zǐhǎn from Sòng
Jìsūn Yìrú from Lǔ, Qiáo Rú from Jìn, Zǐnán Jìng from Jìn,
Tàizǎi Xīn of Zhèng, Duke Bái of Chǔ,
Shàn Tú of Zhōu, Zǐzhī of Yān,
these nine men, in serving as ministers
they all formed gangs and cliques to serve their rulers,
they caused the straight Way to be hidden and practised their crooked tricks.
Above they oppressed the ruler, below they ruined the political order,
they gained outside support to stir up trouble on the inside,
they formed close alliances with those below in order to plot against those above,
and all that was not hard for them to do.
As for ministers like this
only sagely kings and clever rulers are able to contain them.
As for a confused ruler in turmoil
can he see through them?
Now as for Hòu Jì, Gāo Yāo, Yī Yǐn,
Duke Dàn of Zhōu, Tàigōng Wàng, Guǎn Zhòng, Xi Péng,
Bǎi Lǐxī, Jiǎn Shū, Jiù Fàn, Zhào Cui,
Fàn Lí, Dignitary Zhǒng, Páng Tóng, Huá Dēng,
these fifteen men, in their conduct as ministers,
were early risers and went to sleep late,
they humbled their persons and held their limbs in low respect,
they made their attitudes respectful, their intentions plain,
they made punishments and the laws plain, organised offices and official duties
in order to serve their rulers,
they made good proposals, passed laws in accordance with the Way
and did not dare to boast about their excellence
After they had finished achievements and successful projects to their credit
they did not dare to brag about their merits.
They had no problems with ruining their own families in order to serve the state well
and to have themselves killed in order to make things comfortable for the ruler.
They considered their rulers as honoured like high Heaven and Mount Tài,
and themselves as lowly like small mountain gullies, like vulgar pots;
the ruler had a distinguished name and broad fame in the state
and they themselves had no problem accepting
lowly positions like those of little mountain gullies or of vulgar pots.
As for ministers like this
they can make their contributions even to a confused ruler
how much more to a ruler of brilliant enlightenment?
These one calls the aides to hegemon kings.
As for Gǔ Zhī of Zhōu, Wáng Sūnshēn of Zhèng,
Gōngsūn Nìng of Chén, Yí Xíngfǔ, Jīng Yùyǐn Shēn Hái,
Shāo Shí from Suí, Chóng Gàn from Yuè,
Wáng Sūn from Wú, Yáng Chéngxiè from Jìn,
Shù Diāo and Yì Yá from Qí,
these twelve people in their way of acting as ministers
were all concerned for petty profit and disregarded law and moral principles.
When they were promoted they hid away men of talent
in order to keep the ruler in the dark,
when they were demoted they confused all the officials
and they created disasters.
They all were aides to their ruler
and in ministering to the desires of the ruler
if they really could provide a pleasure to the ruler
then even if they ruined the state and caused the death of common people in the process,
they saw no problems doing this.
If there are ministers like this
then even a sage king will still be afraid to be deprived of his position,
and how much more a confused ruler
Is it possible that such a ruler does not fail?
As for anyone who has ministers like this
he will invariably die, lose one's state,
and become the laughing stock of the world.
Thus Duke Wēi of Zhōu was killed,
and the state was divided into three parts.
Zǐ Yáng from Zhèng was killed
and the city-state was divided into three.
Duke Líng of Chén died at the hands of Xià Zhēngshū,
King Líng of Jīng died on Qiānhuò.
Suí was ruined by Jīng.
Wú was annexed by Yuè.
The Earl of Zhì was routed below Jìnyáng.
Duke Huán died and was not encoffined for seven days.
Therefore it is said:
As for toadying ministers
only sage kings see through them,
whereas rulers bound for ruin will be close to them.
And so it will reach the point where these latter rulers lose their lives as well as their states.
The sagely king and the enlightened ruler are not like that:
when appointing members of their own family they do not avoid close relatives
when appointing outsideres they do not avoid those whith whom they have conflicts.
If right is on their side
then they raise them to office;
if wrong is on their side
they punish them.
Therefore the talented make progress and the wicked find themselves demoted.
As a result with one promotion they can make the feudal lords submit.
Regarding this it says in the records:
Yáo had Dān Zhū,
Shùn had Shāng Jūn,
Qǐ had his Five Sons,
the Shāng had Tàijiǎ
King Wǔ had Guǎn and Cài.
The people whom these five kings punished
were all close relatives like fathers, elder brothers, sons or younger brothers
so why, then, was it that those they killed lost their lives and ruined their families?
It was because they were the sort who harm the state, harm the people and ruin the legal system.
If one carefully observes whom they promoted
some were from the mountain forests, marshes and from the caves,
some from prison, fetters and ropes,
some from carving animals and boiling them, giving fodder to domestic animals, feeding buffaloes.
However, the enlightened ruler does not feel embarrassed by lowliness.
He takes those who are capable
and if he considers that they can promote the rule of law
and that they can do something useful for the state and benefit the people.
then as a result the ruler promotes such men
so that his person iremains safe and his name becomes eminent.
A confused ruler, on the other hand, is not like this.
Without understanding the minister's intentions and actions
they put him in charge of the state.
Then at the very least his name is held in low esteem and his territory is decimated,
and in more serious cases he will lose his life as well as his state.
This is because he is not clear about how to employ ministers.
Since he has no standard by which to measure his ministers
he has no alternative but to judge them according to what the masses say.
Those whom the crowd praises
he will go on to feel satisfied with,
and those whom the masses criticise
he will go on to hate.
As a result the ministers will ruin their families and destroy their property,
within the court they will form gangs
and outside they will link up the people in the street to gain fame.
They will link up through secret arrangements to back each other up
they will confer nominal ranks and stipends to encourage each other.
They will announce: "Those who are on my side I will give benefits,
those who are not on my side I shall harm."
The vulgar people are after the benefits
and they usurp authority which is not theirs:
"If these are really delighted
then they will be able to benefit one;
if they are resentful and angry,
then they are able to harm one."
The vulgar people rally to these men, and the common people gather round them
so that their fame fills the whole state
and they come to the attention of the ruler.
The ruler is unable to sort out the real facts of the matter
and he regards them as talented.
Then these men send out deceitful freemen
to pretend outside that they are favoured ambassadors of the feudal lords
and they supply them with fine carriages and horses
make them trusted through jade tablets and bamboo certificates,
establish them solidly through formal diplomatic messages,
support them with gifts of silk,
use the feudal lords to give wanton advice to the ruler.
Secretly they think of their private profit but the provide public-spirited arguments.
Those they pretend to be the ambassadors of
are the rulers of different states;
but those whom they speak for
are people in the entourage.
The ruler is pleased with their proposals and regards their formulations as clever
and he considers these men as the most talented freemen in the world.
At court and outside among the entourage
the indirect suggestions and the talk are all the same.
In the most serious case the ruler has no trouble humiliating himself
and down-valuing his position in order to communicate with them;
in the less serious case they raise their ranks and give them fatter stipends in order to benefit them.
Then the wicked men's ranks and stipends become greater
and their cliques and associations become more numerous,
and if in addition they have their wicked intentions
then wicked ministers will offer more and more resistance and they will advise
and they will say:
"Those who were properly called sagely rulers and enlightened kings
did not succeed their predecessors by regular succession of the eldest.
it is because they organised cliques and associations
and because they gathered neighbours and members of the clan.
They exerted pressure on their superiors, assassinated their rulers
and sought their own advantage."
Then that ruler would reply:
"How do you know that this is so?"
And then they would reply:
Shùn exerted pressure on Yáo
and Yǔ exerted pressure on Shùn.
Tāng ousted Jié
and King Wǔ attacked Zhòu.i
These four kings
are people who as ministers assassinated their rulers
and the whole world is full of praise for them.
If one investigates the facts about these four kings carefully
it turns out they were eager after gain;
if one assesses their conduct
they were violent and rebellious military men.
However, these four kings promoted their own cause
and the whole world praised them as great men.
They promoted their own fame
and the whole world praised them as enlightened.
And so their authority was sufficient to control the whole world,
the benefits they disbursed were sufficient to cover their whole generation.
The whole world joined them."
They go on to say:
"According to what we have now heard
Tián Chéngzǐ took over Qí,
Mayor Zǐhǎn took over Sòng,
Tàizǎi Xīn took over Zhèng,
the Dān took over Zhōu,
Yì Yá took (control of Qi Zi Nán Jing took) control of Wèy,
the three men from Hán, Wèi and Zhào divided up Jìn between them.
These eight people
were all subjects who assassinated their rulers."
When the wicked ministers hear this
they will quickly prick their ears and 'consider this as quite right'.
Thus within the court they will form cliques and associations,
and outside they will gang up with neighbours and members of their clan,
they will look for the right moment to start their undertaking,
and at one go they will take over the nation.
Moreover, those who form cliques in court and rob or assassinate their rulers,
those who outside use the authority of the feudal lords
and make faked changes to their state,
those who hide the straight Way
and who hold on to their selfish crooked paths,
those who constrain the ruler above
and who confuse good government below
are innumerable.
Why is this?
It is because they are not enlightened about choosing ministers.
A historical record says:
"Since the time of King Xuān of Zhōu
several tens of states have been ruined.
Many are the ministers who killed their rulers and took over the state."
However the troubles that arise from inside the court
are as many as the ones originating from the outside.
Those who were able to make complete use of the strength of the people
who ruined their state and got themselves killed,
these were still all talented rulers.
As for those who change the laws and swapping their positions
taking good care of the masses and passing on the state to others,
these are the greatest menace to the state.
As for a ruler
if he is really clear about what his ministers propose,
then even if you race along with hunting nets and stringed arrows
if you strike bells and arrange dances by women,
then still the state will survive;
If he is not clear about what his ministers propose,
then even if he is economic and parsimonious as well as earnest and hard-working
even if he wears commoner's clothes and eats badly,
the state will still be ruined of itself.
The former ruler of Zhào, Lord Jìng,
did not cultivate virtuous behaviour
and he was fond of giving free rein to his desires.
He pleased himself with whatever his body found comfortable
and what his ears and eyes delighted in.
In winter he went out hunting with nets and stringed arrows, in summer he went on wanton boat trips.
He carried on until late at night
and for several days he never ceased to have the wine beaker circulate.
Those who could not drink more he fed wine with a tube
Those who were not dignified in moving back and forth
or who were not respectful in their replies, he had cut down on the spot.
So his behaviour and eating and drinking were untramelled like this
his regime of punishments and his executions were without standard like this
and yet the Lord Jìng enjoyed his state for several dozen years.
His armies were not routed by any enemy states,
no territory was lost to neighbouring states.
Within the court he had no revolts by the ministers or the officials,
and abroad he did not have any troubles from the part of the feudal lords.
And the reason was that he was enlightened about employing ministers.
The ruler of Yān, Zǐkuài
was a descendant of Duke Shì of Shào.
He had a territory of several thousand square lǐ
he had several hundred thousand lances in his arsenals,
he did not indulge in the pleasures of young ladies,
he did not listen to the sound of bells and musical stone instruments,
within his palace he did not build artificial mounds, ponds and terraces with wooden platforms
outside he did not hunt with nets and stringed arrows.
Moreover he personally took the plough and hoe and worked the fields.
Zǐkuài's harsh treatment of himself out of concern for his people
was extreme like this.
Even those who are called the sage kings and enlightened rulers of old
in exerting themselves and caring for the people
were no more extreme than this.
And yet, Zǐkuài died and his state was ruined,
power was wrested from him by Zǐzhī,
and the whole world was laughing at him.
Why is this?
He was not enlightened about employing ministers.
Thus it is said:
Ministers have five kinds of wickedness,
and the rulers do not understand these:
As for ministers,
some are extravagant in their use of resources and of bribes
in order to gain fame;
some strive to make congratulatory rewards an gifts
in order to sway the masses;
some strive to build factions, to seek competent people and to honour freemen
in order to be able to act on their own authority and please themselves;
some strive to set free criminals and prisoners
in order to work for their own position of authority;
some strive to conform to their inferiors view on what is straight and what crooked
on strange speeches, strange clothes, and weird appellations
in order to confuse the ears and eyes of the people.
As for these five
they are what the enlightened ruler is suspicious about,
and they are what the sage ruler constrains.
If one removes these five
then fraudulent people will not dare to present themselves to the ruler with their talk.
Those whose polished proposals are many but whose performance is scanty
and who do not conform to the law
will not dare to distort the real facts in order to come up with chatty explanations.
As a result the ministers will cultivate their persons when at home
and when they engage in action they will use all their strength.
Without an order from their superior
they will not dare to take independent action, come up with rash pronouncements and distort facts.
This is how the sage king shepherds his ministers and subjects.
The sage ruler and the enlightened ruler
do not use these five kinds of suspicious behaviour to survey their ministers.
And those who, when faced with such suspicous behaviour do not revolt,
are few in the world.
Therefore it is said:
Some illegitimate children pretend to the status of legitimate children;
some concubines pretend to the status of regular wives;
some minor ministers at court pretend to the status of prime ministers;
some ministers are in such favour that they pretend to the status of a ruler.
These four things are what is dangerous for the state.
Thus it says:
"When favoured members of the harem emulate the regular queen,
when favoured people outside the court create a second government,
when distant offspring compete with the regular offspring,
when powerful ministers pretend to the status of rulers,
then that is the way to political chaos.
Thus in the Records of Zhōu it says:
"One should not show greater honour to a concubine than to a wife,
do not treat a regular son as illegitimate and honour remote persons in the line of inheritance,
do not honour favourite ministers so that they pretend to the status of senior ministers,
do not honour powerful ministers so that they pretend to the status of a ruler."
When these four arrogations are destroyed
then those above will have no special plots, and those below will have no strange designs.
When the four arrogations are not destroyed
then one will lose one's life and one will destroy the state.
As for important things other than these three
they do exist, but they are not of an urgent nature.
Now there is by no means a lack of benefits to be gained
but the people do not get educated by their superiors;
there is by no means a lack of authority
but subjects do not obey their superiors;
there is by no means a lack of laws for the officers of the state
but their administration does not conform to their job descriptions.
When there is by no means a lack of these three
then that there should be good order in one generation and political turmoil in another
why should that be?
The reason is that what the leadership values highly (being other things than these three)
and that whereby they might conduct good government
are opposed to each other.
As for establishing titles and designations
these are the means by which one gains public honour.
But these days there are people who regard titles as vulgar and performance as unimportant
whom this generation regards as "elevated".
As for establishing ranks and positions
this is designed to lay the basis for low versus high status.
But there are those who slight their superiors and do not seek audiences
whom this generation regards as 'talented'.
The exercise of superior authority and the conferring of benefits
these are designed to insure that ordinances are carried out.
But those who provide no benefits and who make light of higher authorities
this generation calls 'powerful'.
The laws and ordinances
are designed for the conduct of good government.
But those who do not follow the laws and ordinances
but practise what they privately regard as good,
these the world calls 'loyal'.
Offices and ranks
are designed to encourage the people.
But those who are eager for fame and do not advance in office
the world calls 'illustrious freemen'.
Punishments and fines
are designed to enable one to freely deploy one's higher authority.
But criminals who despise the law and do not avoid punishment and death
the world calls 'brave men'.
The people are more eager for fame
than they are to obtain material benefits.
Under these conditions
freemen who are famished and destitute
will surely go to live in craggy mountains and maltreat themselves
in order to seek fame in the world.
Thus the reason why our age is in political disarray
is not the crimes or faults of the subjects,
it is that the leadership has lost the right Way.
They consistently value highly what brings political chaos
and they assign little value to what brings good government.
That is why what the subjects have a desire for
is consistently in conflict with that whereby the leadership governs well.
Now that the subjects should obey their superiors
is something which the superiors eagerly desire.
but those who are generous and diligent, pure and reliable
who give their very best and reticent in speaking up,
these are called 'slight'.
Those who are staunch in upholding the law
and meticulous in obeying ordinances,
they are called 'stupid'.
Those who respect their superiors and fear crime
they are called 'pusillanimous'.
Those who speak of timeliness and proper season
and whose actions are moderate and appropriate
these are called 'incompetent'.
Those who are without divided allegiances and selfish intellectual pursuits
but listen to minor officials and follow their instructions
these are called 'vulgar and ignorant'.
Those who raise objections against summons to high office
these are called 'straight'.
Those who raise objections against official gifts
these are called 'sure'.
Those who raise objections against prohibitions
these are called 'egalitarian'.
Those who do not obey ordinances
are called 'courageous'.
Those who are of no benefit to the leadership
are called 'diligent and sincere'.
Those who have few desires, are charitable and are magnanimous in action
are called 'kindly'.
Those who have great influence and high self-esteem
are called 'distinguished citizens'.
Those who engage in selfish private study and form gangs
are called 'followers of a master'.
Those who relax and dwell in peace
are called 'thoughtful people'.
Those who pursue profit at the expense of kindliness
are called 'fast'.
Those who are garrulous busibodies, frivolous and fickle
are called 'intelligent'.
Those who first act for others in order thereafter to act in their own interest
who regard all ranks as equal
who propose that one should universally love all in the world,
these are called 'sages'.
Those who speak up on great fundamental matters,
who get praised but cannot be used,
whose actions run counter to their times,
these are called 'great men'.
Those who regard ranks and stipends as worthless
and do not bend before the leadership
are called 'heroic'.
If the subjects act wickedly like this
then if at court they will create political turmoil among the people
and if not at the court then they will be good for nothing.
The leadership should stop their desires
and one should put an end to their practices.
And if one does not stop them
but one goes on to honour them
this is to teach subjects to rebel against their leadership and to consider that as good government.
Generally, what the leadership governs with
is punishments and fines.
But now those who practise moral principles with selfish purpose are held in esteem.
That through which the altars of the land and grain are established
is peace and calm.
But the garrulous busibodies and slanderers and flatterers get employed.
The reason why there is obedience within the four borders
is in good faith and magnanimity,
but the devious and clever and the rebellious get employed.
The reason why ordinances get carried out
and why one's superior authority is established
is in polite obedience to the leadership,
but those who dwell in the craggy mountains and negate the world get famous.
The reason why granaries are full
ar the basic occupations of agriculture,
but those working with patterned ribbons, with silk embroideries and with engraved pictures on the wall
who engage in marginal activities get rich.
Those through whom one's reputation as a ruler is established,
and those through whom one's city walls and moats are expanded, are the warriors.
But nowadays the orphans of dead officers are starving and begging on the roads,
while jesters, drunkards and the like ride in vehicles and strut about clad in silk.
Rewards and stipends
are means whereby one causes the people to give their best and causes one's subjects to take death lightly.
But nowadays officers who have fought victorious battles and launched successful attacks
have made successful efforts but do not get the slightest rewards,
while bone and milfoil diviners, readers of hands, and foxy wizzard flatterers
make their smooth formulations to offer them up and receive daily presents.
When the leadership keeps hold of the standards and measures,
that is the means to keep sole control over the instruments of life and death;
but nowadays freemen who keep to the standards and uphold the measures
if they wish to displease the leadership out of sheer loyalty,
then they do not get to see their leader.
But those who use crafty words, and sharp formulations
who practise treachery, and who opportunistically cheat the world
win their leaders' attention frequently.
By basing oneself on the law and speaking up straightforwardly,
by making titles and punishments fit each other,
by following the ink-line of the rules,
and by executing the wicked
one creates order on behalf of the leadership,
but such people are increasingly kept at a distance.
Those who are full of flattery, who please themselves and do what they like
so that they jeopardise the world, these enter the inner circles.
Exhausting the possibilities for land taxes and agricultural taxes,
concentrating the efforts of the people
is a way of guarding against troubles and filling the granaries and storehouses.
But those freemen and soldiers who abscond and hide away,
who seek refuge in the houses of the powerful
in order to avoid civil and military corvee service and military taxes
and whom the authorities do not catch are in the ten thousands.
Arranging for good farming land and convenient housing
is a way of making freemen and soldiers fight.
But those who get their heads cut off and their stomachs slit up,
who scatter their bones on the wilderness,
they have no place to stay.
They die miserable deaths and their lands are taken away from them.
But young girls with sexy looks
important ministers and members of the entourage without any merits,
they make their choices in housing and get what they want,
they make their choices in farming land and live on it.
When rewards and benefits only come from the leadership
that is the way to be good at controlling one's inferiors.
But freemen who have gone to war do not get public employment
while gentlemen of leasure enjoy public honour and illustrious fame.
If the leadership makes this his official doctrine
then how could his name be held in other than low esteem?
How can his position be other than precarious?
Now if one has a lowly reputation and a precarious position
then one's inferiors will not follow orders
and they will be disloyal, pursue private studies and go against their times.
But they do not put a stop to their practices
they do not destroy their associations so as to scatter their factions,
on the contrary they even go on to honour them publicly.
In this the people in charge are making a mistake.
The reason why the leadership will inculcate moral purity and a sense of shame
is because this is a way of giving moral encouragement to their subjects.
Now the freemen and the grandees are not ashamed of dirty shamelessness
to gain public office,
those who have connections through court ladies or private obligations
do not wait for their turn and get public employment.
Rewards and presents
are ways to show one's deep regard for someone.
But freemen with military merits go poor and humble
while flatterers and jesters make flying careers.
If names and designations are truly reliable
that is a way of asserting one's authority everywhere.
But the rulers are blocked off from information,
cronies and chamber maids have their free run.
When the various officials are in charge of assigning rank and transferring people,
then those who are in charge have made a mistake.
When the senior ministers and the officials
first plot with inferiors and form factions
when they only act against the law
and the benefits of control over political authority are reaped by the people below the ruler,
then the ruler will have low status and the senior ministers will be powerful.
The establishment of laws and ordinances
is designed to eliminate private selfishness.
When laws and ordinances are practised
the Way of private selfishness is eliminated.
Private selvishness
is prone to ruin the laws.
But when freemen have divided loyalties and engage in private studies,
when they live in caves and camp out at the bottom of pits,
when they pretend to live in hiding in deep meditation,
then in serious cases they will criticise all the world
and in slight cases they will confuse those below.
But if the leadership does not put a stop to this
and if on the contrary they go on to honour them with public fame
and gives them material benefits.
then under such circumstances they become illustrious without achieving results
and they become wealthy without putting in an honest effort.
In this way
those freemen who have divided loyalties and engage in private study
how can they fail to engage in deep reflection
how can they fail to strain themselves in clever deceit
and in the maligning of laws and ordinances
in order to seek what is at variance with their times.
In general when people bring chaos to their superiors and are at variance with their times
this, as a rule is because the freemen have double loyalties
and engage in private study.
That is why the "Basic Proposals" say:
"That through which good government is achieved
is the law;
that through which political turmoil is achieved
is private selfishness.
When the law is established
then no one gets to indulge in private selfishness"
Thus it is said:
When one takes selfishness as one's Way, there will be political turmoil;
when one takes the law as one's Way, there will be good government.
When the leadership does not have the right way
then those who are clever will indulge in their selfish private formulations
and the men of distinction will pursue their private purposes.
