When the leadership shows private and personal generosity
then the subjects will pursue their private and personal desires.
The sages and the clever men will form groups
they will create proposals and they will use rhetoric
in order to attack that the law is implemented from above.
But those above do not put a stop to those who block them
on the contrary they go on to honour these people.
This is to teach the subjects not to obey superiors or follow the law.
Therefore the men of talent will live in peace as famous people
the wicked people will rely on their rewards to become rich.
The men of talent will be famous and live in peace
and the wicked people will rely on their rewards to become rich,
and thus the leadership is unable to keep the upper hand over their subordinates.
Those whose speech is all twisted and have a craving for knowledge
are fake and deceitful people
but the world honours them and calls them
"well-spoken and wise freemen".
Those who wield the sword and launch murderous attacks
are violent swashbucklers,
but the world honours them and calls them
"freemen of persevering courage".
Those who let villains live and hide wicked people
are the sorts of people who ought to be put to death,
but the world honours them and calls them "men of fame".
These four kinds of people
are the sort that the world praises.
Those who hasten to brook danger and who die for their earnestness
are people who are willing to sacrifice their lives for their values
but the world belittles them and calls them
"people who do not know to set the right priorities".
Those who listen to few things and follow orders
are people who insure the complete realisation of the law
but the world belittles them and calls them
"naive and vulgar people".
Those who earn their living by strenuous effort
are people who create benefits
but the world belittles them and calls them
"people of few abilities".
Those who are generous and pure
are decent nice people
but the world belittles them calling them
"stupid and dumb people".
Those who put great weight on orders and who carry out public business in fear and awe
but the world belittles them calling them chicken-hearted people.
Those who attack villains and stop the wicked
are people who make their leaders illustrious
but the world belittles them and call them
"fawning and foul-mouthed fellows".
These six kinds of people
are severely criticised by the world.
The wicked and false people who are of no benefit are of six kinds
but the world praises them as outlined before.
The people who engage in agriculture and war and are of benefit are of six kinds
but the world speak ill of them as just outlined.
These are called the six contradictions.
If one praises commoners pursuing private profit,
and the rulers of our time listen to their empty speeches and treat them politely.
then where ritual politeness is shown benefits are bound to acrue.
If one scolds the common people when they pursue what is harmful to them
and the rulers of our time are blocked by vulgar custom and treat them as inferior
then where one treats people as inferior harm is bound to acrue.
Thus when fame and rewards go to selfish, wicked and criminal people,
when criticism as well as harm go to the public-spirited and the good freemen who deserve rewards,
then in that way to seek wealth and strength for the state
this is something that cannot be achieved.
In ancient times there was a saying:
"Conducting government is like washing one's hair.
even if there is a loss of hair, one must carry things through."
If one is stingy about the expense of some hair and forgets the benefits for the hair that is growing,
then one does not understand the exercise of power.
If one pricks open an ulcer with a stone needle it hurts,
and when one drinks medicine it tastes bitter.
If because the bitterness and one's exhaustion
one does not prick open the boils and does not drink the medicine,
then one's body will not survive and one's ailment will not be stopped.
Now as for the relations between superiors and inferiors
there is no generosity as between sons and fathers,
and if one wishes to constrain inferiors through moral principle
then in the relationship there are bound to be rifts.
Moreover, when it comes to parents' relation to children
when they get a son they congratulate each other
and when they get a daughter they kill her.
Both these children came from the womb of their parents
and still the son gets congratulated whereas the daughter is killed.
This is because the parents consider usefulness in the future and they calculate their long-term benefits.
Thus even when it comes to the relations between parents and children
they still use their calculating minds
when they deal with each other.
How much more so when there are not the warm feelings that exist between father and son?
Nowadays, when learned men persuade rulers
they all argue for removing the urge for profit
and they put forward the Way of mutual love.
This is to demand that the ruler shows more concern for subjects than parents do for their children.
Such talk is ignorant of how one should discuss generosity,
it is deceitful and dishonest.
So the enlightened ruler will not accept this.
As for the government of a sage ruler
it pays consistent close attention to laws and prohibitions.
When laws and prohibitions are public and clear
then the officials will perform their administrative duties properly.
If one's reactions in terms of rewards and punishments are ineluctable,
if in rewarding and punishing one is not biased by personal concerns,
then the people allow themselves to be deployed.
When the people allow themselves to be deployed and officials conduct their duties properly
then the state will be rich.
When the state is rich
then the army will be strong
and the task of a hegemon king will be achieved.
Being a hegemon king
is of the greatest benefit to the ruler of men.
The ruler concentrates on the greatest benefit in his conduct of government
therefore in employing officials he takes those who have the relevant abilities,
and in rewarding or punishing people he shows no personal favour.
He causes the citizens to be clear about these things:
If they do their utmost at the risk of their lives
then their merit may be established and ranks as well as stipends may be secured.
When rank and stipends are securedthen the task of getting rich and noble may be achieved.
Wealth and nobility are the things of the greatest benefit to the ministers.
The ministers keep in mind what is of greatest benefit in their work
and therefore in their conduct they brave danger to the poing of risking their lives,
they give their very best and do not nourish vain hopes
This means that when the ruler is not sentimentally humane
and the ministers are not sentimentally loyal,
then one can become a hegemon king.
If wickedness is bound to get found out then it is guarded against,
if it is bound to be punished then it will stop.
If wickedness does not get found out then it will remain uncontrolled,
and if it does not get punished then it will be practised freely.
If one lays out light valuables in a dark and hidden place
then one should be suspicious even of Zēng and of Shǐ;
but if one hangs up a hundred cash in the market,
then even a great thief will not pick it up.
If it does not get known
then Zēng and Shǐ should be considered suspicious in dark and hidden places.
But if he is sure to be found out
then even a great thief does not pick up cash hung up in the market.
Thus the enlightened ruler, when it comes to governing a state,
makes sure that many people guard it, and that crimes are treated as heavy.
He ensures that the people are constrained by the law
and do not stop doing things just out of the goodness of their hearts.
A mother loves her children twice as much as a father,
but a father's orders are carried out ten times more than those by the mother.
Minor officials have no special love for the people
but their orders are carried out by the people times more a father's orders.
A mother heaps love on her offspring but her orders go unheaded./
Minor officials use authority and strictness and the people obey./
Surely, the strategies of strictness and love can be clearly judged.
What parents demand of their children is the following:
in what the children do and take initiatives for
the parents wish for their comfort and their well-being;
and in their personal conduct
the parents wish that their children keep away from crimes.
When it comes to the relation between ruler and people,
then when there is trouble they should sacrifice their lives for him;
and in times of peace
they should give their utmost for him.
When parents place their children in comfortable conditions out of great love,
then children do not obey them;
the ruler, without loving or benefitting them,
demands that the people die for him, and that his orders be carried out.
The enlightened ruler understands these things
and therefore he does not cultivate an attitude of generosity and of love
but increases his position of authority and sternness.
Thus where the mother shows great love
the children often fail,
and this is because she pushes love;
where the father shows only slight love, educates and castigates children,
the children often turn out good,
and this is because he uses sternness.
Now as for the members of a family looking after their property
they make each other resilient through putting up with hunger and cold, ?????
and they make each other strong through hard work.
Even when they run into trouble where they have to do military service
or where there is a disastrous famine,
those who have warm clothes and good food
are bound to be the ones from such a family.
When they take warm-hearted care of each other with clothes and food,
when they are generous with each other with relaxed entertainments,
then when there is a famine or a year with bad harvest
those who marry off their own wives and sell their children
are bound to be from such a family.
Thus it is the Way of the law
that it is bitter first, and in the long run advantageous;
and it is the Way of kindliness
that it is self-indulgent and afterwards gets into trouble.
The sage weighs the relative advantages
and produces the great benefit.
Therefore he uses the law which steels people's resilience
and he rejects the kind mutual concern of the kindly man.
The learned men all say:
"Make the punishments light"
But this is the philosophy of chaos and ruin.
In general the reason why rewards and punishments are carried out mechanically
is to exercise encouragement and to constrain.
When rewards are abundant then one gets what one wishes for quickly;
when punishments are heavy then one stops what one dislikes fast.
Now those who desire benefits will necessarily dislike harm.
As for harm
it is the opposite of benefit.
The opposite of what one desires
how can one fail to dislike that?
Whoever desires good government must necessarily hat bad government.
As for political turmoil
it is the opposite of good government.
Therefore, if one has a strong desire for good government,
then the rewards one offers must be large;
and if one has a strong dislike for political turmoil,
then one's punishments must be heavy.
Now as for those who opt for making punishments light
their dislike for political turmoil is not strong
and their desire for government is likewise not strong.
Those do not only lack a proper professional technique they also show no proper behaviour.
Thus the strategy of distinguishing talent and incompetence,
stupidity and knowledgeableness
consists in seeing whether the rewards and punishments they recommend are light or heavy.
Moreover, making punishments heavy
is by no means in order to charge people with criminal offences.
The method of the enlightened ruler consists in making assessments.
Dealing legally with a villain
is not in order to deal with the person one is dealing with.
Dealing with the person one is dealing with
would be dealing with a dead person.
Meting out physical punishment to a thief
is not in order to deal with the person to be physically punished.
Dealing with the peron to be physically punished
that would be to deal with criminals.
Therefore it is said:
Charge one wicked person with heavy crimes
and stop all wickedness within your borders.
This is how one carries out good government.
Those who are punished heavily
are the thieves and the villains;
but those who fearful
are the decent ordinary people.
If one desires good government, why be suspicious about heavy punishments?
Now as for large rewards
they are not only desinged to be rewards for contributions,
they are also designed to encourage the whole state.
Those who receive the rewards appreciate the benefit,
but those who are not yet rewarded look forward to putting in a hard effort.
In this way one rewards one man's contributions
and one encourages the masses within the boundaries of one's country.
If one desires good government, why be suspicious about large rewards?
Now those who do not understand good government will all say:
"Heavy punishments injure the people.
Light punishments can stop the wicked.
What need is there for heavy punishments?"
These do not have a clear understanding of good government.
What one can stop with heavy punishments
cannot necessarily be stopped with light punishments;
but what can be stopped with light punishments
can necessarily be stopped with heavy punishments.
Thus when the leadership sets up heavy punishments
then wickedness will stop completely;
and when wickedness stops completely
then how can this be harming the people.
From what we call heavy punishments
the wicked stand to gain little
but the measures the ruler takes against them are powerful.
The people do not wish to be accused of large crimes for small gain,
and that is the reason why wickedness is bound to stop.
From what we call light punishments
the wicked stand to gain much,
for the measures the ruler takes against them are slight.
The people covet their gains and are non-chalant with crimes.
That is why wickedness will not stop.
Therefore the former sages have a saying:
"One does not stumble over a mountain, one stumbles against an anthill."
A mountain is large,
and therefore people follow its contours;
An anthill is slight and therefore people make light of it.
Now if one makes punishments light
then the people will make light of them.
When they commit offences and one does not apply punishments
this is to drive on everyone in the state and then to abandon it;
When they then commit an offense and one does punish them
this must count as setting up traps for the people.
Thus the popularist suggestion that one should treat crimes lightly
will either lead the state to ruin
or set up traps for the people.
Now THAT may be properly called injuring the people.
The learned men of today quote the panegyrical talk in books and documents
but they do not investigate the facts of their own time.
They say:
"When the ruler does not love the people
and the taxes and levies are constantly heavy,
then they do not have enough for their expenses
and the subjects will resent their superiors
and as a result the world will be in great turmoil."
These people consider that if one ensures that they have enough resources and shows them love
then even if one makes punishments light
one can govern the people properly.
These words are untrue.
In general people bring upon themselves heavy punishments
after they certainly already have enough of everything.
Even if their resources are sufficient,
and one, in addition, shows them great love afterwards,
but one makes punishments light,
then they will still be unruly.
Take the beloved sons of the person in charge of a family,
their resources are enough for their needs.
When their resources are enough for their needs
they easily use them up.
When they easily use them
they become luxurious and extravagant.
When the parents love them
they are indulgent towards them.
When they are indulgent towards them
then they become arrogant and profligate.
When they become luxurious and extravagant
then their families become poor.
When they become arrogant and profligate
their conduct will become ruthless.
Under these circumstances the resources may have been sufficient for their needs, and the love was lavish
but such is the disaster brought on by light punishments.
In general, throughout their lives, men are such
that when they have enough supplies then they are lazy in the use of their strength;
when the leadership is chicken-livered
then the people will be uninhibited in doing evil.
Someone who had sufficient supplies but worked hard
was the Divine Farmer;
as for the case superiors being pusillanimous but subjects behaving properly,
Zēng and Shǐ were cases in point.
But that the people are not up to the Divine Farmer, Zēng and Shǐ
that much is surely clear.
Lǎo Dān has a saying:
"If one knows when one has enough one does not get humiliated,
if one knows where to stop one does not get into danger."
Now as for someone who because of the dangers and humiliations of this world
does not seek anything beyond what is necessary,
Lǎo Dān was such a person.
Now those who imagine that by supplying the needs of the people
one may ensure good government,
this is to consider all people as being wise like Lǎo Dān.
Thus Jié was noble to the point of being Son of Heaven,
but still was dissatisfied with his public honour;
he was rich to the point of controlling all within the Four Seas
but still was dissatisfied with his precious possession.
A ruler over men, even if he supplies the needs of the people
is unable to satisfy them to the point of making them all Sons of Heaven,
but Jié was not sure to be satisfied with being Son of Heaven,
so that even if one were to satisfy the needs of the people
how can one get to ensure good government?
Thus the enlightened ruler, when governing a state
will attend to the business of the times and bring about the necessary things,
he will assess the taxes and corvee services to level out poverty and wealth;
he will give lavish ranks and stipends to make the best use of talent and ability,
he will make punishments heavy in order to constrain the wicked.
He will ensure that the people get wealth through honest effort,
that they get honoured status through public service,
that they are charged with crime in case of transgressions,
and that they obtain rewards in case of achievements,
and that they do not hope for gratuitous gifts of generosity.
This is the government of emperors and kings.
If men are all deep asleep
then the blind will not be found out;
if they are are all silent
then the dumb will not be found out.
When they are awake and one makes them look at something,
if one asks them and makes them reply,
then the dumb and the blind are at their wit's end.
If one does not listen to their proposals
then those without a proper art will not be found out;
if one does not employ them
then the incompetent will not be found out.
If one listens to their proposals and demands that they are adequate,
if one employs them and holds them responsible for their results,
then those without a proper art and the incompetend are finished.
Now if one wants to find a strongman
and one only listens to how he speaks up about himself
then even an ordinary person and Wūhuò
cannot be held apart;
but if one gives them a dǐng vessel or a heavy meat-bowl
then the exhausted and the vigorous show their colours.
Thus offices and official duties
are the dǐng and the meat-bowls for the talented freeman.
If one employs them in public tasks then the stupid and the competent are held apart.
As a result those without any proper art will be pleased not to be used
and the incompetent will be pleased not to get employed.
When their proposals are not used
they give themselves a cultural veneeer and regard themselves as good rhetoricians,
when they are not employed they give themselves a wonderful surface appearance and regard themselves as above such things.
The rulers of our times are blinded by their rhetoric,
they are taken in by their loftiness and give them honours and status.
This is not wait whether they can see before deciding their sharp-sightedness
not to what for their answers before deciding their rhetorical skill:
in that way one cannot pick out the dumb ones and the blind ones.
The enlightened ruler, when he has heard a proposal,
is bound to demand concrete performance.
When he observes conduct,
he is bound to demand results.
And then people will not chatter about empty old-fashioned learning,
and bragging deceitful conduct will not be disguised.
Deviating from general opinion and hiding from the authorities
is called "having a lofty and haughty spirit".
Being cantankerous and going against orders
is called "being tough and talented".
Practising generosity and wooing the allegiance the masses
is called "gaining the support of the masses".
But if one is not abandoning old friends,
then the executive officials will be wicked.
If one treats others humanely
public resources will get depleted.
If one is "a gentleman"
then the people are hard to deploy.
If one "has proper demeanour"
then the legal system will be destroyed.
If one has "a knightly spirit"
then official duties will be carried out in a lax way.
If one is "lofty and haughty in spirit"
then the people will not do their official work.
If one is "tough and talented"
then one's orders will not be carried out.
If one "gains the support of the people"
the ruler above is isolated.
These eight
are the selfish praises of the ordinary man,
and they lead to failure for the ruler of men.
The opposite of these eight are selfishly criticised by the ordinary man
but they are of public benefit for the ruler.
If the ruler does not invetigate the harm and benefit to the nation
but acts according to the selfish praise from the ordinary people
then if he is aiming for the state being without danger and political turmoil
that is an impossible aim.
Employing people according to their public service
is the crucial point for survival and ruin, good government or political turmoil.
If one has no proper technique for employing people
then one employs no one without this leading to failure.
When the rulers of men in general employ people
it is either for their rhetoric and cleverness or for their moral purity.
But to employ a person
is to cause him to occupy a position of power.
Intellectuals are not necessarily trusty.
Because the ruler emphasises their competence
he is, as a result, confused about their trustiness.
If he uses the reasoned strategies of the competent men
and they occupy places where they are in control of the resource of power
and act for their private urgent personal interests,
then the ruler is bound to get cheated.
Because the clever are not to be trusted
one then employs men of moral cultivation
and makes them decide important affairs.
But men of moral cultivation are not necessarily competent.
Because one cultivates the moral purity of one's person
one is confused with respect to cleverness.
When a fool with all his stupidity
occupies an office where he is in charge of affairs
and acts according to what he thinks fit,
then these affairs are bound to end up in turmoil.
Therefore if one has no proper technique for employing people,
then if one employs the clever then the ruler gets cheated,
if one employs the morally cultivated then the ruler's affairs get into a mess.
This is the trouble with being without a proper techique.
The Way of the ruler is to ensure that
those in lowly position get to discuss the noble in court,
and that those below are sure to be held responsible for the crimes of their superiors.
The truth is decided on after investigation,
and there are no back-doors in hearing court cases.
Therefore the clever do not get to do their cheating.
One calculates results and administers rewards accordingly,
one weighs ability and confers tasks accordingly,
one investigates the basic motivations and observes failures.
Those who are guilty of transgressions one charges with crimes,
those who have abilities win through.
Therefore the stupid do not get responsibility for public affairs.
If the clever do not dare to cheat,
the stupid do not get to make decisions,
then nothing will go wrong in public undertakings.
What only bright scholars can understand
should not become an ordinance.
The people are not all bright.
What only the talented can carry out
should not become a law.
The people are not talented all of them.
Yáng Zhū and Mò Dì
are universally regarded as men of astuteness,
they addressed the turmoil in their times but did not solve it in the end.
Their insights may have been astute
but they could not but they could not make orders for officials.
Bào Jiāo and Huá Jiǎo
are universally regarded as talented,
but Bào Jiāo shrivelled to death like a rotting tree
and Huá Jiǎo threw himself into a river.
They may have been talented
but could not become men of agriculture or warriors.
Thus whatever the ruler considers as an astute view
the intellectuals will use all their rhetorical skill on.
whatever the ruler honours publicly
able freemen will do their best to put into practice.
Now if the rulers of our time consider useless rhetoric as intelligence,
if they publicly honour conduct that is far removed from concrete results,
and they seek in this way to achieve wealth and power for the state,
this is impossible to achieve.
If people widely cultivate rhetoric and cleverness like that of Confucius and Mòzǐ
then, since Confucius and Mòzǐ did not engage in agricultural work,
what does the state stand to gain from this?
If they nurse filial piety and reduce their desires like Zēng and Shǐ,
then since Zēng and Shǐ did not engage in offensive warfare
what is the benefit for the state?
Commoners have their private interests
but the ruler is concerned for public benefit.
Not to do productive work and to cultivate self-sufficiency
not to take office but to win an illustrious name
these are private interests;
stopping aesthetic studies and promoting the standards of the law,
putting a stop to private interests and concentrating on results and effort,
that is being concerned for public benefit.
The setting up of laws is for the guidance of the people
but if on the other hand one gives high status to literary pursuits
then the people will be doubtful about the laws they take as their guideline;
offering rewards for results achieved is in order to encourage the people
but if on the other hand one also publicly honours the cultivation of moral purity
then the people will be lazy in producing things that are of public benefit.
Now if one values literary pursuits highly so as to cast doubt on the law,
and if one publicly honours the cultivation of moral purity so as to sow doubt on results,
and one seeks to achieve wealth and power for the state in this way,
then this is impossible to achieve.
Having long jade tablets stuck in one's clothes, a small shield and ceremonial battle axe,
is no match for a sharp lance or the iron short dagger
moving decorously up and down staircases and making prescribed ritual circles
is not as good as showing endurance running with a heavy load. ????
The "Weasel Head" music and the decorated quiver
are no match for the strongbow being released quickly;
defensive shields and city walls, and rams for military attack
are no match for attacks by hidden inundation and hidden fire-blowing engines.
In ancient times people were eager about virtue,
in medieval times one was in pursuit of wisdom,
and in our times people compete with physical strength.
In ancient times people insured they had few affairs and preparations for them were simple,
they were plain and basic and did not exhaust people.
So there were people with large hoes embellished with mother of pearl,
who pushed their own carts.
In ancient times men were few and they were close to each other,
necessary things were in abundance and one easily yielded profits easily made.
As a result there was polite bowing and the polite handing over of the Empire.
And so the practice of bowing and polite deference,
of lofty loving care and generosity
and the following of the path of kindness and munificence
If when living in times where affairs are many
one uses the tools for times when there is little to do,
that is not the preparation of a competent person.
In a generation where there is great conflict
to follow the track of bowing and of polite deference
that is not the good government of a sage.
Therefore the competent person does not rely on pushing carts,
and the sage does not practise pushing-cart-government.
The law is a means to control public affairs,
public affairs is that through which accomplishments get their name.
When a law is instituted and difficulties arise
then if, having weighed the difficulties, the public business still succeeds
then the ruler will institute the law.
If when public business is carried out and turns out to be harmful
then if, when the harm is weighted the positive results are greater than the harm,
then the ruler will go through with it.
Laws that create no problems
and positive results that have no harmful effects
do not exist in this world.
Therefore if, when one takes out a major city with meters of wall,
or when one defeats an army of soldiers
then one in three of one's soldiers will die or get injured,
the armed soldiers get maimed,
the officers and men die or get injured,
one still congratulates each other on the victory in battle and on the gain of territory,
then this is because one disregards the small harm and counts on the great benefit.
Someone who washes his hair will suffer the loss of some hair,
and someone who removes something surgically will do harm to blood and flesh.
If a person is such that when he sees difficulties
he will then go on to give up an undertaking,
then he is not a professional.
The former sages have a saying:
"A compass has its deviations/
and a river has its waves:/
If one wants to change this
there is nothing one can do about it./"
These are the words of someone who understands the weighing of pros and cons of things.
There are explanations which are definitely defensible
but which go beyond practical reality;
there are proposals which are awkwardly worded
but which supply urgent needs.
Therefore the sage does not look for proposals that have no disadvantages,
and makes the unavoidable things his business.
If people make no effort to interfere with the stone weights used on scales
this is not because they are morally pure and quite unconcerned with profit:
the stones cannot be made greater or smaller by men,
scales cannot be made to show things to be lighter or heavier by men.
If one tried to do this one could not succeed.
That is why people do not try.
In the state of an enlightened ruler
the officials would not dare to distort the laws
the executive officials would not dare to work for their personal profit,
corrupt gifts will not circulate:
this is because affairs within the borders
are each and all like scales and stone weights.
If among this ruler's ministers any are wicked, they will become known for that
and those who become known for it will be executed.
Therefore the ruler who has achieved the Way
is not looking for morally pure minor officials
but he aims for a professionalism that ensures that he will know what is going on.
As for the relation of a loving mother to her infant child
no one can surpass her love.
However, when that infant child acts in an unruly way
she makes him follow his teacher;
if he has a serious disease
he makes him submit to medical treatment.
If he does not follow the teacher early he will later suffer mutilating punishment,
and if he does not submit to medical treatment he will get close to death.
If, even if the mother should show loving care for the child,
this will not help towards saving him from punishment and death,
then what makes the child survive is not the love.
The natural disposition of a child and a mother
is one of love;
the power relations between ministers and rulers
is a matter of strategy.
The mother cannot ensure the survival of her family through love,
and how, then, can a ruler maintain a state through love?
If the enlightened ruler is clear about wealth and power
then he can get what he wants.
Therefore being diligent in attending to the government
is the method for wealth and power.
He makes his laws and prohibitions publicly known
and he closely examines political plans.
When laws are publicly known there will be no political revolts within,
if planning is efficient no one will lose their lives or be taken prisoner abroad.
Thus what preserves the state
is not kindliness and rectitude.
Someone who is kindly
is loving and generous and thinks little of material goods;
someone who is cruel
is hard-hearted and will easily mete out punishments.
If one is loving and generous
then one cannot bear certain things;
if one thinks little of material goods
then one is prone to make gifts.
If one is hard-hearted
then one's hatred will become visible to those below;
if one finds it easy to mete out punishments
then arbitrarily executions will be applied to others.
If one cannot bear certain things
then one's fines will often be waived;
if one is fond of giving
then one's rewards will often be to those who have no achievements.
When one's hatred becomes visible to others
then those below will resent their superiors;
if one carries out arbitrary executions then the poeple will revolt.
Thus when a kindly person is in charge
then his subordinates will be unrestrained
and will easly go against laws and prohibitions,
they will go for good luck and place their hope in superiors;
when a cruel man is in charge,
then the laws and ordinances are arbitrary and rulers and ministers are at odds,
the people will be resentful and a spirit of revolution will arise.
Therefore it is said:
the kindly and the cruel
are all the kinds of people who ruin the state.
Those who cannot provide good food but encourage the famished to eat,
are not the kinds of people who are able to make the famished survive.
Those who are unable to remove weeds and let cereals grow
but who encourage people to give loans as munificence and rewards as gratuitous gifts
are the kind of people who cannot make the people rich.
Now the proposals of the learned men today
are not concerned with basic activities but are fond of marginal affairs.
To understand the Way, to be fatuously sagely,
and to persuade the people on this basis,
this is the kind of persuasion that encourages people to eat.
Persuasions which encourage people to eat
the enlightened ruler will not accept.
When writings are concise, disciples will dispute over them;
when laws are elliptic the people will enter litigation about the documents.
Therefore the writings of a sage must be clear in their conclusions,
the laws of an enlightened ruler must be detailed to cover all matters.
To reflect and to think in advance of all matters
and to guess gain and loss,
this is what the clever people find so difficult;
not to reflect and not to think in advance
to take predefined words and demand later results
this is what the stupid find so easy.
The enlightened ruler thinks in advance along the lines the stupid find easy
and he does not demand of them what the clever people find hard.
Thus such a ruler does not use the clever advance planning and the strenuous effort,
but his state is well-governed.
If the sour, the sweet, the salty and the bland
are not judged by the (ruler's) mouth
but are determined by the chief cook
then the cooks will take the ruler lightly
and will the chief cook as important.
If relative pitch and purity versus impurity of tones
are not judged by the (ruler's) ear
but are determined by the chief coordinator of music,
then the blind musicians will take the ruler lightly
and they will regard the chief coordinator of music as important.
If the rights and wrongs in governing the state
are not judged according to professional skill
but are determined by favourites
then ministers and subordinates will take the ruler lightly
and they will regard the favourites as important.
If the ruler does not personally supervise and listen,
but decisions are made by his subordinates
he is parasite to his own state.
Supposing that men without wearing clothes and without eating
were not hungry and not cold,
and that moreover they did not hate death,
then they would have no intention of ever serving their leaders.
If what they desire is not administered by the ruler
then they cannot be controlled.
Now that the handle controlling life and death
is in the hands of the powerful ministers
and that the ordinances of the ruler should be carried out
is something that never happens.
If tigers and panthers are sure never to use their claws and fangs
then they have the same authority as a domestic mouse;
if a family with cash are sure never to use their wealth
then they have the same resources as a janitor.
If a ruler in charge of a territory
is unable to benefit the people with whom he is pleased
and is unable to harm the people whom he dislikes,
then, if he is trying to get others to revere him as powerful
that is an impossible task.
When ministers recklessly put forward their desires
one calls them valiant,
and when the ruler recklessly puts forward his desires
that is called a political revolution;
when a minister thinks little of his superiors he is just called arrogant,
but when a ruler thinks little of his subordinates he is called cruel.
The underlying practice is actually the same
but inferiors are praised on account of it
while superiors are criticised for it.
The ministers make great gains
while the rulers suffer great loss.
As for the state of an enlightened ruler
it will have noble ministers, but it will not have powerful ministers.
Noble ministers hold a distinguished rank and high office;
powerful ministers are the sort whose words get listened to and whose power is great.
In the state of an enlightened ruler
promotion in office is steady, step by step,
office and rank are in accordance with achievements.
Therefore there are noble ministers.
When words are not matched by deeds and there is pretense,
then the person concerned is bound to be punished.
That is why there are no powerful ministers.
As for the "handle", it is the system of killing or letting live;
as for "position of power", it is the asset through which one dominates the masses.
If these are discarded and there is no system, then one's power is weakened;
if rewards and punishments are carried out together with inferiors then his authority is divided.
Therefore the enlightened ruler does not listen to others with loving care
and he does not make plans out of sympathy for others.
Thus if, when listening to proposals, one does not check these
then one's power is shared with the wicked;
when he does not use the power of his intelligence
then the ruler will be manoeuvered into a tight corner by the ministers.
Thus when an enlightened ruler practises a system he behaves like Heaven,
and when he employs others he is behaves like a ghost.
Since he is Heaven he does no wrong,
since he is a ghost he gets into no trouble.
His power is exercised and his teaching is stern,
so go out to welcome him and will not act against him.
Criticism and praise are given according to one rule, without discussion.
Thus rewarding the talented and punishing the cruel
is the utmost point of promoting the good;
rewarding the cruel and punishing the talented
is the utmost point of promoting the bad.
This is what is called rewarding the like-minded and punishing the dissenters.
In rewarding people nothing is more important than municifence,
and this will cause the people to see their benefit;
in giving praise nothing is more important than raising the good points
and this will cause the people to glory in the praise;
in punishing nothing is more important than severeness,
and this will cause the people to stand in awe of one;
in reviling people it is best to be malicious,
and this will cause the people to feel the shame of it.
Only then will there be a unified practice of the law
and the private families will be constrained und punished
so they do not interfere with the public system of achievements or their crimes.
When it comes to rewarding and punishing one will always know about it.
When one knows about it,
then the Way is complete.
2. The Way of the Ruler.
One's strength is no match for that of the crowd,
one's competence does not extend to all things.
Instead of using one's single person
it is better to use the whole state.
As a result one's competence and one's strength are up to their task
and one can deal successfully with everything.
When one guesses right then one personally exhausts oneself,
and when one does not get it right then one has to take responsiblity for the mistake.
The inferior ruler exhausts all his abilities,
the mediocre ruler makes full use of the strength of others,
the superior ruler makes full use of the competence of others.
Therefore when something happens he combines the competence of others,
he listens to people one by one, and then he holds a general meeting.
If he does not listen to everyone one by one
then the later speakers will say things inconsistent with what they meant to say earlier.
then the stupid and the competent are not held apart;
if one does not hold a common meeting
then there will be doubt and one will not reach a decision,
and if one does not reach a decision then the matter at hand will be delayed.
If then, by his own decision, the ruler chooses one proposal,
then he will not fall prey to any disastrous plot.
Thus the ruler makes people put forward their views,
and once he has decided on these views, he will then furiously follow up the results(??)
Therefore, on the day when people make their proposals
the ruler is bound to have records made.
A ruler with links with the competent will test performance after the relevant events have occurred.
A ruler who has links with the able
will decide whether a plan was good or not when the results are seen.
When success or failure are manifest
then rewards and punishments follow suit.
When an undertaking is successful the ruler claims the merit,
when a plan fails then the minister must bear the criminal responsibility.
The ruler does not even hold the tallies together in person
how much less when it comes to making concrete efforts?
When a project is clever he will still not engage in it personally,
how much less when it hangs in the balance
Therefore when he employs people he does not choose those who agree with him,
when they agree with him the ruler will get angry.
If he sees to it that people employ each other then the ruler will look divine,
and when the ruler looks divine then his subordinates will do their best.
When the subordinates do their best
then the ministers will not act in accordance to the rule's detailed instructions
and the Way of the ruler is complete.
Giving Rise to Rebellion
Someone who understands that the ministers and the ruler have different interests will become a king,
he whoe thinks that the interests are the same will get kidnapped,
and he who makes common cause with them will be killed.
Thus the enlightened ruler is clear about the difference between public and private interest,
he is clear about where profit and harm lie
so that the wicked find nothing to avail themselves of.
There are six factors that give rise to rebellion:
the ruler's mother,
one's in-laws,
one's sons,
one's brothers,
powerful ministers,
illustrious men of talent.
If one relies on minor officials and holds ministers responsible for things
then the ruler's mother will not get free reins;
if in the practice of court ritual distinctions in rank are maintained
then the in-laws will not imitate the ruling family;
when the distribution of positions of power is unambiguous
then the indirect and the direct heirs will not compete;
when one does not default in one's exercise of power
then one's elder and younger brothers will not infringe on one's rights;
If one's inferiors are not from one school
then powerful ministers will not block one off;
when prohibitions and rewards are carried out inevitably
then men of illustrious talent will not create havoc.
A minister has two elements to rely on:
and this refers to the outer and and the inner.
On the outside the element is awe-struck fear,
and on the inside it is caring love.
Those of whom one stands in fear and awe get what they seek,
and those whom one loves have their proposals accepted.
This is what seditious ministers rely on.
When, if foreign countries plant their minor officials,
one interrogates and punishes those who have intimate outside connections or who have suspciously heavy funding
then outsiders will not be used (in one's state).
If rank and stipends are in accordance with achievements
and if all those who ask for special favours as guilty of a criminal offence
then insiders will not use their connections.
If outsiders are not used
and insiders do not use their connections
then the wicked and the treacherous will be blocked.
When officers are promoted step by step on the regular ladder
before in the end they achieve a position of great responsibility,
then this is a matter of professional competence.
When their position is extremely high before their are great
one may control them with three constraining measures
"hostages",
"garrisons"
and "firmness".
Blood relations, in-laws, wives and children
are hostages;
ranks and stipends being solid and inevitable
are the "garrisons";
checking performance and holding people responsible for performance
is firmness.
The men of moral talent will be held in their place "hostages"
the greedy are reformed by "garrisons"
and the wicked are given no leeway through firmness.
If one is tolerant and does not exercise control then inferiors will end up as superiors
If one does not deal resolutely with small transgressions then one has to punish large ones.
If behaviour correspond to what is in the rules, then apply these without further ado.
If someone's being alive interferes with the conduct of public affairs
but their death (by one's overt orders) would harm one's good name
then one should act through their drinking and eating (i.e. poison them);
if one does not do that one should hand them over to their enemies.
This is called dealing resolutely with hidden wickedness.
Hiding things is to deceive,
to deceive is to change one's regular ways.
If, when one sees an achievement one gives rewards,
if when one sees a crime one punishes it,
then deception will stop.
If internal conflicts do not leak out
if eloquent remonstrations do not win through,
then irregular means will not be used.
Sending senior relatives and talented men abroad
is called "sending disaster to wander about";
The disastrous consquence is that neighbours and competitors get much support.
Cultivating close contact with men without honour
is called being intimate with villains.
The disaster
consists of feelings of open resentment, suspicion and humiliation arising.
Hiding one's anger and keeping criminal charges to oneself without being open
this is called adding to the chaos.
The disastrous consequence is that people rise through chance promotions.
When two senior ministers are equally powerful and one does not opt for one
this is called wrapping oneself in disaster.
The disastrous consquence is that the families get an elevated status
and troubles like kidnappings and murders arise.
If one is non-chalant and does not cultivate one's own supernatural qualities
that is to catapult away one's authority.
The disastrous consequence is the rise of villains and poisonings.
As for these five disasters,
if the ruler does not understand them,
then there will be cases where he is hijacked or murdered.
As for matters like the discontinuation or the establishment of positions
if these originate from the "inside" then there will be good order
and if they originate from the outside there will be political chaos.
Thus the enlightened ruler will assess internal matters using achievements
and he will support external matters on the basis of their profitability.
As a result his state will be in good order and his enemies will be in disarray.
ways that lead to chaos:
when the ministers are detested
then they start their activities outside and it is as if one is dumbfounded;
when they are loved
then they start their activities inside and they act like poison.
ESTABLISHING THE WAY
THE WAY OF CHECKING AND VERIFYING
One carries out checks in order to plan for better performance,
one practises verification in order to take people to task for failure.
When one carries out checks one must analyse reasons .
When one practises verification one must show proper anger.
When one does not analyse reasons then people will treat superiors without proper respect,
if one does not show anger then people will collude against one.
The evidence that results from analysis
will help one to understand the degree of proper performance,
and before one has shown anger one does not get through to the masses.
The power-play of observing behaviour and listening to suggestions:
When the evidence is that there is factionalism
then one rewards those who do not engage in it;
one punishes those who have not reported (on the factionalism)
and raises criminal charges against those who have connived.
When it comes to suggestions one collects such from all the various points of view:
One must examine them according to Earth,
make plans according to Heaven,
verify them against things,
check them with people,
and when these four kinds tally well together
then one is able to observe well.
One checks words in order to understand their truth,
one shifts one's perspective to change the way things look,
one holds onto one view in order to observe how others are inconstant.
One assigns single tasks60 so as to make one's inner circle do their best to perform them
One makes resounding pronouncements to inspire fear into those who are on distant missions.
One brings up matters of the past to fully understand people's background,
one moves them close in to understand how they perform at the centre,
one establishes them at a distance to understand how they perform outside.
One takes what one is clear on to ask about what one is in the dark about;
one uses tricks in order to prevent them from being messy in their performance of duties.
One says the contrary of what one means in order to test those one is suspicious of,
one states views contraryh to those one holds in order to get hold of hidden wickedness.
One sets up remonstration officials in order to curb ministers' independence
one puts forward mistakes in order to observe how the wicked start moving.
One explains things clearly in order to get people to avoid mistakes,
one is accommodating in order to see whether ministers are straight or fawning.
One divulges what one has already heard in order to get to what one has not yet seen,
one deliberately instigates conflict in order to break up factions.
One goes deeply into one matter as a warning to everyone else,
one divulges opposing views in order to make people change their plans.
By likening kinds to each other one cross-checks,
when one puts forward mistakes one brings out the culprit's stubbornness.
When one learns about a crime one stops it so as to stop the criminals' influence.
One sends out secret agents to go on periodic tours of inspection
in order to find out about their sincere loyalty.
One continuously replaces officals in order to break up their alliances.
One makes arrangements with inferiors that they should go against there superiors:
In the case of a senior minister
one makes arrangements with his senior guard;
in the case of a senior guard
one makes arrangements with his subordinates;
in the case of a minor military official
one makes arrangements with the common soldiers;
when one sends off an envoy
one makes arrangements with their mobile guard;
in the case of a district governor
one makes arrangements with his senior magistrates;
in the case of the courtiers
one makes arrangements with the entourage and one's in-laws,
and one makes arrangements with the palace ladies.
This is called the Way of achievement.
If words get out and projects are leaked out
then the technique is not practised.
CHECKING PROPOSALS [KEEPING THINGS SECRET]
As for the enlightened ruler
his main concern is for comprehensive secretiveness.
Therefore when one shows one's delight with someone
then the ministers will use generosity to reward that person.
When this generosity becomes manifest, then the ruler's authority is diluted.
Therefore, as for the words of the enlightened ruler,
they are blocked off and not to be divulged,
they are all secretive and not forthcoming.
As one person to find ten culprits
that is the inferior Way;
with the aid of ten people to find one culprit
that is the superior Way.
The enlightened ruler uses both the inferior and the superior method,
so the wicked cannot fail to be caught.
Groups of five families, neighbourhoods of, regions of, districts of ,
will be rewarded if they report transgressions
and will be punished when they fail to report such transgressions.
Superiors will be held responsible for inferiors,
inferiors will be held responsible for inferiors in just that way.
Therefore superiors and inferiors, the noble and the base will fear each other because of the law,
and they will teach each other in order to obtain profit.
It is in the nature of the people that there is the substance of life itself on the one hand
and the reputation of one's life on the other.
A true ruler has the good name of a talented and competent person,
and he has the substantial power to hand out punishments and rewards.
The good name and the substantial power are both perfectly realised,
therefore he is bound to be known for good fortune and goodness.
CHECKING WORDS
If when when attending to government business one does not check what has been said against what is done,
then one has nothing to take one's subordinates to task for;
when public statements are not scrutinised for their application in practice
then wicked arguments will come to suit the ruler.
It is in the nature of statements that they become true because many make them.
If something is untrue
then when ten people say it we are in doubt,
when a hundred people say it we consider it as true,
and when a thousand people say it we consider it as incontrovertible.
When a tongue-tied person says something one is in doubt,
when an eloquent person says something we believe it to be true.
When the wicked encroach on the power of their superiors
they gain support from the masses,
they gain trust from their rhetoric ,
and through (distorting) categorisations they paste over their selfishness.
If the ruler does not show his full anger and does not wait with this until everything has been properly checked out
then he will tend to work in favour of his subordinates.
When a ruler who is in possession of the Way listens to a speech
he will survey its uses
and he will check their practical effect.
Rewards and punishments result when the practical effect have been checked.
Therefore such a ruler will not tolerate useless rhetoric at his court.
When a person in charge of something is not competent to carry it out
then he will be dismissed from office and his seal will be confiscated.
If someone makes big words then one should investigate his motivations in every detail
so that the wicked person will be caught and called to account.
Failing to live up to one's word without proper good reason is to cheat,
and when he is cheating one must formally charge a minister with the crime.
When one speaks up there is bound to be a corresponding response
and when one makes an argumentative proposal one is held responsible for its use,
so that partisan proposals will not reach the ruler's ear.
Generally the Way of listening is as follows:
When from diligent ministers' accounts one hears about wickedness,
one opens for wide discussion but accepts one view.
When the ruler is incompetent this will help the wicked.
As for the Way of an enlightened ruler,
when he is excessively delighted with something
he tries to find out why he is so ready to accept it;
when he is very angry at something,
then he tries to find out what brewed up this anger.
He makes his decision after his initial reaction is over
in order get the evidence on what he has maligned, praised, called public-spirited or egotistic.
The ministers make several proposals in a display of cleverness
and then make the ruler choose one course of action, so that they can avoid criminal charges.
As a result, when one or more of the several proposals go wrong
then the ruler's choice will be to blame.
So there must be no hedges (like "probably") as prefaces to what is supposed,
in order to adapt to what is about to happen.
One must ensure that one holds up proposals against what happens afterwards
in order to understand whether this has been misleading or true talk.
In accordance with the Way of the enlightened ruler
a minister is not allowed to make ambiguous political interventions,
and he must be held responsible for one way of talking.
He is not allowed to act on his own authority
and what he does is bound to be checked against his later performance.
As a result the wicked have no path through which to advance.
ACTING ACCORDING TO THE "HANDLES"

div.head:
*官之重也，
When officials are powerful

p.seg: When levies are many they get rich.
The wealth and power of the officials
arises from irregular achievements.
It is the Way of an enlightened ruler
to select people for their formal responsibilities,
to treat them as talented according to the office they hold
and to reward them according to achievements.
If, when proposals are in accordance with laws and regulations
then the ruler is delighted
and both the ruler and the proposer receive benefits;
and if, when proposals are not appropriate
the ruler will show anger
and both the person who proposes and the person proposed will inevitably be harmed,
then as a result people are not partial to their senior relatives
and will promote even their enemies.
Power assigned is sufficient to carry out the law,
stipends are sufficient to have things carried through,
and private favouritism cannot arise anywhere.
As a result the people will work hard and do not show exaggerated regard for officials.
As for those who are in charge of public business one should not make them too powerful
one must ensure that their favour lies in their rank.
As for incumbents of official posts one should not show them any special favour
one must ensure that their profit lies in their stipends.
Then the people will respect rank and attach importance to official stipends.
Ranks and stipends
are means whereby one rewards people;
when the people attach importance to what they are rewarded for
then the state is in good order.
The reason why punishments become numerous
is because public recognition is misguided.
When rewards and praise are inappropriate then the people are left in doubt what to do,
The people attach the same importance to fame and to rewards.
If those who receive rewards are also blamed
then these rewards are not suited to encourage them;
if those who are punished are also praised
then these punishments are not sufficient to stop transgressions.
The Way of the enlightened ruler
is such that his rewards inevitably are motivated by public benefit,
that high reputation is inevitably motivated by service to the ruler.
Rewards and praise move along the same track
disapproval and punishment take the same path.
As a result the people will find no glory outside what is publicly rewarded.
Those who receive heavy punishment are bound to have a bad reputation
and therefore the people will be afraid.
Punishment
is a means to stop things.
If the people are afraid of that by which they are prohibited to do what is illegal,
then the state will be well-governed.
THE RULER'S AUTHORITY
When the practice of rectitude becomes demonstrative the ruler's authority will become diffuse;
when the ruler listens to proposals with an attitude of kindness then the system of law is ruined.
The people stand in awe of the ruler because of an imposed regime,
but the ruler as the person in power behaves humbly towards his subordinates
Therefore if subordinates are reckless, grossly offend against the laws and take pride in following the habit of slighting the ruler,
then the ruler's authority will become diffuse.
If the people find it hard to offend against their superiors because of the law,
but on the basis of the law the ruler makes compromises with loving kind-heartedness
then109 those below will promote loving generosity
and work for a corrupt government system,
as a result laws and regulations decline.
Respect for private action leads to ambiguity about the ruler's authority,
the practice of corruption sows doubt on the law.
If one listens to such private demarches one throws the government into disarray,
and it one does not listen they will slander the ruler.
As a result the ruler will enjoy no respect in his high position
and the law will be thrown into confusion in the public offices.
This is called a state without constant principles.
The Way of the enlightened ruler
is for the ministers to gain no glory through 'just action' beyond the law
and to gain no merit through working for their own clans.
The origin of meritorious achievements and fame
must derive from public office and enactment of the law.
When something is beyond the law
then even if it was hard to do
one must not achieve distinction from it.
Then the people have no way of becoming famous for private actions.
One establishes laws and systems of regulations in order to organise people
one makes rewards and punishments predictable so as to make the people do their best.
One promotes public criticism and public praise in order to encourage and to discourage.
Titles, rewards and punishments, laws and regulations are three cornerstones.
Thus when powerful ministers show proper demeanour
it is to the higher honour of the ruler;
when the people have achievements they serve to benefit their superiors.
Such is the state in which the Way prevails.
When these things got rotten they gave off evil smells
and were harmful to people's stomachs,
and the people were often sick.
Then a sage appeared
he drilled the flint stone and made fire
in order to cook the putrid meat.
So the people felt pleased
and they set him to rule as king over the world.
They gave him the byname "Flint Man".
In middle antiquity
there was a great flood throughout the world
and Gǔn as well as Yǔ dug drainage canals.
In recent antiquity
Jié and Zhòu caused violent turmoil,
Tāng and Wǔ launched expeditions against them.
Now suppose there had been someone who had made nests of wood or drilled flintstone for fire
during the times of the Xià
then they would have been laughed at by Gǔn and Yǔ.
If there had been someone who dug drainage canals
during the times of the Yīn and Zhōu
then they would be bound to be just smiled at by Tāng and Wǔ.
If people praise the Way of Yáo, Shùn, Tāng, Wǔ and Yǔ
now at the present time
then they will be laughed at by the new sages.
Thus the sages are not committed to cultivating antiquity
and they do not take something constantly acceptable as their standard.
They judge the affairs of their age
and they take the appropriate measures for it.
A man from Sòng was working his field
and within his field there was a tree-stump.
A hare came running along and ran into the tree stump.
He broke his neck and died.
So the man from Sòng discarded his plough and kept guard at the stump
hoping he would again get hold of a hare.
It was impossible to get another hare,
and this man became the laughing stock of the state of Sòng.
Now if, using the administrative methods of the former kings
one governs the people of our time
that is always of the same kind as keeping guard at the stump.
In ancient times adult males did not work the fields
the fruits of bushes and trees were enough to live on;
women did not weave
the hides of wild animals were enough to make clothes with.
One did not exert one's strength but there was enough to sustain one,
the population was small but the resources were plentiful,
therefore the people did not compete.
Therefore rich rewards were not dealt out
and severe punishments were not used,
but the people were well-governed of themselves.
Now for a person to have five children is not regarded as many,
the children in turn have five sons,
so before the grandfather is dead there are grandchildren.
As a result the population get large and the goods get scarce,
one exerts all one's strength but this is barely enough to sustain one,
people will start competing with each other
and although one doubles rewards and piles up punishments
one cannot avoid political havoc.
When Yáo was king of the world
the thatching of his house was not trimmed
the painted beams were not hewn plain.
He ate cakes made of coarse-rice cakes,
and he drank pigweed and bean-leaf soup;
in winter he went in young deer coats
in summer he went in kudzu vine clothes.
Even the clothes and nourishment of a janitor
was no less distinguished than this.
When Yǔ was king of the world
he personally held the plough and the rammer to lead the people,
on his thighs there was no hair,
on his shins no hair grew.
Even the toil of a slave prisoner
was no more bitter than this.
Speaking against this background
those who in antiquity abdicated their throne
were getting rid of the kind of treatment of a janitor
and they were leaving the toil of a slave prisoner.
Thus one should not make much of the fact that they handed over the empire.
As for the magistrates of a district in our days
if one day they die
their sons and grandsons will ride fine carriages for generations after.
That is why others respect them.
Therefore when it comes to people's attitudes to resigning the throne
they think little of giving up the position of a Son of Heaven in ancient times,
but they find it hard to relinquish a modern position of a magistrate of a district.
This is because there is a difference in the generosity of the treatment they receive.
Now if one lives in the mountains and fetches water in the valleys
will give each other gifts of water at the feasts during the second and twelfth months;
while those who live in the marshes suffer from floods
hire workers to dig canals for drainage.
Thus in the spring after a year of famine
even the little boys are not given food;
in the autumn of an abundant year
even strangers without close connections are bound to be given food.
This is not because they treat their kith and kin as distant
or love passing strangers.
It is because the material conditions of dearth and abundance are different.
Therefore, when the ancients thought little of material goods
this was by no means because they were of a kindly disposition,
it was because material goods were in abundance;
if today people compete and struggle for material goods
this is not because they are vulgar,
it is because material goods are scarce.
If they thought little of resigning their position as Son of Heaven
this was not because they were high-minded,
it was because the advantages of that position were slight.
If people struggle to gain employment and get close to the aristocracy
this is note because they are base,
it is because these positions of power are important.
Thus the sage will discuss the abundance of supply and judge relative weight
and then conduct his administration on that basis.
Therefore when his fines are slight it is not because he is kind,
and when his punishments are strict this is not because he is cruel:
He adapts to the local social conditions in the action he takes.
Thus public actions adapt to the times
and precautions are adapted to the public business at hand.
In ancient times
King Wén was between Fēng and Hào,
his territory was one hundred square lǐ.
He practised kindness and morality
and won the allegiance of the Western Barbarians
so that in the event he came to rule as king over the world.
King Yǎn of Xú lived east of the River Hàn.
His territory was square lǐ,
he practised kindness and morality
and states offered their allegiance and gave him pieces of territory.
Duke Wén of Jīng, fearing harm for himself
raised an army to attack Xú
and in the end he destroyed the place.
Thus King Wén practised kindness and morality
and became king over the whole world,
King Yǎn practised kindness and morality
and lost his state.
This goes to show that kindness and morality had their use in antiquity
but were not useful in more recent times.
Therefore it is said:
When times are different, circumstances are different.
During the time of Shùn
the Yǒumiáo would not submit
and Yǔ launched a formal campaign against them.
Shùn said:
"This is not acceptable.
When those above are not lavish in their generosity and deploy military force
this is not in accordance with the Way."
Then he engaged in military training for three years
and conducted military dances with shields and battle axes,
and the Yǒumiáo finally submitted.
But in the war against Gōng Gōng
the iron sharp tip daggers were directed at the enemy,
and those whose metal and leather armour was not strong got injured.
This is because shields and battle axes were useful in antiquity
but they were of no use in the more recent past.
Thus it is said:
"Under different circumstances one's precautions must change."
In high antiquity people were competing in the Way and in virtue,
in mid antiquity they were vie with each other in clever strategies,
and in our times they compete with fighting spirit and brute force.
When Qí was about to attack Lǔ
Lǔ sent Zǐgòng out to plead their cause.
The people of Qí said:
"It is not that your speech is not eloquent.
But what we want is territory,
and this speech of yours does not speak about that."
So in the event they raised their army and attacked Lǔ.
They fixed their border ten lǐ from the very gates of the capital of Lǔ.
Thus Duke Yǎn was kindly and righteous but Xú was lost,
Zǐgòng was well-spoken and clever, but Lǔ was decimated.
From this it can be seen:
kindliness and morality, eloquence and cleverness
are not the things by which a state is maintained.
If one had removed King Yǎn's kindliness
and if one had stopped Zǐgòng's cleverness
if one had built up the forces of Xú and Lǔ
to the point where they can be the equal of 10 000 chariots,
then Qí and Jīng would not have got their way with these two states.
Past and present have different customs,
new times and former times require different precautions.
If with lax policies
one wants to reduce to order the people of a desperate age,
this would be like steering wild horses without reins:
this is the trouble that arises from ignorance.
Now the Confucians and the Mohists all praise the former kings
saying that they loved everyone in the world
so that they looked upon the people as parents upon their children.
How does one know that this is so?
They say:
When the minister of justice deploys punishments
the ruler will not conduct any musical entertainment on account of that;
when he hears news of a death penalty
the ruler will shed tears on account of that."
They praise the former kings on account of this.
Now if the relation between ruler and minister is like that between father and son
then there is good government.
It follows from such a statement that there are no unruly relations between fathers and sons.
As for the real inner nature of man nothing has higher priority (for it) than one's parents
they are all well-loved, but this does not necessarily lead to good order.
Even if there be great love
why should there not be disorder?
Now if the way the former kings loved the people
does not go further than parent's love for their children,
and if with children there is no guarantee that they will not revolt,
then why should the people remain in good order?
Moreover, if one carries out a physical punishement according to the law
and the ruler sheds tears on account of this,
this is in order to affect kindliness,
it is not inorder to effect good government.
To shed tears and not to want there to be physical punishment
is a matter of kindness,
but punishment being inevitable
that is a matter of the law.
If the former kings gave precedence to the law
and did not listen to their own sobs.
then that kindliness cannot lead to good government
that is surely clear.
Moreover, the people will certainly subdued by superior power
but few are capable of showing deep concern for rectitude.
Confucius
was the greatest sage in the world.
He cultivated his demeanour and promoted the Way
and thus travelled within the four seas.
Those in the world who were persuaded by his kindliness
who approved his rectitude
and who became his devoted followers were seventy men.
Presumably those who value kindliness are few
and the ability to be dutiful/act out rectitude is hard to achieve.
Thus from a place as large as the whole world
seventy men became devoted followers,
and among these only one was a truly kindly and righteous man.
Duke Ai of Lǔ
was a lesser ruler,
but when he sat on the throne and ruled over his state
there was no one in the land who dared not be his loyal servant.
The people certainly submit to superior position of power.
With superior position of power it is truly easy to make others submit.
As a result Confucius, contrary to what one would expect, was a servant
while Duke Ai, on the other hand, was a ruler.
It was not that Confucius appreciated his ruler's righteousness,
he submitted to his superior power.
Thus from the point of view of rectitude
Confucius should not have submitted to Duke Āi,
but availing himself of his superior position of power
Duke Ai made Confucius his servant.
Now when the learned men persuade rulers
not to rely on the supreme position of power
but to engage in the practice of kindness and morality
so as to be able to become a true king
this is to require that the ruler is bound to do as well as Confucius
and to regard the ordinary people as so many assorted disciples.
This is a philosophy that is bound not lead to success.
Suppose there is a son of no talent.
His parents get angry at him but he will not reform himself.
The neighbours berate him but he will not budge.
His teachers and seniors try to reform him but he will not change.
Now the love of the parents,
the respectable behaviour of the neighbours,
the wisdom of teachers and seniors,
these three excellent influences were brought to bear on him
but until the end he does not budge
and he does not change as much as hair on his shin.
But when the local magistrate
takes along officials and armed men
to promote the public law
and seeks out the offender,
only then he gets terrified,
he changes from his ordinary standards,
and fundamentally reforms his behaviour.
Thus parental love is not enough to reform children,
and one has to rely on the severe punishments by local officials,
and this is because the people are arrogant towards love
but obedient to superior authority.
Thus as for a city wall ten spans ( meters) high
even Lóujì is unable to climb over:
this is because it is so steep.
As for a mountain that is two thousand meters high
lame goats find it easy to grase there,
because it is not too steep.
Therefore the enlightened ruler makes his laws steep and makes his punishments severe.
A few feet of cloth or silk
an ordinary person may not miss an opportunity of taking,
but one hundred taels of red-hot molten gold
even Robber Zhí may not use an opportunity to pick up.
When there is no certainty about ensuing harm
then one will not miss an opportunity to pick up even few feet of cloth;
but when their hands are certain to get hurt
then they will not use an opportunity to pick up a hundred taels.
Therefore the enlightened ruler will make his punishments certain.
This it is best to make rewards abundant and reliable
in order to make the people see their profit in them;
and it is best to make punishment heavy and certain
in order to make the people fear them.
Laws should be unified and firm
in order to make the people understand them.
Therefore the ruler does not change in his deployment of rewards
and he does not show mercy in the meting out of punishment.
If through praise he builds up under his rewards
and he follows up his punishments with criticism
then the talented as well as the incompetent will all do their very best.
But at present things are not like that.
They give ranks to people for their achievements
but assigns them humble office.
They reward people according to their agricultural work
but they reduce the economic conditions for their families;
because people are not taken into the government one treats them as outsiders
but one praises highly that they think little of this world.
One charges people with crimes for breaking prohibitions
but sets great store by their courage.
What one blames and praises, rewards and punishes
is mutually contradictory.
Thus laws and prohibitions lose their efficacy and the people get more and more rebellious.
Nowadays if one's brother suffers an injustice
and one must attack the culprit,
that counts as moral purity;
if one's acquaintance or friend suffers a public disgrace
and one goes after his enemy
that counts as moral probity.
When demeanour characterised by integrity and probity is perfected
then the laws of the ruler get infringed.
The rulers honour demeanour characterised by probity and integrity
and forgets about the crimes of offending against prohibitions.
Therefore the people glory in their valour
and the magistrates are unable to handle them effectively.
If without working hard but has clothes and food enough
that is called ability;
if one does not fight for achievements but to be honoured
that is called talent.
When the demeanour of such ability and talent is perfected
then the army will be weak and the fields will lie fallow.
The ruler delights in demeanour characterised by talent and ability
but he forgets about the disastrous effect of the weakening of the army
and the fallowness of the fields.
Thus egotistic behaviour is established
and public benefit is reduced to nothing.
The Confucians confuse the law on the basis of the polite arts,
the wandering knights offend against prohibitions by the use of weapons,
and the rulers treat them all with politeness.
This is how chaos comes about.
Those who deviate from the law are charged with crimes,
but all the teachers are chosen on the basis of their cultural attainments;
those who offend against prohibitions are punished
but all the wandering knights earn their living with their private swordsmanship.
Thus it is that what the law forbids
is what the ruler opts for at the same time;
what the magistrates punish
is what the leadership fosters at the same time.
The law, and what the ruler chooses, the higher and the lower authorites,
all these four are in contradiction with each other
and they are nowhere properly defined.
Even if there were ten Yellow Emperors
they would not be able to introduce good government.
Thus the practice of kindliness and morality is not what one praises,
for if one praises these then that is harmful to obtaining meritorious results;
specialists in the polite arts are not people to employ,
for if one employs them then one will confuse the law.
When in Chǔ there was a certain Gōng the Straight,
his father had stolen a goat
and he reported this to the magistrate.
The officer in charge said:
"Have him killed"
He considered the man was straight with the ruler but crooked with his father.
He reported the case to the authorities and raised criminal charges against him.
From this it may be seen:
a straight servant to a master
