is a reckless son to a father.
A man from Lǔ had followed his ruler to war,
and in three battles they had suffered three defeats and fled.
Confucius asked why this had happened,
and he replied:
"I have an aged father,
and if I myself die there is no one to look after him.
Confucius considered that he had the virtue of filial piety
and he raised him to a high position.
From this it may be seen:
a filial son to a father
is a renegade servant to a master.
Thus the senior officer of Chǔ meted out a punishment
and wickedness in Chǔ ceased to come to the attention of the authorities;
Confucius rewarded a man and the people of Lǔ became prone to surrendering.
The benefits for authorities and subordinates
are as different as that.
And if a ruler at the same time elevates the behaviour of an ordinary person
and in that way aims to get good fortune for the nation,
he is bound to become a resounding failure.
In ancient times when Cāngjié created the writing system
he called those who walled themselves in "egotistic",
and he called those who went against the private "public".
The opposition between public and private
was certainly something that Cāngjié was already aware of.
To consider now that these two have the same notion of what benefits them
constitutes disastrous lack of perceptiveness.
As a result of this, making plans for a commoner
the best thing for him is to cultivate the practice of private morality and to practise the polite arts.
When his practice of morality is well cultivated he will be trusted,
when he is trusted he will be put in charge of public business.
When the polite arts are well rehearsed he will become a brilliant teacher
if he is a brilliant teacher he will become illustrious,
and this is the most attractive thing for an ordinary person.
And so without any meritorious achievements they are in charge of public business,
without official rank they become illustrious,
and if those who are in charge of government are like this
then the state is bound to be in disarray and the ruler is bound to be in a dangerous position.
Thus incompatible concerns
cannot coexist.
If those who cut off enemys' heads receive rewards
but one gives high status to kind and generous behaviour ,
if those who take out cities receive ranks and stipends
but one shows confidence in talk about integrity and love,
if one has strong armour and fierce troops to guard against trouble
but one praises the elaborate embellishments on sashes,
if one makes the state rich through agriculture
and relies on troops to stave off the enemy
but values highly the gentlemen who specialise in the polite arts,
if one dismisses those who respect superiors and live in fear of the law
but supports wandering knights with their private swords and the like,
if one acts in this way,
then good government and political strength are unobtainable.
If when the state is at peace one supports the Confucians and the knights,
but when trouble arises one uses armoured soldiers
then those whom one benefits are not those whom one uses
and those whom one uses are not those whom one benefits.
As a result those in charge of public affairs will take their duties lightly
and roving scholars will be daily on the increase.
This is how the world is reduced to turmoil.
Moreover what the world calls moral talent
is honest and trustworthy behaviour;
and what they call competence
is subtle and mysterious pronouncements.
Subtle and mysterious pronouncements
are things that even the most competent find hard to understand.
Now if one makes laws for the masses
but uses things that even the most competent find hard to understand
then the common people have no way of being clear about it.
Thus someone who does not get enough of dregs and bran will not go for high quality grain and meats.
Someone who does not even have a complete short garment of coarse cloth
will not be waiting for patterned silk as clothing.
In the business of governing the world,
if one cannot get what is urgent
then one should not make one's business what is not so urgent.
Now in governing an administration, when it comes to matters regarding the common people,
if one does not use words that anyone will understand clearly
and is hoping for conclusions of the utmost intellectual quality
then the effect on the government will be the opposite of that intended.
Thus pronouncements of the subtle and mysterious kind
are not something the people will make their serious concern.
Those whose behaviour is characterised by moral talent, probity and good faith
are bound to be honoured as freemen who are free from deceit;
freemen who are free from deceit
have no method by which to protect themselves from deceit.
As for the friendships of ordinary people
they have no wealth and generosity to benefit each other with
and they have no authority or positions of power to intimidate each other with
that is why they go for freemen who are not deceitful.
Now the ruler occupies the dominant position of ruling over others
and he has the control over the munificence of the whole state.
If he gives ample rewards and metes out stern punishments
if he gets to wield his handle of power
in order to cultivate what his enlightened method makes clear,
then even if there are ministers like Tián Cháng or Zǐhǎn
they will not dare to cheat one.
What need is there to depend non-deceitful freemen?
As for freemen of probity and good faith there are no more than ten,
but the offices within your boundaries are in the hundreds.
If you insist on having honest and faithful freemen
then there are not enough people for the official positions.
When there are not enough people for the official positions
then more people will behave improperly than properly.
Thus the Way of the enlightened ruler
is to unify the law and not to go for cleverness,
to be firm in one's method and not to hope for good faith.
As a result the laws will not fail to be efficient
and the various officials will be without wickedness or deceit.
Now when it comes to ruler's attitudes to public pronouncements
they delight in the rhetoric but do not look for truth;
and when it comes to their use in practical action
he finds their fame impressive and does not take them to task for results.
As a result the masses of people in the world
when it comes to making public pronouncements go for rhetorical effect
and do not consider completely their use in practice.
Thus those who praise the former kings and speak of kindness and morality
fill the courts
but that does not mean there is any less havoc in government;
Those who cultivate their persons vie for high status
and do not adapt themselves to the pursuit of results.
As a result intellectuals withdraw to live in craggy mountain caves
and return official stipends offered to them, refusing to accept
so the armed forces inevitably are weakened.
When the army is inevitably weakened
the administration will inevitably be in turmoil.
What is the reason for this?
It is that what the people praise
and what the authorities show ritual respect for
is a philosophy which brings havoc to the state.
Nowadays all the people within the land talk about good government,
and when it comes to keeping copies of the laws of Shāng Yǎng and Guǎn Zhòng
private families have these in their homes
but the state is getting poorer and poorer,
those who talk about agricultural work are many,
and those who handle the plough are few.
Everyone in the land talks about the army
when it comes to keeping copies of Sūnzǐ's and Wǔ Qǐ's books
private families have these in their homes,
but the armed forces become weaker and weaker.
Many are those who talk about war,
but few are those who bear armour.
Thus the enlightened ruler avails himself of their strength
but does not listen to their pronouncements;
he rewards meritorious achievements
but is sure to ban whatever is useless.
As a result the people give everything they have, including their lives
to follow their leader.
Now working hard in agriculture is exhausting
and the reason why the people engage in this is
because they say:
"One can get rich on this."
The business of warfare is dangerous,
and the reason why the people engage in this is
because they say:
"One can become noble on this."
Now if the people by cultivating the polite arts
and by practising wordy pronouncements,
can, without hard agricultural work, get the precious possession of wealth,
if without exposing themselves to the dangers of war
they can achieve the honours of high status,
then who would not do this?
Therefore for every hundred who work at becoming clever
there is one man who who puts in decent physical work.
When there are many who work at becoming clever
then the laws become ineffective;
if those who do decent work are few
then the state will become poor.
This is how the world is reduced to chaos.
Thus in the state of an enlightened ruler
there are no belles-lettres on inscribed bamboo slips,
and the instrument of education is the law;
there is no talk from the former kings
and the teachers of the people are the police;
there are no fierce exploits of private swordsmen,
and cutting off enemy heads counts as valour.
Under such circumstances the people in the land
will move along the track of the law in what they say
in their actions they will be orientated towards results,
and those who are after valour exercise it to the full in the army.
Thus when there is no trouble, the state is rich,
when there is trouble the army is strong.
These are called the resources of a king.
One must first accumulate the resources of a king
and then latch on to the weaknesses of enemy states.
If one is to surpass the Five Ancestors or to equal the Three Kings
one absolutely has to follow this method.
Nowadays things are not like that.
The citizens behave recklessly at home
and the talkers deploy their power play aboad.
Those abroad and at home are all equally wicked
just awaiting a strong enemy.
Surely that is a dangerous state of affairs.
When the ministers talk about foreign affairs
they are either partial to the horizontal and vertical alliances
or they are doing their utmost to avenge some hostile act
and are trying to enlist the power of the state in their quest.
The vertical alliance
combines a number of weak forces to attack one strong power;
and the horizontal alliance
serves one strong state in order to attack a number of weak states.
None of these are designed to maintain the state.
Now the ministers who speak up in favour of the vertical alliance
all say:
"If we do not serve the big power
then when we meet the enemy that will be disastrous."
When one is serving a big power
and it remains uncertain whether this will lead to concrete results
then one must offer up one's maps and leave them with the big power
one hands up one's official seals and asks for military support.
Once one has handed up one's map then one's territory is decimated,
once one has offered up one's official seals then one's reputation is low.
Once one's territory is decimated then the state is decimated,
once one's reputation is low then one's administration is in turmoil.
But when one serves a big power and works for the vertical alliance
and has not yet seen any concrete benefits
then one has instead lost territory and reduced one's administration to chaos.
Those who speak up for the vertical alliance
all say:
"If we do not rescue the small states and go on to attack the big one
then we shall lose the whole world to the big state.
When the whole world is lost to the big state, then our state is in danger.
When the state is in danger then the ruler's status is low.
Before they have seen concrete results of saving the small states
they are raising armies and facing the big power as an enemy.
When they are rescuing a small state they cannot necessarily survive
and when they launch a formal attack against a big power
one cannot be sure that there won't be divisions in one's alliance.
And if there are divisions in one's camp one will be at the mercy of the big state.
Then if one sends troops to battle one's army will be defeated
and if one withdraws to a defensive position one's city will be conquered.
If one rescues the small states and works for a vertical alliance
then before one has seen any concrete benefits
one will lose one's territory and see one's army defeated.
Thus when one serves one strong state
then one will have powerful alien men holding office in one's country;
and if one rescures small states
then as a result one's powerful men will seek their profit in foreign missions.
Before there is concrete benefit to the state
they will be enfeoffed with territory and have abundant stipends;
the ruler may then have a humble status,
and the ministers enjoy all honours.
The state may be truncated
but the private families will get rich.
If they are successful in their undertakings
then they will enjoy lasting political importance because of their power;
if they fail in their undertakings
then they withdraw with their wealth into a private life.
When the ruler listens to the arguments from his ministers,
then even before a project is completed ranks and stipends are already abundant.
If, when a project fails one will not punish those responsible
then of the wandering freemen who offer their arguments
who would not use arguments which work like stringed arrows
and hope for the best afterwards?
Thus they ruin the state and ruin the ruler
but still the ruler listens to the baseless arguments of the talkers.
Why is that?
This is because the ruler is not clear about public and private profit
are not fully aware of the appropriateness or otherwise of words,
and he does not make certain that there will be punishments after the event.
They all say:
"In foreign affairs
if I am lucky I can become a king
and at the very least I can effect a peace."
Now a king
is someone who is capable of attacking others;
and live in peace
is to be safe from attack.
If one is strong
then one is the sort of person who can attack others,
and if there is good order
then one is safe from attack.
Good political order and political strength cannot depend on through foreign activities,
they are matters to do with internal administration.
Now if one does not use the philosophy of law in internal politics
but one is devoted to cleverness in foreign policy
then one will not achieve good order and strength.
A popular saying goes:
"If you have long sleeves you are good at dancing,/
and if you have a lot of money you will be a good merchant."/
This means that abundant resources make it easy to do work.
Thus a well-governed and strong state is easy to make plans for
while a weak and disorderly state is hard to make plans for.
Those who are employed in Qín may change strategy ten times
but their plans will seldom fail;
those who are employed in Yān may change strategy only once
but their plans will rarely succeed.
This is not because those who are employed in Qín are necessrily competent
while those who are employed in Yān are necessarily stupid.
Presumably it is because the resources of good government versus chaos are different.
Thus Zhōu deserted Qín and worked for the vertical alliance
and within one year they were completely routed;
Wèy deserted Wèi and joined the horizontal alliance,
and within six months they were ruined.
And so Zhōu was annihilated through the vertical alliance
while Wèy was ruined through the horizontal alliance.
If Zhōu and Wèy
had gone easy on their plans for vertical and horisontal alliances
had been strict about good government within their boundaries,
had made laws and prohibitions clear
had made rewards and punishments certain,
had exhausted the resources of their territory to make large stockpiles,
had got their people to risk their lives in order to secure defenses,
and had seen to it that if someone from the outside got the territory
his profit would be small,
and that if he attacked the state then he would suffer great injury
then even a state of ten thousand chariots
would not dare to wear themselves out attacking the firm walls
and to allow their strong enemy to get at them in their reduced state.
This is a method by which one is certain not to be ruined.
To abandon a method by which one is certain not to be ruined
and to engage in projects that are bound to led to ruin,
that would be a mistake by those who are in charge of a state.
If one's cleverness is in trouble outside and the government and one's administration is internally in disarray,
then one is lost beyond saving.
In their administration of their own lives
the people will all opt for comfort and benefits
just as they will avoid danger and deep trouble.
Now if one is engaged in offensive warfare
if by moving forward one is bound to die at the hands of the enemy
and if by withdrawing one dies as a punishment,
then one is in danger.
If they have to abandon their private business at home
and are forced into the hardships of cavalry battle,
if when their families are in trouble the ruler refuses to pay attention to this,
then they are in deep trouble.
When there is deep trouble and danger
how should the people fail to try to get away from these?
So they offer their services to the powerful private families
and are exempt from military service.
If they are thus exempt from military levies they keep far from battles,
if they keep far from battles they have their peace.
If they use bribes and rely improperly on the power of those in charge
then they will seek personal advantage.
When they have won their personal advantage then they cultivate their private peace.
When there is a situation where they will find private peace and where they can garner profits,
then how should they not go for it.
Under such circumstances there will be few public-spirited people
and there will be many people with selfish concerns.
The enlightened ruler's policy in governing a state
is to reduce the number of tradesmen and craftsmen who wander about,
and to give them a poor name,
and this is because few of them are concerned with basic tasks
and because they eagerly engage in marginal pursuits.
Now if nowadays the inner circles engage in private pleading
then offices and ranks can be bought;
if offices and ranks can be bought
then tradesmen and craftsmen will not have low status.
When ill-gotten goods and bribes can be used in the market
then tradesmen will be many.
If by accumulating wealth one can make twice as much as a peasant
and one thus will reach high status, higher than that of peasants or men of war
then properly well-armed gentlemen will be few
and tradesmen will be many.
Thus the custom in a state in chaos is this:
the scholars
will praise the Way of the former kings and will appeal to kindness and morality.
They will pay abundant attention to appearance and clothing and polish their rhetoric and persuasions
so that they throw doubt on the laws of their times
and bring it about that the ruler is in two minds.
The talkers
are concerned to establish their fraudulent reputation;
they avail themselves of foreign forces
in order to further their private interests
and disregard what benefits the altars of the land and grain.
Those who bear swords
gather followers around them
and they establish a code of conduct
in order to make their names illustrious,
and they thus offend against the prohibitions issued by the five government bureaus.
Those who are terrified of corvee service
gather at the gates of the private rich,
they give bribes as best they can
and use contacts with powerful people
in order to be spared the toil of military service.
The traders and craftsmen
make idle and useless tools
and accumulate extravagant wealth.
They accumulate these and wait for the right time
in order to rip off the benefits that properly belong to the peasants.
These five groups are the vermins of the land.
If rulers do not get rid of these five kinds of vermin-like people
and does not support freemen of resplendent integrity
then even if there are states within the four seas that are ruined
and there are courts that decline and fall,
one should surely not be surprised!
After Mòzǐ died
there were the Mr Xiānglǐ Mohists,
there were the Mr Xiāngfū Mohists,
and there were the Mr Dènglíng Mohists.
Thus after Confucius and Mòzi
the Confucians were divided into eight schools,
the Mohists were divided into three schools.
Their preferences were opposed to each other and not at all the same
but they all called themselves true Confucians and true Mohists.
Since Confucius and Mòzǐ cannot be brought to life again
whom is one to set to decide on the learning of our time.
Both Confucius and Mòzǐ followed the Way of Yáo and Shùn,
but their preferences were not the same,
though they all called themselves true followers of Yáo and Shùn.
Since Yáo and Shùn cannot be brought to life again
whom is one to set to decide the truth between Confucians or the Mohists?
Since the times of Yīn and the Zhōu seven hundred odd years have passed.
Since Yú and Xià more than two thousand years have passed.
And one cannot determine the truth between the Confucians and the Mohists.
Now if one wants to investigate the Ways of Yáo and Shùn
three thousand years after the event,
is it conceivable that one should come to a fixed conclusion?
If without checked evidence one comes to certain conclusions
that is stupidity;
if one cannot be certain about something but adduces it as evidence
then one is cheating.
Thus those who openly adduce the former kings as evidence
and who fix down with certainty Yáo and Shùn
are either stupid or fraudulent.
Stupid or fraudulent learning
as well as impure or contradictory ideals of behaviour
the enlightened ruler will not accept.
Mohist burial practice
is to wear winter clothes on a winter day
and to wear summer clothes on a summer day,
to have a paulownia-tree coffin three inches thick,
to wear mourning clothes for three months.
The rulers of the time considered this as modest use of resources and regarded it as ritually appropriate.
The Confucians ruin their families for the sake of funerals,
they wear mourning clothes for three years,
they greatly exhaust themselves and walk with canes.
The rulers of the time consider this as filial and treated them with politeness.
But if one is to regard Mòzǐ's frugality as right
one will have to regard Confucius' excessiveness as wrong;
if one regards Confucius' filial piety as right
one will have to regard Mòzǐ's strictness as wrong.
Now filial piety, strictness, extravagance and frugality
are all present among the Confucians and the Mohists,
and the rulers treat them all at the same time with ritual politeness.
Qìtiáo argument was
that one should not flinch humbly
and that one should not avoid looking others in the eye;
that if one has done something crooked one avoids an ordinary slave,
but if one has acted straightforwardly one will show anger even to a feudal lord.
The rulers of the time thought him morally pure and treated him with respect.
Sòng Róngzǐ's argument was
that one should insist on non-belligerence,
that one should opt for not going after one's enemies
that one should not feel ashamed to be put in jail
and that one should not regard it as a disgrace to be publicly humiliated.
The rulers of the time considered him as broad-minded and treated him with respect.
Now if one considers Qìtiáo's moral integrity as right
then one will have to consider Sòng Róng's tolerance as wrong;
if one considers Sòng Róng's lenience as right
then one will have to consider Qìtiáo's recklessness as wrong.
Now lenience, integrity, forgiveness and recklessness
are all present in these two people,
but the rulers treat them all with respect.
With stupid or fraudulent intellectual pursuits as a starting point,
and with motley and contradictory formulations they struggle,
but the rulers of men all listen to them.
Thus the freemen of the world
do not have a fixed method in their proposals,
and they have no stable arguments for their ideals of behaviour.
Ice and (burning) coals will not be in the same vessel for a long time,
cold and hot weather do not come at the same time.
Motley and contradictory teachings cannot be justified at the same time for there to be good order.
Now if one listens to words about motley teachings and misguided ideals of behaviour
making their fine distinctions among these,
how can one fail to end up in chaos.
If in one's listening practice one is like this,
then one will necessarily also be like that when it comes to governing others.
When freemen of learning nowadays go on about good government
they often say:
"Give land to the poor to provide for those who have no means."
Now if conditions are equal for everyone,
that som without good harvests or side income
all on their own manage to provide sufficiently well for themselves,
then that is either by sheer strength or through frugality.
And people being all alike
if without special famines, diseases, disasters or criminal guilt
one is the only one to be poor
then this must be because one is wasteful or lazy.
Those who are wasteful or lazy become poor
and those who make an effort and are frugal become rich.
Now if the authorities collect levies from the rich
in order to distribute them to the poor families,
this is to take away from those who make an effort and are frugal,
and to give to those whoe are wasteful or lazy.
If in this way one aims to get the people to work hard and be thrifty
that is quite impossible.
Suppose we have a man
and he regards it as right and proper never to enter a city in danger,
and he does not engage in military activities,
and he would not swap a hair on his shin for the benefit of the world.
The rulers of our time are bound to treat him with respect because of this,
they will set store by his wisdom and regard his moral demeanour highly,
and they will consider him
a freeman who takes external things lightly and considers life as important.
Now the reason why the ruler offers good agricultural land and large mansions,
and establishes ranks and stipends
is because makes it easy for the people to sacrifice their lives when ordered to do so.
Now if the leader honours gentlemen who take external things lightly and who consider life as important
and then to hope that the people will go out and sacrifice their lives
and value dying for the leader,
that is quite impossible.
Those who collect books
and who practise talking about theories
who collect followers and slaves around them
who are dedicated to the study of the polite arts and who argue and explain about things,
these the rulers of our time will treat them with respect on this account
and they will say:
"Treating freemen of talent with respect
is the Way of the former kings."
Those from whom the enforcement officials collect taxes
are those who work the fields;
but those whom the leadership supports
are the freemen devoted to learning.
To take heavy agricultural taxes from those who work the fields
and at the same time to give rich rewards to freemen devoted to learning
and then to want the people to work hard and spend little time talking
that is quite impossible.
Those who establish their code of conduct and also enjoy celebrity for that,
those who keep to certain patterns of behaviour and will not be meddled with,
who, when the hear of spiteful talk
are bound to follow this up with the sword,
the rulers of our time are bound to treat with respect on this account
considering that they are freemen of natural grace.
Now if one does not reward the killing of enemies in war
but celebrates valour in squabbles among schools of thought,
and hopes that the people will fight eagerly, stave off the enemy,
and will not engage in private squabbles,
then that is quite imposible.
When the state is at peace
it will support Confucians as well as knights of honour,
but when trouble arises
then they will use armoured freemen.
The ones they support are not the ones they have use for
and the ones they have use for are not the ones whom they support.
This is how political havoc arises.
Moreover, when it comes to a ruler listening to scholars,
if he approves of his pronouncements
he should promulgate them to the officials and employ the person in question;
if he disapproves of his pronouncements
he should remove the person from his presenceand put a stop to the principles proposed.
Now when one considers something as right
then to refuse to make it known to the government offices,
and when one considers something as wrong
then not to put a stop to the principles proposed,
this is to consider things as right but not to act on them,
it is to consider things as wrong but not to put a stop to them,
and it is the way of chaos and ruin.
Tántái Zǐyǔ
had the looks of a gentleman.
Confucius cultivated his acquantance and picked him as a disciple.
When he had spent a long time with him
his behaviour did not live up to his appearance.
Zǎiyú's use of words
was elegant and polished.
Confucius cultivated his acquaintance and picked him as a disciple.
But when he had spent a long time with him
he found that his intelligence was not up to his rhetoric.
Therefore Confucius said:
"Should one choose people on the basis of looks?
I made a mistake with Zǐyǔ.
Should one choose people on the basis of their use of words?
I made a mistake with Zǎiyú."
Thus for all his intelligence
Confucius was still known to have got things wrong.
The new-fangled rhetoric of our time goes further than Zǎiyú
but in listening ability the rulers of our time are less sensitive than Confucius.
Because they feel pleased with someone's use of words
they go on to employ the person for that reason.
How then can they fail to get things wrong?
Thus Wèi employed Mèng Máo because of his rhetoric
and this led to the trouble below Mount Huá;
Zhào employed Mǎ Fú for his rhetoric
and this led to the disaster at Chángpíng.
These two episodes
are cases of mistakes in employing people because of their rhetoric.
If when judging alloy tin used in forging metal one were only to look at the greenish-yellow colour
then even Founder Qū would not be sure it was 'a real sword'.
But if on water you strike a swan or a wild goose with a sword
or on land you cut down a colt or a horse with it,
then even Jack and Jill will be left in no doubt whether the sword is dull or sharp.
If he was only to look at teeth and lips and judge outer shape
then in that way even a Bólè could not be certain about horses;
But if handed a vehicle and harnessed the horse
to see what happens at the finishing line in a race
then even Jack and Jill would not be in any doubt whether it was a hag or good.
In observing looks and clothing
and in listening to speeches
even Confucius cannot be certain about a freeman;
but if he tests them in an official capacity
and examines his actual achievements,
then even a mediocre person is in no doubt about his stupidity or cleverness.
Therefore among the officials of an enlightened ruler
the prime ministers are bound to rise from provincial magistrate offices,
and the senior generals are bound to have risen from the rank and file.
If those who achieve concrete results are inevitably rewarded
then ranks and stipends are regarded as substantial
and people will feel increasingly encouraged;
if promotion in office is gradual by degree
then public offices and duties count for much
and there will be more and more good order.
For the ranks and stipends to be substantial
and for public offices and duties to be well-ordered
that is the Way of a true king.
Ownership of a thousand square lǐ rocky land
cannot be said to be a sign of wealth;
ownership of one million statues
cannot be said to be a sign of military strength.
It is not that the stones are not large,
and it is not that there aren't many of them,
but the reason why these are not signs of wealth and strength
is that rocky land does not allow grain to grow
nor can ivory statues of men be made to stave off enemies.
Now the gentlemen in trade, in office, and in the arts
also eat without cultivating any land.
That land which is not being cultivated
is exactly like rocky land.
If the Confucians and the knights will not do military service
but they achieve illustriousness and glory,
then the people will not allow themselves to be employed by the leadership
and their public service will be that of statues.
Now to understand that rocky land and statues are disastrous
but not to understand that merchants, Confucians and knights are disastrous
along the lines of land not cultivated
and people not deployed,
that is not to understand the natural categories in public undertakings.
Thus even if the ruler and king of a competing state
approves of one's moral standards
one can still not receive tribute from him and treat him as a vassal;
even if the lords within the pass
all disapprove of one's moral standards,
one is still bound to have them arrested and brought to court to show their respect.
Thus if one has a great deal of power
then others will pay their respects to one at court;
and if one's power is slight
then one must pay court to others.
Thus the enlightened ruler will be mainly concerned with power.
Now in a strict household there are no obstreporous slaves
but a doting mother will have good-for-nothing sons.
From this I understand
and that through generosity one cannot stop political chaos.
When a sage governs a state
he does not rely on others acting in one's own best interest
but he makes use of the fact that they cannot commit misdeeds.
When he relies on others doing good for his sake
there won't be more than a dozen people who do this,
but when he makes use of the fact that people cannot do wrong
the whole state can be brought to heel.
A person who is engaged in ruling
will use what works for the majority and dismiss what works for a minority only
therefore he does not make generosity his main concern
but makes the law his main concern.
If one were to rely on arrow-shafts that are naturally straight
then there would not be an arrow in a hundred generations;
if one were to rely on timber that was round by itself
there would not be a wheel in a thousand generations.
Arrow-shafts that are naturally straight
and pieces of timber that are round of themselves
are not found once in a hundred generations.
That people none the less all ride vehicles and shoot for game
why is that?
It is because the tools and techniques of making things round and straight are used.
Even if one without relying on such tools for making things round and straight,
there will be some arrow-shaft that are straight of themselves
and some pieces of timber that are round of themselves,
a competent craftsman would refuse to find this a precious discovery.
Why is this so?
Because those who ride vehicles are not just one or two people
and those who shoot arrows are not one or two people.
The people who without the use of rewards and punishments
rely on becoming good of themselves
the enlightened ruler will refuse to prize highly.
Why is that?
It is because the laws of the land must never fail to work
and the people he governs are not just one or two people.
Thus a ruler who has the right political method
does not go after goodness that is a fortuitous result
on the contrary he walks along the path of inevitable success.
Suppose someone were to tell people:
"I will make sure you will be wise and that you will live long lives"
then the world would be bound to consider him mad.
Wisdom
is a matter of inborn nature;
and long life
is a matter of fate.
Inborn nature and fate
are not things one learns from others,
and offering others something that is not within human abilities
that is reason enough for the world to consider one mad.
[ If one says one can do something when in fact one cannot do it
then that is empty flattery.
Now flattery is not in accordance with human nature. ]
To teach people kindness and morality
that is claiming that one can offer wisdom and long life,
and a ruler who has a political system will refuse to accept this.
Thus praising the beauty of Máo Qiáng and Xī Shī
does not do any good to one's looks.
But if one uses rich grease and powder
then one will be twice as attractive as before.
Talking about the kindness and morality of the former kings
does not do any good to government;
but being clear about one's legal system
making one's rewards and punishments inevitable
this is the rich grease and the black powder of the state.
Thus the enlightened ruler is urgently preoccupied with what helps
and relaxed about panegyrics
and that is why he does not speak of kindness and morality.
Now when the shamans pray for people they say:
"May you live a thousand autumns and ten thousand years"
But the 'thousand autumns and ten thousand years' are just so much din,
and there is no evidence of as much as one day's longer life for a person.
That is why people treat the shamans with little respect.
The Confucians of our time, when they present their views to the rulers,
do not praise the means by which good government is achieved in our time
and they keep talking about the achievements of what was well governed in the past.
They do not study carefully the matter of government offices and laws
and do not look carefully into the facts of wickedness and depravity
and they all take as their guideline
the transmitted praise of high antiquity
and the ready-made achievements of the former kings.
Polishing their phrases the Confucians say:
"If you listen to our proposals
then you can become a hegemon king."
These are the shamans among the advisers,
and a ruler who has his standard to go by will not accept them.
Therefore the enlightened ruler will bring up concrete matters
and get rid of useless pursuits.
He will not take old tales of kindness and morality as his guideline,
he will not listen to the proposals from the learned.
Now those who do not understand good government are bound to say:
"One must win the allegiance of the people."
If by just wanting to win the people's allegiance
one could get to practise good government
then there would be no use for Yī Yǐn and Guǎn Zhòng.
One should simply listen to the people, that is all.
The reason why the intelligence of the people cannot be used
is because it is like the mind of a little child.
If a little child does not have its head shaved in time it will hurt even more,
if one does not pierce a boil then the infection will spread even more.
When one is shaving the child, when one is piercing the boil
one person has to hold the child
as the loving mother deals with him.
And still the child will be weeping and yelling endlessly
The little child does not understand that the minor suffering one causes him
is in order to bring him greater benefits.
Now when the leadership is concerned for working the fields and opening new land
this is in order to bolster up the people's productivity,
but they consider the leadership cruel;
one specifies punishments and makes fines heavy in order to stop wickedness
but (the childlike) people consider the leadership as excessively stern;
one institutes taxes in money and in grain in order to fill up state stockpiles
and moreover it is in order to guard against famine and pay for warfare,
but these child-like people regard the leadership as greedy;
when one makes sure that everyone within the land understands the use of armour.
and that there are no privately motivated exemptions from military service
so that with united strength they can join urgent battles;
it is through these skills that they make prisoners,
but they regard the leadership as excessively fierce.
These four things
are means of ensuring peace
but the people do not know how to appreciate them.
Now if one tries to find freemen of sage-like sagacity
this is because the intelligence of the people is not sufficient to serve.
In ancient times Yǔ opened up channels for the Yangtse and the Yellow River
but the people collected tiles and stones to throw at him;
Zǐchǎn opened up mulberry plant ations,
but the people of Zhèng slandered and maligned him.
Yǔ was working for the benefit of the world
and Zǐchǎn ensured the survival of the people of Zhèng,
and if they all were slandered
that just goes to show clearly tht the intelligence of the people will not suffice.
Thus when one promotes freemen and looks for talent and intelligence
if when running the administration one aims to satisfy the common people
these are all approaches that are doomed to lead to political chaos.
They are not ways to ensure good government.
Yáo, Shùn, Tāng and Wǔ did sometimes offend against the moral obligations between ruler and minister.
They are the kinds of people who confused the teachings of later generations.
Yáo was a ruler, but he made his minister into a ruler;
Shùn was a minister and made his ruler into a subordinate;
Tāng and Wǔ were subordinates
and they assassinated their rulers and mutilated their corpses,
but the world praised them for this.
This is why the world is not well-governed to this day.
Now what one calls the enlightened ruler
is the sort of person who can bring up properly the right ministers;
the so-called talented minister
is able to promote the laws,
who can administrate his official duties and thus support his ruler.
Now Yáo thought of himself as enlightened
but he was unable to properly bring up Shùn.
Shùn thought himself talented
but he was unable to support Yáo.
Tāng and Wǔ thought themselves moral
but they assassinated their ruler and superior.
Like this 'enlightened rulers' then often associated with ministers
and 'talented ministers' then often took the throne.
Thus up to the present those who are sons will sometimes arrogate to themselves their father's family;
those who are ministers will sometimes seize their ruler's state.
For a father to yield politely to sons
and for a ruler to yield politely to a minister,
that is not the way to secure one's position and unify one's instructions.
What Your humble servant has heard is this:
"The minister serves the ruler,
the son serves the father,
the wife serves the husband.
When these three relations are smooth then the world is well-governed;
when in these three relations there are conflicts
then there is political chaos in the world.
This is the constant Way of the world."
When enlightened kings and talented ministers will not change them
then even if a ruler should be incompetent
the ministers would not dare to infringe on his powers.
Nowadays, when one honours moral talent and employs the competent one does not follow fixed rules,
and that goes against the proper Way,
but everyone always considers this to be good government.
And so the Tiáns wrested power from the Lǚs in Qí,
the Dàis wrested power from the Zǐs in Sòng.
These were all talented and competent people:
who would say they were stupid or incompetent?
Thus when disregarding regular practise one honours moral talent
then there will be political chaos,
and when setting aside the law one employs the competent,
then there will be political danger.
Therefore it is said:
One should honour the law more than moral talent.
A record says:
"When Shùn saw his father Gǔsǒu
his face looked flurried as if he was in a hurry.
Confucius said:
'At that point
there was a crisis.
The world was on the brink of disaster.
In the case of a person (like Shùn) possessed of the Way
a father can certainly not treat him like a son
and a ruler can certainly not treat him as a minister.
Your humble servant submits: "Confucius does not quite understand
the Way of brotherly love, loyal effort and obedience,
does this mean that in the case of a person (like Shùn) possessed of the Way
when presenting himself at court he need not act as the minister to a ruler,
and when at home he need not act as the son of his fatfather?
The reason why a father desires to have a talented son
is that if his family is poor such a son can make it reach
and when the father suffers hardship the son can give him pleasure;
the reason why a ruler desires to have talented ministers
is because when the state is in turmoil such a minister will bring order to it,
and when the ruler's status is low the minister will bring him honour.
Now if there is a talented son but he does not work for his father
then the father at home suffers hardship;
if there is a talented minister but he does not work for the ruler
then the ruler will be in a precarious position on his throne.
So then, if the father having a talented son
and the ruler having a talented minister
as it happens only serves to harm them,
how can they derive any profit from these talented people?
A person whom we call a devoted minister
will not endanger his ruler;
and a filial son will not oppose his parents.
Now Shùn took over his ruler's state because of his talent.
Tāng and Wǔ deposed and assassinated their rulers in the name of morality.
These were all men who endangered their rulers because of their talent
and the whole world regards them as talented.
The "illustrious gentlemen" of ancient times
when in public employment did not act as servants to their rulers
and when living in retirement did not work for their families.
This meant that when in public appointment they opposed their rulers
and when in retirement they opposed their parents.
Moreover, not to serve one's ruler when in public employment
and not to work for one's family when living in retirement
that is the way of a generation in turmoil and without legal successors.
Thus to regard Yáo, Shùn, Tāng and Wǔ as talented
and to approve of illustrious freemen,
that is the technique in the world which is most prone to lead to chaos.
Gǔsǒu was Shùn's father, but Shùn sent him away,
Xiàng was Shùn's younger brother, but Shùn killed him.
Sending one's father away and killing one's younger brother cannot be called humane;
Marrying the two daughters of the dì and taking over the empire
cannot be called morally justified.
When kindness and morality are not present
one cannot speak of being enlightened.
The Book of Songs says:
"Everything under Heaven,
without exception, is the king's land;
on the banks of all rivers
everyone is the king's subject."
It really is as the words of the Songs say.
Thus Shùn in public service made the ruler his subject,
and when at home he made his father his subject,
he treated his mother as if she was a concubine and married the daughters of his ruler.
Thus the "illustrious gentleman" did not work for their families at home
he brought chaos to the world and cut off legal succession;
when in public service he fraudulently usurped the ruler's authority.
Their dried bones and their rotten flesh
was to be spread all over the territory
and to float down the rivers and vallies,
but still they did not shrink from stepping in fire and wading through water to achieve their ambitions
they made the whole world follow and imitate them.
This meant people were dying for their cause everywhere in the world
and their hope was for an early death.
That all these men dismissed the world
and did not practise good government was for this reason.
Those who are regarded as illustrious freemen in this world
separate themselves out fromt the masses and act independently,
their choices are different from that of the others.
They devoted themselves to the pursuit of quietude
and tried to sort out pronouncements on the vague and illusory.
Your humble servant considers that quietude
is a useless teaching;
vague illusion
is a lawless expression.
When doctrines take their point of departure in lawlessness
and when teaching starts from the useless,
the whole world calls this acuteness of mind.
Your humble servant considers that a person while alive
must serve his rulers and care well for his parents.
and when one serves one's ruler and cares well for one's parents
one cannot cultivate the doctrine of quietude.
When one is governing others
one must speak of devotion, trustiness, and of the philosophy of law.
When one speaks of devotion, trustiness, and of the philosophy of law
then one cannot be an adherent of vague illusion.
and the teaching of quietude
are the most confused methods in the world.
When a filial son serves his father
this means that he does not struggle to take over the father's home;
when a loyal minister serves his ruler
this means he does not struggle to take over the state.
As for someone's son
if he constantly praises other people's parents and says:
"Such-and-such a son's parents
get to sleep late and get up early,
with all their might they produce material wealth
in order to keep their offspring, their servants and their concubines."
that sort of son is speaking ill of his own parents.
If a minister constantly praises the rich generosity of the former kings
and hopes for a restitution of their system,
these are the sorts of people who speak ill of and slander their rulers.
When someone speaks ill of his parents ond knows to call this unfilial,
but when someone speaks ill of his ruler
the whole world regard him as morally talented.
This is how political chaos arises.
Now ministers should not praise Yáo's and Shùn's talents,
they should not praise Tāng's and Wǔ's military campaigns,
and they should not speak of the elevated morals of illustrious freemen.
They should keep the law with all their might.
Those who single-mindedly serve their ruler are loyal servants.
In ancient times the black-haired people were dull and stupid
That is why one could win them over by empty fame.
Now the people are inquisitive and shrewd,
they want to follow their own ideas
and will not listen to their superiors.
The leadership is bound to encourage them through rewards
before they will ofter themselves for public service;
an again he must scare them through punishments
before they no longer dare to withdraw into retirement.
But the whole world says:
"Xǔ Yóu refused to be given empire,
so rewards were not enough to persuade him to accept;
Robber Zhí risked punishment and went in for danger,
so punishments are not enough to stop people from doing things."
Your humble servant says:
Before he even held control over the world
he had no interest in the world:
such a man was Xǔ Yóu;
when they were in control of the world they had no interest in th world:
such were Yáo and Shùn.
Ruining the morally pure for material gain,
commiting serious crimes to gain profit,
forgetting that he might lose his life,
such was Robber Zhí.
These two people
are dangerous kinds of creatures.
Governing a state is a way of employing the people,
and one must not take these two creatures as one's standard measure.
As for governing
it is about governing the ordinary;
as for leadership it is about leading the ordinary.
Dangerous creatures and rarified pronouncements
are harmful to government.
The most elevated freemen in the world
cannot be encourgaged through rewards,
and the most debased person in the world
cannot be stopped through punishments.
But if because of the most elevated people one establishes no rewards
and because of the most debased people one establishes no punishments
then the Way of governing the state and employing the people will will be lost.
Now people mostly do not speak of the laws of the state
but they speak about the horizontal and vertical alliances.
The feudal lords who speak about the vertical alliance say:
"If the vertical alliance is formed you are bound to become hegemon."
and those who advocte the horizontal alliance say:
"If the horizontal alliance is formed you are bound to become king."
In the region of Shāndōng the talk about horizontal and vertical alliances
has never stopped for a single day.
And yet no results have been achieved
hegemons and kings have not arisen.
This is because empty talk is not what one achieves good government with.
A king acts independently, that is why we call him a king;
Therefore the Three Kings were not concerned about separation and alliance
but they straightened things out;
The Five Hegemons did not rely on vertical or horizontal alliances
but they saw things clearly:
they governed well internally in order to control other states, that was all.
The reason why horses are able to carry heavy loads
and can pull carts over a long distance
is because of their physical strength.
As for a ruler over ten thousand chariots
or a lord over one thousand chariots
the means by which they control the world and chastise the feudal lords
is their position of authority and power.
The position of authority of power is the physical strength of the ruler.
Now when the powerful ministers obtains high authority
and one's entourage arrogates positions of power,
this means that the ruler loses his effective strength.
That a ruler loses his effective strength but can control his state
does not happen in one of a thousand cases.
The reason why tigers and panthers can win against men
and catch wild beasts
is because of their claws and fangs.
If one makes the tigers and panthers lose their claws and fangs
then men can certainly gain control of them.
Now the people who have great power
are the claws and fangs of the ruler.
If the ruler loses his fangs and claws
he is like these tigers and panthers.
The ruler of Sòng lost his claws and fangs to Zǐhǎn,
Duke Jiǎn lost his claws and fangs to Tián Cháng,
and they did not capture them back in good time
so as a result they died and their state was lost.
Now the rulers who have no political method
all understand the mistakes of the ruler of Sòng and of Duke Jiǎn,
and if they do not understand their own mistakes
this is because they do not investigate into the classes of things.
Moreover specialists in the philosophy of law
and ministers being in charge
cannot coexist.
How can one understand that?
When the ruler has freemen who understand political method
then the senior ministers do not get to control decision-making
and those familiar with the ruler do not dare to sell political influence;
when the power of the senior ministers and the entourage is put to rest
then the ruler's Way will shine forth.
But nowadays things are not like that.
If the ministers in charge hold the power and decide matters by themselves
to guard their own profit;
if the entourage and the confidants form their factions and gangs
to control who gets close to the ruler and who is kept at a distance:
how should specialists in the philosophy of law get employed
how should the ruler be able to make his own decisions.
Thus if those who have the right method will not necessarily be employed
and are, under prevailing conditions, incompatible with the incumbents of power,
then specialists in the philosophy of law will surely be in danger.
Thus if the ruler cannot reject minister's arguments
and go against the legal proposals of the entourage
and make up his mind independently on what accords with the Way,
then how can the specialists in the philosophy of law
disregard the danger to their lives
and propose their ideas?
This is why the world is in disarray.
The enlightened ruler assigns rank and stipends according to concrete achievements
and he assigns official duties in accordance with abilities.
Those whom he promotes will always have talent
and those whom he employs will always have abilities.
When men of talent and ability are promoted
then requests on behalf of private families will stop.
If those who have achieved results will get substantial stipends
and those who have abilities will occupy important offices,
then as for freemen who wield their private swords,
how can they fail to dissociate themselves from private bravery
and how can they fail to rush forth against the enemies of the state?
As for the itinerant politicians-to-be,
how can they fail to stand in the way of the private families
and how can they fail to do their best to be clean and pure?
This is the way to gather around one freemen of talent and ability
and to scatter adherents of the private families.
Now one's confidants are not always clever
and in a ruler's relation to others,
if somebody knows something, he will listen to him.
But at court, if he discusses such proposals with his confidantes
and listens to these confidantes without any regard to their level of knowledge,
this is like discussing wisdom with the stupid.
Those who are in charge of things are not necessarily talented.
In the ruler's relation to others
he will treat someone politely if he has certain talents.
But if at court he then discusses proper behaviour with those in charge
and he follows their proposals without taking account of any talent they may have,
this is to discuss talent with the incompetent.
Thus if the intelligent have their strategies decided on by stupid people,
and the freemen of talent have judged their actions by the incompetent
then when can talented and intelligent freemen get employed?
And moreover the ruler's clear insight is blocked by these people.
In ancient times Guān Lóng Páng spoke before Jié and his four limbs were injured;
Prince Bǐgàn remonstrated before Zhòu and he had his heart cut out;
Zǐxū was devoted and straightforward to Fūchái
and he was punished at Shǔlòu.
These three men
were not illoyal as ministers
and their suggestions were not inadequate,
but they did not escape the disaster of death,
and this was because of the rulers did not understand talented and wise proposals
and because they were kept in the dark by stupid and incompetent people.
The rulers of our time
are not willing to employ specialists in the philosophy of law
and listen to stupid and incompetent ministers
then as for the talented and intelligent freemen,
who of them would face the dangers these three men succumbed to
to offer up their knowledge and their ability?
This is why the world is in turmoil.
In the practice of the law, when judging local cases,
if legal cases decided are as many as those of five villages, one will become king,
if they are as many as those of nine villages one will become strong,
and if government action is dragged out one will lose territory.
One should govern through punishments,
one should conduct war through rewards,
one should give abundant stipends and use statecraft.
If one acts against transgressions in the capital
then there will be be no wicked merchants in the capital.
If goods are many and inessentials are abundant
if the peasants will relax their efforts and the wicked will win out
then one's state is bound to lose territory.
If the people have more than enough to eat
see to it that noble ranks are distributed against payment in grain.
If one is bound to have to use one's physical strength
then the peasants will not be lazy.
If a three-inch tube has no bottom
one cannot fill it with liquid.
If one gives offices, benefits and stipends not in accordance with results
then there is no end to it .
If the state confers offices and ranks according to results achieved
this means that one makes plans with consummate intelligence
and one wages war with authority and valour.
Then one's state will have no rivals.
If the state confers offices and ranks according to results achieved
then the number of those who need to be called to order is reduced
and the making of public speeches is blocked.
This is called getting rid of government through government,
and getting rid of speeches through speeches.
It is all because one confers rank according to results achieved.
Thus when the state is very powerful
then no one in the world is able to infringe on its territory.
When it launches its army it is bound to take whatever is its objective
and when it has taken something it is bound to be able to keep it;
and when it keeps the troops in the barracks and does not attack it is bound to become rich.
As for matters in the court
even petty duties are not spoken ill of.
If one has come up with the results one will get rank and stipend.
Even if there are unreglemented speeches
this cannot interfere with the regular distribution of ranks and stipends.
This is called governing with a method.
Those who attack from a position of strength will take ten targets in a single campaign;
if one attacks with words then for ten sallies one loses one hundred times.
If a state cultivates political strength
then it is considered to be hard to attack;
when a state cultivates speeches
then it is considered to be easy to attack.
If people are suitably employed according to their abilites
if they re able to perform their official duties,
if one makes their obligations light
If one makes punishments heavy and rewards small
this means the leadership takes loving care of the people
and the people are prepared to die for rewards.
If one gives ample rewards and makes punishments light
this means that the leadership does not love the people
and the people will not die for rewards.
When benefits come from one opening
one's state will have no rivals;
when benefits come from two openings
only half of the army will be usable;
and if benefits come from ten openings
then the people will not even defend themselves.
If one makes punishments heavy and makes them clear to the people,
and if people are deployed according to one great legal scheme,
then the leadership will derive profit from this.
As for the implementation of punishments,
if one makes the light one's heavy,
then the light offences will not arise
and the heavy cases will never come.
This is called removing punishments through punishments.
If for a heavy crime the punishment is light,
then since the punishment is light such episodes will arise.
This is called bringing about punishments through punishment.,
and one's state will lose territory.
Thus when one is governing a people
for the punishments to have their proper effect
that is the very starting point of good government;
for rewards to be multifarious
is a basis for political chaos.
It is in the inborn nature of people that they delight in chaos and do not keep to the law.
Therefore when the enlightened ruler, governing his state,
makes rewards clear
then the people are encouraged to achieve concrete results;
he makes the punishments severe
so that the people keep to the law.
When they are encouraged to achieve concrete results
then official projects will not be sabotaged;
when they keep to the law
then wickedness has nowhere from which to arise.
Therefore when one governs a people
one nip wickedness in the bud,
and when one uses the army
one concentrates on fighting for the allegiance of the people.
If in preventing things one gives priority to what is basic there will be good order
and if in warfare one fights for the people's minds one will win.
As for the the sage governing his people,
since he governs the basic things first is strong,
since he fights for the basic thing first he will win.
In matters of state one must be concerned with what has priority
and one must unite public opinion,
one must concentrate on promoting the public good
and one must not give one's allegiance to private pursuits.
If one rewards those who denunciat e others then wickedness will not arise,
if one publicly promotes the law government will not be complicated.
He who can deploy these four techniques will grow strong
and he who is unable to employ these four techniques will grow weak.
The means by which a state grows strong
is administration;
the means by which the ruler is honoured
is his position of power.
Therefore the enlightened ruler keeps control of his position and the administration,
and the disorientated ruler also has control of his position and his administration.
but the end result is not the same:
this is because the means by which they establish themselves are different.
Thus the enlightened ruler properly wields his power and the leadership has great weight,
he unifies the administration and the state is well governed.
Thus as for the law
it is the very basis of kinghood;
punishments
are the very source of love.
It is in the inborn nature of people
that they dislike toil and enjoy leisure.
When they have leisure they will waste their time,
when they waste their time they will not be well-governed,
when they are not well-governed there will be chaos,
and when rewards and punishments are not implemented in the world
things are bound to be blocked.
Thus if one wants to accomplish great results
but one has trouble using all his strength,
then the great result cannot be achieved just like that.
If one wants to organise the laws
but one finds it hard to change the old ones,
then chaos among the people cannot be sorted out just like that.
Thus there is not one constant method for governing the people,
and only the (not unchanging!) law leads to political order.
If the law changes with the times there will be good order,
when government adjusts to changing generation there will be results.
Thus when people are naive and you constrain them through the use of words
then there will be good order.
If people are shrewd and you control them through punishments
then you will be followed.
When times change but the government does not change there will be chaos,
when the capable people are many but one does not change one's prohibitions
one will lose territory.
Thus when the sage governs his people
his laws will change with times,
and his prohibitions will change with the abilities of the people.
Those who are able to deploy their strength in agriculture become rich,
those who are able to raise their strength against the enemy get strong,
and those who are strong without getting inhibited become true kings.
Thus the Way of the King is in what he opens up on the one hand
and what he blocks on the other hand:
if he blocks the way for wickedness he is bound to become a true king.
Thus the art of kingship does not depend on the absence of chaos outside,
it consists in not making it possible to be reduced to chaos.
Those who depend on there being no disorder outside
and establish government like this will lose territory;
and those who rely on the fact that they are not open to being reduced to chaos
and practise the rule of law will thrive.
Thus when a worthy ruler governs a state
he will keep to the art behind there being no chaos.
When official rank is highly honoured
the leadership will carry political weight.
Thus the worthy ruler rewards results and confers official rank for duties undertaken
and then there is no opening for wickedness.
Those whose primary concern is with the exercise of their strength, their ranks will be noble;
when these ranks are noble
then the leadership will be publicly respected;
when the leadership is publicly respected,
then one will necessarily become a true king.
When the state is not concerned with the exercise of strength but relies on private studies
then public ranks will be held in low esteem;
when public ranks are hel in low esteem
then the leadership will have low status;
when the leadership has low status it will lose territory.
Thus the Way of establishing a state and employing the people
is to be able to shut out foreign influences and to block private interests
and for the leadership to be self-reliant.
Then true kingship can be realised.
When laws are severe they get through to to men's real inner feelings,
when prohibitions are less than serious fail to affect the reality of the conduct of affairs.
Moreover, the power to die for a cause
is something that the people have.
It is in their very nature that they all will all exercise their power to die for a cause
to achieve what they desire;
but their likes and dislikes on the other hand
are something that is within the control of the leadership:
The people like benefits and stipends
and they hate punishments and fines.
If the leadership is in control of what they like and dislike
so as to control the people's exertion of their strength.
then his public projects are not the kinds of things it is appropriate to get wrong.
And so if prohibitions are made light of and projects fail
that is because the punishments and rewards have been got wrong.
If in governing people you do not regard it as good to stick to the law,
if you act like that,
then this is not to have a law at all.
Thus among the principles guiding the sorting out of political chaos
is that one most pay most urgent attention to the apportioning of punishments and rewards.
Those who govern a state will all have laws,
and yet some states survive and others are ruined.
If they are ruined
it is because in organising punishments and rewards
one does not apportion these properly.
In governing a state
there will always be an apportioning of punishments and rewards:
Some use different standards to do the apportioning,
but that cannot be called the proper apportioning.
When it comes to the proper apportioning by the perceptive ruler
this is an independent apportioning.
As a result the people take the law seriously and stand in awe of prohibitions.
They hope they will not have to suffer for crimes and they dare not expect undeserved rewards.
Thus it is said:
Without the use of punishments and rewards
the people do their duty.
Therefore in an extremely well-governed state
one is good at making it one's business to stop wickedness.
How is this done?
This is because the laws link up with human feelings
and they connect with the very principles of good government.
How is one, then, to get rid of subtle forms of wickedness?
It is by trying to make people observe each others real feelings.
And how is one to make them observe each other?
The answer is:
One makes them responsible for each others' crimes in their neighbourhood, that's all.
If a prohibition will get them involved
then the neighbourhood will not fail to observe each other,
only too much afraid that they may not escape punishment.
And one will not allow those who have wicked intentions to forget
that those who are spying on them are many.
In this way people will be careful with themselves and they will watch others,
they will divulge secrets regarding wicked plans.
Those who denunciate transgressions should be regarded as innocent
and they should receive rewards.
Those who fail to report wicked schemes must always be charged
and must receive the same physical punishment.
If one proceeds like this
then all sorts of wickedness will come out into the open.
When it comes to wickedness even small instances will not be tolerated.
The self-interested denunciation and the sharing of criminal charges ensures this.
The most penetrating point about organising the law
is to rely on administrative technique and not to rely on people.
Therefore in a state where the art of government prevails
it is when one does not use public praise that people avoid transgressions.
And that there is bound to be good order in the land
is because one relies on administrative technique.
If a ruined state allows soldiers to move about publicly in its territory
and is unable to constrain them or put a stop to them
then that is because one relies on persons and does not rely on the art of government.
One's attacking oneself is because of those men,
one's ability to attack others is because of that administrative technique.
Thus a state in which the art of government prevails
does away with speeches and relies on the law.
Generally, it is hard to discern whether unregulated achievements match the agreed standard,
and it is hard to see if there is transgression in proposals.
Therefore punishments and rewards are confused through ambiguity.
If a result is hard to match with the original agreed standard,
then this is a "wicked achievement".
If it is hard to discern the transgression of a minister
the root of good government is lost.
If one follows principles then no vain achievements will be manifest.
If one examines real facts one outwits?? the root of wickedness.
If these two kinds of ambiguous situation exist one certainly will lose both [i.e. both rewards and punishments].
And so the inane freemen make their names inside
and the talkers brew their schemes abroad.
Thus the stupid, the gutless, the brave and the lazy
go ahead to preach their empty ways to the vulgar
and they are tolerated in our time.
As a result the laws are not brought to bear on them
and punishments and fines are not applied to the culprits deserving execution.
If this happens
how can punishments and rewards avoid being ambiguous?
but if one applies ordinary principles one does not get the proper measure of them.
but if one measures them by ordinary principles fails to get the proper measure.
The failure to get the proper measure
is not brought about by the law.
It is because the law is fixed but one relies on cleverness.
When one abandons the law and relies on cleverness
how can those entrusted with public projects perform their tasks?
When the assigned tasks do not correspond with the projects at hand
how can the law then fail to go wrong,
and how can punishments fail to be numerous?
Thus when rewards and punishments are in disarray
and when the Way of the land is all misguided,
then this is because punishments and rewards are not properly apportioned.
